column10:
I hate to say this, but Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is not good. I wanted so badly for this to be good. It falls flat on what made the other Borderlands games fun, yes, even Borderlands 3. The humour is much more watered down and the themes are dialled back which makes the story feel very bland, it just doesn't have the depth of the others.

The class system they introduced was an interesting concept, but overall feels like it limits you by locking you into a more specific set of abilities.

I will say one thing though, it made me realise that I was a little harsh on Borderlands 3, because compared to Tiny Tina's Wonderlands, Borderlands 3 is amazing.

If you liked Borderlands, you'll probably like Wonderlands. If you didn't, you won't. It's really about as simple as that. Also, I really liked some gameplay upgrades, like being able to swap out your melee weapon for something more interesting than something you hold onto the whole game like in the BL series. Equipping magic was fun for the same reason; it's fun to switch up play styles.

While I really don't care much about cosmetic appearance much, I know a lot of other people do and this game has NOOOOOoooo shortage of that either.

All and all, a very solid and excellent game with lots of wink-nudge references to other games and tv/movie media too.

I honestly don't get the hate. It's just Borderlands. I know it, you know it, Gearbox knows it. Selling for 60 bucks is a little ridiculous but I would actually pay more for this game than I would TPS. Just grab it on sale if you like the other Borderlands games, simple stuff. Oh, and I wouldn't recommend this as an entry point for the Borderlands series. Start with 1 2 or 3, not this or TPS.

That's all I have to say on the matter. Again, it's Borderlands. Don't get your expectations up, but don't drop them so low that you refuse to play the game if you like other entries in the series. I truly do recommend this to fans of the previous games, no matter which in the trilogy is your favorite.

THERE ARE MANY SPOILERS.
I did not expect that there is a worse game than Borland 3 and quite boring at that, but here it is.
[spoiler] Let's leave aside that even when it starts, it asks you for a lot of permissions that could have been set when ordering the game, not when it's bought and waiting for you to play. The game is full of gays and lesbians and transvestites and what not even from the regular ones. They played with the colors in such a way that it looks unnatural. The people design is just a skin on a scarecrow. You can't tell the difference between a man and a woman or a goblin. They have gone a bit overboard with the amount of gays, but mostly with too many dumb emotions to such an extent that they are so sugary that it makes me sick. Almost everyone inside is losers and unfortunates, even the villain, and they have gone terribly overboard. And they also mock and overdo it quite a bit, with other characters and some even from their other games. I have the feeling that it was made by Disney with the addition of modern crap. A lot of the missions are either gathering lovers or more emotional garbage. Even at times it gives you a non-violent choice. After you pass the stupid campaign, it gives you 30 minutes of credits, so you can't skip them. Showing all the idiots who made this garbage. So many people don't have an iota of wit. I expected that I would be a bad ass, not a donky ass.
The maps are few and big but empty and most places are visible when you choose to pass the mission because they are all straight lines and not many tasks. Kind of like this part of the map is for a task and sometimes there is no life until you pass the task. There are secrets, but most of them are trash or coffins with trash, and most things it's only worth it when you collect them as a set. Separately, the game from the outside is full of uninteresting arenas, which is the main thing in the game. Which you just have to kill a certain number of enemies, but the enemy is always watching, so there is no point in looking around or sitting in them for a long time. Most weapons are garbage, the rifle has a very bad recoil. The rifle is quite weak. And the price of special items in the store becomes quite high and you earn too little and the upgrades for more ammo and to carry items skyrocket. But then you find so many items that it makes the store meaningless and you only sell because most of them are weak.
They decided to add swords, but most of them are weaker and have many disadvantages compared to firearms. There are many downsides to them and they are more likely to kill you if you focus on them. And again they do the same as other games just for protection. So they haven't achieved anything new.The spells are not so well made, the grenades were more useful, you can use more but they are not in the game. You choose characters that you can change whenever you want without two things quite impersonal. One is the points card and the second is the class, but then it gives you a second one and in the end you can change even the second one. And the class is one third of the old characters. If you rush, you may miss a conversation because another conversation will cover it or miss it. The game has bugs and even the internet affects it. But the balance is the biggest problem. I started on easy, then on normal and I realized that it makes no sense at all. You raise the level and the enemy with you, but he is always weak, you kill the bosses in seconds and they are at your level. And most bosses are poorly made or just bad ass but a little different. Enemies quickly lose their originality and are quite poorly made or pathetic. And the exploding barrels are even more dangerous than the enemies and sometimes some enemy hits so hard and unnaturally that it crushes the armor and almost all the blood quite unbalanced game.There are only 40 levels that are raised quickly and then it's just paragon points like Diablo 3. Weapons will always be level 40 and the enemy and you will never be able to cash out more than that. There is no game plus and there is no point, you beat the game and it unlocks an endless arena to go around in a circle. And you fight for slightly stronger weapons. Usually, by the time you reach the middle of the game, all the things you need to wear are unlocked, but not here, you have to go through the entire campaign to allow you to wear a second ring. And the items are poorly thought out because you use everything even on the other classes and you have to choose constantly because of the bad way of use. And because of the bad balance, I don't even change things for a long time, especially at level 40. Achievements are the icing on the cake, you can pass them with only one character.  I have 5 achievements left, two are grinding and the bottom is extreme grinding for nothing because you don't have enough money and the game has no plus and two are simple but they want a second player. It could have been done without them, given that the game is more for one person, rather stupid of the creators. And most of the hidden things you collect don't even have an achievement. The game ends rather stupidly and pitifully.
The most impudent thing about these lazy creators is the price. They want as much money as their previous games and the game is not even half and the season package is not even a quarter, pitiful. 
Tina's old adventures in DLC of the second game, it was true that there were bugs and it was for balancing, but it is a hundred times better than this shit in every respect, even emotionally. [/spoiler]
I would recommend that these lazy creators balance their game and add stuff equal to the price and fuk off.

Note: I bought the Chaotic Great Edition at 80% off and would recommend the game at THAT price but not at this game's base price.  I also have over 500 hours across the Borderlands series on Steam alone so I'm well grounded on the franchise.

I'll start off with my own personal opinions -- have never played D&D before, so the main theme and dialogue of the game doesn't interest me too much. I also consider Tina to be+ by far one of the worst/cringiest characters in the franchise, so basing a whole game around her was hard to push through at times.  It also didn't help the entire game is narrated by Will Arnet, Andy Sandberg, and Wanda Sikes, and while I don't really have anything against them, their attempt at 'trying-too-hard-to-sound-funny' dialogue made it feel like I was playing through an SNL skit.  

As an avid Borderlands fan I think it's safe to say Wonderlands is probably the worst entry in the entire series.  The game replaces the open world/vehicle elements with an 'overworld' where you become a funko pop variant walking from place to place. The Myth(or 'BA') Rank isn't even unlocked until max level, which really makes you work for what used to be available at all times in previous games.  And for the full edition players, the DLC are the absolute worst in the franchise.  

Some other notable, but not terrible changes are the removal of canon characters replaced with a 'character class' system, which isn't too bad, and makes room for more playstyles, but takes the fun out of playing some of the series now iconic characters.
The removal of the Grenade slot now replaced with a Spell slot, which I have found to be quite fun and actually enjoyed.

Overall, for $60, buy every other Borderlands game instead...they're much better and have much more content, but if you can find the game on sale for about $20 it's worth the money for avid fans.

Despite what people have said in other comments, I think the writing and jokes in Wonderlands are better than BL3, more like they were in BL2. People who say the story is trash when it is supposed to be D&D written by a like 13 year old are looking at it wrong IMO. The combat is probably the best in the series.  I am not a fan of how much of a grind it is to get to Chaos 100 (you gain 5 Chaos levels for each Chaos Trial run completion until 50, then only 1 until 100). I would recommend buying the game with the DLC when it is on sale (I think I got the Chaotic Great Edition for like $40, definitely worth it at that price).

This is my first experience playing gearbox stuff. I have never played borderlands and never knew what this was or what to expect going into this. To be fair, this game does not look appealing at all and the commercials for this make the graphics look cartoon-y and terrible. I played on higher graphics and (here comes the horde) I think this is one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. Actually, I would argue that the scenery (background) is better than sunsets from sea of thieves. I got 100% completion at 80 hours and it is an absolutely massive game. There were 14+ Fortnite sized maps with a bunch of smaller ones for side quests, encounters, boss battles, etc. I probably sound like a bot or some paid liar to tell you all about how great this game was but I really mean it, I really liked this game. After being convinced to play this, I wanted to write a proper and truthful review on my experience on this game specifically with no other strings attached. The game takes some getting used to, it was very unsettling at the beginning. The humor, the graphics at the start (when in a pitch black room with only the cartoon game board), the characters, pretty much everything was not impressive and I debated quitting. When I actually started playing and gave it a chance, it all makes sense in a weird way. One of my all time favorite games is Doom and the movement of this game felt very similar. The gun diversity selection is also pretty indescribable. Know that this is a GUN game first and foremost, magic second (for the most part). If anyone is on the fence about getting this, I truly loved this massive story type game and would be sitting down for hours at a time. Thank you for reading and a big thank you to the ridiculously sized team that went into making this.
10/10 Worth every bit of $20

As a Borderlands 2 fan I'm very disappointed.
But, I'll start off with the positives.

The Positives:

+The Gunplay
 It has a good feel to it, feels like it has a impact.

+The Sounds 
 Sound effects range from fairly decent to outright good, feeds into the feel of the gunplay a lot.

+Melee Weapons
 A good addition, melee was fun to play in BL2, but drops off in the OP levels, so weapons might help keep it more on par with guns.

+Spells, I guess?
 Not sure if I like them or hate them.
 They are interesting if nothing else.


The Negatives:

-The Writing.
 The game's writing took no time to showcase how bad it was, it couldn't go 5 minutes without going "hey, funny joke right? Laugh!"
 The main cast, Tina and the 2 randoms, can't shut up for 1 minute with their stupid comments or even worse "jokes."
 Playing with voices turned off is likely the best way to play the game, and that's really sad given how dialog seems to be one of the main parts of the game, but it's just so bad.
 In BL2 finding a voice log was cool, you learned more about a character, or some funny interaction, but in this game?
 The first random voice log you find is painful to hear, the "jokes" were so unfunny, and yet they repeated it, basically going "it was funny right? I'm going to do it again!"
 This might be the only game to punish you for wanting to learn some more lore.

-The Art Style
 The change in art style made everything look so.. off, borderlands 2 had a much better style to it.
 It also made combat feel very weird, as enemies don't stand out from the background/terrain like they do in BL2. 

-The Health Bars
 I'm guessing there is a different color of health bar for each different type of enemy, but the one for skeletons, the starting enemies, had no thought put into it.
 It's grey, but the bar color for when it's damaged is white, making it almost impossible to tell at a glance if it's about to die or not.

-Pronouns and Body type A & B
 Why someone thought this should be a thing, I have no idea.
 It doesn't effect much of anything.
 But I hate that so many games see the need to add in this stupid political stuff.
 Keep that political BS out of games.


-Small Stuff
 There are other things, like how you can't do the classic esc>end>enter>up>enter to quick quit to the main menu.
 And there is likely more stuff, but I didn't like the game enough to keep playing.
 The gunplay was fairly good, but the writing was so bad.
 Every time I heard one of those awful "jokes" I kept thinking "I paid money.. for THIS?" so it just wasn't worth it.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Probably the worst game in the series.  Mechanically, sure, it plays almost the same as the others in the series, but this one lacks character and direction.  For me, BL2 is the pinnacle of the series.

The world lacks cohesion.  The different zones are kind of just there as an obstacle to the end boss.  They don't tie into the story in any way.

The weapons don't have any character.  Sure, the brands are there in an off-brand way, but all of the weapons can have elemental damage and they just blend into each other.  In the previous games Mailwan means elemental submachine guns.  Jacobs means high damage, low rate of fire sniper rifles, and so on.  They are all here, but then everything can have an element, and the styling is not very unique to each weapon.

The character skill trees were not clearly understandable to me.  I picked some stuff and left it.  If equipment buffs any of my selected skills or not, I didn't really care because the names are meaningless to me, and the icons are hard to extract meaning from.

The characters were fine.  I like their banter and Tiny Tina is Tiny Tina, but inside this fantasy world she's not quite the same.  As a story teller, she's not the best.

The enemies are also not very memorable.  All I really remember is mushrooms, pirates, and land sharks.  Why am I fighting them?  Because they're hostile.  They don't have an agenda, they're just monsters.  The lamia/serpent ladies have something, but that's about it.

The overworld is easily the part of the game I liked the least, especially with the random encounters.  It's very tiring and not interesting.  I'm playing a first person game, I kind of want to navigate the world in that way.  I'm aware that I'm supposed to be playing a tabletop game, but it doesn't feel like it, and I don't think it has to.

I want to like it, and there are some interesting things in it, but I can't recommend it unless you want to play every game in the series.  I thought Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep was okay, but that  had some parts that were dragged out and grindy.  You won't miss anything by skipping this.

This game is just not for me. It seems that there are many people who enjoy digging through endless piles of loot, but I don't. 99% of all loot is trash so what is the point?

The game is whimsical wacky zany cutesie and the voices are somewhat funny, that is well done. Also there are some nice references to actual tabletop RPGs that I enjoy.

If you liked the Borderlands titles you might like this game, but I don't like the genre.

My friends and I had high hopes for this game starting out. It had a fun (though quite standard) fantasy atmosphere with a heaping serving of Borderlands style combat, which is really quite nice throughout the whole game. Plenty of interesting loadouts to be had here, though with a distinct D&D themed twist compared to the usual Borderlands formula: spells replace grenades, wards replace shields, and so on. Melee weapons are also much more prominent in Wonderlands. At first they seemed like a nice addition the Borderlands style of play, but they ended up being a bit redundant for me personally (why use sword when have shotgun?)

Unfortunately the bland side quests, average dialogue, and the utterly repetitive and uninspired "encounters" that the game likes to throw at you slowly whittled away the fun. There were a few good moments for sure, but in the end it all just continued to wear us down to the point where we just wanted to get the silly main quest over with and be done with it (and even that was a complete let down).

I would also recommend avoiding this game if you aren't at least a somewhat avid fan of D&D. Most of the jokes and character banter depend on scenarios and tropes that frequent the D&D meta (honestly the whole story could be seen as one giant commentary on the peculiar relationship that builds between players and the dungeon master.) Seriously, if you don't have experience playing D&D at a table with friends, all of that stuff will be lost on you. You will forfeit the narrative's one saving grace—the thing that was actually able to give me a chuckle sometimes—and you will have nothing.

I like this game. It's beautiful, and fun. Wait for it on sale. The chests mostly just loot ammo, most of which you don't use, and the background doesn't always interact with your shots. But other than that it's pretty fun. The guns are unique. It's art style is one of if not THE MOST beautiful if not THE MOST beautiful game I have ever seen. The companions are cool especially the spore warden. I've had MANY games over the last few years Ive barely played. But I have played the HELL out of this isnce getting the $100 package for $20.
  This game's a GREAT deal at that price. I guess we all have different preferences, but I don't get all the hate. People have liked A LOT LESS, A LOT MORE. People are just expecting too much. 
  I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone thinking about buying it, the next time it's on special. Trust me, and add
this to your wish list. Then come back and thank me with thumbs up when you agree!

Fun as F until you reach the mmorpg style rng endgame when there's nothing else to do there.  Honestly I haven't 100% grinded everything out of a game in years but this one was fun and I grinded it into the ground - and I HATE FPS games.  I prefer deep action Rpgs.  But they turned the gun play here into something akin to spell shooting with tricks and gamuts on the guns that really made game play stunning and clever.  Shame they traded emotes for spells in the quick menu.  Would have been very useful to have a range of spells at my fingertips than corny dance moves.  For all it's faults in mechanical objectives it has great points for style aesthetically - the dialogue is great.  The quest stories are quirky and fun and goofy.  Sadly when you get to end game the personalities disappear and it gets pretty lonely grinding the same boss for days for nothing that matches your stats.  I probably would have bought this full price... but I waited for the sale... it's a gem for sure.

Summary is that I'd recommend this game but only for the campaign. It feels like it should have been another DLC for Borderlands 3 as part of Season Pass 2 and not a stand alone game.


I've given it a real chance, it's a fine fine game with a good story. The campaign and story itself is easily better than Borderlands 3. And the new class systems are fine. Overall I'd give it 12/20

Then comes end game content. The Chaos chamber is the end game content, you want to play a randomize mayhem mode all the time, right? You want no control over what bosses and mini bosses you face, right? Then comes the loot in general, kill a boss? Have 3 greens, 3 blues, maybe 2 purples and rarely a legendary. Part of what made borderlands rewarding in the past was taking 5 minutes to sort though loot after defeating a boss, this game takes 10 seconds. I'm not saying Legendaries and purples should be everywhere but they shouldn't feel like a chore to get.

No new game+, No finding dice again, no resetting any quests without a new character.

Also, Slot machines are gone, so if your friend is sorting loot, the best you can hope for is to kill crabs.

Final plus is that quest rewards appear as the item of the day in vending machines so that's nice.

Edit: Two years later, I played 5 more hours, this game is even worse without the hype surrounding it. Generic and repetitive dungeons done again and again. Just save your money at this point or buy it 90% off, if that ever happens.

Alright, so the goal was to redeliver the 'magic', so called, of the BL2 DLC 'Tiny Tina's Assault On Dragon Keep'. 
  Instead, what was delivered, was an EXTREMELY mediocre experience, one that feels 'unfinished'.

     In the Dragons Keep DLC, you are given an admittedly heart wrenching story behind the adventure about dealing with the loss of a loved one. The levels were well designed, the adventure was amazing, and the jokes were actually funny.

     Wonderlands fails in every single aspect. Everything feels restricted and unfinished. You don't even get a new game plus option, and the multiplayer fuck up from BL3 has carried over.  
    Now, as far as the hidden plot is concerned, I get it. Not every single story has to be an emotional experience that helps people heal/empathize with others. I get that. Not everything has to be a masterpiece like the Claptastic Voyage, that actually had the BALLS to address mental health issues.
    So I'm genuinely confused why Tiny Tina having a bitch fit and acting like a cunt was the 'big reveal'. If you're not going for an emotional journey because you know that your writing team can only make piles of excrement, shouldn't you instead switch gears and go for more of a 'good vibes' thing? Something high energy?   

    While you DO get to kill smurfs, explode the ocean, and the combat is admittedly really good, there is next to no replay- ability. The DLCs are all first class scams. Not at all what was promised. Short, linear tunnels to run and gun through in less than 10 minutes. There is no NewGame+ so you can forget about min-maxing and gear collecting, or having fun experimenting with story specific gear. 

   Do Not buy unless 80% off. Simply not worth the price.


     UPDATE:  I found a save editor that can give the illusion of NG+, or 'fake TVHM' as the creators dubbed it, effectively resetting all quests. I also found a mod that removes the weapons grade cringe that is the dialog. 
   Still doesn't fix the garbage multiplayer setup, and the fact that one would even have to take these measures is proof enough that that Wonderlands is doo doo. like poo emoji doo doo.

What beefs up the game when the story is lacking is the combat. It's responsive, vaulting is back and you can shoot and cast spells at the same time. Spells are a huge difference in this game, as they are switched out instead of grenades. That said the spells has way more use than grenades, since I always recall grenades being lacking except for Transfusion grenades. Slight downside to the game is the DLC. I would not recommend the full price on these and instead just grab the Season Pass during a sale. The problem is that the DLC are small "Encounters" being 4-5 rooms and an end boss. You can unluck up to 4 difficulties, but only the end boss becomes harder from that and not the rooms. This is a bit of a shame and makes the "re-runs" very plain.

I'm a Borderlands fan from the very beginning.  Some people criticized the non-stop gags in Borderlands 2 and the pre-Sequel.  Me, I enjoyed it.  I enjoy all the references.  Even though they toned down the humor after 3, I still enjoy a lot of the references.  Like Ice-T, Penn and Teller, Vincent Price, the Smurphs, the Witcher (though it in no way compares to the Bioshock reference from Bordlands 1).

That being said, starting with Borderlands 3, Gearbox started leaning heavily on liberal cultural touchstones simply to pander to that audience.  Every romantic relationship does not have to be a gay relationship. 
 A weapon called "The Cure" who's weapon details include "vaccines work, those are just facts" isn't clever. 
 Having a whiny customer called "Karen" is lazy.  There's a character that isn't explicitly trans (it's just a female choosing to play as a male avatar), it's obvious the developers were going for trans pandering.
Newsflash, hipsters aren't playing this game.  And liberal pandering merely for the sake of it is tiresome.

That being said, these are enjoyable games.  However, I hope the developers choose to take the series in a different direction with future installments.

This game is extremely disappointing.

Despite the incredible flavor that Tiny Tina brings to the game and the surprisingly competent storytelling and antagonist this game has, it's all held down by shockingly lame content, both during the main story and in the end game.

Nothing about this game sticks me as memorable, besides a few key events during the main story which actually made me laugh out loud. As a Pre-Sequel type spinoff of the main franchise, I'm terrified of the direction Borderlands' future has in hold for us.

Gunplay is at its worst. Too many guns share the same gimmicks as every other weapon and you'll rarely find an actual gun, instead of a "gun" that shoots extremely slow, clunky projectiles or a beam that has astonishingly poor DPS. 

Spells instead of grenades is a cool thought, but the creativity just isn't there. Making spell rarities impact how they actually function seems like a good idea on paper, but this is Borderlands. Rarity means practically nothing unless it's Legendary or Pearlescent (the latter of which is not in the game, unfunnily enough). Rarities influencing how spells work can make some spells extremely powerful or extremely weak based on whether or not you get the blue or purple variant, which sucks; it adds another element to the loot table that makes grinding for weapons and spells just not fun.

Speaking of grinding, this game has hilariously bad post-game content. 
In Borderlands 2, you had Digistruct Peak, Invincible Bosses, and a LOT of bonus content via DLCs that that outvalue this entire game.
In Borderlands 3, you had Raids (I forgot what they're called but I can't be bothered to fact check), which, on their own, are probably some of the best content Borderlands has received as a franchise, and are COMPLETELY FREE. The DLCs also add a lot of content that is enjoyable, in terms of story and gameplay gimmicks.

This game's idea of post-content is a looping arena and free loot at the end based on how you perform. There's nothing else. Not even the DLC is even an inch as good as the DLC content from every other borderlands game.

Speaking of, this game's DLC, or "post-launch content", is LAUGHABLY TERRIBLE. They feature boring missions, boring storylines, and boring bosses. NONE OF THEM ARE WORTH TRIPLE THE ASKING PRICE OF BL2'S HEADHUNTER PACKS, WHICH INCLUDE NEW MAPS, NEW BOSSES, NEW ENEMIES, AND NEW LEGENDARY/UNIQUE LOOT.

ONE WONDERLANDS DLC IS WORTH LESS THAN A QUARTER OF A 5$ DLC FOR BORDERLANDS 2. 

I have no idea how Gearbox let this game flop so god damn hard, and who thought it was a good idea to launch the DLC for this game in such an astonishingly terrible and borderline unfinished state. 

This isn't the Borderlands spinoff you wanted, it's a shameless cash grab with amazing ideas that are executed extremely poorly.
Its a solid borderlands game. If you expect it to be like BL2 don't buy it, but if your looking for some new BL game play id recommend it.

[h1]Awful[/h1]

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is repetitive, shallow, bland, and ultimately - [b][u]miserably[/u] boring[/b].

If you're one to believe that [i]anything[/i] is fun together with friends, you have an opportunity to torpedo that notion for whatever cost this piece of shit retails at.

The genuinely infuriating thing to me is that this game does actually have elements of good-ness.
The world is beautifully crafted.
The voiceacting - great.
Writing? It's engaging, funny, even.
It does have the makings of fun gunplay under the hood.

But then after about 5 hours of playtime they murder all the good bits with horrible scaling, the game becoming brain numbingly easy and unchallenging. And not in a casual, chill-gaming, easygoing way...

There is nothing to adapt to, there is no threat. No thought process involved. It's not possible to die. It does not matter what build you build, what spells you use, what gun you choose - even on hardest difficulty all minions explode instantly, bosses are killed comically quickly. You just churn through a volume of mob HP, timegated by dialogue.

The RPG elements are a facade. Nothing you choose or do matters, you just run and blow stuff up, and its not even fun to "blow stuff up", because in comes lazyness, where the arenas become reused, pasted, making for a very repetitive and constant gameplay loop.

Whatever storyline there is, hard to appreciate it if you're yawning and zoning out due to the stale gameplay.

If I could, I'd refund, but the shallowness and unplayability of this garbage does not become apparent until well beyond 2 hours of gametime.

Stay away.

As someone who has enjoyed all 3 Borderlands games, I cannot say the same about Tiny Tina's Wonderland. I can't pinpoint what exactly I didn't enjoy, cause I think it was many different things, but in general I felt the combat was not fun and not what I expected. Using spells felt much less tactical and satisfying than throwing a grenade, the weapons all seem to have some weird projectile, nothing just shoots a straight bullet, and the enemies felt repetitive at times (many of them will be a skeleton of some sort). The shops and chests never seem to have anything good, and after saving up 50 items just to get a slight upgrade from the shop I felt scammed. The story is fine but nothing exceptional, most of it Tina makes up as she goes, which is the point I guess, but it's just hard to take seriously.  It's not a bad game, just don't expect it to be like Borderlands.

If you like Borderlands 3, you will like this game.  Very hilarious and Tiny Tina is awesome.  A little repetitive but what game isn't?  If you like fetch quests and looking around to find stuff in dungeons and kill things with a huge variety of weird weapons... this game is for you!

It's fun, but it has problems.

The one that annoys me the most, is the appearance customisation drops.  Those things that look like little gold bags.  They happen constantly, and after a while they're 99% ones you've already got.  Why do they continue to drop if you've already got them?  They just end up either clogging up your inventory, the lost loot machine, or both.

Also, most of what drops isn't guns, but wards and spells and stuff.  There is very little weapon variety and quality in this game.

Inventory management is the worst part of this game.  It seems impossible to organise your weapons in a way that makes sense, in terms of using or selling them.

Also, I wish they could have found a way to incorporate BL3's radioactive guns/element into this game.

Like I said: fun.  But there are a lot of frustrating things missing from the game, and that shouldn't be in the game that make it less fun than it could be.

TL:DR For a post DLC completed game experience, the amount of bugs and issues present is unacceptable. If I had paid full price for this game I'd want my money back. Buy it on sale and enjoy the gameplay.

I'll keep this brief as yeah, I do intend to complete the game but not in the sense I did former Borderlands titles by finding the best gear doing all the quests etc. This game is held up by its gameplay for me. If that wasn't fun, honestly I would have refunded it and tried to find a different game for my buddy and I to play. To put it simply, this game is pretty buggy, even moreso than any Borderlands title I've played in the past. They range from complete game crashes, graphical issues minor and major, sound issues minor and major, desync issues, a few of them requiring complete restarts after booting up the game. The gameplay is fun enough to be willing to tolerate these to a degree. Some of the other issues come with the maps design and the existence of certain invisible walls in places they really shouldn't be and some not being in places they should. The worst bug I found is in the magical bean quest area. There's a completely random spot on the map that if you "superhero slide" into it, you just die. The other part, I'm not one for politics in games, left or right unless it's a proper fit to the overall story and really is setting a deep tone of some kind or whatever the case may be. I will say seeing pronouns on the character creation screen had me a little leery and it was rightfully so. Now it isn't that they push themes too harshly or anything but it's just the writing in this game isn't flavorful or really all that good. The lack of wordplay for innuendo and overly crude humor just for the sake of it gets old really really fast. They just don't land, the characters aren't going to be memorable from this game. It's carried solely by Tina so far. If you just want the combat from Borderlands, it's here 100% and it's good. The rest of the game is most likely going to be forgettable.

I picked up this game because Tiny Tina's Assault was a masterpiece, and I've wanted a full game version of that for YEARS. This... This isn't it. The D&D based mechanics are fun and sparkly at first, and that alone kept me playing a lot longer than it should have. The emotion, the humor, the purpose, everything that made the DLC so special is spectacularly missing from this.

Everything in the game is filtered to be "age appropriate" for younger audiences, which effectively destroys almost everything that made Borderlands, well Borderlands, but also removes like 80% of Tina's personality. She's no longer the traumatized, deranged little maniac in a cute basket crumpets. She's just a normal, "quirky" teen girl. She's still cute, but everything that made her a precious bean that needed to be cared for (and provided therapy) is just gone. It's like taking OG Harley Quinn and turning her into an innocent chibi, still nice but not really special anymore.

Tina wasn't the only thing damaged by this either. The side quests are dull, combat is tedious to the point I just run straight through any unscripted fights now. The "big baddies" are waaayyy to easy to fight. The weapons are all the same [i] just in different font [/i], to the point that I don't think I've swapped anything in my loadout for at least 15 in-game hours. I hardly even pick anything off the ground anymore.

I tried so hard to love this game. Some of the mainline story is really cute and fun, and playing a character with 2 summons has been pretty neat (even if it's just the mechromancer with more fairy dust and friendship). Exploring the overlands could probably be considered a game in of itself. On a really good day, if I'm not thinking about it, I might tell you that this is the best game I've played in a couple years. That's just the Tina fangirl playing a game of denial though. The reality is if I stop to really think about my experience playing this game in comparison to the DLC that made me want it, everything just looks so lackluster and leaves me feeling mislead. 

I would still probably recommend this to preteens that want an entry to Borderlands, or maybe for people who don't particularly care about Tiny Tina and just want another Borderlands style game to occupy them for a while. For those who absolutely adored dragons keep or prefer the more traditional Borderlands experience though, don't bother. You're not the target audience. It's not worth the money.

I'm on the borderline with rating "Tiny Tina's Wonderlands."  On the plus side:

- I bought the "Chaotic Great Edition" on sale for a bit over $21 and, so far, have played for 71.4 hours.  That's how long it took us to "complete" the main quest and all the side-quests (plus all the Challenge-type activities and non-grinding Achievements) of the core game.  So, on the plus side, the dollar-per-hour ratio is really good.
- The amount of work they put into the areas, scenery, animations, etc. is amazing.
- The action and general gameplay still maintains a Borderlands feel (with the D&D motif, of course).

On the negative side:

- The game is still woke, but nowhere near as badly woke as Borderlands 3 was.  It's almost tolerable.
- Many of the quest and the actions you have to complete to move through the game are just nasty.  Tina, as game master, does some really bad stuff.  Thinking it all over, in this game, Handsome Jack would have been right in calling us, the supposed heroes, bandits.
- The Overworld is just a pain.  I can understand why they wanted part of the game to look/act the way it does.  But, that doesn't make random encounters, awkward movement, inability to look up, and a general inability to gauge progress any more palatable.
- The inventory system is pretty bad.  Constantly wading through all those weapons with all their randomly named characteristics is just too difficult.  Heck, just figuring out what class of item something is is awkward.
- Similar to the inventory system, the leveling/class systems are a pain.  As if doing that for a single class isn't bad enough, they throw in a second class and then multiple different leveling system a bit later in the game.
- The major story areas, though beautiful, are so twisty-turny all-alike that you can't really figure out where you are, where you've been or where you're going.  Usually, that complexity is in all 3 dimensions, not just on a plane.
- The map desperately needs a fixed north-is-up mode.  Trying find things and explain locations to a co-op partner is almost impossible when the map can be in any orientation with no standard to reference.
- The main quest gives no real sense of progress.  It's almost entirely a case of being told to go here and do this, then go there and do that.  Again and again.  But, those tasks feel random and not like they're logical steps towards a goal.
- Even now, years after the game was released, there are a lot of annoying bugs.  Those should have all been squashed while the game was still an exclusive on Epic.

Overall, I'm going to rate the game as Not Recommended.  It's OK to play and its $/hr ratio is good.  But, its various faults just knocks me over to the negative side of a rating.

I've been sitting on this game for almost a year while I was waiting for my cheap-ass Borderlands buddy to pick it up on sale. (He knows who he is!) Anyway, we've been playing for a couple weeks now and finding it massively entertaining. If you're a fan of Borderlands this is basically another Borderlands with a different skin/theme. The writing and voice acting is fantastic, just what you'd expect from another Borderlands entry. Plus, it's all the Tiny Tina you can handle, the greatest NPC in gaming history.

I got it for $20 on sale. For that I'd say definitely get it. I ended up really enjoying it. And I've enjoyed every Borderlands game.

At first I wasn't liking the gameplay as much as pretty much all the others. I've literally been playing 1, 2, the presequal, 3, then this basically back to back in order on the steam deck. This one I've started using Xreal Airs. 

That said at a certain point my equipment got better and I now am really enjoying gameplay and combat. At first it was like guns were very wobbly with no accuracy..gyro was sucking from when I was popping heads in the others. The over world takes a bit to get used to and start to open up areas.

Anyway the magic replaces your skill and grenades....and idk if it's my build but yeah. My magic slaughters everyone and my guns clean up the residue....I'm using Graveborn and Clawbringer skill trees with Dire Sacrifice skill. With basically Dexterity and Intelligence only being upgraded...slaughtering. it's nuts.

My really only gripe is idk if it's the game or what.  Is with the Xreal glasses the game doesn't let the resolution change from native steam deck resolution even if you change it in the OS. It's kind of weird. So you can't get the resolution right in the glasses which makes it slightly less than perfect.
The story of the base game is decent, but the endgame is boring grind for loot and chaos level. All the DLC is also boring and just another re-skined chaos chamber

TLDR: 5.5/10 (Trophy Difficulty: 5/10) 

After investing nearly sixty hours and earning all the trophies, here's my take on the game. The story, which is a parody of dungeons and dragons, is somewhat surface-level. The game play, while enjoyable, doesn't bring much innovation to the Borderlands series. On the highest difficulty, only a couple of moments required genuine strategy, mostly towards the end.

Trophy hunting was generally straightforward, except for unlocking all inventory upgrades, which became a tedious 10-hour grind of running around in circles opening chests. It is also worth noting that, acquiring all trophies requires purchasing the poorly received DLCs. 

Overall, I'd rate the game 7/10 for its entertaining game play. However, subpar DLCs and a grind-heavy trophy experience bring the score down to around 5.5/10. If you can snag it for $10 and enjoy Borderlands-style game play, it's worth a shot.

I think this is a great crossover of the Dungeons & Dragons culture and Bonderlands.

If you’re a fan of both then you’ll probably enjoy this game, I personally LOVED it until I reached the end game. Unfortunately, for whatever reason, the developers decided to not have New Game + via restarting the game upon completion then scaling up the enemies via True Vault Hunter/Ultimate Vault Hunter modes. They VERY easily could’ve created a True Fatemaker and Ultimate Fatemaker modes but elected not to. Instead we receive the Chaos Chamber, a 100 level battle arena of random enemies from the main story with in my opinion no incentive to complete and to me it’s just boring. Additionally, there is no actual DLC missions, it’s just extra arenas which add enemies to the Chaos Chamber.

Therefore, I recommend this game for the main story however can’t emphasize enough how the endgame is a never-ending death-match which is just lackluster.

The game is whimsical, random, silly, and very fun. The main story is pretty creative and you can loot until your eyes fall out. I beat the main story in less than 48 hours, but there are many things you can do afterward if you want to keep playing. You can also re-play with a different character build for a new/different adventure. 

It also doesn't hurt that Adam Samberg and Wanda Sykes are voices for two important characters :)

If you're someone who spent time playing TTRPGs (namely D&D or Pathfinder) you'll likely feel right at home. Tiny Tina presents her D&D-meme filled campaign that you are likely to enjoy. BUT! If you're not familiar with TTRPGs, the player/DM interactions, jokes, memes and overall culture, you might end up scratching your head most of the time and thinking: "This is supposed to be fun?"

Besides D&D there are also many cultural references that go even as back as Don Quixote (by Miguel de Cervantes from early 17th century) or the mythos around King Arthur for example. These are mainly in sidequests which I personally liked a lot. The quality of side quests certainly motivated me to clear all side quests before proceeding with the many story.

Classes, builds, spells, guns... A LOT (and I mean a LOT) of variety there and you can find plenty of crazy builds online. The higher the level, the crazier things you'll likely find. When done with the main story there are chaos chambers (imagine something like Nephalem trials in Diablo 3). As for the DLC postgame options: easily the weakest part of the game. But if you get it as a bundle, likely discounted, you probably won't really care.

Shift seems to be working now, so flicking this to positive.

There is potential for Shift to sometimes not work I guess (it wasn't really working during the winter sale), if that happens use LAN through Hamachi.  If this is a dealbreaker for you don't buy this game until you look on the forums and don't see complaints about online being broken.   Get your group in the same Hamachi network.  Set game to LAN mode on the main menu, cog in upper-right.  Everyone but the one who wants to host goes to Social - LAN and joins the host.  After doing that, I've never had to wait more than 15 seconds on the "Signing in..." screen, and we've never been disconnected from each other.

You do need to connect to Shift to redeem codes, and redeeming codes sucks too.  Can't copy paste, have to type it in, then get this, you can't just hit enter to redeem, you don't just click redeem, no you have to click redeem and *then* hit enter.

Only other Borderlands I've beaten so far is 3 (though I've played a few hours of 2 a long time ago), I'm finding this one to be a lot of fun.

Took about 35 hours to complete the main game, all sidequests, and find all collectibles (we started using Map Genie about 30% into the game, having to backtrack to areas to finish completion for stuff we missed without it for about 4 areas).  There is still an endgame farm to do if we want, will see how much time we spend there.

I thought I recognized the voice but didn't look it up to confirm until the end - Will Arnett is the voice of Dragon Lord.

On my 3070, maxing everything @ 1080p had drops to low 50s only in a couple zones, so I just set FSR (no official DLSS) to quality and it was locked 60 everywhere.

You might want to turn off minimap rotation (which also makes the big map always face north when opening), it makes it a lot easier for communicating with people.

When doing the rune "puzzles", the only person that can interact with the runes is the person that started the "puzzle".

It is an endless mindless loop. The characters are boring and many sound like they are written by a group of children. 
I got this game on sale and I regretted it.

Below is a spoiler if you wanna see the last reason why a don't recommend this game. Its a little political.

[spoiler] The whole, Queen Butt-stallion jokes were...all the time. It got old way fast. (even in the Borderlands 2 DLC, they made the jokes, but not like this. This is extreme) There is a serious design choice towards the LGBTQQIAA+ community. Like, very much in your face. The first main character you meet is a trans-man. While they don't come right out and say it, its pretty obvious. The second side quest you do, is a slap happy humor about a woman who wants to profess her undying love to another woman so its a lesbian love story side quest. Its kinda stupid, but relatable in the quest steps. A normal "she doesn't know who I am but I am in mad love with her" kinda thing. But what really pissed me off is that normal love story, becomes the girl you have been working with decides she is in love with a polka doted mutant beast goblin, very much leaning into bestiality. Again they don't come right out and say it, but its pretty obvious what they are leaning into. The following quest was more guy loves animal. Slap stick and stupid to the max.
Articles have been written about this game and its "Queer escapism and writing." (literally that is the name of the title of an article)
The humor is very slap stick, juvenile (sometimes that's a good thing, but most the time it falls very flat) and lots of forced sexual preference kinda stuff, even if they done come right out and say it, its blunt in your face. I come to Tina's Wonderlands to play a game and mentally click off, not get told by some sexually deviant fantasy NPC in a monologue that all men are evil and F-the patriarchy kinda thing.

Look I am all for people doing their own thing, and a you do you mentality. But I hate it when people, left or right, force opinions and attitudes on you and expect you to just be ok with it without saying anything. Just shut up and drink the coolaid mentality. [/spoiler]

It's pretty good honestly. It scratches a BL2 kind of itch, although it may help to have had some DND exposure in the past just to get a few of the jokes.  The spell casting bit I think was a interesting addition to the overall play of the Borderlands formula.  The bits that people complain about with the encounters is actually not that far off of how some bits of DND play go, and the Arena boss battle stuff really doesn't feel that out of place from the boss battles in BL2 and later.  We did have stuff like Torgue Arena in the earlier games if nothing else.  The game is worth a play if you've finished out the others and the humor is pretty good.

Do not get this game at full price, special offer might be ok. I'm not recommending mainly on craftsmanship issues - but the concept gets a bit stale nonetheless.

Gearbox and/or UE seems to be regressing:
- Non-rebindable keys in 2022? Come on.
- It's surprisingly hard to get the game to run fluidly without stutters.
- Needs more oomph from your hardware for essentially no visual benefit.
- UI doesn't support all resolutions, using a 16:10 monitor will prevent you from comparing items. Seriously, WTF? (Also no fix for this after 1.5 years?)
- To fix the UI issues, you have no sensible ingame display options and ini hacks don't really work.
- While most of the UI is as fluid as expected, ingame 3D UI (like hovering item details or quest markers) sucks really badly. It's unfathomably laggy/choppy, it doesn't keep up with your FPS I guess and is nailed to 30FPS.
- ...also the UI is really blurry (above 1080p I guess), so not really next-gen.
- Texture streaming is the worst I've ever seen, it takes literally ages for all textures to load and looks like a 1998 game along the way. From M2 SSD on highest streaming settings I might add...
- Managing inventory is somehow the most infuriating in the series.

For the game itself:
- It's borderlands, so it's solid, but nothing new.
- Setting is nice, it's like an expanded Tiny Tina D&D DLC - but that's it.
- Humor is ok, better than BL3, worse than BL2.
- Feels like a reskin, because it is.
- No NG+, you need to do repetitive challenges after the story (also alongside the story, mind you)

Over all, I think Gearbox has committed to resting on their laurels - there's no investment whatsoever in existing game systems, new systems aren't new but rehashed existing ones, the engine looks the same but gets increasingly demanding, UI is kinda fucked up for absolutely no reason, basic convenience is still missing after a decade.

BL games have been very samey for a long time, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. But since BL2 they seem to be on a slow downward spiral - I'm not sure what needs to be done, but something definitely has to be done.

This game has its fair shares of flaws, but the reason I recommend it is purely because the game has potential with mods, and the looter shooter RPG aspect with a decent entertaining story is just good enough for me to say it's worth it when the game is on sale. The game itself is a satirical take on DnD but done borderlands style. You get to customize your character from a bunch of diff "roles" and can customize your appearance and skills as well. The game is pretty much similar to borderlands, but instead of a free world to explore you have sequenced "overworld" area to explore which unlocks the more you explore the story. Combat is broken into instanced areas. There is no shortage of loot, so if you're a loot fiend like me you'll be entertained.

Where it falls a bit is how slow the combat is early on. Reloading takes forever, one full clip of ammo is just not enough to take down 1 enemy, and you just feel like you aren't doing much damage. This could also just be an issue because we started with the hardest difficult, but at the same time the challenge isn't really a challenge so much that everythings just a bullet sponge. That doesn't excuse how slow the combat and gunplay feels early on. Slowly it does get better, as with any borderlands game, but it takes a long time. At this time of review the gunplay and combat still feels slow, but I've watched my friends who are much further in the game and it looks way better. Lastly, there are a couple of bugs that are insanely annoying including multiplayer netcode issues and guns locking your camera randomly. Not sure why it happens so often, but you can drop your gun and re-pick it back up which fixes the locking camera problem.

If you can grind past the slow start and appreciate the game for being a DnD inspired looter shooter RPG style of game, then definitely grab it on sales. Mods exist to improve all the issues the game has.

i don't know why borderlands games lately (3 and onward) have dropped the ball in key areas oif what makes the franchise great. This one is superior to bl3 in charm and story, and equal i would say in gameplay on a moment by moment basis.  However, borderlands 3, while being the worst borderlands writing up to that point, had an excellent end game loop, along with tvhm and subsequent playthroughs. 
      I still recommend tiny tina's wonderland, but what the hell is wrong with the studio, that they would get this far with such a great game, and then completely blow the end game and replay loops? I think it was easier to just type in some code (spawn x amount of enemies, etc), use all the resources and procedural generation tools they already had, and call it a day. I'm specifically referring to the chaos chambers there, which is not included in the base game, but that is the only end game content there is. And you are stuck without progressing the character you used, and have to start with a new one to replay the game. 
      For context, i have a couple thousand hours in bl2, and hundreds of hours in bl3, and played at least one game with each character (i can't swear to that without looking, in the case of 3, but in bl2 i have multiples of each character). I have no problem restarting a borderlands game with a new character. After, usually, i have maxed out one character, usually. But also for a variety of other reasons. The point is, i have only played tiny tina's wonderlands about 1.5 times in all the time it's been out, and that is exclusively because i am so disappointed in the end game loop and lack of 'new game +' type mode (tvhm, uvhm).
      Seems to me, the franchise is given some love, but also plagued with money grubbing execs, woke politics (subjective, i realize), inexperienced and under talented writers (specifically bl3), and burn out or laziness, giving way to lazy procedurally generated end game content to avoid actually having to use play testers and balance for more levels (the skill trees would have to be added to, to avoid maxing out in a few more levels than currently exist). 
     All this being said, it's a very nice game with a fantastic aesthetic, a decent  and kind of charming (and pretty stupid at times, but it's a tiny tina game, what did you expect) story, with, of course, the best quality gameplay imaginable. It's worth it, and for me, even knowing the faults in advance, i still bought the dlc. I don't regret it, but it's just not that fun compared to what it should be, imo.

I love the Borderlands series for its caricature, 4th wall and abundance of stupid humor and good gameplay that motivates for exploration and in-game development, and the main plot at least goes beyond the midiocre narrative. On the other hand, DnD, and although I'm not enough of a nerd to waste my time on role-playing games irl, nevertheless, I am well versed in this topic. TT games are cool, I don’t want to offend anyone, but the main reason is that I don’t like them because the Role-Playing Game can be disrupted, the atmosphere and the desire to continue are broken at this point and everything that happens begins to cause cringe and does not feel to continue.
I express my gratitude to the developers for all the efforts to create this game, BUT... With Tina, it turns out about the same as with DnD or any other tabletop role-playing game in my case. It was hard for me to be in the game and motivate myself to explore the world and develop my character. The main plot is absolutely not engaging and is boring to the point of insanity. The gameplay component has changed little within the series, however, the gameplay design leaves me with lots of questions. Weapons and abilities are as boring as it's possible, despite the abundance of tools. The opponents and battles are as monotonous as possible and begin to get boring after the first couple of hours. 80% of the time in the game is additional content without DLC, which is even worse than the main plot of the game. I don’t even want to talk about the endgame, because I don’t see the point in it, because...its presence in games of this series is already an ordinary tick, but in this case it’s just farming for the sake of farming, for the sake of nothing. Yes, this is a co-op game, perhaps someone will want to replay it with a friend and flex with items that have eaten up a lot of personal time that could have been spent more usefully. In general, it’s nonsense, but if it exists, then let it be, not the first time, but with even less meaning than before.
And it would seem that there is nothing left to add. Yes, this is still the same Borderlands and it will find its fans. Alas, I won’t be like that because due to a bunch of decisions and differences from the main series of this universe, it was simply hard for me to force myself to finish what I started. In my case, the game also turned out to be extremely unstable in terms of optimization and terrible connection within the context of co-op play. The only thing that could have been worse was in Outriders at launch, and even then, there I had no problems with the connection and I didn’t need to spend half an hour to finally play with my friend in this “masterpiece” and not crash on the next loading screen.

I fell in love with Borderlands 2 from its story and gameplay, despite the series recent entries falling short, I still managed to complete them multiple times from the Pre-Sequel to Borderlands 3 (on Playstation consoles). My friends dropped Borderlands 3 due to lack of interest (whether its the story being crap or me going ahead with a different character is still left a mystery) but I still played through it for the occasional decent side missions and legacy characters, plus the gameplay being the best it ever been in Borderlands 3. I had hope that this recent game would be a step forward as the Borderlands 3 dlc was a massive improvement narratively, but I was wrong.

The distinct characters with their own personalities are gone now in exchange for your own custom character, so no use getting attached to them. The starting cast they present you with are so unserious they give off the vibes of a recent MCU movie, with no legacy characters to help counter it. Tiny Tina being the only one like that is fine but the entire cast not acting like freakin adults kills investment for me. It doesn't help the main villain is the same way and I swear he is either the VA or sounds like the VA for Bojack (Bojack Horseman) so I can't take the villain as a threat because I've heard that voice tied to a washed up alcoholic horse. It's baffling how the combination of DND and Borderlands feels more like a lazier Borderlands using the DND theme to justify cutting corners. The board game style open world to replace the large expanded maps feels half assed and leave the "encounters" to just be some horde mode style levels, paying to the lazingness of the the game.

Ok, I saved my biggest grip for last, the starting loadouts in terms of abilities for classes are straight ass, like watching your badass friend get cucked by his girlfriend into being a soy consuming killjoy. I wanted to pick the closest thing to a necromancer and all he does is an aoe attack?? that's my class ability?!?! They locked the companion that you have for later!?!?! What a load a shit.

In short, in the same way Starfield was undercut by the superior storytelling and RPG mechanics of Baldur's Gate 3, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands was completely undercut in the DND department by Baldur's Gate 3 and the FPS gameplay of previous Borderlands titles, like why the fuck would I want to play this game, that doesn't take itself seriously and cuts out all the RPG/dice rolling mechanics, over games that focuses on one aspect and polishes it to a shine?? 

There was a bunch of casuals demanding Baldur's Gate 3 would be better with real-time combat and honestly I can't see a game that would better appeal to that request, and as everyone else can predict, it sucks ass. Btw, this is the first ever steam refund I've ever done so, achievement unlocked?

Gearbox/2k please please get your shit together!

Original Review:
This game seems to be a PR checkbox for the LGB community though at many times it's so forced that it might also be a satirical comment on the current social situation. If you can look past all that crap (and for some that will be very hard as it's thick throughout), the game is fairly decent. Story is short, and replayability is meh, but if you can get it on a deep sale it's good for probably 30-50 hrs of Borderlands fun until they come out with a proper game again.

Short, woke, crudely put together story line that seams disconnected with the actual game play.  Just the same old random encounters that pad game play time.  I fell sorry for people who paid full price on this discount attempt for a Borderlands adjacent game.

Honestly pretty boring. A cut and paste reskin of Borderlands 3; even the guns and the enemies are the same. Quests are repetitive and there's even more wait time/walking between missions and no mounts or cars! I understand the people who bought it at full price and feel cheated.

OK way to kill time if you like Borderlands, but definitely wait for a sale. It regularly goes for $20 on Steam.

The gameplay is similar to Borderlands 3, but the combat and weapons are not. When I first starting playing i hated the game especially when you get to the board game map. Basically the map is just a giant board game and your the main piece that is being manipulated by Tina. Its cool in some ways, but annoying in others...the guns and combat do not get any better until you reach level 10 and above, but this game focuses more on magic and skill usage not overpowered powered weapons like in BL3. Spoilers they threw in swords as a cheap way to melee enemies.. In conclusion you will either like it or hate it...but I only paid $15 for it...so.

It’s the weakest in the series (but not as bad as New Tales of the Borderlands). The game is alright but both the antagonists and protagonist are meh, the narrators are annoying (Tiny Tina is ok though, I meant the other two) and the story is just fine at best. The bosses are too easy and simple and the “random encounters” are repetitive and thoroughly boring. Those random encounters are used everywhere in the game to the point where I just can’t tolerate them anymore. E.g. they are used in Pokémon styled random encounters, in multi-leveled dungeons, in camps you have to beat, as trail runs (in which they are even longer), as side-quests and a few more places that I can’t remember right now.

The gameplay is nice though, they added some interesting classes and abilities. Instead of grenades you have spells with interesting effects that can be really powerful. The gunplay feels just like what you would expect from Borderlands: solid and varied. There are enough weapons that you’ll always find something you like. The DnD theme was fun to return to and the changes they made to accommodate that were really good.

The humor is still mostly there but it has become very careful and dulled down. They watered down the more brutal feel of the older games into a more [insert current year] game. It has some occasional good moments and partially beats the whole influencer/streamer nonsense they had in BL3 to some extent. Emphasis on the “partially” part, the rest of BL3 is still better.

The UI (menus, inventory management, etc.) have been worsened even more than BL3 already did. You can’t even compare items properly because they stick outside of the screen. There were a lot of small annoyances in this area but I can’t remember them all right now and got used to some of them eventually.

Towards the end of the game, they don’t give you enough money to upgrade everything like they did in other Borderland games which made it really annoying to get the final achievement. Me and my friend ended up spending a good 20 hours just grinding the trail runs until we found an exploit that involved hitting dead sharks with a pickaxe for 20 minutes per shark. We did that for 6-9 hours until we found a duplication glitch to get the final 200 million dollars we needed. This process really killed the game for me. Of course, I know it’s optional but the other games made the money system way more reasonable and all these small annoyances add up. I think it might be this way because the game is much shorter and has a much lower level cap while they never bothered adjusting the pricing to compensate. In the previous games getting all the achievements were a lot more fun, even running around aimlessly searching for red-chests in BL2 was more fun than this.

I was looking forward to this game as the BL2 DLC that inspired this game was amazing. I really wanted to like it but it ended up being somewhat of a disappointment for me. It’s alright, not bad, but not as good as what I expected from a BL game. There are just too many small bad things that add up to a “meh” overall experience. I recommend it assuming you have played the other Borderlands games first and that the game is on sale, otherwise no. Don’t let this be your introduction to Borderlands.

What's great about this game is that you can turn off your brain when you play. The story has no meaningful interactions with any interesting characters... although the Voice Actors are absolutely hilarious. I mean no hate to the devs but this is basically like a Tiny Tina Assault on Dragon Keep but like a waterboarded version. So much forced humor into a game that it really turns something off in my brain. 

The most interesting thing about this game is the swords which are VERY fleshed out, tons of different types of swords with interesting options. I really wish Borderlands had this in the next game. The spells are very neat besides finding the same damn legendary spell in one play-through. 

All of the DLC's from what I'm seeing add no new creatures or interesting things in them, try to buy this when its on sale.

I literally couldn't bring myself to finish this game, and i don't have a singular clue why. Oh wait I know why, it's kinda ass.

The game the first time through is fine enough. I like the gist, but the writing is somehow too dated and also too current that it feels stuck between the two. I liked a lot of things this game did for the Borderlands franchise, and the DnD element is fun. 

Main gripes:

- Repetitive Mobbing, far beyond what other BL games have had.
- Voicing: Characters say their quips far too often (Similar issue in BL3)
- Leveling/NG+: No real incentive to continue playing after reaching level cap and finishing the story. The Chaos dungeons are interesting as a concept but really unless we get a level cap increase and DLC there's very little replayability.

After having played, I don't think I would've bought this one if it weren't on steep discount. 

We hold out hope for BL4...

A huge downgrade on the Borderlands formula. Zone exploration has been traded for a clunky world map. Action zones are small and don't feature many points of interest or things to find. Fights are primarily delivered through an encounter system where there is nothing to discover in the environment and the objective is simply to defeat a certain number of enemies and advance to the next wave. Collectibles are remarkably easy to find, leaving very little to discover after the game is beaten and a handful of unremarkable stat-boosting rewards is all you will have to show for it. DLC is woefully uninteresting and fails to complement the main story in any meaningful way, managing to be forgettable both in and out of story context. Chaos Mode, the ostensible post-game content, is literally "get boned by RNG: the game mode". Think mayhem modifiers, but without the choices and with a bunch of new ways to suddenly and inexplicably die in the name of marginally superior loot. All the fun of exploring broken builds is nerfed into the ground by the sad 40-level cap, lackluster gear modifiers, and meager skill trees. Legendary weapons and spells feel phoned in and the armor system seems tacked on to fill a hole. Loot is wholly unrewarding to farm and the process is sometimes excruciatingly bad, with astronomically low drop rates combined with Chaos requirements that make the experience unpleasantly unforgiving. Even the most successful loot farm yields a disappointingly small improvement in firepower while the enemies grow exponentially in difficulty with Chaos enabled. There is no equivalent to TVHM, which means no second playthrough, which means you will hit level cap before you beat the final boss. But hey, you get a bunch of new Tina lines and Torgue finally gets to blow up the ocean.

Final ratings:

Graphics 5/5 - It's a stellar look for the franchise, but the environments are bland and repetitive
Sound 4/5 - Decent enough, but there is a LOT of waiting on audio dialog, with punchlines that often fall flat
Gameplay 3/5 - Borderlands gunplay, without the awesome effects or OP interactions, but with melee weapons
Storyline 2/5 - We knew it would be about Tina's psychosis, but the delivery is distilled cringe and even Torgue can't save it

Overall 3/5 - If you're desperate for more Borderlands, you can give it a try. There won't be as many dick jokes and it is much shorter than BL3, but all the pieces are there.

Many people don't evaluate, and they can't connect.
The general comment is that the series is getting worse and worse, the highlights are scarce, and the skills and equipment are hard to play after the change, and you can try it after the discount.

I've played all the Borderlands games, and my favorite until this day is Borderlands 2, what I really liked about 2 was the Tiny Tina Assault on Dragon Keep DLC. So I was really excited when I learned they were making a standalone game in the same style.

But when I started playing the game I was fairly disappointed, because the game is PG16 rated, there is no gore, blood and profanity. At first I thought the profanity filter was on because they censored some words very strangely, but after a quick search I found out there was not profanity or gore in the whole game. I thought this was a big mistake because one of the reasons I really liked the story of the borderlands games was, it was very brutal and sarcastic.

For the technical side of the game, they improved the in game menus and especially how to use your inventory. The hitboxes of some of the objects are very annoying when using the sniper, like some wooden gates have a hitbox a feet above where the wood ends which is very annoying when taking cover behind them and peeking out to shoot your enemies and then finding out you were just hitting the fence on places where there is not actual fence. There are also a lot of bugs with pathfinding during story parts where the npc just gets stuck behind objects. One other thing I also found really annoying is, every time you start the game, it's recalculating the shaders, and it just takes too long.

Getting to the story, it's just mid. I like the conversations between the party members and the whole DnD aspects, but the rest of the story didn't do it for me. It didn't make me have any desires to get to the endgame.

For getting to let the player know the controls, items and the world, they could've done a better job. I took me ages to find out that wards are shields, but there is also a specific group of shields that are called ward. Quickly comparing items that are on the ground is not as intuitive as the previous games.

I would not recommend playing this game if you think it would be a borderlands 2 experience. If you never played a borderlands game and you can get this game for 10 bucks, maybe it's worth the money.

For now I would rate it 6/10

So I beat the main game... I'm a grinder, thus the high hours... and my verdict is just no. Especially with how the post-game turns out.

The problem is mobbing. In earlier Borderlands games, arenas were just little side things to play with; here, they're a necessity for a LOT of the content. Any area that's a "Combat Encounter" (like any random encounter, Overworld sidequest dungeon, most shrine piece dungeons) drops you in a large zone, but all the mobs that spawn immediately know where you are.

This means if you are a methodical, strategic killer, like a sneaking or sniper sort, you're going to hate this, AND you're going to see and make use of almost NONE of the zone architecture you've been dropped into. All the interesting zone complexity is lost, and you'll have to run around like mad or risk getting cornered by masses of mobs homing in on you.

The worst part? This is the entire design of the post-game content. It's ALL mass mobbing in these kinds of zones and fights. No wandering, no exploring, no planning out how to take down individual groups, just run and gun and masses of mobs homing in on you and that's it. No style. No strategy. VERY limited build options that lean more and more heavily on specific pieces of equipment with specific enchants.

It's all a loss. After Borderlands 3's mediocre experience, I was hoping for something. Desperately mass mobbing ALL the time is NOT fun.

Edit: Went back in to try the DLCs. I tried the third one, with Fyodor and the chains, and got infinitely swarmed while trying to stay on a pressure plate to break a chain. Constant downs, fast death. I don't see a way to do this, and, again... mobbing SUCKS.

On top of that, I forgot to mention that the game is riddled with little bugs, like Quick Travel randomly not working unless you quit out and reload, and equipped gear textures randomly not loading, often until you do the same. Select button randomly not opening the subscreen.

Also the game is LOADED with "small" but strong mobs that beat the crap out of you and quickly run around you, so you're constantly trying to figure out what's hitting you as your shield and health jump down in chunks, looking down and in circles in the middle of a mob of other enemies that are also trying to kill you.

I just have zero love for this game. The first Borderlands game I can honestly say that about. The post-game is miserable.
