If you found the DLC "Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep" in Borderlands 2 appealing, this game might not match that experience. While Borderlands 2 had its merits and Tiny Tina was a crucial character, this version of her in the new game seems more like a nostalgic ploy to attract buyers, leveraging her as a brand.

In terms of voice acting, Wanda Sykes as Frette adds a fun element to the dialogue, and Andy Samberg's portrayal of Captain Valentine, though different from his usual comedic style, blends well with Sykes' character. Familiar voices might be a draw for those interested in this aspect of gaming.

Regarding the story, it didn't particularly captivate or disinterest me; it fell somewhere in the middle. The voice acting kept things entertaining, but the distinct Borderlands vibe seemed lacking, almost as if the game took cues from a less engaging RPG source.

The feel of an open-world characteristic of Borderlands is notably absent. Encounters and skirmishes occur differently, neither impressively nor disappointingly, just averagely.

Starting on the Insane difficulty level, known for its challenge, I found it surprisingly easy. Even when deliberately using lower-level gear and pacing encounters, the difficulty level didn't match up to previous Borderlands games.

Graphically, it maintains the familiar Borderlands style. The enemy designs are well-crafted, and the landscapes are meticulously drawn.

While there are aspects I appreciate in the mechanics and structure, there's more that I find less appealing. Purchasing it on sale for $19.99 felt like a reasonable price for what essentially felt like a basic game.

Ultimately, if you're seeking an experience akin to Borderlands, sticking with Borderlands 3 might be more satisfying. For franchise collectors, a sale purchase might be worthwhile. Those who appreciate strong storytelling and character investment might not find this game fulfilling in those aspects. In essence, if you're after a true Borderlands experience, this game might not quite hit the mark.

[u] Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is a first-person looter-shooter developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K in 2022. This title is a spinoff from the mainline Borderlands games series and features a fully cooperative online campaign. The review will focus on the base campaign experience played entirely in 4-player coop. [/u]

[h3] TL;DR – Re-skinned Borderlands 3 which is not necessarily a good thing as the good doesn’t improve while the bad only feels more dated and problematic now. [/h3]

Story (2/5) – Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is set in “Bunkers & Badasses” a fantasy roleplaying tabletop game in the same vein as D&D that is created and game-mastered by the titular Tiny Tina. Just like the prior Borderlands title, the story is wacky and often at times makes little to no sense. The same is true in Wonderlands only with poorer writing, pacing and general cohesiveness. Tack on the fact that NPCs are always trying to offer you side-quests and following the story can be rather tough and unrewarding. While the same atmosphere worked in the mainline games, it just falls rather flat in Wonderlands.

Gameplay (4/5) – Gunplay remains to be a strong suit of the Borderlands games with all the usual gun manufacturers present. There are whole new classes to fit the fantasy world’s archetypes. The addition of “magic” is an interesting gameplay element, but don’t differ too much from the active skills from the base games. Hybrid classes now exist, but do not matter significantly in the base campaign. 

Controls (4/5) – Played on a mouse and keyboard, Wonderlands felt exactly like playing any other Borderlands title. Fully customizable button layouts are present. Shooting is nice and snappy. While movement is almost identical to Borderlands 3’s which does start to feel a touch dated at this point.

Graphics (3/5) – Borderland’s cel-shaded look is back with Wonderlands and it very much looks like a re-skinned version of Borderlands 3 albeit running much poorer. I liked the artwork and art style for Borderlands 3’s space faring setting, but it doesn’t quite work for the fantasy setting of Wonderlands. Moreover, enemy recognition is also rather tricky as their colour pallet means they often just blur into the background. 

Audio (2/5) – By far the weakest link in Wonderlands, the audio in this game leaves a lot to be desired. The soundtrack is repetitive and forgettable. A lot of audio bites are reused and recycled from the previous games. And the voice acting falls rather flat despite having some rather high-profile voice actors, it was almost as if they were all in different venues recording their lines. 

Issues/Optimization – Wonderlands doesn’t run very well on PC I’m afraid. Despite tweaks and usage of FSR, I had to lock the game to 75 fps due to the large number of frame rate drops and very inconsistent frame pacing. Fortunately, crashes and gameplay bugs were non-existent. 

Overall (3/5) – Having thoroughly enjoyed Borderlands 3, I had high hopes for Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands. While there were certainly moments of fun and laughter in my ~22 hours play through of the base campaign, I never found myself returning to the game to finish its many more side quests left waiting. If you’re new to the Borderlands series, I probably wouldn’t recommend starting here. If you aren’t, you need not rush into this either.

A Fantastical Adventure Beyond Imagination!

I recently embarked on an incredible journey through the whimsical realm of Tiny Tina's Wonderlands, and I must say, it exceeded all my expectations! Gearbox Software has once again delivered a gaming masterpiece that combines the best elements of action, humor, and pure fantasy.

From the moment I stepped into the vibrant and enchanting world, I was captivated by the stunning visuals and creative design. The art direction is nothing short of magical, with each corner of the Wonderlands bursting with color, charm, and a sense of wonder. The attention to detail in the landscapes, characters, and creatures truly immerses you in a fantastical realm that feels alive and dynamic.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands excels not only in its visuals but also in its gameplay. The action-packed combat is both fluid and exhilarating, offering a perfect blend of gunplay and fantastical abilities. The introduction of spellcasting adds a delightful twist to the traditional formula, allowing players to unleash a variety of magical attacks that range from awe-inspiring to downright hilarious. The diverse selection of weaponry and skill trees ensures that no two playthroughs are the same, promoting replayability and experimentation.

One of the game's standout features is its exceptional storytelling, driven by the quirky and lovable Tiny Tina. The narrative unfolds with a perfect balance of humor, emotion, and unexpected twists, keeping players engaged and eager to uncover the mysteries of the Wonderlands. The cast of characters, each with their unique personalities and backstories, adds depth to the overall narrative and creates a connection with the player that goes beyond the screen.

The cooperative multiplayer aspect of Wonderlands is a true highlight. Joining forces with friends or other players online enhances the experience, turning the already fantastic adventure into a collaborative and laughter-filled escapade. The game seamlessly blends single-player and multiplayer elements, offering a dynamic and engaging social experience for players of all preferences.

In addition to its outstanding core gameplay, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands features an impressive soundtrack that complements the game's atmosphere perfectly. The music enhances the sense of epic adventure and adds an extra layer of immersion to an already captivating experience.

In conclusion, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a triumph in game design, offering a delightful and unforgettable journey through a world filled with magic, humor, and endless surprises. Gearbox Software has once again proven their mastery in creating captivating and enjoyable experiences, making this a must-play title for anyone seeking a fantastical escape into a realm of pure joy.

[h1]There's nothing new[/h1]
It's basically a reskin of Borderlands 2. Guns are the same, shooting is the same, skills are the same, enemies are even dumber. You would think that since Borderlands was set in a completely new setting, the developers would reinvent the core gameplay mechanics and give players something new to play, but nah.
TTWL is a giant satire of the entire D&D universe and CRPG genre. The developers could dig a little deeper into that shit and, while looking for the stuff to laugh at, take some points on the mechanics that would make the game feel fresh and new. A feeling I haven't had since Borderlands 2. But all I got is a stat system, which is plain and blank as it could be, and a new weapon type — crossbows. Which sucks.

[h1]Narrative Cringefest[/h1]
I never really liked Tiny Tina as a character. Her personality didn't catch me, I didn't care about her lines and her story. And that might be the reason why the whole narration of this game feels boring, forced and cringeworthy. Every time the narrator tells a joke, a "how do you do fellow kids" meme pops up in my head, and I cringe. In their attempt to laugh at D&D boomers, the writers have become those very boomers, just on the other side of the fence. 

[h1]Just another game in the series[/h1]
Overall, the game feels lazy and talentless. The whole series of the last decade feels stagnant. There is little to no change from game to game. And TTWL is no exception.

The first Borderlands game was something new. A satirical shooter with a pretty interesting universe and a fresh look at shooter mechanics. They basically invented/popularized the looter shooter.
Borderlands 2 polished all of that and doubled the concentration of weapons and jokes and balanced them perfectly.

Since then, we've had a 5th game in a Borderlands series, and they haven't strayed far from the Borderlands 2 formula. Some might say that's a good thing, but personally I've had enough.

Shooting the same enemies with the same guns while listening to all the same recycled jokes for God knows how long since Borderlands 2 in a row is a bit much.  I expected some depth in the new setting: both, gameplay- and narrative-wise. And if you are like me, I strongly suggest you to skip this one.

Less time spent walking around and more time spent in the action and finding hidden loot.

I like the Borderlands franchise, but so far this just isn't IT. Pacing feels terribly awful, difficulty balance in the early game is as bad as it was in BL3 and the story is just horrendous so far; feels made up on the spot.
I bought it at full price and it was such a mistake; less than 30 hours of gameplay, and DLCs are comprised of waves of boring enemies with no story, that can be completed within 10 minutes max (ALL OF THEM COMBINED).

I'm still happy I went through with the purchase because it gave me more experiences of the Borderlands series, but I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who's not a die-hard fan of BL, especially at full price. Buy it only when on high discounts and skip the DLCs, they're just a scam.

Also - I understand Gearbox's motive for advocating for LGBTQ rights and "normalizing" their orientation, but it's so forced at this point that I just feel like I'm being brainwashed and indoctrinated into believing that it is the NORM, when it's just *so* not (mainly referencing the knight with the beard who's also supposed to be a girl apparently...?).

Short: It is not as bad as Borderlands 3 because one can go into the settings and disable all voice and subtitles, completing missions is just a question of following the blue marker.

The gameplay itself is mechanically solid (same as in BL3), map design is much better than BL3 IMHO, however it suffers from many of the same flaws as BL3. There are too many status attacks, there is too much loot to the point it becomes both meaningless and a chore as 99% is junk, as a word of advice ignore anything white and green, not worth the time or in-game money. There so much stuff going on in the screen all at once that you get killed dozens of times and have no clue what is that killed you. You will die many times right after a level has been cleared or a boss defeated because you will step in a pool of some goo that in a second will eat your shield and your health, doesn't matter how high they are.

As with every borderlands game one gun category is rendered useless this time around is shotguns, save the ones that fire bombs or swords 99% are useless. I finished the game just using smgs, pistols and assault rifles, bazookas, snipers and as mentioned shotguns are useless. The loot, there is so much of it that is rendered irrelevant, you find a decent gun level 20 and you can carry it to level 30 discarding 1000 guns in the way, eventually you need to replace it because it becomes a peashooter, when you replace it you won't replace it with a better gun, just whatever you find that can make a dent in the enemy's health just because it is a higher level weapon. All the enchantments and status effects, hero trees, etc, all amount to a huge mess that becomes bothersome quickly, I couldn't bother to look at it proper.

The sound effects are decent, the music is non-existent, is elevator quality at best.

It is a 25/30h mid game buy only heavily discounted. I'm not excited for more Borderlands games anymore, it is clear Gearbox doesn't understand what made BL1 and BL2 fun to play.

Never has a game managed to make me feel such raw, unfiltered quantities of emotion such as this. That emotion being unimaginable, unrelenting boredom.

TTW is an example of a realistic digital soul-numbing experience that I was NOT ready for.
I'm no stranger to Borderlands, having about 280 hours in Borderlands 2, but this game is on another level of soulless. If you like Borderlands 3 then you might like this but then again, [u]you like Borderlands 3[/u].

Terrible writing. The game has no stakes, peaks or troughs, excitement, enjoyable characters. Every line uttered is so sickly interwoven with forced humour and bland jokes that nothing can be taken seriously so you end up just gritting your teeth and pushing through mandatory, dry dialogue, waiting for the next objective to open up. This is my main gripe, bar-none. To have a story with no story is quite a feat.

The gun-play is fine, the spells are interesting and fun, the abilities are mediocre at best (from what few I've played with). Weapon identity is vapid and robotic - whilst the guns look good for the most part, the randomly chosen attachments and mods make most guns look abysmal or indistinguishable aside minor adjustments ( switching a 2-shot burst gun to 3-shot burst? so boring, man). Stat-wise, the game feels less like a game about looting cool guns to a game about finding high percentages and scores. Just use the guns with higher scores. Also the difficulty plays a part in the monotony - I don't feel anything when I defeat a boss 5 seconds after it was hyped up as a really super dangerous bad guy. The graveborn pulse ability just becomes an instakill screenwipe after some time and since the enemies scale to your level you'll never see that change.

The bugs were plentiful and somehow STILL present after all this time. Inability to reload on an empty mag, completely unusable minigun/overheat weapons (I played co-op with a friend hosting), ragdolls bugging out hardcore, janky mantle hitboxes, occasional crashes and missing HUD features. I'm most peeved about the minigun bug like I couldn't use that whole category of weapon because they just didn't work, like huh?????

Above all, this is just such a boring game. Sure, it's flashy, but there's just no substance to anything. I'd catch myself slumped over forgetting to blink due to the monotony. Another thing I just remembered is that the weapons just don't have ANY impact - snipers lack any proper recoil and most guns lack powerful-sounding effects. Feels like you're shooting marshmallows.

As much as I'd like to think that the game gets better, to delude myself further would call for me to be checked into a psychiatric ward. They say the sick delude themselves - perhaps this is the game's doing.

Incredibly lazy writing (you will like it if you watch a lot of Netflix or Amazon Prime's shows). Some weapons don't feel impactful. There are guns in Borderlands 1 that straight-up feel better. Graphics are good, but most NPC models have bad graphics (360/PS3 era). I personally liked the aspect of battling in arenas but 90% of the time you fight in them, making it feel monotone. Freshly introduced characters barely get any dialogue after their first appearance. Monster designs are extremely repetitive.

Then again, I liked some of the music. Sound design is alright. Dialogue is at least 90% pure filler/redundancy. Loot chance is determined by dices you NEED to find first. After the main story, you can do shadow chambers, and you are going to spawn in re-used arenas again and again. I then did some runs and mostly had legendary/epic gear on my level and attempted chaos level 2 and got instantly oneshot by enemies on normal (not elite). I'm just going to tell you, the min-maxing that needs to be done is not worth it for this game. Once you're done-- There's nothing really new.

After playing the standalone Assault on Dragon Keep DLC for Borderlands 2 I had caught the bug and Tiny Tina´s Wonderlands is everything I would wish for in a full blown game version of the DLC and more.
 After so many people were disappointed with Borderlands 3 this is a definite return to form in terms of humor, storytelling and just overall gameplay fun. They took the good innovations from 3 and packaged it in a very charming and character driven game with a lot of nerdy humor and jokes that every DnD player will instantly recognize. Throw to that a lot of funny references, great comedic voice acting and beautiful environments and you are sure to have a good time.
Also you finally get to Blow up the Ocean!
Gameplay and gunplay feel very smooth and rewarding with a lot of ways and options to design your character and what kind of build you want. With the weapons and spells, which replace grenades, being so ubiquitous and varied every new weapon box or beaten elite enemy can give you something that will influence your combat and raw power. You also feel very mobile and fast on your feet which adds to the rush of the game.
Technically it is pretty solid and in around 50 gameplay hours I only had one hard crash and a handful of bugs and glitches, mostly connected to things on the screen not going away when they should but that is usually solved with a quick restart or similar.
Reload your guns and upcast magic missile to lvl 20! 8/10

I overall loved this game.  The story was great!  Tina is my favorite character since she made her appearance and it's awesome seeing this feral character grow.  And as you can expect her storytelling for a roleplaying game is fantastic!

The multiclassing is great, the chaos chambers is actually refreshing.  I finally don't have to hate going back into previous zones.  The chaos chambers are arena runs that are altered by buffs, debuffs, and purchased buffs.  The less purchased buffs you buy, the more RNG you get for gear at the end of the runs.  And the gear chance goes up with chaos levels to spawn Chaotic, Volatile, Primordial, and Ascended ranks of gear.  I think you will be done with the game quicker than most in the series.  But it really does feel better for multiplayer than it used to.

Finding all of the lucky dice, marbles, poetry pages, scrolls and whatnot to maximize your bonuses for the chaos chamber grind can be tough, but it is more fun than looking for those vault logos.

Cons:
I will say that end game is definitely more focused on the elements than previous borderlands games.  I feel like there are too many mixes and layers of resistances in these arenas.  So it can be pretty overwhelming with constantly switching weapons to mow through all of the layers the adds throw at you.  The characters definitely need some damage penetration because you can't focus a damage type like you used to.  Like if I stacked a ton of frost damage it will still lower shield damage, just not as fast.  Well in this game, it starts to feel more like cutting through a brick wall with a plastic spoon than it did in previous games.

Conclusion:
If you liked the borderlands games, but didn't like going through the entire game twice doing normal and then bad a** difficulty to get the better gear, than this one will be more appealing.    I think this one finally dethroned the first borderlands as my favorite in the series.
If you like Borderlands you will like this game.

The campaign of this game is pretty good and was overall a lot of fun, the maps are beautiful and large, the gameplay is very fun and the game makes the most out of its unique setting. The overworld map is pretty unique, there are a lot of character- and build options and the bigger quests are all around interesting.
But all is not well: there are some BAFFLING choices made by the developers starting with the DLCs, which are completely worthless and WAY overpriced at 10€ a piece, locking a class behind a paywall as well. Another thing I hated, was that loot is completely useless in 95% of cases, which is a shitty feeling in a LOOT SHOOTER! I stopped picking up anything in the final levels as I simply got tired of picking up trash and selling it. Speaking of final levels: the second ring slot and enchantments, which are a pretty big factor in builds in my opinion, are unlocked after the story...... 
Most likely for the mindless and extremely boring Chaos Chamber grind, (guess where all the good loot went, lol). Why the F U C K is such a big priority put on the end game? As if the numerous random encounters during the story weren't boring enough, the end game consists of such "encounters" exclusively. Or replay some bosses... and for what exactly?!? 
Why should I even grind this stuff? WHAT FOR??? Honest question!
I finished the story. Why would I WASTE my time with this repetitive, boring endgame, which has nothing new to offer?
My recommendation? Get the base game (wait for a sale) and steer clear of the DLCs. I got the Chaotic Great Editon mostly for the new class during Summer Sale for 26,40€ and I still feel absolutely robbed by the DLCs...
Good game, but end game is boring unless you like min/maxing your build.

[quote][b]Score: 8/10[/b][/quote]

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a spin-off of the Borderlands series. The last game i played from this franchise was actually Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep DLC. Wonderlands brings players back by offering an alternate version of D&D called Bunkers and Badasses. Right from the start, I noticed a lot of nice references to games like The Witcher 3, Path of Exile, Curse of Monkey Island, and of course the older Borderlands games.

The story is really nice. Your main quest is to defeat the evil Dragon Lord and save the fantasy world rules by a unicorn called buttstalion, the game is a continuation of the 2013 DLC. I won't spoil much but it was interesting enough to keep me wondering how it's going to end. The game also has some really high quality side quests that blend seamlessly with the main storylines. The humor and dialogue were lighthearted and kept me engaged without any character wearing out their welcome. In fact, I actually wanted to see more of Tiny Tina. 

Gameplay-wise, the fantasy setting brings welcome new ideas like spellcasting instead of just throwing grenades. Every spell type gives you unique options to experiment with. The weapons felt great and had top notch animations, overall the combat was thrilling and stands out as some of the most fun I've had in recent FPS titles. The overworld was a welcome addition as it really provides a spice of variety when taking a break from chaotic dungeon runs. I can only imagine how much better the experience would be playing coop with a friend.

Last but not least, on the visual and performance side, the game looks great. It has that timeless Borderlands art style that is sure to age gracefully. The game didn't have any FPS drops although I had to cap the fps at 50

[b]TL;DR: Though not revolutionary, Wonderlands impresses with creativity, humor, and polished gameplay. I would easily recommend it for those looking for a fantasy filled looter shooter.[/b]

Overly expensive for what experience you get compared to previous titles.

Take Borderlands 3, replace all those fantastically huge areas with a cheap chibi scale overworld map (the joke wears off within seconds) and reskin everything left as a fantasy game spoof. Gameplay is too similar to BL3 to make a difference, level design is that of an arena shooter and writing along the lines of a middling side quest you were too starved to not accept. I'm almost mad about the fact that they have a pen-and-paper RPG theme but don't bother putting any of that to good use except for overly cheap jokes stretched to almost all imaginable proportions.

But the worst of it all is how the time it takes from character creation to the overworld map (practically the tutorial), you're right beyond the magic 2h refund barrier. I mean come on, what sort of AAA pea brain manager thought this would be a sensible thing to sign off? Add your run-off-the-mill crash grab DLC for unlocking a few +/- percentages and classes... bam, instant regret even when buying it discounted.

Overall, I'm awarding this game the title of "worst investment I made in 2023". Quadruple thumbs down if I could.

I had my suspicions about this game after the travesty that was Borderlands 3, but I was pleasantly surprised by this game and found it to be mostly enjoyable. The game's worth playing, but there's a few things to note.

The game is not nearly has long, expansive, or in depth as its predecessors, Pre-Sequel included. Its DLCs are very short and basically amounts to a short, 10 minute gauntlet, the main storyline and sidequests are fairly limited, and the endgame is short and dry. Instead of a full $60 game, I personally would only recommend buying it if the price falls below half. 

Another buyer-beware is the fact that it's been released here on Steam for a year and nearly two years on Epic, yet a ton of the game's glaring issues were never fixed. The audio level is way too low such that cranking everything to 100 still feels a little too faint. The audio range of sound effects and dialogues have this really weird quirk where if you look away from the sound source, it'll sound like it's been muffled by a wall made of mattresses. Doesn't matter if you're standing right next to the speaker. You look away and it's suddenly a garbled mess. Other than that, there are issues with dialogues skipping or not playing at all here and there, or they may overlap each other completely.

Barring all that. The game's great. I enjoy the banter between Tina, Frette, and Valentine, I enjoy the quirky humor of a Tiny Tina-hosted DnD, and I enjoy the further refinement of the fighting mechanics that were made better in Borderlands 3. Plus, if push comes to shove, there's still the Wonderlands Redux mod.

Lets start with the comedy, yes this is entirely subjective but I honestly don't think there are more than a handful of people that the jokes will land for. The jokes and gags in the game feel like someone trying to emulate BL2s humor but they don't understand what makes the game funny. They also forced in a lot of their political opinions into the game, everyone is entitled to their own opinions but I just wanna play games and escape from reality for a bit, not get reminded of it a bunch.

Second is the length of dialogue, there isn't much to say, there is a ton and it's very slow and boring. If you got the mod to add a skip button you could probably shave a day or two off your playtime depending on how long you can play each day.

Last is the bugs, there are so many UI/Menu/Encounter bugs that can softlock you or crash the game or whatever that it's laughable that they want $60 for the game. When playing through it with my friend we FREQUENTLY had to restart the game due to one of us being unable to do anything in game after an enemy touched us, or quest enemies just not spawning or spawning in a wall making them unkillable. There are many more bugs but those are the most common and most annoying.

Don't buy this, please don't support their slaughter of a once great series.

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands builds on the Borderlands 2 DLC “Tony Tina’s Assault on Dragon Keep.” The levels are bigger, the loot pool is bigger, the gameplay is mostly copied from Borderlands 3. Sounds good, right? But no New Game + (wtf!), a terrible endgame and shortage of farmable bosses make Wonderlands worth buying only with a deep discount.
7/10 for original ideas (but could have been higher)
Total size on my hdd: 49 GB

++ DOOM-inspired gameplay is back. Grenades have been replaced by magic spells.
+ Even with other characters like Aloy (Horizon series) and Parvati (Outer Worlds) to her credit, Tiny Tina will forever be voice actress Ashley Burch’s signature role (for me, anyway). She’s as good as ever here.
+ Wanda Sykes, Andy Samberg and Will Arnett all turn in great performances.
+ Story doesn’t rival the Dragon Keep dlc of Borderlands 2, but is good.
+ Replacing the space-ship and map travel of Borderlands 3 is a table-top-rpg-style “overworld,” where you move a miniature of your in-game character around a 3D game board. There are ambushes, chests of loot, and random encounters. Great addition to Wonderlands, adding to the feeling of playing a classic rpg.
+ Legendaries are rare again!
+ Fun side-quests. One of my favorites was “The Ditcher,” which features famous monster hunter Gerritt of Trivia…
+ The best graphics of any Borderlands game.
+ Lots of character customization options
+ Most of the performance issues that plagued Borderlands 3 are not present in Wonderlands. Ran smooth and stutter free. 
+ Still has a DX11 mode, so if you’re still running an older gpu Wonderlands should work.

+/- Wonderlands is woke. There’s pronouns in the character creator, gay pirates, and Paladin Mike is Lorelei from Borderlands 3 (who has transitioned to Lor by the time New Tales from the Borderlands occurs, though Tiny Tina’s design indicates Wonderlands takes place before Borderlands 3). Whether any of that is a positive or negative is up to you.

-- No New Game +  A core part of every main Borderlands game to date (including the Pre-Sequel) has been replaying the main campaign with tougher enemies and more specialized loot in NG+. Gearbox seriously missed the mark here. 
- Those “random encounters” in the Overworld are the same areas, used over and over. There are a good variety – more than a dozen - which minimizes the fatigue of the repeated encounters. I guess there had to be a way to create randomized encounters while keeping Wonderlands under-budget, but completionists will need some serious fortitude to do everything in the Overworld.
- Endgame content features the “Chaos Chamber,” which repeats the levels from the “random encounters” of the Overworld with a few re-used bosses thrown in. It’s pathetic and borderline insulting ("just keep playing the same levels over and over, like a hamster running in a wheel").
- Shortage of farmable bosses. You’ll get more consistent loot from vending machines.
- Levels are too large. You’ll spend a ton of time running around (because you can’t fast-travel until you’ve visited an area at least once).
- Default audio balance is terrible. Make sure to move some sliders around so you can actually hear the music.

You’ve still got some great ideas, Gearbox. Just need to give us franchise old-timers the bosses and endgame content we’ve come to expect.

Just finished the campaign and figured I've played enough to give a review.  

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is, how do I say this, okay?  I enjoyed the campaign enough, and I can see there is likely some good fun to be had with the endgame systems and mythic ranks, etc.  But about 1/3 of the way through the game I realized that this isn't the game I want to grind endgame with.

So, I set my sights to finishing the campaign and trying to just enjoy that.  For the most part, I did have fun.  I will do a brief pros/cons list below, but the general conclusion that I come up with is that it is a good game, with some nice components, but never really wows or captivates you to push on and explore everything it has to offer (at least for me).

PROS: 

* I absolutely love the way combat encounters are handled in the "Overworld" (that's the main open-world map that functions much like a board game).  You fight in an instance and once you complete the encounter, you get a 20-sided die to roll for loot.  Nice and compact, easily digestible bits of content.

* The dual-classing is nice.  I didn't feel quite as much impact with each choice of skills that I feel in other Borderlands games, but it is nice to be able to freely mix 2 classes together.  There is definitely some fun endgame synergy to be exploited there.

*  Style.  The game, even if it doesn't grab me like earlier Tiny Tina content, is still dripping with the colorful style of Borderlands and the way the visuals were done, combining fantasy and Borderlands, well done.  Great use of colors.

*  Voice acting is solid, even if Tina screams or mumbles most of her lines.  You can get the gist and the banter is at least passable as comedy.  There are some actual drama moments, too, but I will just leave that there as you need to play to discover it...

* Butt Stallion

CONS

*  Not very compelling... this is such a vague way to describe a con, but it just doesn't grab me.  Maybe the standards of prior Tiny Tina content is what makes this a con, as if I never played anything related to Tina before, I might see the content as compelling.  She just set such a bar.  Kinda like how villains have been somewhat ruined by the near perfection that was Handsome Jack.  

*  I didn't like my player voice, just saying...

*  Just didn't feel like playing endgame, which means I got a bit bored... so, take that for what you will.

CONCLUSION

* Good game on sale.  I have been told that the Wonderlands Redux mod is the best way to enjoy this game, but the advice is to have all DLC to enjoy the mod fully and I just didn't feel this game deserved more $ from me just to play the mod.  I actually have tried multiple times and in multiple ways to get someone to let me know just how vital the DLC is for the mod, as the only responses came from people who read the same line as me, suggesting all DLC.  So, in that regard, I'd suggest looking for some great combo sale (on sale a bunch so it shouldn't take long) to be sure you can get everything out of the Wonderlands Redux mod.  

Aside from that, I am glad I played it.  I left the game in menus too many times to really gauge how long it takes to complete as my hours played are way stretched from having to get up and leave it running so often.  I just wouldn't spend more than deep sale prices, there are better full priced options out there.

Note before starting:

This review was made after beating every side quest and the base game, will be updated upon reaching chaos 20 and fighting all forms of raid bosses I can find. There is a TLDR.

I absolutely love the borderlands series (Tales from the Borderlands V2 doesn't exist in my eyes) and I have I estimate around 4000 hours of Borderlands game time over several steam accounts, most of which is Borderlands 2. The series is incredible with exception (New tales), but has some flaws. I am a fan boy, and will leave suggestions for fixes at the end.

Start:
General
The game starts off simple but has great customisation for voice, builds, what your character looks like, and even stats. The new melee, necklace AND ring system is brilliant, it allows for brand spanking new ways to develop a character and new things to potentially farm. The new weapon names are fun and keep in line with the tradition of a less serious game (Ferior being the new tediore and the opposite to inferior is surprisingly funny), with most of the old weapon manufacturers returning. 

Specifics:
Combat:
I was disappointed with how basically every enemy type is the same. The only difference being they are bandits, skeletons, skeleton pirates or an animal (re skins unless your looking at goblins, cobras, crabs or Sharks). Wyvern F***ing suck to fight if you have a melee build, and feel ridiculously annoying to fight with even slightly under powered gear or very few skill points for a build. However, apart from finding the start of the game with very little build quite challenging the rest of the game was easy. Fast fire rate = damage. I found the bosses to be the most challenging but even then they were mostly damage sponges with special attacks to jump over, duck under or sidestep. My favourite boss was Kastor (the normal sized skeleton) Mostly because I thought it was a funny idea, and the boss fight was at the right stage of the game at being just hard enough whilst also not a pushover.

Setting: 
The wonderlands is cool, the world map would be a little more creative with more shortcut methods rather then just punch the bottle cap, and maybe the speed shrine should have been part of the base character kit with the shrine just making them sonic levels speed. The fact you can punch encounters or outrun them does help encounters not feel bad.

Story:
Its not handsome Jack levels of greatness, but not horrendous, you just really have to like Tiny Tina to not get bored (I got bored even with liking her character from Bl2). Its simple and doesn't get in the way too much.

Jokes: 
Its not funny. NEXT (Mr Torgue does get to be awesome though)

Loot:
OK, Compared to borderlands 3 there are very few and occasional legendary items. I myself found around 6 including the 2 I got from the final boss, but the system that makes red text weapons spawn in vendors in brilliant, as I can jot down the name of a weapon I like and farm for it later. Loot luck is a system with a lot to be desired, the loot luck dice system gives you better loot luck (chances at a legendary or purples) the more you collect/at higher chaos levels. This system makes you explore every map for them which would be cool if it gave you hints as to where they are. 

Music:
Fine, but I have nothing positive or negative to say. Its just music unfortuntly.

My fixes: 
More enemy types, flying enemies either land more or come down to the ground slightly more so you can almost always jump hit them.
Loot Luck dice should give a reater bonus and give the maximum buff from a map at 5 dice collected instead of 20. this gives people the benefit of not having to rush through a long map or specifically complete a side quest to unlock an area to get just one more dice and instead spend more time playing the game.

Like running full speed on a hamster wheel going nowhere.

POSITIVE STUFF:
- Game is gorgeous; best arenas and puzzles across the BL games
- Awesome gunplay; spells are really cool
- Great audio design

NEGATIVES:
- The story stinks; even worse than BL3, which I didn't hate. Lots of story setup, the villain gets interesting but then the game ends with a fart. Zero payoff
- The side-quests are bad. The fantasy world created here looks amazing, but its characters are all flat and boring. You'll get a few good sidequests here and there but most are just not interesting.

- Loot is bad; This is what killed the game for me.

- "Luck" mechanic forcing you to collect random dice around the game world in order to increase your chances at gaining good gear in every respect, but the system is WAY too harsh. Destroying a boss and getting showered with green loot never feels good. Felt like every chest I opened, every store visit I would find nothing useful. Literally all of my gear (that I would have to use for 5+ levels) came from SHIFT keys.

- Inventory management is absolutely terrible and felt like busy-work, and you are alwasy having to be in the terrible menus.

- Leveling is very slow and tedious; early on you level up at a good pace but the further you get the more it starts to just CRAWL. 1 hour per level, it seemed like.

I can't recommend this one, especially to Borderlands fans.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands perfectly continues the Borderlands tradition giving you dozens of hours of fun, challenging, and utterly ridiculous FPS/RPG goodness, set in some of the most downright inspiring, majestic, and occasionally hilarious backdrops of any game.  I really feel like everyone involved in the fundamental "impossibly sweeping vistas" aspect of these games deserves royalties because I absolutely play these games in no small part because I know the backgrounds will be incredibly memorable.  The atmosphere and light-hearted nature of the games is also a big appeal for me personally; I play games to have a good time, and the vibes in most of these games fits that perfectly.

In fact, I daresay Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is my favorite Borderlands game so far.  The framing device of characters from the Borderlands world sitting down to play a D&D game--complete with the overworld map being full of soda cans, Cheetos, books, and other tabletop gaming ephemera--is so extremely good and so full of untapped potential on its own that it begs for further sequels aping other real-world-physical-gaming tropes.  I am no wargamer but I absolutely salivate thinking about a second game where Tiny Tina introduces her gaming group to Bunkers & Badasses 40K.  But yeah it is amazing how much more sense the standard Borderlands fourth-wall-breaking comments and constant strings of coincidences make here than in any previous title, and even though I know they are making Borderlands 4, I think they should make it definitively the last and wrap up that game's convoluted narratives in favor of leaning hard into Tina's unreliable narrator metadrama rendition of their world.

They even manage to cruelly mine some heartache out of the out-of-game narrative, especially for people familiar with Tiny Tina's character arc over the span of Borderlands 2/Pre-Sequel/3.

Let's start off by saying that it took me 3 tries playing through this game and about 60 hours to formulate my opinion on this game tbh. After all that time, I've come to the conclusion that it's just not a genuinely good game. It's got some good aspects to it that are unique to it for the series (i.e. character creation, more stats, melee weapons). These aspects really make it stand out from the others in the series. One thing that this has though that is also still like the original series is the terrible writing. Don't come to this game for a decent story. It's biggest flaw is just the lack of loot variety. With all the fun things this game adds, it's just simply crushed by not being able to do anything with it. I wish there was more to do in this game simply because it's got a unique artsyle and premise that you just can't find in most games. It's just a huge piece of wasted potential

If you drill this game down to the very basic gun play, the game is similar to other BL games.  But that is where it ends.  The only reason I have so many hours in this is that it was sooo easy for me to lose interest in this game and I just left it open on my desktop.

There is nothing bad ass about this game.  It is heavily geared toward alternative lifestyles. The main story revolves around the "Butt Stallion" character.   There are no defined body styles - everything is androgynous.  The entire rest of the game leans heavily on these themes.  

There is no more "roaming the borderlands."  Every single interaction is carefully designed to take you to the next interaction.  As long as you accept every side quest, you will cover every single square inch of each map.

All of the levels are waves and check points, the game plays in a wave/guided manner.  

The cut scenes and forced interactions are super painful.  Each of them sometimes takes minutes and there are TONS of them.  You are going to get super sick of Tina, especially when she tells you "RNG aint got nothing on you." a 100 times.

The tree abilities suck.  Nothing special, just plus or minus %'s.

Even if you want to try a different build, you have to sit through the endless cut scenes to get it.  

So "progressive" of them to be so inclusive but this is not a BL game, and no one should pretend it is.

Even at $!5, this is a fail - there is no replay value.

And I still felt like I got scammed. What is here is good. But it is barely anything to be honest. Beat the main quest in well under 30 hours of game play including time spent AFK, side quests, things that were not the main quest. If you wanted too you could beat the main questline in under 10 hours without even using speed run strats or glitches. That's pathetic. And even worse the "DLCs" with this game are nothing but like 10 to 30 minute side quests! I can not stress enough that this feels like a Borderlands 3 DLC. Given a little more time this would have been a fantastic game if they didn't go for a half baked Cash Grab DLC masquerading as a full game. But unfortunately that's all it is. A DLC priced as a full game.

If you enjoy Borderlands style games, then the base game of Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is great. I don't 100% it but did do all the side quest and got around 33 hours out of a single play through, plus the end game chaos trails are a lot funner then the normal Borderlands end game. But do yourself a favor and wait for a 60% or more sale and get the Chaotic Great Edition (the deluxe edition) because even though the base game is probably the best Borderlands game I've played since BL2, the DLCs for this game are beyond absolute garbage. The classes you get from the DLCs are great but the DLC missions leave me without words to describe how bad they are. The DLC missions in this game make BL2s $3 headhunter DLCs look like fully fledged stand alone games in comparison, the thought that anyone could look at the DLCs in this game and say "yea that looks like it's worth $10" blows my mind.

This game says it has cross play, but when naming their service Gearbox added an erroneous F to SHiFT. Because all I got was SHiT. The cross play isn't functional, at least not for PC to PS5, and I've seen videos up to a year old with the exact wonky issue I have.

Try to join a friends game who is on PS5, the settings instant changes to 'Local Only' and then times out after a minute, and then once you click the Error pop up it magical goes back to the actual settings you had. So I basically bought the game made for multiplayer, that promised multiplayer, for no multiplayer. Fuck Gearbox, they already downgraded the writing and quality repeatedly, and not they just straight up aren't supporting core features that they advertise. All so they could have more control over the experience by removing P2P.

Unless they fix SHiFT and make meaningful changes in how they develop games, I'm not going to be buy anything from Gearbox again. Hope 2K gives them the axe.

I don't get to play games as often as i used to, but this game is for every DnD and Borderlands fan out there, if you enjoy high fantasy, guns, comedy, and most of all, SPELL CASTING, get the game, it is fantastic and wonderful.

I've heard a lot of things when the games first came out, and they weren't nice. Fortunately for me, I was only able to start playing this game recently, I've restarted the campaign a few times and had to abandon my first build (companions) cuz my potato PC couldnt handle all the stuff I was spawning and just reached LVL 40 on a "Thor" build.

Holy shit, I watched a few videos about the Thor builds and I'm not even following them closely and my gear is shite but its still so stupidly good. Maybe endgame might change my perspective but Im excited to create other new builds.

Its pretty cool, it seems there are a lot of build variety, vehicles in the BL series is replaced with the Overworld which i think is a cool alternative. 

Most if not all side quests are all packaged into their own areas of the "story" maps OR has their own unique map with its own side quests. Its a tiny bit annoying that some of the side quests are compulsory in order to unlock the rest of the story and hidden stuff in the Overworld, but I can take that as "breathers" for the story.

I have my problems with legendaries. When it comes to variety, Feriore for example, is one of the only viable weapon manufacturer options for a "Companions only" play through, but not a single legendary Feriore weapon does anything companion related. (The rest is WIP)

If things somehow go well, I can foresee Wonderlands having insane expansions, like adding a 3rd tree into the mix, or being able to use the same class twice/thrice, effectively making an ultra pure build. 

I like this game, I like the concept that BL tries to make but also having the ability to make my own character instead of using a preset. I hope Gearbox can somehow make this work cuz I really love it a lot.

(P.S: I love playing Warframe, and if uk Warframe, uk there is insane customization and build making, tho not the same level of insanity as Warframe, Wonderlands still scratches that itch in a more FPS manner, and not many games do dat for me anymore)

Another game that doesn't really deserve the amount of positive reviews it has.

My interest in the game was instantly lost as soon as I opened the game. In character creation you can already see that the game isn't worth the money. Even on sale (imo). The main reason I feel most people are drawn to D&D is the ability to create a character. At the beginning there are so few options, I almost quit and refunded right then and there.  I know there should be some cosmetics to unlock but I feel like it should be a few and maybe just from completing quests or killing bosses. Not random drops. At the point of typing this I have played 8 hours and I have not unlocked anything that makes this game feel like D&D. No hats, no Staffs, no Bows, No accessories of any kind, No cool armor to make my character look badass. nothing, just colors. 

The world is generally empty with TONS of boxes everywhere that give you nothing. 95% of the boxes in the world can be ignored unless you need ammo, which doesn't happen often. The Dice is never worth getting. The quests are extremely boring and the dialogue drags alot, especially during quests.... and the dialogue isn't even that good in most cases. Other than Tiny Tina, the whole game feels soulless. And Tina doesn't even feel like herself, maybe it's because she has way more dialogue now, but she feels way less energetic and she just, kinda explains things and has no other impact on the story or whats happening.  

The game has a tough time starting up most of the time which I don't understand, gotta be a coding issue or something. I'm not a fan of the music in the game, pretty boring or kinda annoying. I've heard better "whimsical" or fantasy music that actually played well into the visuals or atmosphere. This was not it.
The visuals although "cleaner" actually feel like a step back. They are just way less interesting. Bland normal forests and structures. I just feel like there was so little creativity put into this world and the objects. 

The difficulty in the game is weird. It's extremely boring and easy most of the time but randomly a bomb will go off and you almost insta-die. It doesn't feel great. 
Combat feels awful. I think the reticle sensitivity changes based on the gun, which I don't like. Melee feels extremely unsatisfying, feels like i'm hitting them with a pool noodle. Spells are terrible. The only one that actually feels useful is the homing missile, since it can't really miss. 

Overall pretty disappointed with this purchase. It does however make me want to go back and replay Borderlands 2. *shrug*

it's not great, it feels more like a cash grab from gearbox than anything else, it's like they're just feeding into the tiny Tina simps at this point, it's different but that's sort of bad when it comes to the borderlands experience, borderlands 3 was an amazing step up when it game to the gun-play and movement from BL2, the story was worse, but the overall game-play was much better and more fluid. 

TTWL was a step back in both game-play and story, it's guns went to a mixture of melee and arrow physics(which surprisingly don't work out that well in borderlands), everybody raves about the melee aspect for these games, but when they essentially force you into using it, it's very much a bad thing.
the story is also just basically !!!![SPOILERS]!!!! 



OMG! this bad guy who very much resembles handsome jack killed the "mcguffin" queen butt-stallion, go kill him as revenge for killing this character that you met for a total of 10 seconds. oh no the bad guy has a bunch of other bad guys that are trying to stop you from stopping him....here are some dumb quests so that we can drag out the story even longer so we can justify the price tag that we put on the game.

and then the fucking god awful map system. whoever thought that making the transition between levels into a top down view that you have to fucking puzzle your way through to even get to some areas is a complete jackass and they should be shot. like Christ sakes it's a terrible idea. 

also, there are no vehicles in the game, so traversing each level is a slow ass slog across until you find the "rune" or whatever that speeds up your slides, then you end up just sliding across the map everywhere because it's faster. and then the bosses....I can't remember a single god damned boss from this game, they are all THAT forgettable, like honestly, non of the boss fights are even worth looking back on at all because none of them drop any loot that is worth a damn. people complained about dedicated legendarys in BL3, but funnily enough this game is worse for that.

long story short, this game is bad when it comes to gameplay, good when it comes to graphics and particle effects, but terrible in so many other ways. so all in all this game gets a solid 4/10 in my opinion.
In a nutshell, this is a buggier Borderlands with DnD themes. Nice idea but zero on execution...

Few weapons in the loot pool, equipment generally is just numbers going higher instead of adding layers and build decisions to game play... and the dialogue is so cringe it physically hurts... Not many games i fall asleep playing, but this is one of them. Really awful.

I know - albeit without personal experience - that this game had a rough launch. However, I firmly believe that this addition to the Borderlands franchise is a must have for fans of the series and, furthermore, new fans coming in for a first taste of this formula. A game for 9 year olds. I cannot recommend Tiny Tina's Wonderlands as it falls short in delivering an engaging experience. The game's storyline is lackluster and fails to captivate, feeling like a step down from the more dynamic narratives seen in earlier titles like Borderlands 2. While Borderlands 3 also didn't quite hit the mark, this latest installment continues the trend of diminishing quality. The only redeeming aspect is the improved graphics, but that alone doesn't make up for the overall disappointing and uninspiring gameplay.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is just not fun. It's very bland and ultimately feels like a BL3 minigame. The story writing has gone downhill since Borderlands 2 so I didn't expect that to be any better (and to no surprise, its horrible) but usually they balance it out with the combat (skills, weapons, etc). The skill trees in this game are a literal joke, like 20% of the size of the skill trees in past games. I was looking forward to there being a bigger focus on melee combat since there wasn't much of that in previous games, but it's actually the exact same melee as in the previous games (press ... to bash - single animation, minimal dev effort). Unfortunately for me, I didn't play it until a few weeks after I bought it so I can't refund. I'm pretty disappointed that they made this game look like a regular, full game when in reality, it has about as much content as a $10 indie game.

I couldn't put my finger on why I wasn't enjoying a Borderlands game.  BL2 was great, BL3 was alright minus the writing.  Then I found Torgue.  They CENSORED Torgue.  That's what this game is missing: Edge, Soul, the Borderlands appeal of gutsy, raunchy humor.  The game feels like a watered down Borderlands clone.  In this game, we get "collect 10 ore" side quests instead of a true Borderlands "Shoot me in the face!".

I did enjoy being able to create your own character, but it needs more body type options in the general loot pool.  The class actions are weak and replacing grenades with spammy "magic" items is a mistake.  Having one skill tree per class is very boring and restricts how you can play your toon.

TTWL really should have been a BL3 DLC and I had waited until it was priced accordingly.  $15 USD still might be too much.  I doubt I'll be able to finish this game.  The Borderlands brand has fallen!

It's simply another Borderlands with a fantasy story mostly told through Tina's voice over. There are cute elements to it, but the fact that you're handed more guns and ammunition was too disappointing. I thought I was getting a fantasy Borderlands, with bows and swords, but it's exactly the same battle system as the others just renamed. Still a shield, still a sniper rifle...yeah there is a sword, but it's just your melee weapon. It's a let down.

I was going into this game with thoughts it would be something similar to Serious Sam's games, or even Doom Eternal and Painkiller, because from the video reviews it looked fun to run around and shoot people. But it turned out to be a pretty boring looter shooter like Destiny, without any feel of great shooter, just nothing, you run around and collect loot that doesn't give you noticeable upgrade at all. This game follows patters that goes like this - clear randomly picked map (they have around 5 of them at best), loot cheapest items you could ever get, watch uninteresting cinematic with story,  that surely was influenced by LGBTQ+ , that has nothing of soul to it, just feeds you some politics that you want to take and throw out from your mind in a second. Strong 3/10. If you want to shoot and have fun, run away from this game.

I read other reviews of the game before purchase and have to agree with their less than stellar commentary. The narration was a bit too middle-schoolish and lacked the adult targeted humor I remember from the last Tiny Tina dlc. A number of the voice overs just didn't land for me either - Wanda as the robot co-dnd character landed flat for me. Her voice and inflection seems a fit for the nonchalant robot, but her voice just drew me out of the narrative of the story. Every time she speaks it sounds like I'm listening to a disinterested actor reading from a card. 

The gun play as well ... this IS the reason to play borderlands - shoot and loot - empowered by the satisfaction you get from the said pew pew. I'll keep playing this game to see if it just takes more time to find the right weapon for me, but every drop in this so far feels very under powered or has a needlessly overpowered scope. Where are the iron sights?

Lastly, I am playing on an ultrawide monitor - from my research this is becoming a more popular choice in monitor. I won't weight my criticism of the game as heavily based on the fact that this category of monitor is not mainstream, but with loot and weapon stats being a primary driver for this style of game, not having an inventory UI that calibrates correctly with my choice resolution is a game killer.

So there's this dude, Dave, right? He's all hyped up to dive into Tiny Tina's Wonderlands, this supposed epic adventure full of whimsy, wonder, and high-powered weaponry. Roll your own multiclass hero, they said. Shoot, loot, slash, and cast on a quest to stop the Dragon Lord, they promised. Sounds like a blast, right? Well, not for Dave.

Our hero starts his journey expecting a fantasy-themed Borderlands extravaganza. But hold on to your loot bags, because Dave's ride through this so-called "Wonderland" feels more like a trip to Mr. Bones' Wild Ride—a roller coaster that never ends and is about as much fun as a dentist appointment.

First off, people are hating on this game like it's the last season of Game of Thrones. One disgruntled fan even said, "I regret pre-ordering now, thinking I would get a fantasy-themed Borderlands game, and then got this." Ouch, Dave's off to a fantastic start.

Now, let's talk about the characters. Apparently, Tiny Tina, the once-beloved dynamo, got a downgrade to "unlikable" in this game. And don't even get started on her co-player characters—the robot and bland guy. They're so forgettable they don't even deserve names. Someone's sipping on a tall glass of disappointment.

The humor, or lack thereof, is another sore point. One player mournfully recalls, "I laughed maybe once in this whole game." Yeah, Tiny Tina's attempt at comedy is about as successful as a fish riding a unicycle. And the skills? Lame. The companions? Annoying. Skeletor screaming in your ear every five minutes? What kind of sadistic game designer thought that was a good idea?

Now, let's take a moment for the villain, Mr. Dragon Lord. Apparently, his plan is to destroy the planet he lives on. Real genius move, buddy. The whole "I don't like one little girl, so let's destroy everything" shtick is just plain stupid. Handsome Jack is rolling in his villainous grave.

And don't even get me started on the movement. Walking feels like a chore, and you know what's missing? Cars! Yup, the first Borderlands IP without a single car. Because who needs vehicles in a lootershooter, right?

Dave, poor Dave, is feeling like he's stuck on Mr. Bones' Wild Ride, desperately searching for an exit. Consider uninstalling midway? That's on the table. And the final verdict? "Annoying characters, bad movement, boring combat, and uninteresting story. If you like Borderlands, skip this game."

So there you have it, folks. Dave's descent into Tiny Tina's No-Fun Wonderland, where whimsy and wonder take a backseat to disappointment.

what made me love the original borderlands? The characters. The humor. The chaotic fighting brought on by awesome skills. All gone in here.
The characters are reduced to shallow one note versions of themselves.
The humor just... well it doesn't hit for me. I laughed maybe once in this whole game.
The skills are pretty lame. The companions are extremely annoying because they come with extra voice lines. Oh yeah I sure love hearing Skeletor screaming the thing in my ear every 5 minutes. Or my character making the same fart joke at a mushroom. The chaotic playstyle feels gutted. All those special skills that would completely change your entire play style are just gone. Now it's just "if you hit a critical the bullet ricochets" (away from enemies I stg)
And the villain GOD. The best thing about the first few games was Handsome Jack. The worst thing about the third games were the evil tiktok twins. But those were believable compared to Mr. Dragon Lord. What's your plan? oh to destroy the planet? BITCH YOU LIVE HERE. you dont have a space ship to leave. It's just "I don't like one little girl" spite to kill himself and everyone else around him. I'm sorry that's stupid. You can't make me care about a villain you're trying to make empathetic. 
Also, they added secrets, would be fun but the movement has been severely gutted. Walking feels like a chore and all you can do is walk. First borderlands IP without a single car. 
Speaking of the horrid movement, and I talk about level design? So this game is a lootershooter. The loot is a big and FUN part of the game. Collecting, selling... well I'd love to sell, if there were any vendors. In one map, the only 2 vendors are like a 5 minute walk from the nearest teleport point. in one map, there's only a teleportable vendor at the very very end of a map, after a 30 minute mission. It ain't fun. Just not. 
At this point, I feel like I'm playing it as a chore because I already put money into it. But I'm really considering just uninstalling midway through then never touching it again. 

TLDR; Annoying characters, bad movement, boring combat, and uninteresting story. If you like borderlands, skip this game

This game has all the humor of other installments in the Borderlands series with the added charm of a D&D twist. The structure of the quests will feel familiar to veteran players paired with the satisfaction of finding collectibles (dice/marbles/scrolls instead of audio logs). The over world is very cute and it's appreciated when game series take risks and try something new!
A whimsical and eccentric adventure. A great game to play solo or with friends.

To put it bluntly this game isn't worth picking up (at the price it's at currently which is $59.99.)

I am a little under 20 hours into the game and have practically done everything this game has to offer. It needs more meat on its bones if they expect people to shell out a full $60 on this. The DLCs offered do nothing to remedy this issue as each of them feel like they were made in a week. You can clear an entire DLC in under an hour and while they allow you to replay them, there really is no point other then to farm currency for random loot. You also don't have a real reason to replay the game as you can somewhat swap your entire characters class, although you wont be able to do every single combination on one character.

The story and writing is something I can shrug off. I don't think its necessarily bad even though some of the voice lines make me cringe, but I can also tell its just not targeted for me. The inverse could be said for the earlier entries and some players not enjoying the writing in the Borderlands universe so I don't feel I can fault the game for that. The progression is an interesting idea and I enjoyed it but I wish they kind of stuck to the DND theme of the game. It's kinda off putting to believe that its just a tabletop but the way its portrayed is more akin to you just existing in the table tops dimension? One or the other would have been better than both at the same time.

The guns suck, they don't feel as fun as Gearbox traditionally has made them and changing up a lot of the formula with all the extra equippable slots isn't something I'm fond of as it's still a little too complex for me to know if I'm building correctly. The entire feel of the game however is very polished in my opinion. I rarely come across gameplay issues but I will say their system for hidden collectibles is so asinine. It's so much more painful to collect everything than it was in Borderlands 3. I absolutely detest this system. 

In total I give the game a 6/10 but highly suggest avoiding it at it's AAA price tag.

This is a fantastic game, I love it, and if you're a Borderlands fan you'll love it too.  It gets a thumbs-down for two specific reasons:
1. the inability to copy-paste Shift codes.
2. the ending credits are unskippable and [i]27 MINUTES LONG[/i].  I am not making this up.  You are forced to watch a listing of increasingly tenuous connections to the game's development.  The actual devs.  The people at the video company.  The people at the audio company.  People who are married to the people at the audio company.  People who used to date the people married to the people at the audio company.  Anyone who had threesomes with people at both the video and the audio companies.  The entire cast of Shrek 2.  The current population of Norway.  Everyone whose Kevin Bacon number is greater than, equal to, or less than 5.  Production babies who were [i]conceived and born while the ending credits were still scrolling[/i].

First of all i must warn you that this game has nothing to do with Borderlands lore (nearly). So consider this as a new game. Yes you still have Tina but other than that everything has changed even the gameplay. You do not have grenades and instead of that you have skills and abilities at the same time in different slots. That was hard to get used to but after that phase it felt really good. And most importantly you do not play as a specific character. You are playing yourself. The Borderlands universe welcomes you as a "newbie" and you are just you who plays bunkers and badasses with Tina. So that is why you we do not have lore info in this game

I do not really know why they developed a game like this but as i said it before: if your approach to this game is have a new experience then this game fills your expectations. It has different item slots like rings and books and melee weapons, it has a very similar atmosphere with borderlands 3 which is nice, and it has a really smooth and chaotic gameplay that satisfies both new players to this universe and fans like me. I did not quit the game until finished every single side quest. So i can easily give 7.5 out of 10.

There are 2 reasons behind why this wonderlands does not deserve 10. Firstly, this game might have better atmosphere with better musics but instead musics are just existing and you do not even recognize them. Second reason is lack of enemy types. There are just 3 maybe 4 different types of enemies and that's it. You are keeping fighting against same enemies around the world. 

Final point: 7.5/10

What I lived about TTW over BL series:

One of the pitfalls of BL1 and 2 was "Loot didn't become interesting until *after* you beat the game".  This was fixed in BL3, which was a BLAST.  In Tina's... The loot options were abysmal, somehow exeedingly worse than any of the series.  
At one point, most of the enemies had thousands of health, and 90% of the weapons/spells being dropped had a dps in the teens.  Or my favorite "Worst weapon in the history of gaming": "Unlimited magazine, 4.6s time to fix, 5 shots per second... Magazine size... TWO"  And the damage was *really* low on the two shots.  You'd spend 99% of your time reloading.
It didn't matter if something was interesting, as 99.9% of drops weren't even remotely close to viable.
Same with spells... Got stuck with one spell for 20 levels, because everything else was TWO orders of magnitude less damage... and the spell I had wasn't even good.

Prices were all over the map too... sell price $2000 for a white trash loot... $300 for that epic that just dropped.  

The insistent whining by the "narrators"... 
They made Tina absolutely pathetic, whiny, and desperate for attention
Jokes were unfunny, as they constantly filled in with obligatory "We can't do that because it's insensitive"

These next two really, really got me:
Constant, not stop, gurgling/screaming at *bat sh*** crazy obnoxious volumes  (If you turn these down, you can't hear anything else...)
Bright flashes overlapping to the point where it was utterly impossible to see the enemy 99% of the time.  The only way I could even kill stuff was to use non-target spells/abilities/weapons.

To be remotely playable, remove the screaming/gurgling entirely.  When you char screams at you for 30 seconds, while 10+ skeletons are gurgle/screaming at the same time... It's obnoxious and removes all fun.
Tone down the brightness of flashes by 99% and make them transparent by reducing alpha by 99% so I can *see* the enemies.

Worst in the series by a *very* large margin.

Look at # of reviews and rating... BL3 90k reviews, 85% positive.  TTW: 10k reviews 76% positive.

It has some cash grabby elements that one can expect from a company and licenser like this. For a A title developer it's still not bad. Some of the typical "postmodern" things are in here. If you have young ones and don't want them exposed to things such as sexuality or more complicated things, this game is probably one you may not want the kids playing. The rating sort of speaks for itself, anyway. 

As for the gameplay, haters gonna hate but I find this one so much better than Borderlands that it's sort of how Borderlands should've been. "Classes" replace talent trees, so you pick a class then pick a second. Just about everything can "work", though some things obviously work far better, that doesn't mean the exact right combination of skills, mods (armor in this game), weapons and other variables can't make the more obscure pairings work (thinking about say, blightcaller+spellshot, which you don't see very often). 

As per the usual, it's absolutely hilarious. Go make the magic and cast. Say the magic words: SHKIPPITY DOOBAP DA WAP YEAHHH!

This game is an 8/10. If you are a fan of Borderlands, or looter shooters in general, then this is worth a purchase. The story telling is an improvement from 3 along with some new features to the gameplay. The endgame might not be what typical Borderlands fans want, but I believe is serviceable for a spin off title developed during the pandemic. It is a DND-themed game so having the game play loop being a dungeon crawler mode I thought was fitting. If you are not sold on the chaos chamber endgame then the story, and its 40-some-odd side quests, will provide around 35-40 hrs of game play. Every side quest was very entertaining, and they may even be the best of the entire series. Lastly, I will note the T rating shows in this one. The jokes are definitely geared towards a younger audience, but that didn't harm my play through like it did with BL3.

Overall Tiny's wonderland is fine if you like the Borderlands series, although maybe not worth the full asking price in comparison to other entries in the series (the DLC in particular doesn't seem worth it at all). 

It falls short in terms of meaningful character progression and plot when compared to older entries in the borderlands universe, but it doesn't really feel like it matters overall as the gameplay is fun enough to save it. 

It's good dumb fun with a silly plot line, entertaining characters, some Borderlands staple pop-culture references, and lovingly pokes fun at DnD in the same manner as the Borderlands 2 DLC "Assault on Dragon Keep".
 
It can get a bit repetitive, with some grindy "combat encounters" (which can be made less frequent/avoided, although some are still part of side quests), but it does offer solid gun play with the usual ridiculous Borderlands weaponry and scratches the "looter" itch. 

Magic (rather than grenades) makes a fun addition to the character loadout and the familiars are handy if you are not playing co-op. 

Word of warning: I did get really irritated by some really bad use of invisible walls throughout. 
For example: 
- Tangledrift in particular repeatedly has ledges that should be reachable, blocked off by invisible walls so you fall to your death, when they could simply have NOT put the ledges there?
- In another area an entire bridge gap is blocked by an invisible wall so you can't jump it, because a bridge will be put there later, even though the gap is VERY clearable. 

--------

TLDR

Pros:
- Good borderlands gunplay and loot
- beautiful fantasy landscapes in the Borderlands style 
- Magic and DnD theme is fun
- Familiars can be helpful if you are playing solo

Cons:
- some bad invisible wall usage
- bit grindy / repetitive
- missing the "depth" of some of the better Borderlands entries


It's not for everyone (I think I preferred the Pre-sequel to this) but the Wonderlands are still a fun distraction for those that love the Borderlands series and a bit of DnD. 
Probably worth catching in a sale although the DLC could be passed over for no real loss.

worst game of the borderlands franchising, by far.

THE GOOD
Borderlands 3 game play and design.
D&D themed.  Spells replace grenades.
Tiny Tina story telling. 
Main quests and side quests.
The Overworld.  A mini adventuring area.

THE BAD
Maps with multiple levels can be difficult to view.
Limited end game content.
I didn't see any Mini Events.
No New Game+.  Creating a new character didn't seem to receive many advantages.

THE UGLY
Reviews for the DLC are so bad I don't even want to try them.

The problem is it's not good.

I enjoyed Dragon Keep, but Dragon Keep worked because it was about something.

Wonderlands feels like a gigantic meaningless blip of a game.

The voice acting is fine, but the writing feels flat and bland. The script leans on references instead of humor, and it's peppered with "we're playing an arr pee gee, isn't that kind of lame?" remarks, which, like. I can't believe I'm writing this, but something like South Park Stick Of Truth pulls this formula off way better because it actually cares about and has an opinion on the rpg stuff it's making fun of.

Wonderlands feels like it's made entirely of filler text. Half its content is airgapped from the main plot, stuffed into *large* optional areas, and none of the npcs really have any luster to them.

Tina's VA does a fantastic job, but is fighting uphill against the phoned-in-ed-ness of the rest of the game.

The gameplay is roughly the same as other Borderlands, with a neat change in that you select your class, not your character, and you can multiclass to mix power sets. However, Wonderlands is also buggier than any other Borderlands, and there's a persistent interact glitch that I keep getting stuck in. I've also bugged out the fight for your life state by jumping, and this turned enemy AI and damage vulnerability off. It's been ages since release, and I don't think these are getting fixed.

If you're really desperate for a looter shooter, I guess Wonderlands fits the bill, but I'd get it on super duper sale and keep your expectations at floor level.

Also the dlc feels even more phoned in than the main game. It's just arenas with a voiceover. It barely has waypoint markers.

Edit: Rolled credits. It picks up slightly at the end, but *very* slightly. Not enough to justify having to get to it. And in a setting like Borderlands, where the bulk of the appeal is the characters, the villain being the only really likeable one is painful. The plot doesn't go anywhere. If it was shortened down to the length of Dragon's Keep, it would be better, but still not better than Dragon's Keep, which is a problem because it doesn't tread any new territory. There's zero reason to recommend this thing over a years old dlc, which sucks, because the premise is genuinely fun.

I wanted to like this game, I truly honest-to-god did. I ignored everyone I knew when they told me the game wasn't good and had faith that they couldn't possibly ruin the iconic Borderlands formula thats been cultivated for years and years and has brought me many years of joy. I was wrong. This game is mediocre at best, it's blatantly obvious how shallow and superficial everything about this game is. It looks flashy on the outside and draws you in with promises of a fully fleshed out version of the Bunkers and Badasses expansion for BL2, but its a painted facade. The gameplay *can* be fun at times, and there were some points when I enjoyed myself, but any replay value I would've gotten is spoiled by the games awful ending. One of the biggest letdowns of my whole life frankly, and I had to be told that my dad was a meth addict when I was 10. 2/10, this game is an insult to the franchise, and that's saying a lot considering it was preceded by BL3
