Literally downloaded a mandatory update before I can play three days in a row. This one today is 1.3 gigs. What is this playstation online in 2009??? 

SICK of the updates. 

Since I have the time let's discuss some of the problems with this game aside from the already stated. 

1. Half assed. Reskinned borderlands 3. A few additions but really not much. The addition of magic is great but there is very little in the way of variety. It's clear that not much effort was put into this making it feel like a last minute after thought.  The same applies to the wepons. Nothing original when it comes to the guns. SERIOUS disappointment. 

2. Plot holes. No real explanation of where we are in the borderlands universe / timeline. Our main characters get basically no backstory and there is very little that gives us any connection to the story other than random memory drops through dialog as the game progresses. All of which leads to an explanation about the games origin which has no point of reference at any point in any borderlands game prior. This is like putting a Pepsi sticker on a coke can........

3. Overworld. Not a fan. It's cheesy in a bad way not a charming way. It's slow, tedious, and uninventive. The only thing about it that makes it even slightly redeemable is the possibility of random encounters. This seems like a throwback to vintage games that no one cares about or remembers. It also feels like some kind of move to make the game feel Nintendo-ish, to be clear I'm not a fan of the wii u menu word and that is what it reminds me of. 

4. Gear. Drops are garbage. I literally picked up three rerolls of the same spell in a single loot. The story and environments are a bigger part of the drive in the game for me, but the big fights are all about loot, LOOT!!!! Sadly there is very little and nothing much in the way of rares, even on big fights and boss fights. FAIL!

5. Points system, skill tree. You don't even get enough points to make it to the bottom of your two trees. Who's idea was this? Cause you need to fire that person. You're telling me that I have to choose between completing a skill tree to reach the ultimate ability or having a balanced character who is "multiclass"?... ??? You're  F$%&ing joking right? At cap level I have one tree barely filled in and a second 1/3 complete with no way to gain anymore points. Your call but if your going to handicap the players ability to build the character don't call it multiclassing. 


The positive things about the game, the art is incredible.  The environments are visually impressive.  I wish there were more interactive items in world, but again this entire production feels rushed. There are clearly places in the map that were intended for something but have no purpose or function. I'm one of those turn over every rock, look behind every waterfall kind of players. 

I acknowledge that this isn't borderlands and I'm okay with that. It wasn't meant to be, but this feels like a half finished game, or a bunch of DLC's slapped together under a singular title. I like the game more or less. Maybe start putting some effort in to rounding it out and making it the actual game it should have been with all of these updates. Add some content so it's not so limited.

If you like the Borderlands franchise, you will like this one. I had a lot of fun with this game. True, it does get a little bit repetitive and the main quest is pretty meh but overall I had a blast with the guns and gameplay. Love the fantasy twist for sure.

If you venture into Tina's weird fantasy, absolutely do all of the side quest. They are hilarious! Some of the best laughs I had in a while.

Also, I see people complaining about the overworld. To me, it was eh, not great not terrible. Not that bad tbh.

Overall, would recommend!

Let's get this out of the way, this is an incredible, massive, godly step up compared to BL3, I would say this is my second favorite game in the series, nothing can compare to how great 2 was~

It was almost an immediate turn off to hear Andy Samberg and Wanda Sykes in the opening and you are unfortunately stuck with them for the entire game. Bojack Horseman did his job pretty decently, absolutely no reasons to complain there. And it was nice that they reverted Tina back to when she was actually funny instead of whatever they did to her in 3.

They decided to go for an entirely different experience with character customization and it's not horrible, but there aren't nearly enough options from the start. It's crazy difficult to make a feminine looking character and all of the armor colors are dingy, drab, and bland OR a massive seizure inducing headache.

My personal highlight of the entire game is the classes! There's so many choices and they all play fairly uniquely,  The choice to put stat points in the game is fitting for the DnD style but it is annoying, with the level cap being 40, how you have to specialize in stats to get the most out of your build.

The addition of spells instead of grenades was a welcome change! There's plenty of different effects from healing, to buffing, to just straight damage and they're infinite! No more having to worry about running out of them mid-fight. They added ring slots as well, a nice little extra buff to help specialize whatever build you're going for, but you unfortunately don't get the second ring slot until you beat the game. A very stupid decision.

I hated the overworld when I first got there. It's ugly, you're a bobblehead for no particular reason, and the controls are jank as hell. Eventually it grows on you I guess, it's a very different way of doing travel between areas compared to older games but hopefully they won't be using it again in the next games.

There's shockingly not that many glitches in the game in my experience, you will get constant ui glitches where things get stuck until they're refreshed but it's not game breaking so get over it. The quest Little Boys Blue in the Weepwild Dankness is broken as hell, I had to restart is twice because spawns kept breaking and there is no work-around aside from just starting over.

It's a weird issue to have but there's multiple examples of fast travel points not being at the start of levels? Which is a crazy design choice that I can't remember ever being a problem before. As I was writing this I learned you can actually travel straight to the overworld :D But it's still weird to not have fast travel stations at the start of levels. And there aren't nearly enough vending machines in this game. There were stretches where I'd go an entire level without selling anything because I didn't want to have to run back to where I was.

All in all this game is great! It's shocking they could actually still make something this decent after the sh*tshow that was BL3. Definitely get it on sale, you'd be crazy to think this game is worth 60 bucks.

Pros. Gotta start here to give it SOME credit because it actually does some good things:
- Melee weapons; A whole slew of melee enhancing weapons that actually add something that enhances the gameplay, it's always fun to get a new weapon that does some crazy shit when you swing it.
- Crossbow/magic guns; a very interesting addition to borderland's already growing arsenal and honestly some of them are really fun to use.
- Borderlands 3 engine; Despite it's mixed reviews on the story, Borderlands 3 had the best gunplay out of the entire franchise so passing that on to this was actually a pretty good idea.
- Magic instead of grenades; the spells are actually really fun to use at times because of their variety and cast method. you can make some pretty fun builds with them if you find the right ones.

The Meh, things that arent that good but also not bad enough, kinda a middle ground:
- The story; it's not good but it's not bad. it's lacking overall but it does still have a few fun moments. Most of it is entirely forgettable though.

The Cons, there is no good without some bad:
- Dull enemies; The enemies are bland and generic having no more than 5-7 voice lines for each enemy type and they range from either easy references or puns. You will hear lines repeated sometimes twice in a row from the same enemy. None of them seem to have any personality to them.
- That world map; This is by far the worst travel system I've seen in any borderlands game as well as being completely pointless. The other borderlands games already had a decent method of travel as well as an easy to use fast travel. This on the other hand is just annoying.
- Combat arenas; not sure what else to call these but that's what they are. instead of making new areas to fight in they just occasionally stick you in a premade arena and fight waves of enemies till you get spat back out to the world map and call that a mission. You will absolutely fight in each of the same spaces at least 30 times in you're adventure.

- The Rating. 
Had to give this one it's own space because this is the biggest flaw in the game. This is currently the only borderlands game in the franchise that is rated T for teen as opposed to M for mature. If you played this game before and wondered why it doesn't feel like the other borderlands games, this is why. It's limited itself with its ability to go all the way with certain jokes and it causes them to fall flat. The main charm of the borderlands games have always been how unnecessarily brutal, disturbing and gritty it could get with it's world. This is essentially a borderlands game that's trying to play it safe and not hurt anyone's feelings with it's unique brand of humor and it doesn't work. Even the most entertaining character's from the previous games like Mister Tourgue is a bit underwhelming (I mean he's trying and he still manages to be the best part of the game again). 

I'm gonna leave the comment's open in case I decide to add more but this is essentially it.

[b]Relevant for the online 2-player co-op playthrough of the game on “Intense” level of difficulty.[/b]
 
Wonderlands – is a spin-off of the Borderlands series. Gameplay and storytelling systems are virtually identical. It’s certainly not without some innovations, but it generally plays and feels the same as BL3.
 
There’s not a lot of room for deep dives. I’ll list a few main points that felt the most substantial and differentiating between Wonderlands and Borderlands to me.
[list]
[*]For the first time in the series there is a character creation system. It’s not the most in-depth, yet not exactly simplistic either. You may create a standard fantasy knight, as well as sculpt some monstrosity of various degrees of freakishness. Due to this, the main character(s) have lost some of their identity. The vault hunters you could choose in the previous games of the series still had some sort of unique character or personality traits after all. And here you play as a non-charismatic, but at least customizable character. Whatever floats your boat, I guess.
 
[*]The quality of the loot drops now depends on the number of discovered Lucky Dices in the given location. This feature is inherently controversial, especially seeing how drastically it affected the traditional loot drop system. The logic is clear: the more you explore the map – the more Lucky Dices you get as a reward for that, and as a result your chances of high-tier loot drops increase. However, why the fuсk would you fix something that ain’t broke? If you’ll excuse my language. Was this change really necessary? Not quite, imo. Definitely not cool. Seeing green and blue drops as a reward for a sweaty (boss) fight is not an amazing or Borderlands-esque sight to behold.
 
[*]There are no vehicles in the game. However, I haven’t encountered any problems with the traversal in my playthrough. There’s plenty of fast travel stations and the maps aren’t that large either.
 
[*]Melee combat has been taken to the next level: there’s a separate melee weapon slot now + a few passive and active abilities. Overall, I see it as a welcome change. It especially goes well with the Brr-zerker class – the one I picked up at the start.
 
[*]Speaking of which, there’s only one branch of abilities the players can choose within the class. However, later on in the game you’ll be able to acquire another class on top of your main one, therefore creating a mixed character. Stabbomancer was a great pairing for Brr-zerker. This multiclass allowed the new melee system to shine and showcased its true potential.
 
[*]As for gunplay, here we’re dealing with a cut down version of Borderlands 3 in terms of weapon variety. All in all, on a mechanical level alone, it has remained unchanged. The first few hours might mislead you into believing that the crossbows are the only weapon type you’ll be using. However, just a couple of hours later the traditional weapon assortment will fill up your inventory.
 
[*]Vast locations are connected with each other by the Overland – a separate unique area, which along with the Lucky Dices, appear to be the most prominent references to the board games’ aesthetics.
 
[*]In my subjective opinion, this is the funniest game in the series. Humor is subjective, so no further explanation is required.[/list]
 
[b]Yes, they have sold us virtually the same game once again. But I can’t condemn the developers for this, as the excellent core of Borderlands 3 is difficult to botch, even though they tried to do so by adding Lucky Dices. Despite all of that, overall it’s still a wonderful co-op looter shooter with a few new features and implementations.[/b]

After the disappointment of Borderlands 3's writing, I wasn't expecting much. So I was very pleasantly surprised to find that Tiny Tina's Wonderlands was actually pretty solid in the writing department. There were low points, to be sure, (that opening cinematic makes my head hurt) but overall, the characters were fun, the story was well-structured, and the jokes did something Borderlands hasn't done in a while: made me laugh.

As for the gameplay, Borderlands 3 has fantastic gameplay, and Wonderlands is no different. I'm iffy on certain aspects, like random critical hits and the multiclassing, but other aspects, like turning melee weapons into their own class of gear, or the addition of spells, were very good. I hope melee weapons as collectible gear becomes a mainstay of future installments.

If you're a Borderlands fan who liked 3's gameplay, but can't stand to play it without the dialogue muted... try this game. You might enjoy it. I know I did.

[h1]Overview: A Tiresome, Dull Borderlands Spin-off (Easily the Worst of the Series)[/h1]
Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a game that thinks its giving fans more of what they want. Take a popular Borderlands 2 DLC add more absurd non-sequitur dialogue and characters, repeat the fantasy background, with its D&D trappings, make the maps bigger, add some dice rolls and voila you get this predictable, painfully formulaic, forgettable game that forgets to ask where exactly is the fun in any of it?

[h1]The Good:[/h1]

[i][u]Gameplay:[/u][/i]
The new mechanics of spell casting and unique class abilities are genuinely a solid improvement to the gameplay experience from previous borderlands games. Additionally some of the purple and gold weapons are innovative in their combat mechanics and fun to play with (however they are few and far between leaving you more often with a banal weapon going experience).

[h1]The Bad:[/h1]

[i][u]Loot[/u][/i]
How do you make a looter shooter with bad loot? Easy. Have terrible drop rates for any loot you would actually want to keep. Wonderlands has - by far - the worst drop rates of any modern Borderlands game (BL2 or later, I honestly can't remember the drop rates in BL1). I did not see anything but low level whites and greens for the first 10levels. Blues dropped like purples from other Borderlands games until I was past level 20. This is likely due to the 'loot luck' system Tiny Tina employees where you have to run around the maps and do challenges to find hidden dice to 'raise your loot luck.' If you stick with the default 'loot luck,' you will have an extremely unrewarding experience. 

The developers have said they want gold drops in Wonderlands to 'feel special,' 'rewarding,' etc. What they've actually done is make the game feel unrewarding to play. It is not hyperbolic to say I did not see a gold drop until I was 20+hrs into the game and over level 20 (the cap is level 40). I did not see my first gold weapon drop until level 22 - which was immediately pointless as it was a 1-shot shotgun that had to be reloaded every time you fire. This was not a weapon that suits my play style so instead of 'feeling special' or 'rewarding' what it actually felt like was trolling from the game. It was not until I was around lvl30 I found another gold weapon drop, fortunately the 2nd time around it turned out to be worth playing with.  But this experience begs the question why do the developers think spacing gold drops so absurdly few and far between creates an exciting or rewarding game-play experience? It simply doesn't. And I say this as someone with 800+ hrs in Borderlands 2 and 400+ in both the Pre-Sequel and BL3. Initially when playing BL3 I thought the gold drops were a bit too generous but after playing Wonderlands I would far prefer a game lean on being overly generous than end up as stingy as Wonderlands is.

[i][u]Story[/u][/i]
Like Borderlands 3, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands turns up the level of absurd non-sequitur one-liner humor to 11 with the same cringe results. The lesson none of the Borderlands writers seem capable of assimilating into their work is that however big or broad the humor may want to be - fundamentally - the story and the character's desires need to be based on something real. As an example, part of the humor of the original Borderlands 2 Tiny Tina DLC comes from Mr. Torgue who wanted to be accepted and allowed to play a game of D&D even though he seems like a poor fit given his jock-ish appearance. The broad, over the top humor in that scenario was still grounded by a reality for each of the characters. 

While the voice acting in Wonderlands is largely serviceable none of the characters are memorable (unlike any of the BL2 characters). What's worse is one of the main characters, played by Wanda Sykes (who I normally love) phoned in her performance. She gives the most wooden, and stilted dialogue in the game.  Finally, the ending of Wonderlands' story is perfectly serviceable however the moment to moment journey is not something you'll likely pay much attention to undermining most of your time with it.

[i][u]Exploration & Gameplay[/u][/i]
2 new additions to Wonderlands is the D&D inspired overworld map & the larger map zones (sans vehicles) filled with challenges, collectibles etc. The problem with both of these additions is the lack of immersion and exhaustion they create. Previous Borderlands games typically had zones that could be cleared in a play session of an hour or so. These larger maps will exhaust you if you try to clear the side quests in one go never mind the challenges. Fundamentally it is a problem of proper pacing which takes you out of the game and makes the experience into a grindy checklist. None of the quests or dialogue is that memorable or compelling so everything sinks to the lowest common denominator of feeling like a fetch quest. The maps themselves are too homogeneous. If its a shipwreck map everything fits the aesthetic of a shipwreck, if it's a bean stock then it's all vines and floating rocks etc etc. Part of the reason a player wants to explore something is to come across the unexpected. With every map in Wonderlands showing you exactly what it is from the start - why would you really be that invested in seeing what's around the next corner? 

The over-world map that's added on the surface feels like a welcome new addition, a chance to experiment with a new idea etc. Unfortunately it quickly devolves into a nuisance that takes you away from the more compelling game play elements that typify a normal borderlands game. 

[i][u]Technical[/u][/i]
Wonderlands is supposed to be a kind of re-skin of BL3 so I have no idea why the performance is so much worse for me. Frame rates are noticeably worse in Wonderlands than in BL3. Texture pop-ins are noticeable and common. The same lack of attention to detail you see in the lack of character avatars that aren't shown in-game when someone is speaking seems to pertain to what is under the hood of the game as well. Wonderlands is far from the days of BL2 - a light weight game which could run on almost every potato PC.

[h1]Bottom Line:[/h1]

As someone with literally over 1k hours in all of the previous Borderlands games and only 50ish hours in this one (at the time of review) I can honestly say I will not be spending much more time with this game. Gearbox has really hit a wall in my mind with the latest 2 borderlands games. Instead of creating more immersive and memorable environments, characters, and compelling game play elements they seem content with retreading familiar ground to the point of nausea and headache. Even on Sale, Wonderlands is not worth your time. You're better off checking out any other borderlands game or simply dipping your toe in a different fps direction.

It's alright, but the devs abandoned it too quickly and it feels like an incomplete rip-off as a result.

The base game's story is fun to play through as it's just long enough and doesn't drag on as much as BL3's did. If you try to do all sidequests as they pop up and explore the maps for lucky dice it feels like a proper adventure. Player customization is also more varied this time around as you make your own character and pick a class. You can make some very ugly characters, me and my friend played as a goblin and orc for example.

The issue is that the base game doesn't have anything to do aside from 100%ing the maps and finishing the story. The endgame feels unbalanced, builds feel like a step down from any previous borderlands game except 1, there aren't any fun farms or exciting equipment to strive towards. The game had potential, but the devs squandered it by rushing out short, shitty, overpriced DLCs and not adding more content to the main game as they did with cartels and takedowns in BL3.

Basically, just get it on sale and play the story in co-op if you like borderlands games. It's more of the same but not enough for a full game with this pricetag.

The D&D spin on a classic Borderlands title is fun, however this game contains a quantity of content equal to a DLC rather than a standalone game. Even at its highest difficulty, I didn't find the game particularly challenging. It contains an arena system that is fun with friends, however after one or two hours of play, you will exhaust most of the variety available. 

Overall, a fun game, I would absolutely recommend it, even at full price. That being said, expect your unique experience to end and your wonder to fade within 20 hours of play. Without a doubt, the game is 10 times better when played with friends.  I had hoped that a significant DLC would have been released at this point, but am left wanting.

I really wanted to like this game, I did.  But I find it struggling to hold my attention for the 2nd time.  Granted I'm a 47 year old man and I'm quite sure that I'm not the target audience for this game.  I played all the Borderlands games and like most things about most of those games.  But this is just too much.  It's like Borderlands for 10 year old girls with ADHD.  The stories/plots are boring and uninteresting.  I find myself not caring at all about what is happening in the game.  The quests are really quick/short and it's always "go to this place and kill a few easy enemies and then go back to the quest giver and turn it in".  I'm tired or sleepy sometimes at night after a long day of work and I find myself almost falling asleep playing this game because it doesn't make me think at all and it's just plain boring.  The colors are a bit too much and half the time it hurts my eyes playing this.  The gun play is OK but not nearly as good as Borderlands games.  I don't really like the whole magic thing.  It's difficult to tell what a lot of the items even do.  But the guns aren't nearly as good or as fun as in Borderlands.  The enemies seem dumbed down and easier to kill and therefore the gear is toned down too.  I'm only about level 15 but I find myself barely wanting to continue playing this and I may never finish it.  Too bad since I'm pretty sure I spent decent money on it. I'm glad I paid nothing close to full price however.  I think I'd choose a refund if that was a possibility.  I'm sure there are some other games out right now that I'd rather play than this one.  I just find right now is a really bad time for the video game industry as a whole.  It seems like all the people who worked from home barely worked and the games coming out now are rushed and half-done, or just not good period.  Here's to hoping the games from Gearbox/2K are better than this one moving forward.  I've replayed all the Borderlands games but don't think I even want to finish this one.  Too childish for me with bad/uninteresting writing and plots/quests.

This is a pretty fun game with really funny dialogue, especially to gamers of both the videogame type and TTRPG type. I would say that its best played with friends--I played with my hubby, and we had a pretty good time with it. I can't imagine having as much fun doing it solo.

 I appreciate the fact that when you beat the game, the game acknowledges you cleared it and you can choose to proceed with clearing side missions in Chapter 11 Epilogue, which is just an endless chapter meant for you to keep playing. Unsure if I would keep playing just to clear side missions, but overall I had a pretty good time with it. I'd probably rank it 7.5/10.

EDIT: Thought of some more. Really liked how character customization works. Loot drops could be better (you reach a point where you're better off buying gear from a shop, cause the drops are mostly not worth it). Game tells you that melee is an option, but it does feel like ranged it the way to go. 

If you want a game to play with your buddies, this is a solid choice. But please get it on sale.

This is the Borderlands 1 of the Wonderlands series (assuming there will be more)
Borderlands 1 was more of an exploratory game that tried out new ideas that were more completely fleshed out in later games. The same thing happened here. 
Tiny Tina's Wonderlands has cool ideas that never manage to coalesce into a proper game, instead standing on their own, and suffers from removing basically all established borderlands characters without offering any worthwhile replacements.
It's a neat picture into what a sequel could be like, and is a decent romp that borderlands players will probably enjoy, but the lack of existing characters and personalities (save for tina and 2 other short cameos) as well as just being a hodgepodge of various ideas tossed together keeps this from being great.

Combat is that of BL3 but tweaked and refined making a better game play experience, unfortunately the anointed system makes a unwanted return making getting the gear you want tedious instead of fun. Which leads to the lack off dedicated drops, just like BL3. Most gear is tied to world drops, yet again making building your "Fatemaker" boring and long-winded.

The UI is yet again appalling. Gearbox had a fantastic UI for BL2 and BL;TPS worked like a dream for keyboard and mouse, and controller alike. But since BL3 the UI has been god awful for comparing gear and inventory management. 

Finally the DLC. What the actual fuck were they thinking. the content they seem to be discharging from their asses should just be free updates as they are just glorified chaos chambers. If they decided to pull a fast one and do a season pass 2... which we will all inevitably buy. (Already bought this game once from the stupid timed exclusive BS.) I want to see some story content! 

All in all I would recommend the base game and nothing more. shorter than BL3, perhaps just a little too short but if that's what it takes for a decent story then i'll take it.

This review will be a word vomit, and the first game I write a review for that makes me wish Steam had an in-between rating rather than strictly yes/no.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands was a game I was very hyped for upon its announcement after playing the hell out of Borderlands 2. I love Dungeons and Dragons and fantasy settings, so seeing a looter shooter from Gearbox set in a fantasy world with Tina herself as the dungeon master? I said count me the hell in! I love Tina as a character, she's whimsical and funny and the right amount of crazy. Her voice actress is phenomenal, I love how she's brought Tina to life over the years.

Going into gameplay, it's your typical borderlands looter-shooter. You kill tons of enemies, get loot, sell it (a lot) and optionally spend time grinding bosses for the specific loot you want. Nothing about the gameplay loop has changed here in that regard, but the class system brings a refreshing take in Wonderlands. I like the idea of mixing and matching the equally great classes in this game. I started the game as a spellshot/graveborn, and finished it on a second character as a sporewarden/clawbringer (love my little buddies.) The abilities they have and the trees you spec into are great, it's fun and varied. Take note of that second playthrough, though.

As for story, it's hit or miss for some. I enjoyed what I got out of it, for the most part, but the ending was very very rushed. There was a buildup and suddenly you are being ushered to the final fight. Despite my playtime, the game is WICKEDLY short if you avoid the side quests (more on that later, too.) Because of this, I hate to say it, but DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE. It's sad to scream that, but this game simply does not have the content to justify $60. At best, it's a $30 game, so pick it up on sale. It's worth a playthrough, yes, but definitely on sale.

Okay, now to the nitty-gritty. Look, just...don't bother with most of the side quests. There's really only a few that I enjoyed, those specifically being: Walk The Stalk (Though it overstays its welcome), Little Boys Blue, Lyre and Brimstone, Inner Daemons, Goblins Tired of Forced Oppression, Trial of Crooked-Eye Phil, A Walk To Dismember, and A Wandering Aye. There are more quests in the later game areas but I honestly didn't bother touching them at all because of one thing: MOST QUESTS IN THIS GAME ARE FETCH QUESTS. I despise fetch quests, and Wonderlands is laden with them. 90% of the time you pick up a side quest, it's to go get something for someone and bring it back. That's it.

I mentioned a second playthrough, and that's because I gave up on my first one simply because of the overabundance of these lame fetch quests that were never worth the reward. I was level 32, made it to the third area of the game and just realized, sitting there, I wasn't having much fun outside of the main story. When it comes to Borderlands games, I LOVE the sidequests. They're engaging and have fun objectives and dialogue. This game's sidequests are just the same thing over and over and over again and I got really tired of it quickly. It killed the fun I was having running around and killing things because you'd go into a marked dungeon, clear waves of enemies across several rooms, get the item you need in a chest, dip out, and go back to the quest giver.

The primary reason I came back to Wonderlands and finished it at all, honestly, is because I'm clearing my backlog while waiting for Lies of P. In the end, I am glad I finished it because the main story is fun, but outside of it, very little else is.

So...there you have it. My probably spicy take on Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. Do I recommend it in the end? Yes, with an asterisk. Get it on a BIG sale, look up the worthwhile sidequests ahead of time, and stick your guns to the main story.

I love it. It has good parts and bad parts. But definitely, for me at least, much better experience than that cringe festival of BL3.

And to be honest, I do not play it clean because I edit my saves. My general opinion in games is FUCC RANDOM LOOT WITH NO CRAFTING and always "fix" it this when possible. Note that I play only solo with crafted gear.

I use save editor to craft equipment by transferring parts and traits from one stuff to another following my own set of rules for crafting, and also generation logic that allows gear to exist in the game. When a part or a trait is transferred, the gear from which the trait is transferred is deleted. This includes, level, rarity, parts etc. Single step advancement. One trait at a time. Traits only within the same class and vendor. In other words, parts or traits only from Skuldigger AR to another Skuldigger AR. Same part type replaces the old one if present and no duplication allowed, even if the generation logic allows it (hilariously, one gun can have 2 different overlapping barrel types and work in the game). Multiple part transfer is only allowed for legendaries and uniques as they sometimes have a part set they need to have for generation logic to allow them to be remade.

This allows me to actually fully explore the possibilities of the weapon classes and their vendors, and also discover genius hidden part combinations that do insane things that I would never discover in this game with how it is designed by default.
And this actually makes me more engaged into analyzing the equipment that might look useless at first glance, but actually has one awesome detail that is overshadowed by it's comparative uselessness to something of higher rarity or having some other better metric.

Playing one fight for 1 million times just to get a non craftable and non customizable randomized equipment I want with good part combination is FORCED REPLAYABILITY mechanic made to milk playtime hours and makes the game pointlessly boring and repeatable.

This is a scummy mechanic is made to "encourage" the player to waste more time into the game by making ideal result more difficult to attain. This is not making the game more enjoyable, it just makes it longer and less rewarding to put time into.

Weapon crafting through the save edit can create some miraculous, amazing and hilarious stuff. 
If it was implemented in the core game, the game would be fantastic and far more appealing for just exploring and finding the perfect piece to complete an absolute masterpiece of a perfect gun. Or even different variations of perfect guns of the same class and vendor.

Even some of the best legendary weapons become just shiny trinkets that look cool compared to the insane crafted builds.

Too bad the real crafting will NEVER be implemented in this franchise as the developers are more concerned with BEING WOKE AS FUCC and forcing the players to waste time on clutter mechanics to steal player time.

The setting may be fantasy, but it’s still Borderlands. Which means you’ll be collecting a lot of randomly generated guns and comparing stats. Some are going to have aspects that aren’t clear until you try and use them, like bad sights, or excessive recoil, or a weird shot pattern that makes them useless at anything but short range or against huge targets.

There are 6 character classes, plus one unlocked via DLC. Each only has one skill tree, where prior games had 3, but you eventually get to choose an additional class, so there’s a wide variety of mix-and-match. Skill effects are very gradual, so it takes a lot of progression down a tree before the class feels at all different from the generic shooting that all classes do.

In addition to guns, there are spells. Which feel like the guns with the various random attributes, though some do things that guns don’t, like spawn hydra heads that act like turrets. Some classes do better with spells than others.

The fantasy setting means the environments are much more varied than the typical Borderlands game. There are several large zones, and they’re all maze-like enough that they’re confusing to navigate, even while referencing the map.

There are a bunch of smaller maps for random encounters / pocket dungeons. Most are like Doom-style death match arenas, moderately complex rather than the simple open spaces of arenas in older Borderlands games, but still somewhat smalll overall.

Combat balance isn’t really to my liking. Lots of enemies like to close to melee range, and a fair number of the later game enemies can teleport to do so. Random encounters / pocket dungeons will outright spawn enemies behind you. This makes the game chaotic rather than tactical, it’s often a matter of holing up in a corner and shooting enemies as they charge, or running around like mad. 

Not once did I find a situation where using a rocket launcher made sense. I used spells for big area of effect attacks, because I could have both a spell and a regular, fast-firing single target gun equipped at the same time.

I enjoyed the side-quests a lot more than the main story. The conceit is that it’s a tabletop RPG with a manic 13 year old as a game master, so everything is intentionally silly and juvenile. This works for the side quests that are generally pop-culture parodies of games and movies, but it also means the main quest feels pretty shallow.

One aspect of the main quest I really disliked was that the main villain has a mind of his own, and is rebelling against Tina as game master. Which doesn’t make any sense, really, and his complaints about her “tyranny” ring hollow, since it’s explicitly a game. I think Wonderlands would have been better, overall, if they’d skipped that and stuck with the idea that he’s an NPC played by Tina, like the rest of the major NPCs.

Overall, it’s pretty good. It took me a while to warm to it at first, but eventually I adapted to the vibe.

Side quests are often just boring, none of them are that funny or entertaining, personally cleared them just for completition. Weirdly enough for the kind of game it is, it has quite a few quests that takes themselves really seriously. 

In conclusion: If you feel like playing something like Borderlands, but don't feel like going for yet another run, this is a nice option, better if on discount, I don't think it's worth the original price. Even though it's much weaker than the main series, it does its job.

[h1]Cozylands[/h1]
[b]Things I liked in Wonderlands[/b]
[list]
[*]it has little to none connection with previous Borderlands
Set in a medieval kingdom, the story steers away from Pandora (finally!). There are still familiar faces giving your quests (Torgue, Claptrap, Brick), but they are so subtle or just hilarious. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2907628326
[*]Atmosphere
Sunny and chill. Mini board POV in-between worlds and bright levels (with few dark story levels) - all that makes you want to play more. There are dices to collect (well hidden or guarded), which boost your stats.
[*]Spells > Grenades
Instead of explosives, your character snaps fingers, summons creatures, throws fireballs or intensively waves magic wands.
Then your enemies are either being hit by lightening, bounce off jelly cubes or being chased by tiny hydra snakes. Fun times!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3024025544
[*]Character customization
A lot of options to create your hero, starting with class and body type, finishing with nose shapes, hairdos and armour patterns. [/list]

[b]What I didn't enjoy[/b]
[list]
[*]Enemies. It's mostly skeletons. 
Somehow they are everywhere. Every second mission has skeletons. Major rescue quest features skeletons, their ghost ship, which was fun, but at that point I fed up with them.
Of course there are other types - sentient mushrooms, goblins, dragons, yuan-ti, sharks... but it's mainly skeletons.
[*]Only a few bosses.
1-2 interesting and real giant beasts to kill. There are more in the trial chambers.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3024026239
[*]Loot can be a bitch. 
At some point you can select a subclass. This is where RNG will go wild. Constantly generating half of your main and half of another warrior. Shame.
[/list]

Ah, Wonderlands. 
Back when it was announced late 2021 - early 2022, I was sceptical: a new BL game to come out only a few years after the latest installment? During the Schmovid Schmandemic no less? I had a gut feeling that it wouldn't be that great, so I tampered my enthousiasm and held off of it for a while.

But that has passed, obviously, and I have given it a chance. So, what do I think after my first playthrough? Here are some of my personal thoughts and reflections

[h1]The good[/h1]
[list]
[*] Absolutely stunning visuals,  The maps and environments have received a lot of attention and their diversity is rich, and the same can generally be said about the enemies as well.
[*] I enjoyed the writing in this game A LOT more than that of BL3. Our villain is maybe no Handsome Jack, but I found him a lot more interesting and more fleshed out than others in the series. The humor goes a bit more back to the older games in the franchise. And the player is once again the center point in the story and its driving force, a stark contrast with BL3 wherein your achievements often felt futile and your presence ignored.
[*] The more complex Character Creation is awesome (you can even choose your spoken voice), you can create some real beauties with it. 
[*] The general reflavor of loot to match the fantasy setting more is a nice touch: spells instead of grenades, armor (that can substantially change your appearance) instead of classmods, crossbow rifles,... and the introduction of melee weapons are fun additions, but it is done so that it still feels perfectly like Borderlands.
[*] Once again a TON of references to be found. This game has some of my all-time favorite side quests
[/list]


[h2]The bad:[/h2]
[list]
[*] a level cap of 40, for some reason, despite the fact that every BL game before went to at least 50 AND had ways to increase it. And the Myth Rank system (comparable to Badass Rank in earlier games) is horribly barebones. Why did they decide to take a step back from the far superior system implemented in BL3, the game that was the blueprint for this one?
[*] speaking of a step back from BL3: they kept the mantling and climbing, but added a metric crapton of invisible walls and ledges that LOOK mountable but are not. In a game series that rewards players for map exploration, this feels like a slap in the face.
[*] the endgame does not appeal to me. The Chaos chamber is fun for a few times but it gets repetitive pretty quickly. And even if you enjoy the gauntlet and get some top-tier gear, then what? Test it out in a Takedown or on a Raid Boss? Sorry, no can do. There are seemingly also no returning Seasonal Events, like the Cartel or Captain Haunt in BL3 (which you can now toggle on and off whenever you wish btw).
[*] the lack of vehicles and the relatively low amount of travel stations make the maps often a slog to navigate through
[*] the balance of the loots feels all over the place
[/list]

Overal, it is a very colourful BL game that nails the aestetic and has a lot of content early and midgame, but in many ways it does things worse than its predecessors. It feels rushed, even more than after its release. I don't think I would recommend it for full price, but 40 or lower? Absolutely

This is basically just an inflated version of BL2 Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep DLC. That one was a great piece of writing because it capitalised on great story and characters from BL2. It was a respite from gloomy times, a wonky child's suppression of life's tragedies.
Wonderlands, however, don't have the advantage to be a DLC of a great base game. It's just random and tries hard to be funny with recycled old characters. 
It's not a bad game, the gameplay is smooth and fast-paced. (Unless in Overworld. Navigating it was a drag.) 
Guns and spells are satisfyingly destructive and satisfyingly varied – at first. Then, however, nearing the endgame I just gave up and used the same type of SMG's (Hyperion and Dahl) with different status effects because it didn't make sense to play with anything else – they simply had the best DPS.
Classes aren't very appealing, they all kind of blend together. Adding skill points makes no noticeable change in gameplay, you don't feel empowered like in the previous installments. 
I don't recommend this game for a full price, but if you want to rekindle your fondness of the series, buy it discounted.

So, I have yet to finish this game, but I have played three separate characters up to the multiclassing part (some past this part) just to play around with the classes/multiclassing. I've had this on my wishlist for a year since it came out and I am even more pleased with it than I had anticipated. The sale for the game + DLC for under $30 was so worth it, I bought it for myself and two others so I'd have people to play with. I'm curious to see how multiplayer is different than solo, but this game does a fantastic job of giving that feeling of playing a D&D game with your friends, collecting loot, selling loot, and building the perfect build for your chosen classes. Also love the fact you can share loot between your own different characters, I've been taking advantage of this as I often get loot for my other classes and not the one I'm playing as. Overall, 10/10 for me!

100% of the non-dlc is done. I enjoyed this game as I came into it with the mindset of this not being a "Borderlands" game but Tiny Tina's! It is very linear with a decent enough story. Early game was fun as i used a good amount of weapons which later turned into me using the same gun archtype (blackpowder} for the rest even using a pistol 12 levels below me before I found its replacement. 

Grinding out bosses for their drops does not feel worth it at all. 

The loot luck system makes sense but even with being max level, all lucky dice found, and wearing luck up gear the drop rate for items still average around 6% maxed. When you play with my rng that's around 30-40 runs to get a single drop of what you are looking for. Not worth. 

Overall though I had fun. Got the game on a heavy sale which is the only way to do it. 

Would I play this game again? By myself? Not a chance. With a friend? Maybe.

Campy and sometimes juvenile, I still enjoyed Wonderlands through to the finish. Having sat through those awkward roleplaying moments with friends in my youth, and understanding the context of the Borderlands series, were both invaluable to appreciating this game - and I can see where many folks may call its plot "cringey". It feel niche to me, but I also am a part of that niche market I guess :-) so it worked for me! Your mileage may vary.

Though I got it at a discount, this game is no where near worth $60, let alone the DLC. Game looks abandoned, because there are still errors and stuff needing to be fixed and development talk ceased 6 months ago. Even more reason not to buy.

Endgame is nothing but grinding levels for meager increases to grind the same content, but harder. Buy when it's $20.

I haven't played a borderlands game in a long time, since borderlands 2 came out, and i have to say i really missed the borderlands charm.
The game is set on the D&D universe, with a new overworld "area" where you travel from location to location unlocking new parts of the map, get some side quests and other stuff, like shrines that gives you buffs to your character stats.
I enjoyed the story, it was  ok, there are some really funny side quests, and the overworld adds a new flavor to the game.
The part where this game really shines is on the weapons department, there are tons of fun crazy weapons to try out and have fun with, they all feel great to shoot and just feel nice use.
I didn't really like the amount of loot you get , it's just too much, usually just trash loot you are not going to use, you can still it sell it on the vending machines sure, but i still think it would have been nice to get less trash loot and more good loot.
Overall i enjoyed my time with tiny tinas, a good story with some funny side quests, nice weapons and good character customization made for a really enjoyable game. If you played other borderlands games and enjoyed them, you really need to give this one a try, you're going to like it.

First of all, if you want to buy this game buy it in sale.
This game is not worth the full price, the main story is a bit bland and simple and not memorable.
Some dialog is funny but overall they try too hard and you spend rolling your eyes as a lot. 

The game play itself is also a bland, while you are able to multi-class in several classes and combine abilities in your build it doesn't add much to the game play.
For a looter shooter you really have to search for the enemies as they are spread thin around the map which is really a hassle and breaking the flow of the game play.
The normal game mode is so easy and it is boring even on the highest difficulty.
The endgame is a boring repetitive grind which makes the game a tad harder every time you complete a special level as in... the enemies become bullet sponges so not much interesting there.
There is no replay value in this game and you can't start a new game+ as you might be familiar with in the normal Borderlands games.

If you want a fun game go play Borderlands 2, and try the Tina DLC there because that's just so much more fun than this boring and bland game.

A great twist on the classic Borderlands shoot 'n loot. I particularly like the way they mix fantasy archetypes with futuristic means. 

For example in this game you can expect to be gathering teeth from un-dead skeletons for a goblin dressed as a tooth fairy with your laser shotgun that transforms into a bolt of lighting when you throw it. And that's not to mention your spells that raise ice stalagmites out of the ground to repeatedly pierce their bones from below.

The humor remains the crass cacophony of spin-off characters from well known pop culture that the previous Borderlands games championed in the early 2010's. Overall I strongly recommend this game to any fan of first person shooter games. 

Even though the multiplayer is generally co-operative as opposed to competitive, I would say this game provides a fun experience for nearly anyone willing to go into it with an open mind.

It's Borderland 3 but the story is straight up sloggy at parts. The looter shooter aspect is more or less the same as B3, take it however you will.

The biggest gripe for me was the gameplay loop. Having to switch between the main hub, the table top map, and the encounters was annoying; each forces you into half a 15s loading screen. 

You do a main quest dungeon, then you have to grind out a bunch of encounters to progress. 
These encounters a series of maps You finish certain waves of mobs in a map, take a portal with 15s loading screen to another map, rinse and repeat ~5 times until the encounter is finish. Maps and mobs are reused and look so... uninspiring to say the least.

For PC, the control scheme is quite counter-intuitive and clunky, especially the inventory menu. Seriously, this is a looter shooter, and a big chunk of time you'd spend is in the inventory menu, so I'd say this is another big negative.

I wish I didn't have to write a negative review, because the game itself is fantastic. It captures the essence of the original Borderlands humor and is, in my opinion, the funniest game in the Borderlands universe.

HOWEVER, I've played Borderlands 1, 2, Pre-Sequel, 3, and numerous DLCs with my wife. We've enjoyed them immensely, mainly because the co-op experience was either good or at least satisfactory. This installment made it nearly unplayable for us due to one significant change from the other games in this series: players earn more experience points (EP) for delivering the finishing blow. Over time, the level/EP disparity between my wife and me grew so substantial that I had to intentionally hold back, which reduced my enjoyment. From levels 10 to 40, I found myself merely running into every battle, hoping my pet wouldn't defeat the enemies, and allowing my wife to finish them off. It became incredibly frustrating to just watch her engage in combat while I still had a considerable EP lead, regardless of our efforts to balance it. My uncontrollable pet often dealt the killing blows, and my main objective became avoiding enemy kills. The thrill of acquiring and using powerful weapons vanished because what was the point? I constantly felt unsatisfied and powerless.

Why introduce such a mechanic in co-op? It would be more suitable for a "competition" mode or something similar. Co-op players should have the freedom to choose whether they want a level difference or not.

Overall, it was a disheartening experience. The only solace came from the humorous dialogues between battles. Each encounter was pure frustration, and we won't be revisiting this game. For context, we've replayed BL1, 2, Pre-Sequel, and 3 multiple times, amassing over 3,000 hours of gameplay combined.

Very disapointing!!!

PS: Yes, we googled and tried a lot of things to get rid of the EP difference. But after 2-3 fights I had (thanks to the pet) again an enormous EP advantage!

Honestly if you are a huge fan of the Borderlands franchise like I am then you are probably going to enjoy this game. A lot of the basics of the game and menu ui is similar so getting around it won't be as confusing. There are different mechanics when it comes to weapons though because now you have spells instead of weapon elemental mods and your ward vs your shield which just gives extra buffs. All in all I sped through the game a bit and finished it in about a week so it's not very long but I did enjoy playing it coop with my friends and bf. Highly recommend you do too!

This has been a n interesting return to Borderlands for me. From the heydays of BL2 to the 'oh hey, no!' days of the latest missteps, it's been a complicated journey for me. But I am glad to say that TTWL is certainly a worthy successor to what's been built before and a definitely good game from GearBox.  Kudos to the team, especially the voice actors, the story writers and the art team for building a world I would love to immerse myself in. There are quibbles, no game being perfect or suited to everyone, but they are, for me, forgettable. I have huge qualms about replaying on multiple characters, but hopefully, the linear story telling doesn't burn me out too quickly. Looking forward to seeing more Tiny Tina. RIP Roland.

In a lot of ways, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is just another borderlands game, and in a lot of ways it isn't. While it keeps a lot of the things we associate with the borderlands franchise, the game also removes some of the core elements. 

In this game, there are no premade characters to choose from, instead you choose your own stats and design of your character. This feels very natural since this game is Borderlands meets Dungeons and Dragons. Building on this concept, the game introduces its own "tabletop rpg board" called: "Overworld". 

The Overworld works as transportation between zones, but also offers quests of its own and things to collect. Here the game introduces the very interesting need to complete one quest, in order to unlock a new path that allows you to finish a previous quest. Unfortunately, the content in the Overworld can get very repetitive and I recommend completing it in between main missions. 

The story is not the main selling point of the game, but then again, that's not really the selling point of any borderlands game. What we do come back for is, in my opinion; fun gameplay and fun dialogue. The gameplay is great, capturing that fantasy/DnD setting by, for example, replacing grenades with spells feels so spot on. The dialog and humor in borderlands is its own thing, being very silly, stupid and sometimes a little cringe. In Borderlands 3 a lot of players, myself included, felt that the characters and dialogue were just too cringe to enjoy. I want to make the claim that they have reversed that and I much more enjoy the conversations in Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. And as a big fan of Brooklyn 99, having Andy Samberg voice one of the main characters is a blast. 

In conclusion; this game is not just another Borderlands game. The pacing is sometimes slower and some core ideas of all previous Borderlands games are gone. It's best enjoyed if you have some experience playing Dnd, but definitely not a necessity. It improves dialog compared to Borderlands 3, but unfortunately keeps it's difficult to navigate map. This game deserves a lot more attention, and I believe that most borderlands fans approaching this game with an open mind will have a good time playing this game.

This game is pretty mid, it gets boring and repetitive fast. There are random encounters which are pretty much just wave based battles that serve no purpose except to fill game time. The side quest are also pretty boring with a lot of them just requiring you to do these wave based battles in the same small arena over and over. Its like they took the worse parts of a fantasy rpg and put them into this game. The jokes also suck for a borderlands game because they written as PG and woke. If they kept that crude humor of the first couple games it would of been tolerable.

Gameplay wise Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is not really good. Yes the shooting/using special skill/casting spells is not particulary bad. But for some reason compared with Borderlands 3 this doesn't have that many [i]fun guns,[/i] they all feel like standard fare. 
The areas you fight at are not great either, for some reason every spot you fight at feels like a [i]Arena[/i] of sorts and not a good designed one. It doesn't help that most of the time it is enough that you stand at the entrance and either enemies come running or you can just snipe them off and then they come running. There is never any gameplay like in the other Borderlands games where you run around in a Level and every spot spawns some enemies which can spawn all around you making you explore while combat is going on.
The AI feels off with enemies sometimes just running between two places if the player is not close enough, feels worse sometimes then Far Cry 6 AI.

Another negative thing for me is that Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is not even 30 hours long, including all the DLC... for a game they charge $79.99 for. Compared you get allot more bang for your buck if you buy Borderlands 3: Super Deluxe Edition you get more content for the same price.

But I waited on a deep deep sale of Tiny Tina's Wonderlands, which came in Summer Sale 2023 where I paid for the [i]Tiny Tina's Wonderlands: Chaotic Great Edition[/i] $26.39... but now I [i]still[/i] regret that purchase.

I think you have to be [b]really starved[/b] for some FPS action and/or be not bothered with all the woke bells, whistles & rainbows this game comes with, in order to really enjoy it.

This is a good game, however I was hoping it would be closer to the style of borderlands 3. I find the weapons to be lacking in fun to use, and the Dungeons and Dragons style of the game takes some getting used to if you are not familiar with that style of game. However as I gain more experience in playing this game maybe thing will feel better and weapons will improve.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]

Game is fun, [b]but I would wait for sale as the game feels short and doesn't have TVHM[/b] like the previous Borderlands entries. Writing is thankfully better than BL3, and the gameplay is a fun twist on the Borderlands formula, with some changes that fit the fantasy DnD roleplay feel, while still keeping the gameplay that made Borderlands fun. If you plan to play the endgame, get the DLC, otherwise, you can skip the DLC. Also consider looking at the Wonderlands Redux mod on Nexus.

[h1]Full Review:[/h1]

Fun game! I wanted to review the game being a long time fan of the Borderlands series. I'm a bit late to the party, as I was busy with other games at the time, but I picked the game up on sale recently, and I'm pleasantly suprised!

First off, thankfully the writing is not too bad, definitely an improvement over Borderlands 3 (not as good as Borderlands 2, but that's fine given this is a DnD side story based on a DLC). Granted, while Borderlands has never been the best example of good writing in games, I feel many would agree the drop in quality from BL2 > BL3 was very disappointing. The BL3 writing definitely soured the opinion of many who played BL3 despite it's fun gameplay and vast endgame content. 

The gameplay is just as fun as BL3, with some fun twists. You now can mix and match 2 classes, with the option to reroll your 2nd class freely (after a certain point in the game), grenades are now replaced with spells (they recharge on a timer), and there are now melee weapons with unique effects. It's different enough to feel the fantasy element while still having many of the elements that make Borderlands so fun.

However, the main story of the game feels very short compared to the other Borderlands Games (My first playthrough which played mostly only the main story finished the game at level 26 in around 13-14 hours), so I would recommend you to play and explore many of the side quests on your first playthrough if you want to enjoy your first playthrough. Side quests aren't mind blowing or anything, but are fun and entertaining enough to help with the short length of the main story. 

There's also a mod called Wonderlands Redux found on Nexus that improves some gameplay aspects that some may want to install, so check it out and see if it interests you. If you plan to play the endgame, I would encourage you to download it as it makes the endgame much, much better. Either play install it on your first playthrough, or play through the game once in vanilla and then endgame with Redux, either works IMO, it's up to you to decide. (If you plan to play Redux's endgame content, you pretty much need the DLC, so keep that in mind).

Some notable additions in the Redux mod include: 
- Fun movement options (double jump, air dash, improved slide momentum, etc.)
- Unlocks/skips/changes game mechanics that players may find tedious/annoying (starts the game with all 4 weapons slots, chaos level is now capped at 10 instead of 100, unique gear now have their own rarity and are easier to identify, etc)
- Pearlescent Rarity, along with Legacy Hunts (think Legendary Hunts from BL3)

Overall, the game is very fun, and unlike with BL3, there is no major flaw in the game that would make me iffy about playing this title (Seriously, the writing in BL3 was very hard to stomach). It's fun solo or with friends, and is an enjoyable entry in the series.

My only real big complaint is the pricing of the game. It feels a bit short for a $60 title. IMO, it feels more like it should be $40, especially since there's no TVHM like the older games. Chaos runs are fun but aren't the same as THVM, and IMO I feel it provides less replay value compared to TVHM. Add this to how short the main story feels, the game definitely can feel a bit lacking in content compared to the previous games. 

The game seems to go on sale for about $20 with the Chaotic Great Edition (Game + DLC Bundle) going for $26, so I would definitely recommend waiting for a sale if you can, as I would only buy the game at full price if you really, really, really love Borderlands and must play it despite its short length and lower replay value compared to the previous Borderlands entries.

Again, if you plan to play the game's endgame, I would recommend getting the DLC and highly encourage the Redux mod (buy the DLC on sale, the $30 Season's Pass isn't worth it IMO). Otherwise, if you only plan to play the game's main/side content, you can skip the DLC.

PROS:

CONS:

After playing through this, doing all the side content (as well as the "DLCs") and getting all the achievements, I can say that this game is worth your time. However, I'm leaving a negative review.

Wonderlands fixes Borderlands 3's greatest flaw: story and characters. Along with that, it brings some genuinely worthwhile content and gameplay elements, however, it's still a reskin, and, essentially, nothing we haven't seen before.

[b]The Good:[/b]

- The Story and Characters are great. Tina is amazing as Bunker Master and I loved every single voiceline she screamed in my ears; Valentine, Frette and the Dragonlord are also funny and expertly voiced, even if sometimes it might feel a little bit too much.

- The World varies from beatiful to simply breathtaking. Even if they're just shotting arenas for us players, you can tell that a lot of work has been put to differentiate each and every setting in this D&D campaign - from pirate coves to desert temples, from snowy mountain peaks to giant beanstalks, every corner of this map looks amazing.

- The Classes also let the player mix and match tons of builds by combining two of them at once, fiddling around with your skills and gear to make the perfect build; this (along with the combat and loot) has always been the franchise's main selling point, and this time is no different. Oh, spells are amazing too.

- The customization is actually one of Wonderlands' best features, we don't spend a lot of time looking at our characters, but I really enjoyed messing around with all the options at our disposal here.

[b]The Bad:[/b]

- It's just more Borderlands. The quests can have as much window dressing and dialogue as they want, this is too similar to Borderlands 3 and I started to get bored halfway through; your mileage may vary, but Borderlands 4 NEEDS to bring something new to the table.

- The UI. For the love of all that is holy, change this UI. It was already terrible in 3, and there's no excuse for it to keep being this terrible in Wonderlands, it's confusing, buggy and frustating to use.

- The optimization is still as bad as it was on 3; just goes to show, again, how little time was invested in making the game actually differ from it's predecessor. 

- Who the hell thought loot luck, one of the most (if not THE most) important stats in a looter shooter should be based on over 200 little collectible dice scattered throughout the map with NO map markers for them?

[b]THE UGLY:[/b]

- The monetization, "DLC" and late game content are the reason why I'm leaving a negative review. By now, you probably noticed the review score for the Season Pass that Wonderlands offers.

The "DLC" are 4 separate "dungeons" that straight up reutilize the base game's arenas over and over, there's no story (the 30 seconds cutscene before you start the dungeon doesn't count), no unique, exciting loot waiting for you as a reward for beating the boss, nothing. It's a pathetic excuse for a DLC for a game that, by itself, IS a DLC; trust me, with the money they're asking for this game you can buy at least a few copies of Borderlands 3's Ultimate Edition (which also has a shitty "Season Pass 2", but that's another discussion). There's no endgame content. 

Gearbox is getting way to greedy and way too comfortable with this franchise, and I hope Borderlands 4 can inovate and somehow surprise us.

I have never gotten one of the legendaries I was trying to farm for.
I've never seen a legend appear in a machine.
A loot dice rolling a 20 has never given me a legendary, and ironically rolling 1's has given me better loot.
Borderlands 3 was too rewarding, this game seems to forget that it needed to reward you. Side quests on the other hand always seem to have at least a blue with red text.

Some bugs persist, such as netcode issues. People disconnect once in a while.
Others are new, I seem be freezing at least once per session, a long lockup that resolves 15 to 20 seconds later, often confusing my friends in multiplayer.

They have some funny bits, and I like some of the voice actors they've chosen. The actor for Bojack Horseman makes a good candid villain, and he's a better villain than BL3 had. They give him a strange narrative. He's evil, but if he knows none of these characters are real, then his actions have no true negative impact. He tries to buddy up to the character, appealing to them. Maybe that story will go somewhere good. I have no issues with the story beats so far, they haven't killed half the cast this time for dramatic effect.

It also smells like Egoraptor, I'm glad he's in this again (as the demi-lich).

TL;DR: I'm glad I bought it at a sale. It's a weaker game than BL3 with a better story (though abstract and silly). It doesn't fill your pockets with legendaries, but also somehow only gives me a duplicate cosmetic on a nat 20 on dice that don't respawn and don't exist across characters. Really?

Buy it if you want to shoot some stuff and ran out of other content, but leave it alone if you want it to be the best new looter shooter in your life.

Alright, let's talk about Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. It's like Borderlands 3 with a fantasy twist, and I have to admit, it's been a wild ride. You get to shoot goblins in the face with a flaming crossbow, throw gigantic meteors at weird mushrooms, and hang out with a horse made of diamonds. It's pure chaos, and I love it!

The writing and voice acting in Wonderlands are top-notch. The comedic cast is one of the best I've seen in a game, and it's been a laugh-out-loud experience from start to finish. The absurdity and violence in this fantasy-infused looter shooter RPG are just my cup of tea. I mean, who wouldn't enjoy killing Smurfs and trying to figure out how to remove "plot armor" from a character?

Combat is a blast, and the thousands of crazy weapons you can find make it even better. Sure, there are some reused elements from Borderlands 3, but the transition to high fantasy has added a fun twist to the gameplay. Plus, the addition of spells and magical abilities keeps things fresh.

On the downside, the main story falls a bit flat. It's predictable, and the fact that it takes place within a simulated tabletop campaign leaves it feeling somewhat frivolous. But honestly, the sheer fun of the gameplay and the memorable characters make up for it.

There are a few missteps, like the uninspired combat encounters and the samey feeling of character classes when playing in a full squad. However, the overworld exploration adds a charming touch and breaks up the action nicely.

In the end, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a fantastic spinoff that delivers on the humor and mayhem we love in Borderlands games. It may play it safe in some areas, but the crazy adventure and hilarious moments make it absolutely worth diving into. If you're a fan of looter shooters and over-the-top fantasy, this game is a must-play. So grab your flaming crossbow and let the goblin-hunting begin!

This game is tedious. That's the best way I can put it. The classic Borderlands humor is there in bits and pieces; the Skelly-mens dialogue in fights is hilarious. But the overarching story falls flat. Plus, the Tiny Tina bit gets old FAST. In BL2, it was great to meet this quirky character who did funny voices, or called you Mamasita, etc. But an entire game of that - it got old quick. 
Dungeons are a slog. Most of the game is "encounters." Where you collect a shrine piece, or a side quest item. You hop into a closed arena with a pre-set amount of mobs to kill and at the end get your item. This, over and over and over again, gets tedious.
Adding stats to your character - Strength = Crit Damage Buff, Dexterity = Crit Chance Buff - that was a nice touch, and you can pick an Archetype at creation that innately buffed your class choice, i.e. +Wisdon if you wanted a caster, etc.
There's a heavy emphasis on melee attacks in this game. In fact, your melee weapon is now equippable with its own stats and damage like any other weapon. However, you still only have the default melee attack button as with any other BL game. No combos, no rolling or dodging, you just stand in front of an enemy and mash 'V' (for PC players) over and over. Tedious.
Everything else about the game is boilerplate for a BL game. Weapon types, damage types, art style, it's all the same. This feels more like an up-jumped DLC than a full game on its own. Like the main BL team handed over all of its art assets and game engine to another studio to make something BL-adjacent.
Lastly, for lack of a better term, the game as "Woke" as hell. Quests, NPCs, even audio-only lore narration - someone is gay, or trans, or asexual. That by itself isn't a bad thing, but the game just clobbers you over the head with it at every turn. It reminds me of a 12 year old, green-haired tween at Thanksgiving who's decided they have new pronouns, are Bi and everyone else there needs to know it *constantly.* It's obnoxious.
"We get it, Tina. You're on the right side of history. Now eat your carrots."

"Tiny Tina's Wonderlands" is -- what? the fifth installment? -- in the "Borderlands" series (Tales from the Borderlands notwithstanding), and continues in its parent franchise's tradition of crass, stupid, irreverent humour and ridiculous cartoon violence. Something that sets this game apart from the rest is its wealth of heart. Other instalments have had some heart, sure, but it was always in short supply, secondary by far to the humour. This game balances the two more cleanly, with tales of redemption, true love and romantic ambition, to name just a few themes. Also, the aesthetics are gay AF.

On the other hand, the graphics are still a bit unstable. Sometimes textures don't load, sometimes buttons stay middle screen far too long. Sometimes your companions's status bars show dead when the companion is fine. The inventory system is bulky and the weapons naming system is somewhere between senseless and hard to decode. A tighter algorithm for single-person play might benefit a good deal, but, hey, at least there's plenty of loot to sell. Also, in-game cut scenes tend to slow the pacing somewhat.

A good-ass game, all told. 7.5/10.

TTW - For its current sale price of $29, I say it is definitely worth a purchase especially if you are into the borderland series. I would not pay its original asking price though. See my reasons below. 

Reasons to play - 

✅ The game runs great. I played at a consistent 4k 60 with barely any fps drops even in chaotic areas. Its feels very well optimised compared to BL3
✅The story is enjoyable and stays on its path. Some of the other BL steer from the main objective a little but TTW stays on the same story path.
✅ It has a much better dialogue than BL3. Admittedly cheesy at times but that's BL in general and if your a BL fan you know what to expect. 
✅It still oozes with the borderlands that we love in terms of art style, gameplay etc.
✅ Graphically beautiful with very dynamic and changing maps as you play through the story.
✅ New classes to play with, with an option to combine two classes into one build.
✅ New weapons to play with and a higher focus on melee weapons. Spells are also a great feature to your build. 

Reasons its not worth more than $29,

❌ The level cap is at level 40 which is really low compared to the other BL Series. You end game at roughly level 38 with around 20 side quests completed. 
❌ The Chaos Chamber is an end game feature unlock, But i personally feel there is no point to it as there is no real reason to play it unless you want the level 20 chaos chamber achievement and the level 40 achievement, if you didn't make that level by end game. 
❌ There is no True Vault Hunter mode or similar. You play once, finish once, and that's you which makes grinding for legendary weapons absolutely pointless in my opinion. With previous BL series farming was a big thing to kill the higher tier enemies but as above once your at story end game, Thats you. there is nothing else to enjoy unless you want to start at level 1 again with a new class. 
❌ Golden key chest / skeleton key as they call them in this game is useless. I've put around 500 keys through it and ended up with roughly 50 legendary weapons which had terrible stats. Previous BL series all weapons etc were all legendary items. This time they are mostly just rare or common.
❌ Very limited weapons compared to the other BL series. It seems to be the same weapons with different damages or elemental effects.
❌ limited amount of gear in general. 
❌ Enemy variation isn't great. Again very limited and the same ones appear with different elemental damages or buffs
❌ Drop rates are not the best through the story. I think i had 2 legendary items drop from 0 - level 38. All legendary were obtained at the end when there's no real need for them.
❌ DLC is overpriced and absolutely pointless for 20 minutes worth of gameplay. I didnt purchase it but I did watch videos of those who have. 

Overall, I enjoyed the game. I did enjoy the detailed dynamic maps, bright colours, the Dungeons and Dragons themed story, the new class system, spells and the return of butt stallion as dragons keep was my all time favourite DLC from BL2. I finished the game at roughly 29 hours in which makes $1 an hours worth of game play. Worth in in my opinion but i wouldn't pay its original asking price.

The story is fun and there's lots of genuinely funny moments, and if you like Tina this will only make you like her more. 
It's understandable if some of the more reference heavy jokes don't land though.
However the pacing is a bit off sometimes, like basically the game expects you to push the story only until you open up traversing the ocean as several things like weapon and gear slots are locked behind that. Additionally if you just focus the story the game is very short as you only need to do 8-9 quests to reach the final boss including the tutorial. Also the world map feature makes the world feel small too despite in theory having roughly the same amount of locations/maps as other Borderlands games the fact that 5 of them are 100% optional and don't feel connected in anyway means this "Big Fantasy World" feels tiny. However that might be a intentional aspect due to it's B&B(D&D) inspired world. 

Also, no actual DLC. All the DLC is extra optional dungeons which are just a series of arena fights and not full exploratory areas.

In conclusion I had fun, The game is not Bad however it suffers simply from the "AAA" label and by extension it's pricing.
