Games great

A step in the right direction after borderlands 3.
Bosses
 I felt 3's bosses had immunity phases for no reason although they are still present in this game they are lessened to a significant degree. Bosses have more unique move sets then past iterations and feels more individualized. 
Loot.
Legendarys feel alright to good, though i think borderlands 2 still had the most diverse legendays. 
Loots new anoints can be rolled making it more feasible to get god rolls without taking out the need to farm which i enjoy. 
Classes
Classes all are fun and can be powerful in their own right. 
Endgame
endgame is in the style of repeating dungeons/ rouge-lite making it feel fun and fresh. 
Their are different types of dungeons like boss only or daily challenge as well giving you a good bit of options to run.
however endgame is missing the classic raid boss which is a shame.
Story
Story is still borderlands humor but not nearly as forced and 2012 like as the 3rd. (no "amazballs" nonsense)
DLC
i do not have the dlc as its $30 dollars with terrible reviews and after watching some videos on it seems very content lacking. Though i like the game so much i will get it when its on sale again if its $5-$10.
Overworld
i think the overworld is boring and takes you out of the flow and experience. Also the fast travel system is the worst out of any in the series but is decently easy to use when you figure it out.

All in all i like it more then 3 by a significant degree even though it was shorter and would recommend to get it when its on sale unless your really lacking a game to play or need to scratch that looter shooter itch.

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is a soulless spin off from the Borderlands franchise that fails to understand what made the Borderlands series popular. Which is disappointing because the premise is a unique one that has the potential to be done well. In Wonderland you play as an unnamed character joining Borderlands’ recurring character Tiny Tina as she leads you and some other characters on a DnD campaign she has written herself. The game starts out really good as they introduce you to the mechanics, gameplay elements and the unique twists they’ve introduced to the game, but then it falls apart quickly.

My biggest problem with this game is that it is incredibly repetitive. See most Borderlands games involve a lot of shooting the room full of bad guys and moving on to complete your next objective, no big deal. But this game frequently insists on stopping all progression until you stand in a room and fight off waves of enemies until you hit a certain quota, then sending you one room over to repeat the process. An objective that should take me 2 minutes to get too ends up taking 20 minutes because of how frequently they insist I stop and fight off waves of enemies. This is further amplified with the games overworld. Instead of having a world map you fast travel with, you’re instead given a recreation of the map that your character can walk around on and go to your next objective, a unique idea to make the world feel connected. But it’s littered with random encounters and areas that all teleport you to a small map where you fight off waves of enemies until a progress bar fills, then they boot you back to the overworld when you’re done. The game is constantly throwing you into waves of fights against the same enemies with very slight variations. While they do have DnD inspired enemies like trolls, goblins, and skeletons they all shoot guns like the regular enemies and have a melee and grenade attack, essentially making them the same enemies with different skins. This issue is most prominent after the final boss where you unlock challenge runs where you are sent to several encounters in a row that consist of being sent to a small map and fighting off waves of enemies. There’s no variety of challenge even in the fights that they’re constantly forcing you to be a part of. The most they do is give the enemies more health making these fights last even longer.

The story doesn’t fare much better. Borderlands has always been a series with several iconic characters that they’ve built up throughout the games, but Wonderlands wants to jump straight into having lots of wacky characters so they introduce a new one every 10 minutes hoping that at least one of them becomes a wakey mainstay. The problem is with so many characters at once we never really get time to know anything about them before we’ve given a new one. Some of them are only around for one quest so we’re quickly given an exposition dump to their backstory, motivations and their character arc. It makes their stories feel pointless because we race through them so quickly. Even Tina and her friends don’t add much to the story because all their dialog is either quips or narrating what another character just told us to do but with a cheeky comment. Here’s how a typical situation plays out:

Quest Giver: ‘I need you to open this locked door’
Tina: ‘Ok everyone time to open this locked door, you’ll probably want to find something key shaped to open this door that is locked’
Tina’s Friend: ‘What’s something key shaped we could use to open this door?’
Tina’s Friend 2: ‘Maybe a key?’
Everyone: *loses their minds over solving the puzzle*

Meanwhile we’re in our 4th fight since the quest started heading to the key that is one room over. 

It’s so frustrating and boring. I’ve been trying to finish this game for over a year now but just kept getting so bored I’d put it down for a while and then pick it back up, only to get bored and put it back down. The only character with any kind of depth is the final boss the Dragon Lord. They establish that he actually has the power to change the story that Tina has written and is trying to break free of her control. Yet another interesting concept of the DnD characters trying to rebel against the players of the game. But they do nothing with it. They keep building up that the Dragon Lord is going to break free and take over the story but they do nothing with it. It’s so frustrating when we reach the climax where we learn the truth about the Dragon Lord and his powers and then do absolutely nothing about it. Nope we jump right into a boss fight then get a generic ending that’s implied to be deep because of the emotional moment we were supposed to have earlier, but it isn’t earned. You can’t just have a character say a bunch of stuff that sounds emotional and then do nothing with it. I need a reason to care for these characters. If a character tells me a sad story about their childhood then leaves and never comes back I have no investment in them as a character because there’s no arc or resolution. It’s just pointless. And that’s the thing that annoys me most about this game. They’re trying so hard for you to have an emotional attachment to these characters but they have no arcs. They’ll just tell a sad story that happened to them in their life and expect that to be enough for you to be fully invested and like them. When in reality they’re just a bunch of nothing characters in a completely forgettable game.

I’ve never been so disappointed in a Borderlands game. I get that I’m not going to get an incredibly deep story or groundbreaking gameplay in these games, but this one especially is taking the piss. It’s like they were banking that Tiny Tina and the franchise were so big that people would like it on that alone and did nothing to try and write a good story or introduce any new ideas. It’s just a bad, boring game that is so proud of itself that it doesn’t realize how shallow and pointless it really is.
love the game although it takes like 10 hours to beat so its kinda worth it but its probably the shortest game weve seen from them

Technical issues: 1/5
Game (campaign): 4/5

Steam should add a neutral rating after all these years.

(After 2-3 hours in:) Too many crashes and other games just work fine. My system has 32 GB of RAM and 12 GB of VRAM, graphics settings are medium, yet this game still has memory allocation crash issues more than a year after release? There, have your thumbs down for that.

(After 18 hours in:) Had some other game that also uses a "newer" UE4 (Unreal Engine 4) crash with similar issues. It has an option for "slow CPUs" that fixed the issues there. I turned texture streaming to "low" (makes levels look pretty bad initially) and also applied "-maxmem" command line option to limit RAM usage and that seems to have fixed the issues, mostly. I will not iterate over all this to find the most optimal solution, I'm not getting paid for this QA work.

Big plus: The game has shown only one small glitch in regard to aspect ratio, many more modern games have huge troubles with anything not 16:9 (what a regression over the years), and it is also able to deal more properly with 2 screens with different resolutions (some games have no option at all for that).

About the game: The Borderlands 3 roots are very obvious. It feels like someone tried to implement a pen'n'paper RPG campaign BL3 style with a big world board (homage to oldschool JRPGs with BL twist), some predefined (and often recycled) small encounter areas, and larger "normal" main campaign areas that equal typical BL maps. Sprinkled with BL type humor and tons of references in all sorts of directions and that is TTW.

Item comparisons not working properly, text covering each other up, lag in trying to tag favorites/trash that will instead change whatever is under the mouse if the mouse moves (I lost some good items until I discovered I had accidentally marked things I wanted to keep as trash because of that click lag), and still more issues.

If you like Borderlands games, you will love Tiny Tina's wonderlands. It is a revamp of the games series loosely based on the Dungeons and Dragons add-on to Borderlands 2.

Instead of Vault Hunters, you have Fate Makers, which like Vault Hunters, have a special ability (and a second one later in the game). Instead of grenades, you have spells.

The weapons are typical Borderlands style. Some look just like the ones in Borderlands 3. This time, you also have variations on crossbows.

I found plenty of Epic weapons and equipment but Legendary loot was in scarce supply. maybe I've been unlucky!

Like all Borderlands games, you have  the opportunity to play through again at a higher level with better loot when you complete the story (arguably more fun than the first play-through).

You can look forward to having fun with it for hours and hours (I have over 2,000 hours on Borderlands 20. It's great value, especially when on sale.

in a far off land i began my day with a long stroll through a mysterious forest. I looked up through the trees and was blinded by a rainbow, a brilliant beam cutting the sky in twain i followed it. As i neared the end of the beacon i noticed from red to violet slamming into the ground over and over. i continued closer and nearly obscured by the light was a red pulp at the intersection of sky and ground. a confusing sight for sure but why was this rainbow slamming into the pulp on the ground? i pondered for many moments even as i made my way home i remained confused for sure... but as i sat by the fire trying to recall the scene i happened upon that day, i recalled a nearby horseshoe why had i not realized this in the moment? that poor, poor horse, what had it done to deserve such a beating? perhaps we will never know.

BORING. The graphics are good, the piles of weapons really enjoyable (like all Borderlands games). But its just boring. The narration is the best thing about it, and even then it gets old, fast.

The weapon effects, the variety of enemies, the  map design good and voice acting is  top notch, but it's just boring, there is no immersion. 

Got to new area grab quest, got to quest area, meet whacky character that has some weird or "humourous" quirk, finish mission, rinse repeat. Take this formula and add some pointless platforming and you have the game in a nutshell.....

I have no real interest in finishing the story is laboured and tries so hard to be funny that flops. Borderlands 2 to this day, is still one of my favorite games, I'd rather play that for the 300th time, Even BL3 with its lackluster villains and repetitive quest formula is more fun.

If you are a big fan of the franchise, and this game is on sale for dirt cheap, then maybe - but this just feels so bland and phoned in that it's a struggle to continue to play.

Despite the abysmal DLC compared to other entries, the reports of it being a scam, the fact I had to actually limit the game to 30 FPS on my Deck because it lagged a lot otherwise, the bugs I encountered, and the pain of even being near the new Claptrap (Seriously, as someone who loved Claptrap and even chose him to play as first when I first got Pre-Sequel, this post-Eddings Claptrap fcuking sucks. It's not even because this is a B&B world because I still liked him in the BL2 DLC, he's just insufferable now, either because of his new voice, how he's written this game, or both. #NotMyClaptrap, give me back my depressed unlucky boi), I actually enjoyed this. As someone who refuses to get BL3 because of the story despite wanting to because of everything else (It's tempting, but the story is just awful, so I will stay strong), it's my first experience to the newer generation of Borderlands games, and this allowed me to actually enjoy it. It looks good, I don't mind it being a bit short, and I enjoyed the story and how it centered around Tina just being a kid trying to DM a TTRPG, and a character that resents her and trying to fight back, and it gives a bit more backstory of how she became a DM to begin with. Do I recommend it? Eh, just get it on sale. I got the CGE when it was 2/3rds off, and the DLC are basically just arenas that increase in difficulty with each completion, not bad if you want to test out stuff without going through the Chaos Chambers, but they offer basically no extra story. However if you do want to get the DLC, just get the CGE on sale like I did instead of buying the season pass or something, it's cheaper that way.

Verdict: 7.86/10
Shouldn't be a $60-$80 game, get either version when CGE is less than $30

Pros:
+ Spells of many different types
+ Interesting D&d setting full of 4th-wall breaking, but without being annoying
+ Tina narrator

Cons:
- midgame is boring
- overworld dungeons and subquests can be boring
- bad RNG can make the game boring (it's really fun to try out new spells/guns, but most of the time doing so is just a dps downgrade)
- class system is underutilized. I feel like you should be able to cast all action skills, even if they shared a cooldown. Also, for Spellshot in particular, the whole skill tree heavily pushes you towards 1 of the 2 action skills.

The introduction of a proper Character Creation a la DnD style unlike other Borderlands was refreshing, and a myriad of classes above one of Gearboxes favorite numbers (4), left me sitting there for a good moment making the right choice. I quickly learned however that this doesn't matter in the slightest when you challenge the World of Might and Magic with a Trench Gun and a Remington 700. though from the small amount of time I've played, I feel as though there isn't much to gleam out of this game aside from its likeness to the beloved brain-dead shooter series, and the fact that it has Tiny Tina in it. All in all, It isn't the best, but it isn't the worst either. If you do play it, you might as well set it to the highest difficulty by default if you want any semblance of fun, or a challenge.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is an excellent take on a new idea for a series that has felt dry and repetitive. 

+ Amazing setting
+ Great voice acting
+ Immersive sound 
+ High fidelity environments
+ Fluid gameplay

- Few fast travel points
- Dungeons can get repetitive
- Loot is a hit or miss
- Only a handful of spells
- No postFX options in menu. Need a mod to disable Chromatic Aberration, DOF and Vignette

Steam Curator: https://rb.gy/w9b9x

Overall, this game is what I personally believe the borderlands series needed to feel fresh. The pre sequel was a boring disaster, and Borderlands 3 felt like the same game, just more fleshed out. This gives us a setting that I have not seen in an FPS like this before. 

When the "players" interject as your mission goes on and add actually funny commentary, it gives a creative freedom to the game that I do not see often. The way the game is set up gives it the unique opportunity to get crazy, imaginative, and unique, without needing to make a lot of sense. Suspension of disbelief is very easily achieved because of this.

My favourite moments in the game is when the dungeon master, Tina, comes up with some elaborate scheme to trick you, or to change a circumstance to suit the progression in a convenient way. There are also moments where the setting she comes up with is dodgy at best, but in reality she was not trying to trick anyone. Things backfire, and it makes for a surprisingly decent character development for the dungeon master, as well as the other players in the game. 

The story so far is fairly decent, with a funny villain that I cannot wait to get my hands on. There are no vehicles for exploration as you just traverse the main world hub as if you were a pawn on a tabletop game. This does however mean that the exploring in the actual mission maps might come at a deficit since you have to walk everywhere, and fast travel points are far fewer than I would prefer.

It is notable however that the main areas are A TAD smaller than in B3, so the lack of a vehicle is not as impactful. The class system is also present and you can dual class after a certain point. Do not worry too much about which class you choose as your second class as changing it is possible.

I have been putting a lot of hours in B3 on my Steam Deck primarily, and I was starting to feel the fatigue of just going through the game mindlessly. Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is such a favourable setting, to me, that it takes away the monotony of just progressing through a game by making it a lot more interesting. I would highly recommend this game, especially on a deep discount. Currently under 20$ on Steam and that is a steal.

Stay away from the DLC of this game however. Especially the season pass. Borderlands games have already been laughable at making good DLC and this is no exception. 

For more, consider subscribing and leaving a like, it goes a long way for me.

Ive played all the borderlands. When the first borderlands came out it introduced many new mechanics combining shooter looter rpg elements. Now with this latest installment capitalising on its most interesting and likeable character, Tiny Tina, it tries to bring in more variety whilst sticking to its roots. It is a fun game I can recommend to any borderlands fan. 
New changes ive noted and welcomed - a dual class system for more experimenting with builds. 
More character customisation. 
The unpredictable usage of old fav characters from prev series. 

Things that were missing:
I think a backdrop story relating to the main borderlands would have been helpful. I think a story where Tiny Tina discovers old DnD rulebooks and modifies it to her own rules because she is a lazy genius. She then kidnaps unwilling players to play her game. Thats where you the new player comes in, waking up strapped to a chair, answering basic questions as part of character customisation, as part of being interrogated by Tina to see if you are 'willing' to play her game and while she designs your character card/backstory. Rather than a tabletop and using imagination, she uses VR and tabletop. The game therefore switches back and forth between three 'worlds', VR (main game), tabletop (overworld), reality (cutscenes in the real world with dialog choices - these cutscenes can be short & initiated by the removal of the VR goggles to warn players, and then speaking to Tina and the other unwilling players in the reality. It can also sometimes be a small ingame window as per the older borderlands game). I think it would be cool where cutscenes showing what remains of previous players who refuse to voiceact for example or of Tina sometimes showing a mature side would really elevate the main story. In the end, the ultimate story of Tina really wanting to force finish this game as escapism for finding her parents and living happily ever after, but in the end settling for her friends instead and learning to form real relationships would be a more meaningful story but can also be as lighthearted/satirical as needed for a borderlands game. Sidequests will elude to various clues to tie in with the real world. It could have been a real gem of a story, with DLCs relating to backstories of the other characters in the real world. Also... claptrap didnt need to be the same old claptrap. A missed opportunity would have been to used him as the tutorial guide but in a different form, such as the hero he envisions himself as, as a throwback to earlier games. In fact, he could be the programmer for Tina's VR game, therefore funny glitches/malfunctions can happen in game. 
With a RPG focus, I think the inventory screen could be much better... its still the same sidebar even when within the inventory tab, there is so much wasted real estate on screen. 
Inability to switch spells on the fly like guns. If you are in a spell build, and your one equipped spell is ineffective against an enemy then its abit annoying. at least allowing players to equip 2 spells or quickswap would have been useful and easily implemented. Same for melee. Maybe could have made guns that double as melee weapons too.
Certain guns have lost all advantage. I found myself just selling any snipers and most bazookas i had. They were pretty useless in dps and since crits seldom one hit an enemy... not even 2 hit... probably 10+ headshots to down one. 
Borderlands enemies are typically interesting & unique but this one felt uninteresting due to fantasy elements being very explored by other games. They could have gone really wild with the characters here since its a meld between postapocalypse, cyberpunk, steampunk and medieval with a satirical setting. Instead we see goblins, skeletons, imps and mushroom people... really? Eg. i really liked their play on magic missle and the bardbarian... Im not sure why they couldnt go a little more unique on their enemy designs... Eg. Tina loves bunnies, why not use that instead. Rather than help a town besieged by skeletons yawn... Maybe a town of unwilling playactors dressed in bunny costumes besieged by redneck zombie werewolves or something. 

Bad stuff
I personally hate games that scatter hidden items that are crucial. Its ok if its just for fun to discover but items like the lucky dice which increases your loot luck makes it somewhat crucial to find. This game mechanic is there as a filler. It should be made 100pc optional. The game relies on gear discovery more than levelling up to progress as  a powerful character... so i think this is a huge oversight. As someone who works, I can only spend so much time playing a game. Thus to maximise efficiency, I found myself either scouring the edges of the map from the getgo, not being able to appreciate the handcrafted maps as it should, but instead looking out for the nooks and crannies. When NPCs start talking, Id wander off to stupid places like trying to climb roofs or jump ledges, where else in the past, Id pay more attention to the ingame scenes. The other option would be to check on the internet for the hidden locations and it becomes much more of a chore rather than a discovery. To all game designers please do not do this esp for AAA titles. Id say borderlands devolved abit when it became more reliant on such mechanics as a filler. 
There were other RPG elements they could have added instead such as dialogue choices, minigames, recruitable NPCs, skill checks, more fledging out of the melee combat. 
Instances in a grassfield akin to pokemon was annoying. I found myself running away whenever i could as they were so so meaningless.

Overall, I think this installment has played it safe here and because of that it was uninteresting. However, it does deliver a solid borderlands experience. To a newcomer, I wouldnt recommend this game though as it would just seem like a mixmash of mechanics which fails to deliver on what seems like crucial aspects of combat like melee/spellcasting (which to the usual borderlands fan is totally acceptable)

Despite my low play time shown here, I can safely say this game is absolutely worth a play if you like Borderlands or looter shooters in general. I played for over 135 hours on the Epic games store and bought it here anyway when it was on a good sale just for the convenience Steam provides.

It's not as good or as long a game as most Borderlands titles, but it's a goofy fun looter shooter that doesn't take itself seriously and lets you customize your character heavily. I'd love to see more entries into the Wonderlands IP since it brings features I love that wouldn't make sense in Borderlands, but with the tabletop fantasy/Pathfinder style setting here they can hand wave away anything as just "homebrew" and give the players basically anything to play with.

Definitely give it a shot, just don't expect the story to be anything too serious or heavy.

There's thing to love, but it feels like a 20 to 30€ game, not a full price one, and some design decisions are not really fun. You can't change your secondary class before you beat the game, you can't even change your main class even if your character is a pure blank slate. 

Thanksfully, Wonderlands Redux solve most of the issue, but modders shouldn't have to fix the game. 

It's still a good improvement around the base formula. Inclusion of Melee and revamp of life steal notably are great. 

Oh also, some class just don't work as well as others. Graveborn for example has synergies all over the place and can be a good main or sub while Clawbringer is kind of a one trick poney that isn't even that good at what it does.

Edit : 
Tried it again because the Wonderlands Redux overhaul mod seems awesome, and my opinion on the game just dropped lower. The mod is awesome, but the base game has some deep issues. UI notably is really bad. For example, if your cursor is on an element (or if the game decides your cursor is there on its own), even if you use arrows to highligh another element then press Enter, you'll in the one of the cursor, not the newly highlighted one. And there's a lot of menues, so UI issues are just stacking stress over time and it just feels that bad.

I know there will be a mod that tries to delete this comment, then promptly ban me from the forums because I am leaving a negative review, I also know there will be the orbiting rabid fans that will false flag my steam account because of this negative review. So, before I get into the game stuff, I thought It is high time someone mention this, and well it might as well be me.

I never thought I would see the borderlands fandom turn so foul that if you dislike an entry into the series, that no matter how peaceful and respectful you write a review out, you are then labelled a hater and a troll and must be censored. If you say you have been with borderlands since day one of the original game (i.e.: Borderlands Veteran) then you are labelled a bigoted exclusionary elitist (yes, this was actually said to me more than once) and censored then false flagged.  I did a well thought out respectful negative review for borderlands three, and next I know I had a mod try to VAC ban me on steam. Why? Because I was not gushing about the game. I always allow comments on my reviews, so I would love to know how a fandom community could go from laughing and enjoying tongue in cheek humor to give this game a glowing review otherwise you need to remove from the gaming platform.

Now as for Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. I will not lie; I picked up the Chaotic Great Edition as (at time of my review) the steam summer sale is going on, and if I could get it for $33 then why not? I mean sure, I had a very low interest in the game but I do love me Butt Stallion, so why not?

I lasted an hour before I said I had enough and put in for a refund, and here is why:

[b] Graphics [/b]
I have a rather beefy gaming computer. I mean I can play Monster Hunter Rise (released 2021) on Ultra getting 120 FPS. I can play Atomic Heart that was released four months ago (February 2023) on Ultra and get 120fps. However, when it comes to Tiny Tina's Wonderlands (released 2022) on low settings and get a weak 20 FPS., no thanks as I am not going to play a game the way I did seven years ago when I first started gaming.

[b] Tutorial [/b]
Remember when these used to words on a screen, or even an option to the game? Not in this game. You are actually taken by the hand and coddled through it. We are in 2023, who does not know how to walk or move in a game? At this point even those new to the franchise with this game knows the basics of Borderlands, so I am not sure who the baby treatment is for.

[b] Game play [/b]
When did the Bad Ess's (Steam will not let me say the real name) become weak wet paper bags? At level one I was taking down Bad Ess's like they were nothing, in fact I was taking them down in less than 30 seconds while using the randomized loot dropped from previous enemies (not the DLC stuff from the edition) Where did the challenge go? Same with the first level boss, less the two minutes he was done.

[b] Voice Acting [/b]
[i] IAshly Burch (Tiny Tina) [/i] is back, and it is always a joy to hear how she plays the role. 

[i] IWanda Sykes (Fretta) [/i] I always adored both her acting and voice acting, as I find she is a great comedy and fits wonderfully in any role she is give.

[i] Will Arnett (Dragon Lord aka Bo Jack) [/i] A fantastic replacement for [i] IDameon Clarke (Handsome Jack) [/i]. If I was not laughing so hard at what Will Arnett popped off with, I would wonder how many lines he ad libbed.

[i] IAndy Samberg  (Captain Valentine)  [/i] I wanted to reach through the screen and smack the hell out of this character.

Now, after all that, I will not recommend you buy this game. However, I am also not going to recommend someone buy this game. It is your money, it is your interest, and it is your time into the game that is going to be vested. This has been my experience and my opinion on the game nothing more or less.

Title: A Disappointing Spin-off That Fails to Capture the Magic - Tiny Tina's Wonderlands

Rating: ⭐⭐

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands, the spin-off title in the Borderlands universe, sadly falls short of expectations and fails to deliver the same level of excitement and enjoyment as its predecessors. Despite its charming premise and attempts to inject humor and fantasy elements into the gameplay, the overall execution leaves much to be desired.

One of the biggest letdowns in Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is the lackluster storytelling. While the Borderlands series is known for its witty writing and engaging narratives, this spin-off struggles to find a cohesive and compelling story. The humor feels forced and often falls flat, and the plot fails to create a sense of investment or intrigue. The attempts to blend fantasy elements with the established Borderlands universe feel disjointed and disconnected, resulting in an underwhelming and confusing narrative experience.

Furthermore, the gameplay in Tiny Tina's Wonderlands fails to impress. The combat lacks depth and strategy, often devolving into repetitive button-mashing with little variation or challenge. The character progression system feels shallow, with limited options for customization and advancement. The overall gameplay loop becomes monotonous quickly, with little incentive to continue playing beyond the initial novelty.

The visual presentation of Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a mixed bag. While the game retains the colorful and cel-shaded art style that is synonymous with the Borderlands series, it feels uninspired and lacks the visual flair that made its predecessors stand out. The environments, while varied, lack the level of detail and creativity that would have enhanced the fantasy-themed setting. Additionally, the technical performance can be inconsistent, with occasional frame rate drops and graphical glitches.

Another notable drawback is the lack of substantial multiplayer features. While the Borderlands franchise has thrived on its cooperative gameplay experience, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands fails to deliver a satisfying multiplayer component. The cooperative play feels tacked on and lacks the depth and seamless integration found in previous titles, resulting in a less enjoyable and cohesive multiplayer experience.

In conclusion, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a disappointing spin-off that fails to capture the magic of the Borderlands series. From its lackluster storytelling and unimpressive gameplay to its underwhelming visual presentation and subpar multiplayer features, the game falls short in nearly every aspect. While it may appeal to die-hard fans of the franchise or those seeking a lighthearted and simplistic gaming experience, it ultimately fails to deliver a satisfying and engaging adventure.

[h1]Post Game "Completion" Update[/h1]
Me and the friends I played with didn't actually end up finishing the game, but we got to the final boss. I wanted to add my updated notes to the end of my last review but It somehow way surpassed the text limit (lol) so I'm gonna just try and reformat my thoughts Into a condensed checklist.

I only played BL2 before this game and did not play the DLC this Is based on. I went In with 2 friends and came out with 0 (sorry for making you guys play this shit). 

[b]TL:DR -[/b] Game has Incredible themeing and has gorgeous art design and world, but Is very boring, repetitive and tedious. Extremely overpriced and feels lazy and lackluster compared to other games In the franchise. Don't bother with this one.

[b][u]Pros[/u][/b]
[list]
   [*] Character customisation.
   [*] Gorgeous art direction. The world and setting Is colourful, creative and fantastic.
   [*] Some epic cutscene moments and cool character Introductions.
   [*] Fantasy theming.
   [*] Some cool magical spells, abilities and classes.
   [*] More diversity and inclusivity.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons[/u][/b]
[list]
   [*] Game Is overpriced EVEN on sale. $30 Is more than me and my friends would spend on most games, and that was this game on HALF price.
   [*] Character customisation Is lackluster. You can pick a voice but they all say the same things and lack the unique and fun personalities of characters from other Borderlands games.
   [*] Player voices are all British (I think) but voiced by Americans and It's.. Noticeable..
   [*] Levels feel extremely closed off / boxed In and repetitive. A lot of really small instances, but some bigger levels here and there.
   [*] Levels are connected via invisible wall instead of the more immersive gates and such as other Borderlands and feels awkward at times.
   [*] Random encounters and side quests feel half arsed and are extremely repetitive and BORING.
   [*] Story missions feel randomly strung together and not cohesive (like this checklist).
   [*] Half of the game feels like 0 effort went Into It. Some incredible scenes happen In the main story just for you to walk into an invisible wall and have your immersion ruined, before transitioning to a lame DnD board overworld.
   [*] DnD overworld Is kind of funny at first, but It takes you out of whats going on and feels like a drag to navigate later on.
   [*] Most weapons feel very clunky and weak, and most of them don't even feel like they fit the weapon they are meant to be, like shotguns where you aim down the sight and zoom In super far?
   [*] Melee weapons do NO damage and you feel punished for getting up close to do a melee attack when the guns do 10x the damage.
   [*] Store Is confusing. Me and my other 2 friends sold all our items by mistake the first time we used It due to the weird formatting.
   [*] Combat doesn't feel as satisfying, you don't really notice as many colourful numbers popping up as you did In other games whilst dealing damage.
   [*] Extremely repetitive enemies. There Is a small amount of diversity here and there, but I hope you enjoy fighting skeletons for 90% of the game.
   [*] Very hard to tell when someone dies In this game. Barely any sound effect or visual cue compared to previous games.
   [*] DLC Is shoved In your face In some areas and by the looks of their reviews, I guess you don't wanna buy that-
   [*] Visual bugs like showing players as being dead when they are not, or having pop ups stuck on the screen.
   [*] Being forced to listen to characters talk forever as the map refuses to let you progress until they STFU. Happens way too often and feels like It just wants to drag more playtime out of you.
   [*] Map Is too clunky to control or use.
   [*] Main story level progression Is too extreme. From one story mission to the next, It will jump up 5 to almost 10 levels.
   [*] You need to do side missions to progress some of the story but they are not MARKED as your main story so you can get lost or confused.
   [*] Side quests that have you find items just spawn them In a fat chest at the end of 50 tiny crappy instances Instead of being found naturally In the world.
   [*] Spells target enemies you're not even aiming at.
   [*] Fights that have many allies and foes don't show healthbars so you can't tell who's on your team or not.
   [*] Characters teleporting to the next location or vanishing Instead of walking there.
   [*] Story feels disjointed or Idk how half of It Is even meant to be connected?
   [*] Healthbar hitboxes are bigger than some enemies so will show you a healthbar for an enemy you're not focusing on.
   [*] Giant bricks having the physics of styrofoam.
   [*] [spoiler]Finding an object to help you cross an "invisible bridge" that you just FALL THROUGH without the object? The definition of Invisible changed apparently.[/spoiler]
   [*] Hordes of enemies spamming the EXACT SAME SOUNDS..
   [*] Too many quests requiring you to just "kill every enemy". These missions could repeat up to 7+ TIMES per level.
   [*] For said quest one of our enemies got stuck underwater some how and we COULDN'T kill them.
   [*] Being attacked whilst you're already DEAD.
   [*] Bug where my character was unkillable.
   [*] Story cutscene knocked my friend off a ledge and triggered the checkpoint at the start of the map. He was stuck there until we got a new one.
   [*] Too many tanky shield regen bosses that are just BORING and unfun to play against.
   [*] Bugged quest marker on minimap.
   [*] Friend teleported somewhere I don't think he was meant to be (looked like a dev edit space).
   [*] Can't change your secondary class until finishing the game (despite the tool tip suggesting otherwise).
   [*] Getting a kill can revive you but friends and status effects can easily steal these kills.
   [*] Some bosses charge and move way faster than you and you have no dodge or mobility moves to counter this.
   [*] Basic enemies being tedious and near unkillable sometimes.
   [*] Friend grinding to reccomended level of 30 only for his enemies to also level up to about 37 anyway.
   [*] Friend dying during a LOADING screen despite entering It full HP and getting fined for It.
   [*] Changing the difficulty doesn't make a difference.
   [*] Final boss has no music and Is a clusterfuck of unfair anti-fun bullshit.
   [*] Story just kind of sucks and gets extremely annoying, despite having some cool moments here and there.
[/list]

This game is absolutely awful. Credit where it's due, the weapons are awesome. Outside of that, NOTHING but trash. Enjoy fighting skeletons and sometimes a crab or two in every single level throughout the entire game, all repeating the same screaming audio line overlayed a hundred times, more and more enemies spawning out of nowhere constantly, enemies all having way more health than they should for no reason, a boring and disjointed world of various places separated by an overworld because it feels like the devs were too lazy to make a full map, the most uninteresting quests of any game i've ever played, and cringeworthy fake accents.
Me and two friends played borderlands 2 and absolutely loved it, so we chose this as the next game to play together. We all hated this one. One of them got so bored he gave up with the game, but me and the other friend agreed to try finish it if i did a bit of grinding to make it less agonising. So i did a bit of grinding which i didn't mind because like i said the loot is pretty interesting, but then after i spent 5 hours getting to level 29 so I was more prepared for this level 30 final mission, all the enemies were suddenly level 38. They literally now outlevel my friend who played normally without grinding by 16 levels. I'm basically at the recommended level, with enchanted legendary gear and elemental advantages, yet some of the enemies including the boss actually regen their shield faster than i can damage them. Also worth noting we were playing on easy mode, which didn't feel like it changed anything.
We quickly changed our minds about finishing the game. The fact that this game has level scaling but only uses it to make the game less enjoyable speaks volumes about what to expect from this game.
What a miserable experience. I want my money and my time back.
Fun D&D-like game with guns and jokes

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is just more of the same if you are looking to play more BL3 with a fantasy element to it. That's not really a bad thing since BL3 was a blast to play. This is just more of the same with some added stuff so it doesn't feel exactly like a BL3 extended DLC. 
It does add a lot of interesting stuff to the overall game-play. Guns feel powerful and the classes and being able to multi class is just a really fun addition to the game. 
Game-play is Solid. If you just want more Borderlands loot and shoot action, pick this game up (preferably on sale.) 

What really let me down was the humor, story, character writing, and overall vibe of the story. It's a bit weird that your Bunker and Badasses mates don't have a character of their own and they just tell the player what to do with some VERY lame banter. It was really hard to connect with them since they were just disembodied voices with no way to interact with them. I can't believe they were able to make Andy Samberg lame and boring. 

The side quests don't really have any humor or wittyness to them. I especially hated the Witcher quest where they just made Garret to be an asshat and that's the joke. That whole story-line just felt like someone who hated the witcher wanted to spite witcher fans. 

The main storyline was also very boring. It had no payoff, no suspense, nothing. It's just Tina being the worst kind of DM and never really getting punished for it. She never learned to let her players do the storytelling and rolling with the punches. No one really grows as characters in the story as well. The main bad guy has no payoff to him as well. 

There are some pretty alright jokes and jabs to TTRPG and D&D tropes, but it was pretty few and far between. 
I was also disappointed that there wasn't a lot of returning characters in this game. I was really waiting for Mordecai but he never shows up, or anybody else other than Brick and Mr. Torgue. 


Overall and TL;DR:
Great gameplay and graphics, horrible everything else. Pick it up when it's on sale.

I do not like when games have marriage and relationship stuff in them (straight or homosexual) because it takes away from the enjoyable selling points of the game, if a game would like to have that stuff in the game it should be part of the selling points instead of forcing it down peoples throat. I just want to play a shooting game why is it so important for the devs to have homosexual relationship in so many quest?

Ok. So 86 hours on record. I'll put it this way, this game is "not as great as I was expecting" IT IS STILL GOOD THOUGH. The story line was worth the play through though. It is a grinding game. The endgame content is somewhat lackluster since it's just chaos dungeons which are essentially just pushing the game difficulty as high as you can. I wish there was a little more diversity in the builds you could make but every time someone releases a video of a strong build it gets nerfed or you have to grind hours to get the gear maxed rolls. Thats the other downside. The RNG of gear is SO BAD. It's hard enough to find the damn item you want but it's another thing to get the rolls you want. The effects on the gear are not static which makes it even worse! Once you do find the item with the rolls you want though you notice the difference. Getting the right gear and the right stats makes a HUGE difference in our damage. Not sure I will play until chaos 100 it's a bit to much of a grind seeing all the same enemies but just more hp/damage from them. Needless to say I got 86 hours out of the game so it was worth the money. Story 8/10 because "I love explosions" but it did feel a little short. End game 5/10 theres only 1 way to push "chaos" levels. Loot 4/10 RNG is so bad affecting the stats and the item effects is just bad design when it could already take 100 hours just to get perfect stat rolls on the right effects but now you have to factor in even just getting the right effects on the item it might take me years, not fun. Overall though 7.5/10 I love that I can make a build around using spells or guns, or melee, or even my companion although balancing is clearly hard. Guns/companions feel weak imo but there are guides that show it's possible to push highish chaos with them.

I would LOVE this game and put hundreds of hours into it if I could just shoot enemies and sift through their loot. This game is not made for you to easily shoot people and sift through their loot. This game is made for you to be forced into watching and listening to unskippable custscenes/dialogue/animations. This was the major problem with Borderlands 3 and it has persisted here. Seriously, this sucks. I genuinely hate to see one of my favorite series do bad for NO OTHER REASON than the developers put as many unskippable narrative moments into their shooter as possible. This is a looter shooter, not Skyrim. But, EVEN IN SKYRIM YOU CAN SKIP ALMOST ALL OF THE DIALOGUE AND CUT-SCENES IF YOU WANT TO, SERIOUSLY GEARBOX TAKE A HINT! WHO THINKS ITS OKAY TO NEVER SKIP ANY DIALOGUE OR CUT-SCENES OR CHARACTER ANIMATIONS IN YOUR STUDIO??? 

Did you guys like actually sit through any of your dialogue more than once? Did you think it was worth listening to more than three times? Did you listen to it while pretending you would rather shoot stuff than listen to someone flap their gums? I won't be buying the next title you guys release as a shooter, even after playing all of the borderlands games throughout my life. I get the feeling you guys have forgotten about your customers that just want to shoot stuff, and I mean JUST WANT TO SHOOT STUFF, not EVER be forced into listening to things that I am physically required to stand directly next to. Even Borderlands 1 and 2 had the option to listen to people through some kind of long distance stuff if you walked away from them, you guys stopped doing that on purpose and it was one of the worst design decisions I have ever seen a developer make. 

This was so bad in Borderlands 3 that during my contract in The Navy I didn't have time between duty shifts to finish some of the unskippable narrative moments in that game with how long they were. That kind of development process is alive and well here. With respect to all of the time everyone has wasted on moments they could have skipped, respectfully, screw you guys and your failing studio that can't ship games with a 'skip' button.

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands seemed to struggle to truly find its identity and is left feeling as though it desperately leans on the formula that made previous Borderlands titles majorly successful, whilst it does attempts to build on said formula none of it’s new features ever truly seem to shine through as phenomenal additions and even begun to feel jarring towards the games conclusion. With that said it isn’t all bad the games looter shooter design and gunplay mechanics make it undeniably fun to mow down waves of enemies but is never truly enough for Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands to identify as anything more than a carbon copy of all the other entries in the Borderland series.

Right from the Opening Credits Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands oozes with the colourful charm and on the nose humour that its predecessors were beloved for, however I couldn't help but feel as though the writers had limited their sense of creativity by binding themselves to the theme of Dungeons and Dragons, this is felt exponentially through it’s main campaign that at times felt stale, uninspired, and as if the writers never truly knew where to go with the games overall story and theme. What started as a very tongue in cheek take on the self proclaimed “Worlds Greatest Roleplaying Game”, pretty quickly became a handful of jokes about the most common tropes and clichés that have been recited to death in other forms of media. On many occasions I found myself pulled from my enjoyment by one of these various clumsily delivered quips that left me wanting for something more that didn’t feel like a second hand joke that had been pulled from the mouth of someone much more charismatic. The main campaign felt rushed and as though the inclusion of side quests was only to extend the average time it takes to reach the story's climax. At the time of review I have spent just under 20 hours in Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands with roughly over half of that spent deviating from the main campaigns path in order to reach the level recommendations for each quest, which resulted in slogging through many forgettable quests that just never truly captured that Borderlands charm. The story is told through the form of an in-universe version of D&D known as Bunkers & Badasses and is rather excellently narrated by the prolific voice over talent in Ashley Burch who returns to reprise her role as Tiny Tina, throughout the main story Tina as the “Bunker Master” guides her players through a wild and haphazardly thrown together Bunkers & Badasses campaign which sees the Player referred to as “Newbie” and the other players at the Table, Frett & Valentine, take on the evil forces of The Dragon Lord. Whilst the voiceover work that is put on display is top notch and the cast boasts names such as Ashley Burch, Andy Samburg and Wanda Sykes their terrific performances are never quite enough to save the campaign from itself and fail to make up for the very apparent rushed and lazy writing. I found myself giving a resounding sigh of relief at the sight of the games end credits and was left with no real desire to continue on with what remained of Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands clearly lazily thrown together side content.

For the most part Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands minute to minute gameplay loop is undeniably fun, however it seems to fall apart during the implementation of its new features that mostly feel ill-thought-out and at times tacked on to artificially increase the amount of time Gearbox could keep their players in game. The decision to completely remove vehicular travel and combat in favour for the new Overworld that seemed out of place and better implemented by games akin to Nino Kuni and Final Fantasies of old was a flawed design choice that not only had me feeling detached from the game world but has ensured that Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands has had more loading screens than most modern AAA titles. Unfortunately the cures of the new Overworld feature doesn’t end there, clearly added to the game in order to implement the new “Random Encounters'' that are a blatant design choice to reduce the amount of quality content needed to fill the game world. These random encounters see the player put into a small handful of encounter maps fighting a smaller diversity in enemy types making this new feature a very unwelcome one. My time in Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands was spent on their “balanced” or normal difficulty which was anything but balanced, leaving many of their bosses and minions feeling super easy to mow down and as though I was never in any real threat. My recommendation to anyone choosing to pick up Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands over any of the other entries into the Borderlands series is to play this game on its hardest difficulty in order to have the most enjoyable experience. Despite my harsh criticism the feature that I’d like to commend Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands for is their new class system that sees the player choosing from one of six classes that each are a take on typical character tropes from Dungeons & Dragons, this feature removes the character selection from previous Borderlands games and offers the player more choice in the character they want to play, this feature reaches greater depths once the player unlocks the capability to “Multiclass” giving them the chance to pick up a second one of the six classes. I spent my time playing a combination of the Clawbringer and Spellshot that gave me access to the wyvern companion and later multiclassing into the Spellshot heavily boosted the usefulness of my spells which take the place of grenades from the games of old. This combination of classes really allowed me to feel increasingly stronger the further along each skill tree I found myself going down. Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands gunplay is one of its best features, this however is overshadowed by the fact that it is still the basic combat and gameplay loop that other Borderlands games that in the past were renowned for  and resulted in it once again leaning on that Borderlands crutch in an attempt to fight for relevance.

To summarise, Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands never truly manages to find its way out of the shadow of its predecessors and ultimately suffers from its lack of identity, whilst a fun but short experience it struggles under the weight of expectation that comes with the territory of being a spin off of a widely beloved series. After the curtain fell on its lacklustre campaign I couldn’t help but feel as though Gearbox Software never truly gave Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands the love and attention it needed to truly flourish into the game it tried to be. I cannot in good faith recommend this game at its full asking price but do believe it’s a valuable pick up on a hefty discount and believe that despite its glaring flaws there is still a fun experience underneath to be had. During my time with Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands I couldn’t help but feel as though this should have and would have been a great DLC inclusion to a main line Borderlands game instead of the half baked solo release that we received. My harsh criticisms come from a place of wanting Gearbox to recapture the love and attention older Borderlands games had in spades and not succumb in putting out soulless releases that rely heavily on the legacy of older games that other studios have become guilty of mass producing. Ultimately I had fun with Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands but couldn’t shake the unbearable feeling that it could have been so much more.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is an absolute blast that takes the Borderlands universe to a whole new level of whimsical mayhem. With its imaginative setting, hilarious humor, and addictive gameplay, it offers an unforgettable and exhilarating experience. The game's vibrant and fantastical world, filled with mythical creatures and larger-than-life bosses, creates a sense of wonder and excitement at every turn. The addition of magic spells, epic loot, and the ability to customize your character adds depth and replayability to the gameplay. The witty writing, quirky characters, and the lovable Tiny Tina herself make for an unforgettable journey filled with laughter and surprises. Get ready to embark on a wild and unpredictable adventure that blends the best of fantasy and first-person shooting. The story line is a bit fun but short.  There's very little interest in the side quests.  There's just not a lot of story to them.  Like a lot of people I started on BL2 where the tirade over the radio about butt stallion was so hilarious we'd keep referencing it.  We would laugh about all the funny things that torgue said and hunt for the funny possessed gun that yells at you. On the many MANY replays. 

There's not really anything quotable in this game.  Which is surprising since Tina is such a great character normally. The others sorta make appearances and that's fun but that's about it. 

Your skills are blurred between the different characters so even though one might start with better skills for a sniper nothing is really a big difference. 

The game play it repetitive.  None of the bosses are very challenging.  You just spam away and they die. 

Once you get through the story which doesn't take long you're leveled out.  You get orange things all the time. Gold keys are kinda pointless at this level because the chest doesn't get you anything better than you get for normal dungeon grinds.  You can get a currency to add an enchantment to your weapon but you cap out anytime you run the dungeons so it's not hard to get tons more.  And the enchantments don't really add much. 

For the price it was just really disappointing. And buggy.  You have companions that show as dead on your hud but are fine.  Teammates show as dead or no health when they're actually fine.  You loose your mini map icons randomly including that of your teammate. Just riddled with bugs. 

Basically I play whenever my friends want to run a dungeon but otherwise it's just not worth a replay.

Definitely worth it while it's on sale, but don't bother with DLCs, especially at full price. 

This entry into the series is by far the least polished, with multiple bugs found throughout a relatively short (for a borderlands game) campaign. There was surely more to the story at some point, but it must have been cut, because I beat the campaign in about 8 hours (don't let my playtime fool you, i left my pc on idle over three play sessions). 

When you think of completing all the quests (both main and side) in a Borderlands game, you envision an endeavor that may take weeks, if not a month or two, as each location is overflowing with side quests. In Tiny Tina's wonderland, each map has <6 side quests, meaning that my 2nd playthrough (100% quests on Intense mode) only took me about a day. A Borderlands pro can probably knock it out in an afternoon.

The game had the potential to be a lot more than what it ended up being, but with the pandemic interrupting the development process and everyone having to work from home... well, let's just say it shows. Still, a pretty fun experience, wouldn't want to pay full price though. 

Unfortunately the devs released extremely buggy and lackluster DLCs and then abandoned this game, so don't hold out any hope for future updates. There is little to do post-game, as they replaced TVHM/UVHM with an endless "chaos" dungeon which borrows heavily from the roguelike genre. It's honestly not worth the effort though, as by this point you are earning incremental (like, 1%) buffs to your stats (as the level cap is a ridiculously low lvl40), and there isn't anything to DO with the guns you get from the chaos runs except do more chaos runs. It's fun for a few, but quickly feels shallow and repetitive.  

Likely the team is working on the next installment in the Borderlands franchise, and honestly I didn't mind all the flashy spells and lack of gore, I actually prefer the spells to grenades as they are more powerful and easier to control, but the writing suffered from the ESRB restrictions. I hope they abandon the T for Tina rating and go back to their roots, a full-length M rated Tiny Tina's 2 would be at the top of my wishlist.

I purchased the game for 40USD and I think that was a bit expensive for what it delivers. The gameplay is clearly oriented around multiple players and as a solo all of the combat arenas last just a bit too long. The game gives you no time to experiment with the classes but I realized that without a class that provides a companion your DPS is significantly throttled. Overall the game just feel very slow. You have to stop to open chest, often taking quite a few precious seconds in the middle of combat. And the random loot is never worth killing enemies for compared to buying items from the shops. The narrative is really weak, often introducing bosses in the same battle you fight them which removes any narrative payoff you could derive from building. The games movement, dialogue, and art are all superb. Though, in another annoying instance of slowing the game down, you cannot skip through diegetic cutscenes. This leaves you to often jump around a room simply waiting for the NPCs to get through their long winded dialogue. 

In summary, the game is just a bit too slow and it fairly straight-forward take on the looter shooter genre doesn't hardly justify the asking price of 60USD. I would recommend it for 15USD.

I have some complaints, but it's generally really good and a solid entry to the series.
TTW takes a different approach to the theme of the Borderlands franchise, being set in a world of fantasy and magic controlled by the bunkermaster; Tiny Tina. This looter-shooter can be very satisfying but also feel a little off in a few ways: 
1) Loot drops feel really lame, and there is a major reason for this. Your chance of getting rare loot has a lot to do with how many lucky dice you have found, and how far you are through the game. This can leave new players feeling like the loot pool isn't rewarding. But after getting into the mechanic it does play into my completionist mentality and does finally manage to win me over in the end.
2) The soundtrack is designed with the theme in mind; it feels a little airy and mystical while previous entries felt energetic, mysterious and exciting. I also feel the volume in this game is really low and I cant hear dialogue clearly even at full volume. 
3) There aren't really any main characters in this one, the idea is that you make a custom character to play with. And while this can open up some creativity it can feel devoid of the personality from previous entries.
4) Being a mock DND session, there is a lot of story changes happening all around you as Tina dictates the action, sometimes it's really fun and exciting, while other times it feels like a cop-out to having the writers plan out the story better.
5) Random encounters on the overworld map are a nod to more classic games but they make the smooth gameplay of the Borderlands series feel clunky. I am learning to be thankful for the traditional open world fighting the game still has to offer. 

The levels are fun, imaginative and well designed. The spells are interesting and unique, albeit a little weak. The classes are all really fun to play around with and feel powerful. The story telling is intentionally a little awkward but still plenty funny and interesting.

Not sure why so many people complained about this game being too short, it took me over 40 hours to finish the story with still a few side quests to do and plenty of collectables left to gather. That's plenty of game and honestly it got a bit samey after a while anyway. After about halfway through you've pretty much seen all the enemy types in the game so the combat can get repetitive. That said it is also very fun if you're just after more Borderlands. The inclusion of spells is a nice change from grenades for the franchise, though I'll admit I pretty much used only 1 or 2 different spell types because having to hold down a button for several seconds looking at the point you want to cast a spell leaves you a vulnerable so got annoying. Good variety of classes and more interesting perk upgrades than usual.

Now the bad stuff. The game is way too easy. I rarely died and if I did it was because I missed a jump or accidentally bashed an exploding barrel thinking it was a regular one. Most boss fights were over within a matter of seconds with no strategy needed to defeat them. Ammo crates are spammed every 5 metres you walk so you never run out of ammo and have to change weapon so you only do so when you get bored. The UI is pretty poor. For example, to put a way point down on the map you think it would make sense that you could just click on the map where your mouse cursor is right? Well apparently not, because you have to drag your mouse across the screen to move the map cursor to the point on the map you want the way point to be. It's really awkward. Also the characters in the game apart from Tiny Tina are really lame and annoying. Not quite as bad as in BL3 but not far off. It was cringe inducing stuff.

There's a good game to be had, but the incessant chatter from cringey dialogue and laughably easy combat makes it easy to forget that the core gun play is the only thing holding this game together.

I have really enjoyed my 50+ hours in Tiny Tina's.  It's appeal is a Borderlands style comedy and adventure mixed in with homage and references to Dungeons and Dragons.  If you enjoy FPS gun play and loot pinata like Borderlands Looter Shooter gameplay then I'd urge you to give this one a shot.  I'm a bit of a completionist and 50hrs into the game I'm still probably 10hrs from the end of the main story.  There's post-game and some cool things to do and discover when you're done with the main storyline.  It's a shame that it wasn't more popular than it is but I think it was definitely worth it for the money and I'd pay full price for it again in a heartbeat.  Also, the multiplayer is fun as hell and just as much of a blast as Borderlands.

Pro:
* Funny writing.
* Beyond-imaginative world.
* By-the-book exploration.
* Beautiful graphics and good sounds.

Cons:
* The whole frikking gunplay. I mean, what's even going on here. Normal difficulty: A 5th-level, absolutely lowly mob takes 2 headshots from a unique 5th-level sniper rifle with flat damage bigger than anything else. A 12th-level melee fighter with the biggest, rarest, two-handed weapon and all skill points invested in a melee tree still has to smash three times into a common mob to kill it. Submachine guns have generally 3-5x less flat damage than a pistol (!!). Okay, I get it. Supposedly, that should be balanced by the rate of fire. What a joke. What good is the rate of fire if I have to empty half a clip into one single mob.  Don't get me even started on tougher enemies. Weapons in general are either powerful but shoot in ways that are weird and cumbersome (whereas enemies move to and fro as if on cocaine) or are shooting straight but are "rightfully" much weaker. 


You might say this gets better later on, when you supplement the weapons with passives and abilities. No, it does not. Once in 5 hours you get a weapon that, by some miracle, operates on sane levels at least two more hours, before it becomes under-par, or an inventory mod that could technically make one more skill work wonders if only you had those other two mods that would complement it, and you would search for them another 5 hours, and once you get those, the mods are already outperformed, and... AAAAARRGGGH!

This was most of my experience with Tiny Tina's. I am no stranger to FPSs; I've always done my successful builds in many ARPGs or FPS/RPG hybrids to satisfactory levels. I've played and mostly loved everything Borderlands with some exceptions of some weird choices in BIII. This... this is just no.

I finished the game because of the scenery, humor, and imagination. But gameplay-wise it was a frikking chore to begin with and ended the same.
This is conditional, don't buy this game and play by yourself. You will fall asleep. Play with friends and it makes the experience worth it.

FYI:
- Purchased during half-off sale.

Yay: 
- RPG elements galore.
- Interesting character classes.
- Random loot generation feels good. 
- Combat feels good.
- Nice character customization; lots of cosmetics that unlock through game play.
- Some of the visuals are legitimately breathtaking.
- Nice voice acting, though the writing does the cast a disservice.
- Runs surprisingly well; no technical issues thus far, only the occasional wacky rag doll physics.

Meh:
- The NPCs are bland; majority of characters severely lack in personality, perhaps with the exception of a few cameo characters from Borderlands.
- The writing is bland, and some dialogue drags on far longer than it needs to.
- Excessive use of invisible walls in some places.
- Mimics.

Overall:
- It's certainly not the next Borderlands. It's a "Teen" rated first-person shooter D&D campaign, as DM'd by a crazy teenager. With that in mind, it's quite a fun game!

This is an okay game to play to around Chaos Level 60. After that your damage cannot be bursted to a level where playing is fun. If you search around the web, you learn that there are a few bosses that can take 20-60 minutes to grind down, the Son-Of-A-Witch (Wastard) being the most infamous, Knight Mare and Dry'l standing just behind. You take instant down damage from basically all sources, and grind the boss for 20 minutes, because after Ascended gear the game does not really provide a meaningful way to boost your own damage. If I compare this gameplay to BL2 overlevels, BL2 scales much better. Story-wise this isn't as fun as BL2 was, but it has its moments! I do not regret buying this, it was fun for many hours, but the endgame lacks content: You just grind chambers after another, and after getting around chaos level 60 (these are end game levels you get by completing chaos trials) the bosses scale much more than you do. Trash mobs are not the problem, but some bosses are. They are not impossible, but they just take so much time to complete that it isn't worth the invested time anymore.

The (base) game is not worth the 60€ price tag and probably not even the 30€ that I got it at. Skyrim with My Little Pony mod installed feels more Borderlands than this.

The story of the game follows the familiar Borderlands format, with two caveats: there's basically no NPCs that follow you through the story, which is incredibly short. Sure, Tiny Tina and the Bad Guy narrate your adventures, but you're not regularly interacting with any recurring NPCs and there's very few familiar faces scattered about. For example, I would've expected Roland and Mr. Torgue to play significant parts in the game, what with their relationships with Tina. NPCs, in general, are entirely forgettable, with some minor exceptions.

While the overworld map that connects all of the different zones is a neat idea and I like the various items scattered across it, I feel that it is very lacking in execution and is thoroughly undermined by the fast travel system. Either the overworld or the fast travel system should not exist. Additionally, the approximately four or five maps that are there for the so-called combat/random encounters in the overworld get incredibly boring, incredibly fast. 

Speaking of maps, they are all very generic fantasy natural-scenery maps: there's a bit of grasslands, woods, city, sea floor and pirate beach. These are all fine and dandy, but the variety is significantly lacking in comparison to prior Borderlands titles. There's no volcano or underground biomes, for example, and what maps are there are very unimpressive visually.

The maps feature four primary factions: skeletons, greenskins, fungi and coiled (naga). None of the four factions have distinct mechanics or gameplay elements; there's nothing along the lines of skeletaurs, goliaths or hyperion bots at least before whatever is the equivalent of TVHM in this game. Technically, there's also pirates and bandits, but these are barely even visually distinct from skeletons, let alone mechanically. Scattered between the forces of the main factions are some fantastical beasts, such as wyverns and dogfish, which do distinguish themselves from one another.

With the fantasy theme come spells, which replace grenades and come with an automatic recharge mechanic. While some spells are incredibly powerful and feel great to activate as they can destroy an entire wave of enemies and put a huge dent even into badasses, most spells are lackluster and usually worse than firing a gun. The variety of spells is pretty good, but I wish that anything besides fissures actually had any "oomph" at all. For example, meteors come with a significant cast delay and have _tiny_ impact areas by comparison and absurd recharge times to boot.

Alongside spells there are the class-based skills. There are exactly three interesting skills: polymorph, invisibility and reaper of bones, though ambi-hextrous deserves an honorable mention for conceding that the spells are strictly more interesting than the action skills. Everything else is of the format "press button to deal damage", which is confusing at best considering how easily many of the action skills in Borderlands titles could have been reskinned with a fantasy theme. 

Skill modifiers also do not exist, which combined with the above leads to every class feeling basically the same despite having extremely distinct themes. Your choices are to either shoot at stuff or hit them with your sword/axe/mace. None of the skill trees feel like a substantial change to how I play the game.

As there is only a single skill tree for every class, an opportunity to "multiclass" is presented. This essentially means slapping on the passives from another class to your initially chosen class. Don't forget to google the skill trees before you lock in, because the game does not actually give you any indication as to what the choice entails beyond a "this class is good at fire damage" when choosing and I don't know whether it is even possible to choose again. Nor do I really care, because why would I when there is essentially no difference?

You can freely choose your character's body shape, pronoun and voice independent of one another, which is nice, I guess, if I cared about any of that and if all of them weren't so incredibly bland. I have always enjoyed the various quips, puns and dialogue of the Borderlands player characters, but that does not materialize here.

All characters look essentially the same and outfits — the visually most distinctive part of your character — are tied to your class mod. There seems to only be a small handful of variants, all of which look the same. If you thought you could be a robot-ninja-pirate, think again. The color/pattern alterations you can make to your outfit are also incredibly bland and require you to find them as drops from enemies or from collectibles scattered around the world. If you thought Borderlands 3 had bad customization options with the ugly-ass head and body options, you really don't want to see what Wonderlands has to offer.

TL;DR: it's bland. Buying and playing the DLC again is a better use of your time and money.

This game honestly addressed all of the bullshit, lame and utterly juvenile problems that I had with the BL series. This game took the best of all of them, made it have it's own colorful and amazing style and added classes, game-play and just irrefutable FUN that's fucking cherry.

I was goddamn-near repulsed, vomitously sickened with what they called "humor in the BL games". And here I am, a few hours in, and haven't had to deal with  anything like that. Monsters and loot are great, the story is fun and unpredictable (and who wouldn't want Tina as your DM? She embodies the crazy-cool girl.)

I could keep going on and on, but to keep it simple, this game alone has made my faith in Gearbox resurgent. One of the most fun games I've played in some time. (And just a tip, for beginners wanting a fun class combo, go with Spore Warden and then at lvl 40 when you get Mythical you can add another, choose CLAWBRINGER. why? Spore warden has a companion and tons of buffs for your poison-spewing mushroom, but then then Clawbringer has a dragon, and get this: ALL OF THE COMPANION BUFFS ARE RETROACTIVE, and the dragon is already powerful as fuck anyway. So you essentially become a one man/woman/? MAELSTROM. This doesn't even say anything about your personal abilities as well as spells you'll be slinging along with gun/swordplay. See what I'm saying? You become a one man wrecking crew.

(As a really important aside when it comes to including our friends, THERE ARE TONS OF OPTIONS FOR THE LGBTQ? community. Probably the most I've ever seen in a game. And it always makes me feel great to know I supported a company that cares about ALL their players.)

I will stop there, to those of you who were tired of the whole "space redneck" montage of Borderlands, and JESUS, FUCK-ME CHRIST WAS IT SO GODDAMN ANNOYING, please, fear no longer. This game has everything we were looking for otherwise. Probably in my top 10 of all time.

As it's pretty much just a Borderlands game, I'll only point out what would be different:
1. you start off with only one skill tree for your class. You will unlock the ability to choose a skill tree from another class later on. After you finish the main story, you can change your second skill tree to any other class in the game.
2. There is no New game plus or "True Vault Hunter mode". I'm a bit disappointed by that. The game is pretty easy, and I was hoping for a meaningful challenge to work through.
3. Melee weapons. On the other games, melee is an afterthought, except for maybe a couple characters, and even then it's practically useless.  In Wonderlands, you can actually build a character around melee AND melee weapons are a specific item class, complete with their own stats. Some bosses you still need to use guns on because you cannot reach them, but it's a big improvement that I hope they keep in future titles.
4. The Overworld. As the whole thing is framed as a game of Bunker's and Badasses DM'd by Tina, there is a sort of map that you can traverse between areas. There are some sidequests and other things you can do on the overworld. Overall it's an alright concept that did it's job.

That's all I have to say.
