[h1]NOT RECOMMENDED - MY REVIEW[/h1]

[b][u]COMBAT (4/10)[/u]
-Extremely repetitive. You'll fight through the same combat arenas over and over again whilst clearing out bandit camps and dungeons etc.
-There's a solid range in weapons and magic, but again, over time this will become repetitive and you'll genuinely find yourself getting bored. 

[b][u]STORY (2/10)[/u]
-The story seems like it's tailored for an audience of five year old's or teens with the sense of humour of a toddler. For me, it didn't really draw me in that much as the boss fights were lackluster along with the rest of the combat. Nothing felt really special. 
-There's an abundance of left-wing wokeness in this game. You have trans/gay pirates, pronouns, gender-neutral terminology, so on so forth. I don't play a game to be surrounded by political propaganda.

[b][u]THE OPEN WORLD/EXPLORATION (6/10)[/u]
-The Overworld is poorly designed and looks terrible. 'Nuff said. 
-The area's you'll go into all unique in their own way, and host a lot of side-quests (which I'll touch on later in this review), which is somewhat of a good thing. 
-These unique areas can be quite large and repetitive however, so you'll find yourself getting bored after only a few hours of playing. 

[b][u]SIDE-QUESTS (3/10)[/u]
-The side quests feel the same as the main story - very plain and boring. "Go from A to B to collect or kill XYZ". You'll fight against the same enemies spouting the same two voice lines they have over and over again. Very boring and tedious. 

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS (6/10)[/u]
-I've been unlocking a few achievements just by playing through the main story and the side quests, but I've taken the time to look at the rest of the achievements for 100% completion. If you look at my profile you'll realise that I'm a fan of 100% games, but I don't think I'll be able to bring myself to do it for this one. The niche achievements look very boring and way too grind-filled. At this time I'm not planning on completing this game with all achievements, but if that changes I'll be sure to update this review. 

[b][u]VOICE ACTING (8/10[/u]
-The voice acting in this game was good, done by some familiar names such as Andy Samberg. At the end of the day you can't blame the cast for bad writing. They did their job well for this game and how bad the writing was. Hats off to them. 
-You can see the full cast here https://www.imdb.com/title/tt14831458/

[b][u]SUMMARY/OVERALL SCORE = 4.8/10[/u]
-I purchased this game at 33% off and would not recommend anyone to buy it at full price. The game was enjoyable for the first few hours, but after that everything this game provided became repetitive, and the cringe writing became unbearable. The voice acting was good, and the weapons/spells were mostly enjoyable, but everything else about this game is just plain boring.

TDLR: If you like DnD and loot n' shoot games this will be fun. For me it was more of a mixed bag, but I can definitely see the right person enjoying this addition to the Borderlands series. It just wasn't for me. 

While it's certainly not as good as Borderlands 2 or even 3, if you enjoyed the theme of the Assault on the Dragon Keep DLC you'll probably like this game. But otherwise, you could skip this entry into the series. My main issue with the game, same as BL3, is the writing. What made the original DLC work was that it was shorter and still felt relavent to BL2. he jokes didn't get a chance to feel repetitive or annoying, the story was connected to the main series and had emotion. Here, about halfway through the campaign, I was begging the characters to shut up and stop going on about the power of friendship and unicorns. Everything else, gameplay wise, is the same as BL3 just reskinned to fit the DnD aesthetic. If you want to do tedious side quests, delivering items to NPCs or fighting 50 skeletons, you could just play one of the previous installments. There's little replay value, especially seeing as the campaign's dialogue and writing is so poor. 

The addition of spells and the expanded character classes was a nice change of pace to the main series of games, 
be interested to see if any of that carries over into future games. The "guns" shooting arrows instead of bullets and having slightly different physics because of that is a fun twist on fps as well. But sadly the game doesn't offer much challenge in terms of combat unless you play on the highest tier of difficulty. On "Balanced", I played as a Clawbringer and Graveborn and I could just sit back and let my companions take out everyone.

TIny Tina's Wonderland has one of the greatest setups of all time - a few characters from the Borderlands world are stuck on a ship with nothing to do and decide to play their equivalent of Dungeons and Dragons.  You are among them and you are the main hero in the D&D campaign.

Characters are great and extremely funny, in some ways excelling the already-outstanding characters from Borderlands.  Very, very well done.

Gameplay is essentially Borderlands but with a Medieval twisting.  Unfortunately this isn't quite as addictive as the basically identical gameplay in the Borderlands series, I'm not quite sure why.  It may just be that it feels a bit more repetitive and maybe less well explained.... certainly the usage of spells and armor go almost completely unexplained, though the wide variety of spells ensures that you will probably find something that is fun for you to play.

Get it on a discount or pay full price if you are a Borderlands nut.

Its wild, because I feel like on paper this game is what I wanted, a "return to form" by way of revisiting Borderland 2's best DLC in style, but it's got the opposite problem of Borderlands 3 in my opinion- playing it is boring. Borderlands 3 had terrific game feel, crazy named weapons even at low levels, pretty environments, and good enemy types and density. Something feels off here- it doesn't quite have the compelling and addictive loop that ANY of the other Borderlands game had. I found my self trying not to fall asleep while completing quests, and it's difficult to put my finger on what exactly the issue is. The end result is it feels like the skeleton of a borderlands game, checks most of the boxes. but at the end of the day, isnt rewarding or especially challenging in the moment to moment, particularly when the guns themselves are a fraction as potent and intriguing as the last Borderlands game. Borderlands 3 is unplayable due to story, and this game (barely, if at all) passes the story benchmark, but lacks the backbone of a fun looter shooter experience.

I dont know how else to describe it- it's depressingly uninteresting

As much as I enjoyed this game, I cant recommend this game to people. This game was made during the pandemic and it shows. There are so many different things wrong with how this plays that I feel like some play testing would have caught a lot of the problems this game exhibits. This game tried several new things with the borderlands looter shooter formula and some worked and some did not. As I said, this game I initially enjoyed, but borderlands endgame revolves around farming bosses to get certain items to make a build and play on a harder difficulty thats where the flaws show the worst.

In order to talk about what the game did wrong we need to talk about the parts that worked first. This game is set in a world of magic, so grenades have been changed to spells and it works so well. With grenades working so well, its important to get spells that work with your build. In addition, the class trees worked well for customizing your character and it let you mix and match what you liked out of two classes. These were the two major changes that i think worked well, but their inclusion also exasperates the problems with this game. New rolls were added to accomidate these changes such as ability, all, and spell categories, each with straight damage, cooldown, crit chance, ect added drastically to the pool items could roll from.

The endgame, which is where everyone is headed at some point and where builds come together, is where by far the majority of issues are. The game includes some collectathons which feel mandatory and almost all of them need to be done per character, making trying different characters a complete pain in the butt. The next problem has to do with the addition of generic class mods, the addition of stats supporting spells, and adding more slots for rng on most equipment. These problems are a direct extension of the good changes they made above, but as i said, could have been found and resolved if they had tested these changes during the development of the game. All of these result in requiring every playthrough to be a completionist playthrough just to actually starting farming your gear, and once you do theres an order of magnatude more rng to deal with before you can get reasonable gear to support your build. 

The rng in this game is the biggest problem to this game and is by far my biggest reason for not recommending it for people. The addition of new potential stats and extra slots those stats can be on due to the class generalization changes mean that even just wanting a good rolled item means getting the legendary item to drop, then trying to get that items stats decently rolled, which is darn near impossible when you need to roll 3 to 5 stats an item, and each of those stats has dozens of possibilities and you are looking for a specific set of them in order to have it viable for your build really made it an rng hell. If the item drops and it doesnt have any stat you want then you have to keep farming in hopes of that item even dropping. In the event that you do actually get your desired drop with a stat or two you like, the end game introduces another layer of rng, the chaos level. Now you need to farm everything all over again but now that item with a small chance of having the stats you want now also needs to drop with an chaos modifier which is higher rng based on how high in the chaos chambers you are. Its a complete grindfest with little hope of getting the gear you want and even less hope of getting it to drop multiple times as you progress through the chaos chamber leveling. When the top tier of chaos modifier was released it was only 1% chance, so a 1 in 100 chance that your required legendary(or legendaries) for your build upon actually dropping, and then dropping enough to have good enough stats, would actually be a viable end game upgrade. Its just far too much rng, most people do not have the time or paitence to spend hundreds of hours farming per character, and thats where the game lost me. I'm all for farming in a looter shooter, but when it changes from getting an item to drop a few times and taking the best one for your build to needing that item to drop hundreds of times to get something remotely good that starts to feel hopeless for completing a build.

Lastly theres the actual end game content which is sadly lacking. Unlike other borderlands installments you dont really farm bosses, you end up just doing whats called a chaos chamber. Initially these are kinda fun, but after a few the novelty wares off... but theres no better way to farm gear so you are stuck doing them. This concept would probably be better if it wasnt directly tied to rng hell. In addition the game lacks the borderlands traditional raid type bosses so its just farming story bosses and farming chaos chambers in the hopes of any usable loot.

My enjoyment of this game ended when i started farming the endgame. I felt the story was nothing special, but entertaining in its own way. If you wanted play through the story because you felt you wanted a looter shooter type game and you have already played the other borderlands games then this is a fun game to play through. However if you plan to do the endgame content you will find yourself in a joyless unending grind that will devour your soul and all enjoyment you had for the game. If this review ignored the endgame I would probably give it a 6 out of 10, but accounting for the endgame I give this game a 3 out of 10, theres loot grinding, and then theres whatever hell this is.

[h1]This is not Borderlands 3.5 and that's a good thing (in some ways)[/h1]

After the fustercluck that is BL3 and all its controversy it's nice to actually get a break from the series. Sure, Wonderlands uses Borderlands elements at its core, and yet it feels like a fresh experience. It shows the potential for the Borderlands series to become something more and explore new areas; perhaps even Wonderlands can be its own spin-off series with sequels.


[b]The writing[/b]
I know someone is going to point out that "ackshually" this is Borderlands 2.5, but besides Assault on Dragon Keep, this is far from being anything like BL2, so from a features standpoint 3.5 is more accurate. Technicalities aside, the game takes place between 2 and 3, but Borderlands universe is definitely not the main focus here, and that is what makes this feel fresh. If we had just got another Pre-Sequel, it would have been a lore dump that could have passed off as a DLC, but because it decides to do its own thing it is better than that. To embrace the fantasy element the manufacturers as well as gear have been renamed to better suit that, and of course that doesn't stop Tina from adding guns to a fantasy story!

Unlike Assault on Dragon Keep it is not a reimagining of an existing story it is its own story. It's on the same level as any other fantasy game in terms of cliches (you are the chosen one, etc.), but it is shaken up by the D and D aspect, which adds a sort of 4th wall element, that compliments the gameplay and writing. The villain is much better than the twins, nowhere near Handsome Jack level, but is a significant improvement over those two. Lots of humour sprinkled throughout, I think anyone expecting something more serious will be annoyed, but consider the context; you are playing a board game, Handsome Jack is dead, there is no reason for things to be serious. Do what the characters are doing and just focus on having fun!


[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay of course has taken on the more modernised FPS elements that appeared in BL3, but it still is Borderlands at its core, as there is no shortage of looting, farming, and trying new builds. Speaking of which we now have a sub-class system that allows you to pick a second class in addition to your current one, once you complete a certain mission, allowing a combination of 15 classes (there is a new class on the horizon, that raises that number to 21!) This makes the replay value huge, and I know some people (like myself) will explore every single combination as we have fun playing this game for hours on end. I am worried that so many class combinations will lead to poor balance in the long run (i.e. some combinations might be fun, but weak), but so far I am very happy with the balance, as gear seems to be primary and class skills secondary.

Wonderlands has added a difficulty setting (not talking about instanced loot from BL3, as in literal easy, normal, hard). Naturally as a veteran I am playing on the hardest, but I guess things will feel much more like a challenge at max level + Chaos levels. So far just like BL3 I feel like the difficulty is lacking compared to BL2. Don't get me wrong BL2's difficulty had flaws, but I am so used to that challenge now (especially as my main was Krieg), that this feels a bit easy in comparison. It's definitely not a cake walk though and will be enjoyable to everyone.


[b]Epic exclusivity[/b]
No matter which side you are on, one thing is very clear, the only reason the game came in 3 months instead of 6 is a lack of sales. There is no other possibility. This is a good thing. Epic and 2K's anti-consumer practices are catching up to them and by being patient, we are making progress.

[b]Major downsides that need to be addressed[/b]
- Endgame content is severely lacking:
                [b]a)[/b] Chaos Chambers are encounters that you have to do over and over. They increased the Chaos Level multiple times and it is now at 100, this is way too high and takes forever to do.
                [b]b)[/b] No new game+ or ability to reset playthrough
                [b]c)[/b] DLC are short combat encounters

- Farming is the worst it has ever been:
                [b]a)[/b] I see what they were going for with Loot Luck, which is keeping farming an endgame thing, but the implementation is terrible. If you are not maximising Loot Luck you will not get good drops. Problem is you need to get all dice (which is a chore, but thankfully apply to all characters), loot luck bonuses from gear (more on that later), hit max level and increase your chaos levels. Needs to be rebalanced to rely less on dice and chaos levels, which give huge multipliers
                [b]b)[/b] Class mod farming is awful there are 21 unique combinations of classes. For class mods this is bad because for class mods that includes whether the class is primary or secondary which doubles that number to 42! They should make it so that only the classes you are using affect the class mods that spawn.
                [b]c)[/b] Getting good stats on gear is awful. Class mods, amulets and trinkets all have a chance of spawning with additional stats, this would not be so bad, if there was not already the issues that class mods currently have, and additionally as an example if you wanted a melee focused amulet and ring it can also roll gun focused bonuses, despite the main stat being melee. There is farming and then there is torture.
                [b]d[/b] Loot luck as a bonus stat is evil, it forces you to optimise your build or get better loot and was never an issue in other titles. In the end game not optimising your build is a bad idea, as the difficulty curve is insane.


[b]Overall[/b]
My original review was way too positive, and it has taken me way too long to finally change it, I am left disappointed in some ways. It's a great experience, but it could be better. Borderlands 2 remains the best game in the franchise in my opinion.

Tiny Tina's Wonderland is a colorful and whimsical RPG that features fun characters and a lighthearted sense of humor. The game's combat system is engaging, with a variety of weapons and abilities to choose from, and the fantasy setting offers plenty of opportunities for exploration and discovery.

However, the game's storyline can feel disjointed and lacking in coherence at times, and the humor may not be to everyone's taste. Additionally, some players may find the game's reliance on RNG-based loot drops frustrating, as it can make progression feel slow and tedious.

Despite these shortcomings, Tiny Tina's Wonderland is still a fun and enjoyable game that will appeal to fans of the RPG genre. The game's vibrant visuals and engaging combat system are sure to provide hours of entertainment, even if the story and progression can be a bit uneven.

A bit short compared to other Borderland games, but still very much enjoyable. Gameplay is super fun, just like it was in Borderlands 3. Story is there and it's okay-ish, not as cringe like BL3 was, overall nothing special to write books about. Endgame is good too, but there isn't much to do after you've beat the main game besides getting the best gear etc. 

As far as I know, DLC's are 15 minutes long, offering little content and no story content whatsoever. What really sucks is that some of the achievements on steam are tied to DLC's, so if you are a true perfectionist like me and want to get that juicy 100% you will need to spend quite a bit of money for pretty much not worth DLC's to get this sweet 100%.

Overall a very fun and enjoyable game, especially if you have someone to play it with in Co-Op.

This is a good borderlands game, but its not an amazing one. This is a good return to form from what I think was a disaster of BL3. I think this took the good of BL3 like gunplay and...gunplay. The rest was kind of a return of BL2 form and some I have to say misses. I definitely think if you are a fan of Borderlands games you should give this a go, but only if its on sale. $40 if your a fan of borderlands $30 if your not. This feels like a dlc or standalone game rather than its own game. The new mechanics aren't exactly the most game changing and the endgame is honestly very boring. The story and side quests honestly have some strong dialogue and story, there just isnt that many or varied amount of memorable characters. The main cast though is very strong and I honestly think can be brought into BL4 if they wanted to. Skill tree and skills are both a bit varied but at the same time kind of shallow. Alot of skills dont feel unique and this is probably due to the secondary class which on paper sound good but feel like it doesn't hit the mark for me. Gunplay is still amazing and keeps the same gunplay from BL3 which is both a good and bad thing, on one hand its the best gunplay in the series and on the other hand it feels like I am play a very overprices BL3 dlc. The unique gun types are ok like wave shotguns of crossbows but they feel like a lateral upgrade to their BL3 counterpart. Melee to be honest is forgettable and it was suppose to be a selling point. I think for a game that was made during quarantine its passable but just not worth the base price they are asking for. The dlc is also sad as hell and should have just been part of the base game, alot of it is tedious.

Most fun I've had in a Borderlands game since the pre-sequel. The classes are interesting and fun, and multi-classing especially gives some really interesting options when it comes to character creation. If you enjoy the gameplay loop of Borderlands games, you'll probably enjoy this one. One nice thing is that the game isn't too long so I managed to finish all the sidequests before getting bored. No comment on the endgame loop since I haven't really done much of that. 

The writing isn't as bad as people make it out to be - at the very least it's better than the trainwreck that was Borderlands 3. This game really doubles down on the wacky and zany part of Borderlands writing.. and I think it works really well. I think at least they were able to give the supporting characters some fun personalities. There are also some neat ties to the lore of Borderlands 2.

The one major complaint I have is that I ran into very frequent game stuttering when I played through the game. My game will freeze from anywhere between half a second to 5 whole seconds randomly. My hardware is quite good and I don't have this issue when playing any other game. I don't know if it's an issue with the mod or something else but it's certainly the biggest gripe I have with the game. The DLC areas are also super unfun.

This game has, without doubt, some of the most terrible voice acting ever. If you thought the "Pre-Sequel" was grating, you haven't seen anything yet. It sounds like a bunch of fresh head-injury victims who didn't make the the cut for voice work  on Shrek. Please tell Americans never to attempt generic "Scottish" ever again, in particular, but generally all attempts at "briddish" are horrifying in this. As someone who has had to be involved in employing actors for a major broadcaster a few times now, I can tell you that there's no shortage of surprisingly competent and keen actors out there. There is no excuse for these inept chucklefucks to ever be allowed to do this sort of voice work ever again.

End of rant.

Oh yeah, the rest of the game. Well, err, having played every other Borderlands game  (other than the weird Tales stuff), players are used to the "real" game starting in New Game+ mode. This is fine as the relatively poor loot luck and scrimping for points for your build is only a mild irritant for the initial run. This game appears to be calibrated in a roughly equivalent manner, but for some Bob-forsaken reason, THERE IS NO FUCKING NEW GAME+ MODE. 

Yeah, you read that right, none. The much-loved mayhem of the NG+ run is completely missing. This makes it feel like a) half a game b) an insipid mess.

Yes, I get that you'd need more more voice work to swing it- luckily only the core cast and not the terrible, terrible NPCs (I thought Dick Van Dyke was no longer with us, but his gift for accent lives on). 

However, those extra voice lines would be a pleasant change the second time around.. and it's not like you'd need a lot of effort, a lot of the writing feels quite thin and phoned-in too, since BL2. At this point, the general level of the "humour" is to scream "BUTTS" at a high volume, it's hardly going to need an army of Pulitzer winners to extend it for a second play-through.

Yes, the shooting flows beautifully- the spells instead of 'nades are an excellent change, too. How great all of that would be, in a complete Borderlands with NG+ and maybe some chaos levels. It's just a shame that this is a phoned in half-a-game affair. 

If you buy it, only do so at a very steep discount. I would also suggest skipping all the DLCs, with the possibly exception of "Shattering Spectreglass", which has a new class. All the rest of the "new content" is basically slapdash little arenas. Again. You should absolutely check out the Steam review page for the Season Pass though, it's hilarious reading.

So while i really loved Tiny Tinas Wonderland and all the fun things it did with both the story and change of gameplay while keeping the "many many guns" from Borderlands i have a couple of "buts" to the game.

I really love all the different guns BUT the loot leveling system feels like it is broken. 
Several times during the game, I still had weapons 10 level lower than me (sometimes even green/blue) because new weapons my level was never/very rarely better. This is especially felt during the end game when max level has been reached and you take on the chaos mode (harder enemies for better loot). 
Borderlands 3 I felt did it right and the higher level of weapons could quickly be felt in that game.
In Tiny Tina, I could never feel/see it at all. Chaos mode increases the challenge, but the “chaos” weapons you have a chance to get were never better than my standard ones. By chaos level 20 (out of 100) the enemies close to +400% health and do +40% damage. But your weapons haven’t caught up even a tiny bit. So now you are just trying to kill “spongy” enemies who can kill you A LOT easier.

I like collecting achievements and 90% of all achievements in Tiny Tina you get from the story or are easy to do stuff. BUT the “purchase every inventory upgrade” achievement is really annoying when the end game isn’t better.
There is no special currency to farm in this game for them. You buy it with your gold/cash like everything else you want in the game. But 65 hours into the game, Max level, collected everything (lucky dices, poems, etc.) I have only maxed out 1 of the 12 upgrades. A quick google shows this will take around 200-300 million to buy everything. To put it into perspective, a maxed out inventory with average selling level price is around 10k per item so about 500k. You only need to grind that  400-500 times and you should have all upgrades. Ohh and by the way the upgrades feel kind of useless anyway. I never ran out of ammo at any point in the game (primary use was pistol or assault) except for the sniper and rocket launcher.

What I really love about this game with no back sides was:
-the Coop as usual was fun and with loot set to “cooperation”. Each player gets their own loot and can’t see the other players’ loot. No fighting and no dividing, everything you see is yours.  
-the character type voices. You can choose between several types of voices and on a slider decide your characters pitch. My SO had made a copy of Thor which was hilarious with the Gruff voice and the slider at the deepest setting. I had chosen the weirder “strange” type and much lighter voice which just made the exchanges with NPC’s a lot more fun when we never knew which of our characters were going to answer and with what.

All in all I really loved the game. I wished the end game would have been better to keep me coming back but sadly not in this game. The story and the changes from the other borderlands games have been hit on the head in my opinion. But it has some downsides that stopped me from putting 100-200+ hours into it like I probably would have.

"Oh Borderlands 3 has so much more content than Tiny Tina's Wonderlands" Mate the content in Borderlands 3 is utterly dreadful so I'm not sure already how that's a good thing? Anyways.

-The story is better than BL3,

-The humour is WAYY better, it's still not that funny but I havent smiled even a single time playing BL3 so that's that,

-Characters are less cringe than BL3, they're still cringe, but not as bad as BL3,

-Game is WAAAAY too easy, even on highest difficulty, it's not even funny, I have not met a single enemy that truly posed a threat to me in any way shape or form,

Which is made especially ironic when you remember Randy fucking Pitchford is at the helm, but then again, this isn't very surprising, these kinds of people usually have skeletons in their closets.

-Buttstallion... For the love of god Gearbox I am on my KNEES begging you to leave that joke in BL2, it was kinda funny once, get over it.

I could go on more about it all but eh,

TL;DR - 8/10 - Keeps the gameplay improvements from Borderlands 3 and combines them with a lukewarm story that won't piss you off, but also won't wow you. Not bad. Enjoyable, but not a must play.

And now, the longer review you will almost certainly not read...

GAMEPLAY
Just like Borderlands 3, the actual gameplay in Wonderlands is fantastic. It features all the QOL improvements of the previous title (like damage scaling so that you can play with anyone at any level, sliding, and not getting stuck on every single little piece of map geometry) and combines them with some new D&D-esque mechanics and the chaos chamber, which operates like a randomized dungeon arena.

STORYTELLING, CHARACTERS, AND HUMOR
The story is an improvement over Borderlands 3, but this is very much not a game to be recommended for its story. Most of the time it feels very lukewarm, not pissing me off, but not wowing me either. Exceptions are any quest involving Mr. Torgue or Claptrap [spoiler](Especially the ending of Torgue's main story quest: there is just no topping that)[/spoiler], the Pirate Words scroll, seducing the door, and Peasant-Ass Peasant. Like almost every Borderlands game, the jokes are very much hit or miss. The characters are often referential jokes, and they are also very much hit or miss.

GLITCHES AND BUGS
Had a bug where the game would freeze for about 20 seconds once after launching and spawning in a map, but that may have been due to my graphics settings. I never did look into trying to fix it. Mildly annoying more than anything. Also had the game crash twice without error message and without warning. Once in the middle of a chaos chamber I had reached the final boss of. Kept my gold and everything I got up to that point, but I was still pissed because I wanted to finish the chamber. That seems to have been due to graphics settings because I lowered them and didn't have a crashing issue after that.

SEASON PASS
I'm not buying it at this time. It seems overpriced for what you get.

OVERALL
I did enjoy the game and I do recommend it, especially if there's a sale. I feel like I got my money's worth. Gameplay is great. Story is mostly eh, but it didn't piss me off.

Yes, I would recommend to play this. Not at full price but at 50% off or more it's a blast if you're ever played DnD, are into fantasy, is into borderlands or none of the above. Good story, fun characters, gameplay is different than BL3 but still very similar. If you're on the fence, buy and play for an hour. Otherwise just refund.

A fun and excellent mixup to the Borderlands formula.
Naturally extends and modifies the core loops and mechanics to feel "RPG-ish" (grenades are replaced with spells, you can get equip-able rings, necklaces, etc with their own effects).
And it fleshes out Tina's character a bit more. (Note this game takes place before BL3, so [spoiler]Tina is still a child[/spoiler])

The "plot" and character dialog is much better written this time, compared to (let's be honest) BL3's writing quality significantly decreasing about mid-way through the story. And to a lesser extent, the character dialog and interactions too.

Also a new element is added, and the element vs health type is now explicitly shown in game (though per-species resistances/vulnerabilities you still have to discover for yourself).

Another thing I hope Gearbox keeps in the future is showing the parts on equipment that gives the modifications to stats. And maybe expanding it a bit to show more (e.g. there are many more parts to a gun that can have modifiers than the in-game component list. Anyone who has dabbled with the game's/gane save's data structures should know this full well)
Also, TTW only has this for guns and shields(?), but it would be great to see it for more equipment types too.
This kind of transparency into inner game mechanics is a good thing.

Another change I like is that the level cap is still what it was on release, 40. This avoids issues with enemy and/or player scaling formulas going a bit out of control and making the game exponentially punishing with every enemy with ludicrous amounts of HP that previous games had. (Though it does lead to the opposite problem, as discussed below)
And they finally fixed the side-mission level issue; all enemies and quests scale to your current level. (Though this does have the unfortunate side effect of incentives you to do all sidequests after max cap, for max level quest equipment)

Side-quest reward equipment (with a short list of exceptions) is no longer a one-time thing!
The rewards (again, except a few) get added to the pool of things that can show up in vending machines, albiet with a pretty low probability (and pretty steep costs).
This means if you do get a special reward at too low of a level, you will (eventually) have a chance to get it again at your current level.

The small list of complaints I have (so far):
[list]
[*] At max level and a good set of equipment, enemies are complete joke. Really only super badasses and bosses have any real chance of giving you a problem. [spoiler]But secret bosses in the chaos chamber are quite threatening, so credit for that[/spoiler].
You can kind of fix this using Chaos modes (this game's equivalent to Mayhem mode), but you need to raise it a good chunk to start getting "regular" overworld stuff to be a challenge a bit. And raising that level is in an easy to overlook, undocumented (in-game),  grindy session.
[*] Similar to this, no "new game+" option. Granted, with a level cap of only 40, this wouldn't actually add all that much replay value, but it would be nice to have the option anyways.
[*] The world map/[spoiler]board[/spoiler] matches very well thematically, but isn't quite as satisfying as a "real" overworld. (This one I will give some slack since TTW was supposed to be a sort of "side-ish project" during pandemic)
[*] Not enough "natural" enemy spawns, combat is a bit too sparse when not on an active mission with scripted spawns.
[*] STORY SPOILER: [spoiler]Tina never got the callout/wake up call she needs about her being too "clingy" to the other non-RPG protagonists. She can't make the world stop just because she wants companionship badly. Yes, Tina has [i]severe[/i] abandonment problems (which if you know your BL2 lore, is completely understandable). But while she can get a loyal, consistent friends/authority figures (BL1 and BL2 cast at this point in the story), the world will not halt regardless of how severe the issues she may have. That is something Tina is going to have to grasp at some point.[/spoiler]

None of these are game-breaking; I still thoroughly enjoyed and continue to enjoy the game!

[spoiler]I do however have some issues about how the DLCs were done, but I will leave those for my reviews on the DLCs[/spoiler]

I went into this game extremely negative with some curiosity. My interests in the game were shaped by content creators and word of mouth, who said that the endgame was infuriatingly padded out, among other mostly negative critiques, and that's how I perceived the game and avoided it for a really long time. However with the advent of Wonderlands Redux, and a sale that lines up pretty damn well, I finally decided to give it a shot.

I'm glad I did.

If you're here to shoot things (a lot), then you're going to have a good time.

If you're here to have a good laugh (I did, a lot), then you're going to have a good time.

If you're here for an enjoyable (and occasionally heart-wrenching) story-line, then you're going to have a good time.

I'm generally a fan of the franchise, which makes me a little biased, and I thing the meta commentary is on point here too.

The end-game chaos runs are a bit of a pain once you get past level 10 or so, if you're not willing to do a lot of optimization, but hey, that's for the real hardcore nerds anyway.
(Please don't hurt me, you nerds are wonderful and deserve all the optimization you want, but when I'm forced to hold down the shoot button at a boss for half an hour straight, I get a bit bored...)

All in all, a great addition to the franchise, I'm looking forward to more!

My second favorite of the Borderlands series, honestly such an absolutely wonderful Fantasy TTRPG take on a futuristic game! The narrator (Tina) is charming, as always, the characters are hilarious, the puns unbearable AND wonderful and even surprisingly high brow at times. The gameplay is iconic to Borderlands and much of the TTRPG world in that it doesnt take itself too seriously (until it does), and is as challenging as you want it to be. I adore this game, just as I adored Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep in the era of Borderlands 2 DLC, and it is clearly a game made with a love of TTRPGs AND the Borderlands world.
It's a borderlands experience in medieval fantasy setting. With some RPG elements! Funny and a bit weird. I recommend it!

Been playing this on and off over the course of the last few months, recently finished the main campaign.

Borderlands was my entry-point into the looter-shooter genre, BL2 (and TFTB) is one of my favorite games of all time, but BL3 pretty nastily killed most of the joy I found in the franchise. The gunplay there had everything I'd ever dreamed of for this series, but the soul was just left to dust.

Luckily, the Wonderlands help reel it back in.

This game contains the feel of BL3 and houses an incredibly solid improvement on the narrative design and writing, yet also brings new and original gameplay ideas to the table that, while not drastically changing the core foundation, propel the series and franchise forward in interesting ways.

If you're a Borderlands fan and want to scratch that Gearbox-specific looter-shooter itch, but also actually enjoy the time you spend in the world of the game, this will satiate that hole in your stomach BL3 left you with. Note though that it'll only be a one-and-done ordeal. The endgame here is fairly non-existent and only the most desperate will be able to find fun in the replayability of this game.

But the thing that made me most happy... it's got heart.

I can tell this was a labor of love by the team of people who made it. It shines through in all its colors. I was laughing and smiling on more than one occasion. It's damn nice to get that from Borderlands once again :)

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is overall a great game. It has many similar elements to BL3 but has some good jokes and fun fights. It doesn't do much for the Lore or to expand the Borderlands universe but it's a fun play until BL4 comes out.

Do be warned that the DLCs are a waste of time and money though. They are each just a 12-20 minute dungeon where you just kill the same enemies you fought all game with a variant boss at the end.

This game is cool! 

It delivers exactly what is promised - a Borderlands game where the story is actually an RPG campaign, and the dungeon master is Tiny Tina the maniac.

The gunplay is fantastic as always. Tons of different crazy weapons that turn into Hydras and all kinds of crazy stuff that you can imagine, the loot is addictive and the skills are fun to learn.

Don't expect too much from the story. It's kind of silly and the humor is... hm... teenager-ish if that makes any sense? Tiny Tina is a teenager after all, and the story is an RPG campaign dictated by her so... don't expect any fantastic plot twists that will make you cry or something (some of the puns are cringe though, be aware!)

The main story is a bit short but there's a huge loop at the end that will make you keep playing for hours after finishing the main quests.

Overall, if you like Borderlands and you know how Tiny Tina is, there's a high chance you'll like this game. Maybe I would not recommend purchasing it at full price, but I'd definitely recommend getting it if it's on sale.

If you love Borderlands humor and game play then you will like this. It's the exact same thing about Borderlands 3. Personally I like the world / universe Borderlands has created and enjoy it. I also understand that some people are looking for revolutionary systems and a whole new shooter experience, that is not this. Its a good comical story, where you get to kill things. Sometimes kill things in humorous ways.

Really let down by this game considering the overall positive response to it compared to BL3.

My main issue with this game is the gameplay. 
-Guns feel very unimpactful and more just for chipping.
-Usually have to unload at least a magazine to kill an enemy.
-Guns are very uninteresting and not unique whatsoever, usually you find one decent weapon in 4 hours of gameplay.

Skills are where most of your damage comes from. However, as apposed to something interesting, most boil down to "Click button to do more damage." and you just save it until there's a boss or miniboss.

Aside from the damage feeling flat, the world being ripped out does no merit whatsoever for the game, not even from a "oh it's like a board game!" point of view. It just feels lazy and like i'm playing an arcade game rather than something with a thought out and grounded world. I have no sense of where anything is or why I am anywhere.

The loot dice you can find seem cool at first, but they are really just there to make you look around every barren crevice and corner to inflate play time so you can't refund it.

I really am at a loss as to how the reception to this was significantly better than BL3. This game is just not fun to play. It is a chore.

The only redeeming aspect of this game is Tina is funny. That's it.
More borderlands fun and humor!

Pros: It has a much more fun light hearted story compared to 3
- The humor was pretty fun this time compared to the past few games in the BL series
-Guns still feel really good to shoot and melee has been given more focus 
-classes are fun to play 
-Story is light and interesting

Cons: The environments for the last half are too ocean. water themed (eg coral, pirate cove, oasis)
- The constant talking can get annoying 
- loot feels a lot more scaled back from previous BL games (eg lots of guns look the same and less varieties)

Overall if you like BL games you will probably enjoy this game and if you don't and just like loot shooters you should give it a try

Best Borderlands game to date, awesome story, well written characters, a villain to rival or IMO surpass Jack. Gunplay has been enhanced by Spell (grenade) and Melee builds that feel great. Don't bother with the DLC on this one though, the main game is more than enough and the DLCs are pretty forced as loot grind.

However, the most recent update (as of writing) added chaos 100, which is their end game progression system. This is a change from chaos 50 which was already a large grind. Add to this the crazy level of RNG that comes with the tiered gear and you get one hell of a grind system; which some people love, but is far beyond most casual players. I don't want to leave the game on a negative note because it is amazing in every other way, [strike]but despite only finishing to chaos 51, I think I am finished the game for now unless some QoL changes get implemented.[/strike] EDIT: grinded to chaos 100, god rolled one of my gear pieces for my main build, safe to say my main character is a god now, all is well :)

 Very much recommend for lovers of any of the borderlands series, lovers of DnD or lovers of good looter shooters.

Lotta reviews complaining about the writing in this game but I think it's much better than BL3. It's a nice break away from the main series storyline, which I think majority of players would agree was suffering a bit. The dialogue is cute and funny and the voice actors all sound like they had a lot of fun with their characters.

Gameplay is a definite step up, offering even more classes to choose from, complete with fun explosive abilities to mix and match to your fancy. If you enjoy build crafting this is definitely for you. There are many quality of life additions as well, like the change of grenades to spells with cooldowns so I'm not constantly pressed to scour for ammo. The ability to fast travel anywhere without the need of a terminal and the removal of vehicles is a welcome change too, cutting out the time spent trudging through vast nothingness as you traverse from quest to quest.

The only part I did not enjoy was the overworld system which felt like an absolute chore to get through. All I wanted was to get to new exciting map locations and explore but instead I was forced to slow down, break my immersion and complete multiple mini side encounters, for upgrades; locked behind menial tasks, to make the entire thing slightly more bearable.

Still, it's undeniably a fun Borderlands experience and one I would recommend. Grab your friends and get to lootin!

The level scaling feels predictably terrible. It blows my mind that this is the new norm in gaming. A beloved handicapping system made to allow players to eventually overcome obstacles as the game scales the players numbers higher in respect to simulated in character experience rewarding out of character diligence and hard work. Turned to shit by donut headed developers that turn the obstacles up in balance to not only your character but the expected loot they guess you will have. This turns levelling up into a punishment number that merely reminds you your clothing is now out of date and things are about to beat you down harder. Worse by having many levels, you guarantee that eventually you will hit a dry spell on your loot drops by running the statistic long enough promising a terrible time at some point in your game play. Promising inevitable hours of painful grindy powerless boaring widdle fights against hp balloons you have no choice but to circle kite.

I have been a fan of the Borderlands series since the first game. And I have to be honest here, I CANNOT recommend Tiny Tina's Wonderlands at all. I can't even recommend it when it's on sale. I found the writing to be just as bad, if not worse than Borderlands 3. Just about all of the dialogue was either generic or annoying. Sadly, the gunplay wasn't fun this time around. I understand that it's a fantasy game and that gives you freedom to make some pretty off the wall weapons. Unfortunately, I didn't really like how most weapons shot arrows. I just usually went for normal guns. Not to mention that the guns actually felt really weak in this game. It was a neat idea to give Melee weapons its own weapon slot, but it felt kinda meh to me. I enjoy Melee classes in the Borderlands series, and that hurts me to say that melee weapons and melee classes aren't fun in this game.
  Spells were fun enough as a replacement for grenades, but I never bothered to experiment too much on what each spell book could do. It was very painful to level up in this game. It felt like the enemies gave out too little experience for how much damage you had to do. It actually reminded me a lot about Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel and how little experience you would get from that game. I heard, read, and watched a lot of negative reviews about the DLC. I didn't really bother on picking up DLC outside the Blight caller class.
  In my eyes, the Borderlands franchise started to go down hill in Tales from the Borderlands. The series fell even harder in Borderlands 3. And as for Wonderlands, I really don't like it. It felt more like Borderlands 3 and less Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep. The only parts I enjoyed about Tiny Tina's Wonderlands was Mr. Torgue, the totally not Smurfs side quest, quest items being available in vending machines after completing the side quest, and the ending of the game... when it ended.
  Look, I gave this game a real chance. I wanted to like it. I even made a second character to see if I would it enjoy it more than the Clawbringer+Brr-zerker combo. I tried Spore warden+ Blightcaller combo and it didn't make the game any more or any less enjoyable for me. This game is a disgrace to the Borderlands franchise as a whole. I don't care that it's a spin off game. I will NEVER buy any future installments to the Borderlands franchise.

I've played and finished the main campaigns for all the other versions, save BL1 (which just feels too old for me at this point) and Tina's Wonderland is probably my favorite BL game so far. 

Overall, the gameplay is of course very similar to the other games, but i find that the change from grenade mods to spells actually makes a big difference in how you play. The weapons feel pretty good as well, though perhaps slightly less fun than in Pre-Sequel. The classes are fun too, and the multi-classing (allowing you to pick a second class after a certain point in the campaign) allows for some nice build variety. The ability trees are smaller than in all the other versions (save BL1 I guess?) and the special class abilities aren't quite as awesome as in some of the other games (some of them are a bit bland in fact). But you eventually get to hot swap from 4 different class abilities, and you get 2 fairly strong passives, making things pretty good still. Also, you get to spend ability points à la DnD i.e. Constitution, Dexterity, Strength etc. which again allows for cool build diversity. Difficulty level is low to medium, with maybe one or two bosses that might catch you by surprise with a few cheap abilities, until you get the mechanics down (I played a more tanky character with high health, YMMV with low health builds I guess). It's the usual BL stuff really. A few annoyingly cheap moments, but overall it's fairly well balanced.

Visually, it's very nice. The various environments feel way more colorful and vibrant than in the other BL games. Levels are more varied in style, and for me, just more fun. The story was fine by me as well. I've always felt that the BL universe was nonsensical anyway. Playing the game under the pretence of being a DnD character and having Tina as the DM seems no more ridiculous (to me) than the other stories I've seen in BL so far. It's not a super long campaign, but there are quite a few side missions, and the end-game 'chaos-room' (basically a dungeon generator) adds more or less unlimited replay value if you really want to take things to the ultimate level with your character. Level cap is 40, but there is a secondary levelling system that opens up at that point (I can't speak to that, I haven't reached that level yet). 

I'd like to add a note regarding the absolutely awesome voice work from Ashly Burch in her role of Tina. You get to hear a lot from Tina of course, and Ashly is just amazing in how she delivers her lines. Yeah, it's a bit cringe sometimes, but it does work given the context. Will Arnett is very good as well, as are all the other voice actors.

I got the game on sale with a bunch of DLCs, and I've put in about 60 hours or so now I think, and completed the main quest along with 75% of the side quests on one character. I'm glad I picked it up. It's good satisfying action as you'd expect from a BL title, with a few twists to make things a bit different compared to the other versions.

Would say though to get the game while on sale as that's a more reasonable price for the game, £54.99 for the game is very pricey for whats on offer. The "raid bosses" in the chaos chambers are fun and semi challenging and the way to get them tells you a bit on what the bosses have to offer in terms of skills they use in the fights. The guns themselves range from meh to awesome and I feel the modelling on some of them really fit well with the style of the game and others look like they've pulled straight from a Borderlands game, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. The DLC themselves is where the game feels like it falls apart a bit, they all play like a glorified chaos chamber but still look very good and unique in what they offer but like with the base game it's best to get these on sale when it's on if you want a little bit more content and variety

Grab your [b]dice[/b] and get ready for a wild ride in Tiny Tina's Wonderlands! This game is like Dungeons & Dragons on steroids with a splash of caffeine. With classes like Boom Slinger, Spellslamzer, and Bunnylord, you know you're in for a wild ride. And the boss battles? Let's just say they're crazier than a tea party with the Mad Hatter. So grab your favorite tea cup and get ready to slay some dragons, bunnies, and who knows what else in this wacky, wild and wonderful game.

I was back into the Borderlands game-play hook by the 3rd chapter. Looting, shooting and laughing. Wonderlands has new mechanics that make it feel fresh compared to the previous titles. Wonderlands is still really fun despite the missing mature content, though I hope Gearbox keeps the mainline series the way it was. Mature.

It's also kinda short for a Borderlands game, but playing the side quests to level-up will make your play-though longer.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is wonderfully witty and in many ways much better than Borderlands 3. Tina, the Fatemaker, their two party members, and the Dragon Lord are all well written and well voiced. The side content is not always well written, but still fun.

Sadly, the user interface is terrible. It was bad throughout the whole Borderlands series, and they somehow managed to make it even worse. Another gripe I have with the game is its difficulty, it's too easy for me even on 'intense' difficulty, and I'm not even good at FPS games.

Despite those two negatives, this game is mostly fun, and I'm having a blast playing it. The Borderlands-esque silliness works better in this setting, as it's already a parody. I must note that I am personally a fervent Dungeons & Dragons player, and though the story and most of the jokes work for me, I can't promise they'll work for you.

I recommend this game if you're either craving for more Borderlands, or in the mood for some wacky D&D satire. If you liked the Borderlands 2 expansion Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon's Keep, you will most certainly like this.

P.S. If your game crashes all the time, switch to Direct X 11 in the options menu, that fixed it for me.

Tina's Wonderlands; A game that, despite my hours, I am still quite mixed on. 
Most of my issues with the game come from the writing, main story especially. Where characters feel like caricatures, either flanderised or just one-note. The main story itself doesn't go too far either, opting to stay completely safe to the entire franchise rather than do anything actually interesting. Tina isn't really Tina anymore, but the safe and wacky version of Tina with little to no issues aside from maybe a few quests.

For main story conflict, there is little to none (aside from a few main issues that get resolved almost instantly) and the universe itself doesn't actually make sense. Things happen in-game independent of the DM and characters outside of the game, which then affect the outside world, rather than the other way around. 
Also, Tina is still 12/13 in this game and will occasionally make inappropriate jokes. There were maybe 3 or 4, but, those times were just uncomfortable and definitely not as tasteful as the game seems to play them off as. 

The humour in this entry feels like it changed a lot, which makes sense considering the best head writer in the series hasn't been here since Borderlands 2. So we're stuck with reddit-tier or below-reddit tier jokes. Find them funny if you wish, but it is incredibly low effort in terms of writing. With the slap in the face being how safe it plays every single joke, considering one of the main draws of Borderlands used to be how messed up the world was while being so lighthearted. This is just light-hearted without the reality to it.

However, and the biggest however possible -- if you can get past the writing or just mute while playing, the actual gunplay itself and how classes work feels phenomenal. As of Chapter 4, you unlock multiclassing which opens you up to just over 20 combinations of classes that can let you play the game whichever way you wish. My only criticism with multiclassing is the fact that the game doesn't give you your secondary class sheet upon choosing, and, you can only switch second classes at the end of the game. 

But that is the reason I played through this game so many times (and will likely play through more in the future), because of how effective the skills, spells, guns and classes work in tandem with each other. I was quite surprised, since, I really thought I wouldn't like this game from the story alone. I'm glad I stuck through it.

Another side note, for people who do care about postgame, the most fun you'll be having is save editing on your own or messing around with the game of your own accord. Since, the only post-game is the Chaos Chamber, and you have to save edit for anything close to the replayability of the TVHM seen in other previous games. The modding "community" isn't as strong as BL3 and especially not BL2, though I can't remove points on this game for it I feel the need to point it out for anyone looking to mod the game like BL3/BL2.

Get it on sale for sure (considering the price, and the lack of content compared to similar priced games of the series), and avoid the short cashgrab DLC's -- unless you're just getting Shattering Spectreglass for the Blightcaller class, because that was the only highlight of the entire extra amount of money I spent on said DLC. I'm sure you can look through the DLCs for yourself to realise why people don't like them, but all they really do is add more chaos chamber content at the end of the day and not a whole lot of it.
And if you don't like the writing, take a speedrun tip and exit to main menu whenever a character talks for too long. Works most of the time for skipping dialogue.

The gameplay is alright. It's a bit repetitive, and less varied than other BL games, but not terrible. Just average.

The dialogue, on the other hand, is absolutely terrible. The sheer cringe-inducing power of the writers makes the game experience almost painful. Perhaps I've simply grown since my last playthrough of a BL game, but over time the humor just became grating and repetitive. The over-reliance on absurdity in order to stay clear of anything potentially "too edgy" is probably what killed it.

I wouldn't recommend the game either way, but if you're going to get it anyway, do yourself a favor and wait for a sale.

The game is fun, there's a lot of unique settings and enemies to keep you occupied. I'm a big fan of BL2, I was in my 20s when BL2 came out so the humor hit me just right back then whereas the jokes in this game were hit and miss. I do love the comedians in this game, aka, Wanda Sykes, Will Arnett, and Andy Samburg. I did think the Smurfs and Witcher parody quests were standouts for me. 

I loved BL2, and Tiny Tina was a favorite character of mine. Unfortunately, they do a disservice to her in this game... even moreso than BL3 did. At some point, Tina whimpers to her playmates, "I don't wanna be left all alone..." and I think that was a mistake, showing her vulnerability like that. What made Tiny Tina so interesting, is that she was a little kid in the brutal borderlands setting and she did NOT show any vulnerability, as you'd expect any kid who lost their parents and were all alone to be crying and needy towards folks. Not Tina, she was quite independent, blew up the bandit that killed her fam and then had a tea party with some imaginary friends. Interesting! Different! By making Tina cry about being all alone, asking these new characters if they'll "stay and play" with her, they took away what made Tiny Tina unique and made her just like every other kid. In BL2, for example, they didn't have to spell out, "Tina & Roland were close," they just show their picture together in Tina's bunker, and when she's playing Dragon Keep, she is waiting for Roland to appear ready to play even though he's been *spoiler for BL2* killed. Anyway, I liked Tiny straight up crazy and this game made her a bit too sane is my only complaint! :P

From what I understand, the majority of this game's lowest reception in Borderlands franchise is attributed to terrible DLCs and weak endgame.
And if you're like me - you don't care about endgame, only the journey to it. For that, Wonderlands is excellent. A step-up in narrative from BL3, a visual feast, and the fun combat from BL3. 
+ Dragon Lord is no Handsome Jack, but still 2nd best villain in the franchise after him
+ The support characters are fun and have great chemistry (unlike Ava). There are also 5 return characters from mainline Borderldands, and none of them I felt were bastardized.
+ [b]SPELLS[/b] replacing grenades is, IMO, the best thing to happen to grenades in franchise. I never played classes that focused on them and would have good bonuses to damage and recovery, and so to me they were always just an afterthought, but Spells are just so much more fun and varied, and you don't have to conserve them, since they are just on cooldown. Finished the game as Spellshot with class ability replaced by 2nd Spell.
+ By the end of the game I realized that I don't actually miss vehicles. Overworld with bobblehead characters replaced that part of traversal, and it contributes to the game's great pacing. The vehicles themselves were always cool, but the encounters focused on them weren't ever worthwhile. A simple yet effective and pretty overworld is a great replacement, even if it wouldn't make sense in mainline.
+ Another big contributor to the game's great pacing is quest design. Short, meaningless ones are like this - you find quest giver on Overworld, listen to their 1-minute long exposition, move like 10 meters to arena-like encounter, finish 2 stages, collect quest item and go back to quest giver for reward. Longer, well written ones typically have their own section on big maps, and a few are even the main reason to be on that map, because a bunch of them you'll never visit for main quest chain, and yet they are all absolutely worth exploring just for sights alone. As a result, maps never feel cluttered by side quests and almost never have backtracking issues. Small encounters you accept and complete almost on the spot and bigger ones that are worth your time are not lost in cluttered questlog.

If I had to nitpick my experience on the journey to the endgame, there are 2 minor issues:
- The game insists on cluttering your inventory with melee weapons for loot, but melee system is not reworked to make melee focused builds worthwhile. No block, no dodge, no heavy attacks, no variety in how different melee weapons behave, besides swing speed and stats. It's mostly the same as any other BL game, and the melee loot is just a waste of RNG rolls. Even if melee builds were some of the most powerful in game, with this gameplay I cannot take them seriously, after being spoiled by games like Vermintide and Dying Light.
- The balancing is definitely off. After I reached level 24 and got capstone skill on my Spellshot the game just lost all challenge. I just dumped all my points in crit chance, took the SMG spewing the highest amount of projectiles/second, the biggest baddest 2 spells, and just cruised through 2nd half of the game. I still had fun, courtesy of writing, art direction and spell variety, but the only times I died were environmental hazards, not enemies TRYING to kill me.

Just don't waste money on DLC, get standard edition, and enjoy this wonderful spin-off

Since Steam forces us to either give a thumbs up or down I am going with the "no". Let me explain. The game looks gorgeous. The artistry on display reinforced by the Unreal engine makes this game the best looking in the Franchise. But (you knew this was coming) that is the best thing about the game. And when the visuals are the best thing in a Looter-Shooter you know something is not right. The "bazillion guns" that drop make it arbitrary if you really want to waste your time comparing stats when you will find one that is ever so slightly better just around the corner. I stopped caring altogether and just sold everything without ever looking at them. Ever so often I would take new one after leveling up a few levels but it was not really enganging wich brings me to my second problem. The enemies are just as arbitrary. The vast majority of enemies don't require you to tackle them differently. Basically all of them can be killed by spamming them with bullets and your special skills. Those could be interesting but they aren't because you just don't have any reason to refine them. 

And the skill tree is a smoke screen. They split them in multiple parts and sell them as extra classes which might feel like more but if you compare it with BL2 they just split them up and made them smaller and in direct comparison not remotely as interesting. Minor stats changes don't affect your playstyle and major new abilities are very rare and disappointing me more often than not.

What made BL2 click for me just is not present here and it is really hard to pin down. Lots of quality of life stuff is missing, odd decisions like the names of your friends being just that bit too large on screen are annoying. The total overload of effects make strategic play absolutely impossible (not that you would need to) and the story is okay. The voice actors do a good job and the writing is okay but a far cry from being memorable like BL2. The tons ob side missions do almost nothing for the main story and you forget what it's all about constantly. The many cameos of characters from the other games are undercooked and feel like lame fan service.

All in all, the sum of its parts leave me mostly indifferent. I stopped interacting with most of the systems like skill tree, weapon selection, listening to the story since none of it matters much since the core gameplay loop is just so plain. 

So, If I could, I would give it a neutral "meh" instead of the thumbs down. It is just not interesting enough for a recommendation and just not bad enough for a "stay away" warning. It is okay if you really do not have anything else which should be impossible these days.

If you like Gear Box's other games, and if you like the Borderlands series, and if you don't mind poking lighthearted fun at Dungeons and Dragons, Then this game might be just up your alley. It helps with the humour if you've played D&D type games including playing with miniatures, and turning spilled soda pop into rivers and lakes, and Cheetos into road blocks is priceless. And of course the 20 sided dice are present. 
If you have not played D&D with a group of other players the game will still be worth playing. You just might not get all of the humour. There are also the usual references to pop media, inducing quite a few which may make older players laugh, such as references to Beetles songs, and there are references to much more recent songs to. All in all, this crew of developers knows how to put together a game that is both fun, and funny. I can recommend it for the humour alone. But in addition to that, it runs pretty well, even on my ancient machine. If your machine meets the minimum requirements, then you shouldn't have problems.
Get it for the fun. Play it for the adventure! It's nuts to be whaling away at a monster with a sword one moment, and a sub machine gun the next. It's beautifully incongruous, just as Tiny Tina's mind (or the mind of any somewhat wild and unconventional little girl that age) would cook up.
Enjoy, and I hope you have as much fun with it as I have.

Each new game in the Borderlands series somehow manages to reduce replayability and the total time you spent on the game. The DLC are a total disgrace each of them being a 10 minute dungeon. Unlike other Borderlands series game there is no (Ultimate) True Vault hunter mode and there are no invincible bosses.

After just 40 hours of gameplay you will have completed every quest and have one of every unique legendary weapon. The only real gameplay element at that point is mayhem mode which uses very repetetive dungeons.

Not to mention the skill required even on the highest difficulty is much lower then in past titles.

Bought this game on sale for $30 and it was the perfect price. This game isn't worth $60 but has enough value in it to be bought at $30. 

This is fantasy mixed with Borderlands. I personally enjoyed the main story line and the side quests were entertaining and enjoyable. The fantasy setting is engaging, the monsters are awesome, and the Overworld setting mixes well with the actual game. I beat the game in a good 20 hours and it was a blast!

There are a few shortcomings with Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. The main one being the lack of legendary loot. I play these games for the thrill of seeing a legendary item drop and having the icon pop up on the map. In my 20 hours of beating the game, only TWO legendary items dropped before the final fight. I received two more from quests but still, only TWO legendary items dropping in 20 hours of game play is unacceptable. You can argue that this makes greens/blues/purples more balanced but I don't like having to sift through hundreds of weapons to find the right one. When I saw the trailer for this game and the dice rolls I thought they had so much potential to drop good loot but they feel so underwhelming. The loot is easily the biggest problem with the game but everything else is amazing. 

Another shortcoming is the credits. Why are there 20+ minutes of FORCED credits? I'm all for appreciating the developers for the game but when I'm having to sit there for 20-30 minutes and I can't get out that feels real bad. Other reviews mentioned LBGQT being forced down their throats during the game but I didn't notice it (probably because I didn't play with sound for most of it). There's some characters here and there that are LBGQT but overall it doesn't feel pushy. 

In conclusion, this game was a lot of fun for what it is - a Borderlands game mixed in a fantasy world. The story and side quests are at their best but the loot feeling so underwhelming is a clear issue. Also, the credits... WHY

Final Score: 8/10
-1.5 for lackluster loot
-0.5 for 20+ minutes of forced credits

After playing through twice now i can say this. the story is bare-bones, you're not really gonna care much or get too invested in any of the main people (except maybe a certain skeleton couple, they pretty cool)

 The side quests are honestly mostly pretty good, they're goofy and usually have pretty cool rewards, all of the games main and side quests can be completed in around 35 - 40 hours which is a massive downgrade from any other borderlands game.

 Do not buy this game for 60 dollars, its just not 60 bucks worth of content for most people. chaos trials are a decent way to farm some cool loot, but make for a boring endgame as that's the only endgame gearbox gave us with this one.

the game-play is amazing, same as borderlands 3 but a bit goofier with all the fantasy based elements, the guns feel great, the movement feels great, the spells feel great and way better than grenades ever have in a borderlands game. its a very very fun game because gearbox has gotten great at making interesting weapons and build opportunities, its just a shame the endgame is so lackluster because this game had so much potential.

The dlc are a joke. each one gives you 1 new (not good) boss fight and some new loot. the loots cool but borderlands 3 did this for free with seasonal events, the dlc should have been seasonal events. The dlc are a pathetic money grab and gearbox should be ashamed of doing their fans dirty with dlc again.

Overall, wouldn't pay much more than 30 to 40 bucks for this game and all the dlc. there's fun times to be had, and its worth playing for any borderlands fan, but its nowhere near any mainline borderlands game in terms of content.

As a huge fan of this series, I loved BL1, BL2 and came to at least enjoy the Pre-Sequel enough to finish it(eventually).  I was so excited for BL3 I did the pre-order, but then was immediately disappointed in playing (just like Fallout 76). I watched this game coming, and refused to buy early or even at full price.  Waited patiently for the Spring Sale where I thought it wasn't too bad of a price to be totally ripped off.  Even so, read other reviews and one person had mentioned similar distaste for things after BL2 and said this went back to the original things you loved about BL but had some new twists.  I was in...  and it IS!  This is more like what I had hoped BL3 would be - a twist on the old with some new sprinkled in.  

If you are hesitant like I was, then feel good about buying this game on sale.  I am almost done with my first play-through and I've gotten nearly 60 hours out of it already.  So that's like $2 per hour of fun, which is way cheaper than most things these days and I think I'll be able to do it a couple more times with various characters to try them out.  

Now, if only they could make BL4 follow a similar recipe...

The developers were too busy trying to create unique abilities that they didn't stop to ask themselves if those abilities were fun to use... in previous games the abilities of the characters were enjoyable to cast and all had fun visuals and felt good to use. In this one the abilities were crap and disappointing, and didn't make you feel powerful just felt janky.

[list] I picked this up during the free weekend, I had heard the gameplay was great while the writing was...less than great. That turned out to be a dramatic understatement. [/list][list]The gameplay is indeed fine, it's BL 3 with some new additions, but the writing is so bad that I had to skip every cutscene and before too long couldn't take playing the game anymore. Humor like the type attempted by the writers only works in contrast to serious content, so when LITERALLY every line of dialogue or tip or tutorial prompt is a joke then nothing is funny. [/list][list]Also, it's time for Tiny Tina to be retired. The character was okay in small doses in Borderlands 2, her BL 2 DLC worked because there was genuine emotion behind the story it was trying to tell which contrasted with her normally silly tone. Her presence in BL 3 was...less than great...but the story in that game was hot garbage anyway, so her addition was like the least offensive part. [/list][list]But this? This is too much Tiny Tina. This is too much jokey-jokey-jokey, it comes across as desperate, even pathetic. It's full-on fedora-tipping, cringe-inducing, reddit atheist "muh lady" levels of embarrassing. It was so bad that I just couldn't play the game anymore. Hard pass on this one.

If you like previous Borderlands games, you'll probably like this one. At least to start with. The problem is not the game itself, but rather the brevity - it just seems so much shorter, start to finish, than previous Borderlands games. Things get worse with the DLC, which is simply a rehash of the "chaos chamber" nonsense at the end of the game, which is in turn a rehash of the "combat encounters" in the Overlands section (kind of a map to get from area to area). All these aspects of the game are story-free shoot and loots, and whilst the Borderlands games are largely based on loot and shoot, these short sections seem utterly soul-less because they have no motivation other than shoot everything.I bought the game on special, and enjoyed the first playthrough but was surprised at how short it was. The Chaos Chambers and DLC left me cold, I did one Chaos run and the first DLC then gave up - they provide no motivation to continue!Buy it on super-special.

I want to like this game. The concept of a hybrid shooting/fantasy game is pretty interesting.

I don't like this game as much as I should, though. 

The only mechanics I truly love are some of the interesting spells, and some of the quirky weapons. 

The gameplay is otherwise quite boring. Melee weapons are useless. Companion wyvern is.. there? I guess?  Dual spells for spellshot is the only "yes please", since spells are pretty diverse and interesting. I found most the action skills just kinda boring. If they get better, I don't want to invest the time necessary to "level around and find out" if I am wrong.  

Borderlands 1 was this funny, creative beast. Borderlands 2 did a solid job of building off of that, with better mechanics, and a story that was still engaging. 

3? Prequel? This? Sigh. Think that's the 3 strikes and you're out.
