Well I bought this to play with friends and ended up playing with them for way too long to realize I disliked this game. I liked Borderlands 1, I thought Borderlands 2 was cool, but I never cared for the Pre-Sequel and I never even bothered with Borderlands 3. I personally did not like this game. My friends made it cool to play, because the writing is so cringe and terrible that we could just make fun of it and the characters which got me past the parts where someone is talking. But what you'll quickly realize is that everyone is always talking. Your character you created never stops talking, the npcs talk forever, and the quality of the jokes is not clever and or well executed. The game play is not very explanatory on what stats you'll actually need to be successful in a class when joining mid game on someone else's progress, which lead to me making a very poor character at first. So I started over, with some understanding of the mechanics a little better, which lead to a better character build, but now i'm playing solo and I feel like I am dying inside playing this game. The only fun part of this game is the combat because of how smooth it is, but let's be real, despite all of the options, it just boils down to shooting and casting a spell or doing your action skill in between. It's cool, it's fine, but it gets old fast. Your tolerance of terrible dialogue, excessive chatter, and loot to take forever looking at wondering if it's worth using maybe higher than mine. I bought this on sale and I feel robbed. I regret this purchase.

I like BL1 and 2. This and BL3 just aren't my cup of tea. This game has way too much platforming for my taste and the crossbolt mechanic is not something I enjoy. It also feels like the story board team wants to make sure that we all agree that everything LGBTQIA++the rest of the alphabet is normal and everyone should be a part of it takes away from enjoyment of the story for me. Sexual and gender identity video games are also not my cup of tea.
The spell mechanics of the spell slinger class, can't be arsed to remember the name, has its charm but the RNG loot system makes it difficult to gear up with the right spells to make my build work and when I get spell combos I do like, I quickly out level their usefulness and have to wait for the RNG dance to make it fun again.
There's some potential with the mechanics of this game and there's some charm to the environment, but not for a CIS gendered individual who likes the RP in an RPG and the guns of BL2.
Honestly, if Gearbox would just make a game that wasn't trying to be woke, or politically correct, took the loot system of BL3, the class system of this game and the Guns from BL2, and just went with a bland generic story, or even resurrect Jack and have us kick Hyperion's, or even a new indsutry's, ass across several galaxies and multiple planets, it would be amazing.
This game is not something I can recommend because it's sour notes are ruining the flavor of the soup.

That's a huge disappointment after Borderlands 3. Besides better graphics everything is much worse.
Shooting feels poor, no satisfaction from killing these creatures - they could rly add some dismemberment of skeletons upon crit kills, not a big deal.
The world is "plastic" and torn apart - to be honest, it wasn't supposed to be whole, but Tina's and the team's comments didn't make any success in creating any sort of "world" in this kinda DnD fantasy.
3 hours is enough for a story to catch you at least a bit - it couldn't here. Flat childish humor, non-organic, forced and unnecessary non-binary shit - everything makes you getting bored as fast as possible.

I even think that it's not gearbox software making that but some bunch of students used great developers team to make their dreams come true.

In short: if you were looking for to extend you borderlands experience - it's not here, keep looking.

The game is very fun and clever, with a great sense of humor. The graphics are gorgeous; the maps are enormous; the voice actors are incredible; the character customization has about as many options as Bethesda games do; the DLC is just as addictive as the main game; and the cross-platform compatibility really opens up the game world for multiplayer experiences.

It's a little buggy though. The Lost Loot feature doesn't work at all, which is probably the most disappointing bug. They're releasing updates and patches, but sometimes they do more harm than good. And I'm a little disappointed that the level cap is 40. With multi-classing available, I'd like to be able to explore more with skill points, but with only 40 skill points, your choices are to dabble in both classes a little, and never get to the really good skills, or master one class and barely scratch the surface of your second class. But they've released DLC with increased level caps before, so I remain hopeful.

That said, even with the level cap and ever-present glitches, it's a fantastic game and definitely worth buying.

After reading all of the mixed reviews I decided to pick this one up on sale along with all of its DLC for the extra $10. It's been a minute since I played Borderlands and Borderlands 2 and I'm not tabletop DnD player so I came into this with a limited expectations and a vague idea of what it was all about, and I can not say that I'm disappointed!
The play style is familiar and comfortable and its easy to get back into the Borderlands groove again. The artwork is nostalgic to my early days as a gamer though the color pallet is far more vibrant and spashy. The story narrative is absolutely hilarious! It's creative and well delivered and full of twists that will blind-side you and keep you on your toes. The professional comedic voice acting is a cherry on top. It's not any reason to purchase the game but it sure doesn't hurt it. There are choices (and consequences) to your actions and whether you take that short cut to an objective or put in the effort and see a part of the story that would otherwise be left untold.
Is it another 2K Borderlands game? Yes, but lets look at the roots of this one. It was a BL2 DLC that 2K decided was worth its own game. And they delivered! They took the Borderlands model (that works and has been successful) and re-skinned it. Then they added magic and fantasy and kept the guns. They gave it a paint job. And then they gave it full serving of comedy. They put all of that into a tabletop game and threw it into a box and called it Tiny Tina's Wonderlands and I'm not sorry to spend the $50 on it and it's 4 DLC on sale. Even at only 4 hours in at the time of this review, this has already become my new favorite game, and based on my previous Borderlands experience, I'll be playing this one for a very long time.

In short, is it worth the price tag? For me, yeah. I was happy to dish out the $50 CDN on this one for the full game and the 4 DLC.

[EDIT:] Now 80 Hours in and going for 100% completion. Can't say I'm bored yet, and I haven't even begun looking at the replayability of it with all of the viable class combinations. I stand by my original review. I'm happy with the amount of content here for the price I paid and I'm looking forward to putting in my next 80 hours.

TIny Tina's Wonderland is just another Borderlands game. I played this co-op and the combat was largely the same as prior entries just in a different setting. I think personally the Borderlands series is starting to lose its charm. The dialogue felt grating but in line with Borderlands 3. The side quests dragged on and had a ton of dialogue that served little purpose other than to waste time and tell bad jokes. You might expect combat to be different since this is a fantasy world but you still use guns - although there are a few new variants. The biggest deviation is using spells instead of grenades. The spells in the game do have some various new effects and visuals that were fun to use. 

I did have some good mindless fun playing this co-op but I think Gearbox needs to reevaluate it's formula - but maybe I'm just aging out of the target demographic. Overall there is some fun to be had here but I find it hard to recommend unless the game is at a steep discount.

EASILY the best borderlands to come out since borderlands 2. I might be biased as I have many sentimental and nostalgic memories of borderlands 2 with my brother so Im a huge fan of the series in general, but even if I take off those rose tinted glasses this game holds up. As always the art style is timeless and will always age like a fine wine. One of the most gorgeous borderlands yet, the colors are less faded than previous games, the lighting got a upgrade, the vistas look wonderful, and the stylistic choices of textures and U.I. all blend really well. The actual story is a nice surprise too, after the atrocious borderlands 3 I was concerned how awful this games writing would be but its actually pretty good and even got a few chuckles out of me. And the new big bad could obviously never fill the shoes of Handsome Jack but he does give similar vibes and is a huge step up from BL3 twins. So far I like the gear, abilities, and build potentials and the combat too, so its pretty solid on the gameplay aspect of it. I enjoy this game and it gives me hope for the franchise that was previously shattered by BL3. If you liked the assault on dragon keep dlc of borderlands 2 Im sure you will enjoy this.

Weapons and weapon drops are nerfed and this game has turned into a sloggy grind where it takes multiple reloads to take out even basic monsters.  Somewhere between BL3 and this there has to be a happy medium with loot drops.

Edit : Finished the game, figured out what happened.   During the first part of the game I was seriously having to grind through everything - every monster seemed to take 2 reloads just to finish off.  
At some point after that first third, either by grinding +loot% dice or the +loot% gear I was wearing, the gear caught up to the game and it stopped being as much of a slog.  
  
Switching the review to Yes - I recommend it to other players.  Not highly recommended though - the game was pretty repetitive and the combat was lacking in anything special about it.    The voice acting and the dialogue was stellar however.  

The DLCs were underwhelming though, lacking that sparkle from Frette, Valentine and Tina.

It's amazing. Honestly I find borderlands a bit to bogged down. The overworld map here reduces the amount of fast travel and adds some fun game play to the movement around the world. The quests are fun, and there are a lot of cheeky jokes that you can pick up on, from pun names to creatures that resemble other shows (like smurfs). 
The only real complaints I have are the lack of stuff to use money on - new gear is great but I wish there was something meaningful I could use it on, like town upgrades, or something. And the loot system ends up being a little lack lustre. After a while I don't even bother to pick up certain color item drops cause it's not worth the inventory space. Lastly, I wish we could use and have more traditional weapons. Like, I want a bow and arrow, and a staff and wand. 

Otherwise, I think if you're looking for something light, easy to play and quick paced that you can pick up and put down on a whim, this game is perfect.

I don't usually leave reviews, since I don't normally 100% games.
Short: Was 'ight, worth the money, especially if on sale

Long:
It took me about 45 hours give or take 4-5 for being in menus or afk to 100% the game, the story was, fine, nothing ground breaking or terrible, tho I must say the pattern Gearbox has made with the Borderlands franchise is odd, being one step forward half a step back in the timeline, since its now goes, 1, 2, pre-sequel, 3, and now Wonderlands which is strange since the only return characters are CL4P-TP, Brick, Mr.Torgue, and Tina, kinda was hoping more would have showed up. This game becomes rather repetitive if you 100% as some of the parts are just random arenas and the end game becomes a seem-ie rogue lite were you pick up curses or boon as you go through those Arenas ending in a boss from the story, its interesting and can be enjoyable for a quick pick up and spend an hour doing a run, but having gotten far enough in to say for sure on that end. that all being said, it was a fun enough story, its worth the money I spent, but I will most likely be avoiding the DLCs until a sale happens.

It is with a heavy heart that I feel compelled to post a negative review for a Borderlands game, but this one is quite a rip off, compared to previous titles.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands substitutes grinding and repetitive combat for story and content. This isn't even funny, like a Tiny Tina quest, the writing is just bollocks.

It was OK, I was getting through it, enduring it for a higher purpose... to get into the second playthrough and get the skill perks all unlocked, and keep getting better gear like the Borderlands formula has always been.

I finished the game, did most of the side quests, did the DLC encounters all twice to get "lost souls" to spin the Wheel of Fate to get gear, but the gear was always repetitions of the same things so I gave that up.

Time to start the second playthrough. Wait a minute, how do I do that, I don't see it in the Character choosing interface.

There isn't one! The game is essentially over at level 40 and there's no more gameplay for that character unless you just want to repeat tedious encounters. There is no incentive for me to want to start this game over with a new character, it's just not that much fun.

STEAM DECK REVIEW:  
Battery Life.  Apx. 1 Hr on Standard Settings
Story:  Short; 24 Hours 
Replayability:  High
Improvements:  Better than Borderlands 3 in both story content & replayability.  Introducing Chaos Levels allows the difficulty and quality of look to be increased exponentially.  This includes a weekly featured run, and chaos runs to fit your appetite.  This function also applies to zones outside of the Chaos Room which felt great when catching up on side content.  
Bugs:  Enemies get stuck from time to time.  Nothing else that impacts experience.  
DLC:  Could be better.  Added a few "Challenge" levels with a specific theme.  Not any major story content.
Verdict:  8/10;  Runs better on deck than expected without any real crashes or major issues.  If you are playing on battery life keep in mind you will get about 1 hour's worth of time with this game. It feels less like a borderlands game and more like Assault on Dragon Keep extended edition.  I thoroughly enjoyed it though.

This makes me sad as a borderlands and a D&D fan... but i can't recommend this. There are a lot of nice references to D&D tropes that will raise a smile if you're a fan but compared with Borderlands 2 and 3 the game just feels lazy, it feels small. I know exactly why they did it- to recreate the feel of D&D encounter maps- but this gets repetative fast, the 'arenas' that most of the fights take place in are small and unimaginative and have little to no distinctive qualities. The 'Overworld' map is an poor replacement for the true open nature of the aforementioned Borderlands games and gets old real fast. The 'random encounters' do nothing to further the game other than pad out the short runtime. Even the loot in this one feels forced, there's too much of it and not enough things to make it stand out.

It's a 6/10 at best. By all means buy it but do so at a heavy discount. I got it at 50% off and feel mildly disappointed by it.

After playing the game for more than a hundred hours, I finally decided to give the game a fair review. 

Been a fan of the series since the first Borderlands game. TTW gives me mixed feelings. Don't get me wrong. The game is good and felt like the rest of the series. Love the lore and new elements tailored for TTW. 

SPELLS & GUNS:
I find myself spending more time mix and match with the spells than guns. The guns are fun and top notch just like any other Borderlands guns. However the spells are the cream and butter of the game. Each time I obtained a new spell, I would spend time to develop new builds to make use of them. Although later in the end game, I find myself sticking to only few of the spells... Wish there is more variety and fun to use spell. 

CLASSES:
The dual class is fun! Only that I have so many skill point to spend. 

LORE and Characters:
Mix feeling about the lore and characters come back. I wish to see more old faces in the game. It's a pity only a handful of the series characters joined the game. If only the later DLC could have them in the content. Dragon Lord is my 2nd fav antagonist of the series. Not gonna spoil, but he is funny and yet serve the purpose of carrying throughout the entire journey. 

END GAME:
The CHaos Chamber is actually quite fun. I didn't expect myself to spend so much time in it. It has became one of my daily activities. It's like the whole campaign is just a prologue to finally unlocking this mode. 

DLC:
Meh...... 

TTW isn't perfect and may or may not live up to your expectation, but hey, if you like Borderlands and especially the Dragonbane Keep, TTW is a game that you shouldn't miss.

Yes, this game has it's bugs and it's combat monotony among other things but that's not why I recommend this game. Firstly, while some find the narrative a bit annoying and un-skippable, I find it hilarious especially if you like old table top D&D. This game brings you right back to the days of demi-gorgons (Skellymans et. al) in your mother's basement with your closest friends and a table top pieced together with random household odds and ends.  
Secondly, speaking of friends, this game is about an infinite amount of times better than soloing it. You can even punch each other in free roam. 
Yes, there's bugs, but the story is entertaining and spending time in a game just running around gathering money and epic loot to pass the time while laughing at ridiculous jokes and hilariously named Bosses is entertainment enough for any rainy or snowy day. If you're looking for something light (ish) and funny to pass the time with friends, this might be the game you're looking for.

Great fun, especially on a discount. But who pays full price for games on steam anymore? Isnt that why we all have $2,000 computers??  Fast paced action with spells and gunplay; with special abilities  for each class. The combos you can create are many. The main story is easy peasy even on the hardest difficulty but once you unlock chaos levels the game gets harder, much harder. Proper builds and gear will be essential to make it through all 100 chaos levels. Infinite respecs and the ability to rechoose your second class after beating the game go along way for replayability. And the loot, the loot, the loot! So much loot, and there are many different types of guns and spells which all have randomly rolled damage types and buffs so you will grind away searching for that perfect gun or armor with the stats you need for your build. And the game runs great on mid to low tier hardware. I have a 3060ti with a 10600k and can pull off pretty much maxed out graphics at 1440p while maintaining 70-100 FPS depending on the area. Grab it on sale and join the fun! Did I mention 4 play co op with cross play? If you have friends this is a fun one to do boss runs and grinding with.

I can see why this game got worse reviews than the other Borderlands games. However, I’m still really enjoying it:

The good:
+Movement feels the best out of any Borderlands game I’ve played
+Loot pool is vast, weapon models and animations are top tier, alternative fire modes are far more creative than BL2 for example
+When you level up, you get a skill point AND a hero point (classic STR/DEX/CON etc.)
+Loot dice and marbles incentivize exploring and you develop a sense of “I should check over here for dice/marble”. Finding dice drops loot and gives a buff for finding better items that persists for the rest of the game. Finding all of the marbles grants a permanent buff to STR and dmg(?)
+Lots of new enemies with a familiar flavor to the Borderlands franchise. One of my favorites is the shark dog lol

The bad:
-The way your character acts is like the rest of the dialogue and writing: annoying, rude, childish
-The encounter system is new and fun the first few times… and then you notice the same couple of maps over and over
-You are able to poke around and explore a lot of these giant maps. Then later, you get a quest for… those areas you already explored… so there you are again but this time with quest objectives / a purpose 

The ugly:
-The writing and dialogue is awful. It is so annoying. Their audience clearly isn’t the now older generation that played Borderlands 1/2. It’s like it was written by teenagers for teenagers.
-The game takes place as a visualization of playing Dungeons and Dragons. The world and your impact on it feels trivial / pointless because this all takes place in a game of DnD rather than saving the world/town/etc. 


Overall, I’d give this game a solid 7/10

It's a dungeons and dragons type feel, but with wonderlands aspects to it. Lot's of interaction with Tiny Tina and many opportunities to fully customize your character and make the game more unique to you. The multiplayer is great. Haven't played solo

In terms of the storyline, I would say its a nice (but short) story. Some good humour, not too forced and in general is a borderlands-like experience.
The main downside to this game, is unlike borderlands, the room to explore, the amount of side quests to do, bosses to beat, loot to explore etc. is no where near the level it should be. After completing the story, you're almost at a stand still. You can grind for better weapons, and upgrade your myth rank, but the skill tree and fighting style would never be as "Badass" as the Borderlands games.
The DLC's also aren't extended storylines, but more the equivalent of the headhunter packs in Borderlands 2 which in term, is just another dungeon boss to beat, except it feels too forced with bad storytelling.
I paid full price for this game, so for that I don't recommend. For the price-to-playability/story length ratio, I wouldn't pay more than £20 for the game.

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is a First Person Shooter set in the Borderlands universe, where the player is taking part in a Dungeons & Dragons style Bunkers & Badasses campaign run by Tina.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

•	Its Borderlands with a fantasy theme, so if you’ve played any Borderlands shooter, the combat will feel familiar.

•	Fight against skeletons, goblins, giant crabs, shark dogs and nagas. Borderlands has always featured strange creatures, so the fantasy theme basically just means “no robots”.

•	There are a few character classes to choose from. I started with Clawbringer, who reminded me of Marvel’s Thor because they can throw a massive hammer to deal lightning (or fire) damage to all enemies in a large area. I also had a pet wyvern who flies around breathing fire at enemies. Part way through the game you can multiclass, and I chose Spore Warden to get a pet mushroom who runs around biting enemies. Those pets are surprisingly useful and got quite a few kills as well as just generally distracting enemies.

•	As usual you can equip a variety of pistols, SMGs, assault rifles, sniper rifles, shotguns, and rocket launchers, which all have different magazine sizes, zoom sights, elemental damage, etc. You can also use spells, which are just fantasy themed grenades, and melee weapons.

•	The best part of the game is the unique gun designs, which are a lot of fun to use. There were so many times that I decided “this is my new favourite gun”, only to find something else that was even better a short time later.  A few of my favourites include an SMG which freezes enemies, a sniper rifle that shoots triple saw blades, a crossbow that fires crossbows (which fire extra bolts), an SMG which fires a poison damage laser beam that slightly homes in on nearby enemies, and a rapid fire pistol which halved my health when reloading but leeched health back when damaging enemies.

•	The hard / “intense” difficulty started out fairly challenging, but over time became easier as I found more powerful guns.

[h1]Story[/h1]

•	Both the main story and all the side quests are absolute nonsense. Dialogue is terrible. Every character is annoying. Because Tina is the DM, everything sounds like it was written by her. In previous Borderlands games, when Tina shows up for a couple of quests, her chaotic energy can be an interesting change of pace. But it turns out that a whole game that sounds like Tina is just exhausting. After a few hours I lost interest and stopped listening as much as possible.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

•	It took me 29 hours to complete the main story and most of the side quests.

•	I didn’t have any problems with bugs, crashes or framerate.

•	Controls are fully rebindable and work great with mouse and keyboard.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is a decent game if you just want to turn off your brain and shoot stuff. Buy on sale.

Or more like 'Maaaaybe". If it's on an insane sale. The load time between areas is insane. You'll think your computer has locked up. Also the game pauses, freezes and hangs up a lot. Sometimes you'll weapon switch and the game will freeze for a while.
Besides those two issues, the game itself is just not Borderlands quality. It's boring. It's more of a children's game. It struggles really desperately to be clever but it's like they hired a team of woke 12 year olds to write the story and the dialogue.
Examples:
The bar you are told to go to makes a point in emphatically emphasizing more than once that all the drinks are non-alcoholic. Besides that there's no reason for you to go there or for it to exist in the game. RIP Moxi I guess. (Anytime you run into anyone drinking anything the game goes out of it's way to assure you it's just a soda. It's weird.)

One of the skills on your skill tree is to give your companion the ability to fart.

I only remember there being one straight character in the game and he is in love with a broom, because it has straight blond hair. Get it? He thinks the straw is hair.

Your way is blocked so you must find the pure essence of snot to clear the way.

You do a quest for an archer who is looking for a legendary bow. When you find it, it's actually a bow-tie. Get it? BOW...... tie. Get it?

And those are the knee slappers.
The only time I laughed was when the little angry feminist npc called my female character a misogynist out of the blue. 
Buy it if you think those gags are clever and hilarious or if it's on an incredible sale and there's nothing else to play.
(the Borderlands 2 Tiny Tina DLC on the other hand is really great)

It is a Borderlands game, it has the gunning, it has the looting, it has the humor and it has all the good gameplay mechanics BL3 brought into the franchise (faster and fluent movement, climbing, enjoyable gun controls, etc.).

Why put it on neutral? Well it's relatively short. It has one of the best settings (DnD) and the possibilities are endless but yet, it is short and every single one of the DLCs does not really add anything. They are just another boss in like 1 room you can run through, they are rightfully voted as "very negative" here on steam. 

Since it's a fantasy setting where Tina literally creates the world, the possibilities are truly endless but the devs apparently decided to not do anything with that and just let that idea die. That's the saddest part of this game.

An interesting spin-off of the Borderlands games that brings some new stuff, but is also unfortunately hindered by other aspects.

Based on Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep (originally a BL2 DLC but later released as a standalone), Wonderlands is a new tale being told by Tiny Tina during a game of Bunkers & Badasses, with a new group this time, and the player's character is a newbie in the group.

This time, instead of playing as pre-set characters as in previous Borderlands games, for the first time, the player is able to create their own character, not only choosing how they look and sound but also assigning attribute points as well. While I think the way attributes affect the character feels a little too simple in this game and could have been expanded on, I think this is a good starting point if future Borderlands games (or at least future Wonderlands games) use this concept - which I think they should.

As for designing the character in terms of visuals... While I like the idea, I'm not a fan of the execution. It kinda feels like no matter how much you change your character, they never look satisfying, there is always something off about how they look.

Gameplay-wise, there aren't a lot of complaints - it's basically how other Borderlands games work with a few changes, mostly on how grenades are replaced with spells and how the game now has actual melee combat. While melee combat is very simple and it's really only about holding the middle mouse button to attack, it's still a step in the right direction for future games and far better than other games where it was only guns granting melee damage bonuses and with enemies' melee attacks causing constant knockback. Spells are also a cool addition to the game, working on cooldown (varying with each spell) rather than based on amount and with different effects that go beyond just causing damage, as some spells are more focused on utility. Guns are still mostly guns, with some crossbows and other ranged weapons added to it, but the gunplay is still the same for the most part.

The story is... Okay. I don't hate it, but I don't love it either and I think it's definitely a step back from Assault on Dragon Keep, which was a lot more interesting. The story has its moments, but the villain feels severely underused - it's only later in the game when the villain finally makes an appearance and gives the player's character an actual reason to want to defeat them, before that it's only some lines of dialogue from him and Tina telling the player's character that he's the big bad guy. And after that, the only moment when the villain becomes relevant again besides the occasional dialogue is right close to the end.

Like Borderlands 3 before, Wonderlands has challenges to be completed in each map which involve finding certain things. This is mostly fun and encourages exploration, but the problem is how the game deals with the Loot Die. Basically, without finding these, the chances for higher rarity drops in the game is very low, so finding these die becomes sort of mandatory if the player wants to have a decent chance at acquiring better loot. Fortunately, it only has to be done once, as it carries over to other characters.

The game also removes the ability to farm bosses for drops, as bosses no longer respawn after they're defeated, which is a very weird design choice for a Borderlands spin-off game.

Classes are fun to play as - while the skill selection for each class feels slightly limited, the ability to multi-class later in the game allows for different skills from two different classes to be mixed together, which then allow for some interesting builds.

I also specially like how Myth Ranks work in the game, where points spent are cycled through 4 different groups of stats instead of offering random selections - even though each point has to be spent on each of these different groups, you can choose in which stat inside that group that point goes to, so it's possible to focus and max out certain stats to the player's preferences.

The way the game deals with end-game content is interesting, but extremely repetitive, with the inclusion of Chaos Chambers, a sort of roguelike mode where the player goes into these chambers, getting progressively harder while also unlocking bonuses for the player's character, then rewarding them with loot at the end. It's the main way the game has of acquiring legendaries and it's fun at first, but with a total of 50 chaos levels to progress through, it gets very repetitive very fast.

Overall, Wonderlands does some things right and some things wrong, tries a few new things, some of these work and some don't. There is room for improvement in future games and I hope that some of the new things included in Wonderlands carry over to future games, while others should be improved on.

So, I will preface all of this by saying that I went into this game with low expectations. The Borderlands games were an absolute favorite of mine for the first and second games, but by the time The Pre-Sequel and 3 came out (I forget which order they were released in, I want to say Pre-Sequel was released first) I had pretty much lost interest in the franchise and really FPS games entirely, but when I saw Tiny Tina's my inner RPG addict tag teamed with my nostalgia and convinced me to buy the game after I had beaten Elden Ring for the nth time and was in desperate search of something new. 

[hr][/hr]

[h1][u][b]The Pros[/b][/u][/h1]

○ [u]Classic Borderlands[/u] 
And I do mean classic. It felt like playing the original game again. No grand universe-scope plot. Just you as some random nobody going around and beating up on crap until it spits out loot and gold...so much gold!

○ [u]The Comedic Value[/u] 
This was one of the many things I loved about the original game. Is the humor brash and juvenile? Absolutely. But it's part of what makes the game so unique. I love it.

○ [u]What RPG elements were in the game, were solid[/u] 
I liked the class mechanics (I've only done Gloombringer (Graveborn/Clawbringer) so far, but I fully intend to give the other classes a test run). The action skills were cool, I really dug the talent trees and the way the different class combos could play off of each other.

○ [u]The utter disregard for the Fourth Wall[/u] 
Okay. So, I'm a writer. This is one of my favorite literary devices of all time. That direct split where the fourth wall comes down and the characters in the story are [b]fully[/b] aware that they're fictional characters is just...yes. I loved it.

○ [u]Tina, Valentine, and Fette[/u] 
The dynamic between these three was just fantastic. They really brought the game together, and Andy Samburg's performance as Valentine was A plus.

○ [u]Claptrap[/u]
Seeing this little guy pop up at various points was a really nice dose of nostalgia. I don't really have much else to say than that without risking spoiling anything, but thank you Gearbox for bringing him into the fold for this one.

○ [u]The Story[/u]
Once again, Gearbox managed to do what so few FPS games have been able to manage in the past. We got a compelling narrative alongside great gunplay. I was invested in the story, I wanted to know what was going to happen next. I even went as far as loading an outdated cloud save when my computer decided to seize up right before a cutscene.

○ [u]The Atmosphere[/u]
I have to admit, this impressed me [i]a lot[/i]. Gearbox managed to encapsulate what it's like to sit at a TTRPG session with an absolute loon of a DM (love you Tina, but you're off your rocker and that's what I love most about you). The bickering between Valentine and Fette, as well as two of them regularly poking holes in Tina's prepared content that resulted in her having to improvise like hell. It was great. It brought back some fond memories from a campaign I ran years ago.

[hr][/hr]

[h1][u][b]The Cons[/b][/u][/h1]

○ [u]I felt a little...misled[/u] 
This is probably my own fault because truth be told, I knew [i]nothing[/i] about this game aside from the vague explanation of "It's Borderlands meets D&D." I went into it expecting more RPG elements than it had, something with more focus on sword and board and less guns. But, again. I think I did that one to myself. 

○ [u]The guns[/u] 
So, as we all know from our time spent playing Borderlands (and if you don't know, then now you will), one of the big themes in all the games was the whole "every gun manufacturer has their own gimmick" deal. I feel like I get what Gearbox was trying to do here, that is to blend magic into modern/futuristic firearms, but in my opinion it just fell short. 

In the 40 hours or so it took me to work my way to the end of the game whilst being distracted by side quests, I found myself almost always holding onto a Blackpowder weapon that was a huge item level gap behind other options because there wasn't some gimmick to it. It was just a gun.

○ [u]The Character Customization[/u]

Okay, I want to preface this with one very important thing. To my knowledge, Gearbox has never given us any sort of customization options besides color (I think that was a thing, that might not even have been) in any of the previous games, so I applaud them for finally doing so. 

That being said, I found the whole system utterly clunky and annoying. The initial character creation had so few options, I finally ended up just randomizing things because even with the slider overdrive on there just was not enough diversity of options to really compel me to sit there on character creation for hours on end like I've done with many RPG titles in the past.

○ [u]The Overworld[/u]

I felt like I needed a map to read what was essentially the world map. The Overworld, to me, felt like an unnecessary mini game and a pretty perfunctory attempt at giving that open world feel to a game franchise that has traditionally been pretty linear. The shrine piece collecting was tiresome considering the limited reward for finishing each of them, and the side quests were almost without exception nothing more than the same fetch quest with different flavor text.

○[u]The Spells[/u]

The only reason I found myself actually using spells was because of the Graveborn talent that granted HP regen on spell use and Morhaim's Blessing which gave you all of those wonderful kill skills every time you activated a spell. They were a utility item for me, half the time I didn't even bother to aim them I just tapped the button to gain the bonuses it would bring. I feel like more could have been done here.

○ [u]Performance Issues[/u]

Specs for the PC I played on
◘ Intel i5 9400F 2.90GHz
◘ 8GB DDR4 RAM
◘ NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650 SUPER
◘ Game data stored on HDD (not 100% sure on speed, but I think 7200)

For starters, I want to state clearly that I am completely aware that I am barely above the minimum requirements to run the game. This is a hand-me-down PC that I'm still working on getting new parts for.

That being said, I ran into [i]constant[/i] crashes when I first started playing, and this was with the game's settings set as low as they could go. There was stuttering, and freezing, and all sorts of crazy stuff. I ended up having to go into NVIDIA's control panel and fiddle with some rendering settings just to get the game stable. 

Vsync was not an option for me, much to my chagrin (motion sickness issues), but I believe this is a me problem given the strain that vSync puts on the GPU and my GPU's inability to handle it.

Cutscenes were also still a pretty big problem even after my fiddling in the NVIDIA control panel. I had to cut power to the machine via the power supply switch at one point because a cutscene locked my computer up to the point where even holding the power button down wouldn't send a shutdown command.

[hr][/hr]

[h1][b][u]To Summarize: A solid 8/10 from me[/u][/b][/h1]

If you read everything above, I just want to say thank you for taking the time. I know that's a lot of opinion to throw about with only 40 hours of gameplay under my belt, but I wanted to write this while it was still fresh in my mind. Despite the nature of my Con's list might indicate, I would still highly recommend the game to anyone and everyone who asks me about it. 

I had one hell of a good time playing it, and am going to keep playing it for the post lvl 40 content (at least until the loot pinata stuff you unlock after beating the game gets stale). It's an amazing blend of the FPS and RPG genres and I was very satisfied with my purchase. 

I look forward to what the future of the game has to offer in the form of DLC and hope that this turns into as much of a long standing and active title as Borderlands 3 has (which I now fully intend to download on this PC and finally get around to playing).

Ive always been a fan of the borderlands series since it released! Ive played every one of them.. so this game was an easy certainty to be picked up! 

Visually the game has a very attractive feel to it, the guns i found were fun to use, there were enough styles and types to keep me happy! 

I very much enjoyed the character class selection followed by being able to link with another class shortly into the game! As i was playing solo i went spore and dragon pet build which just made life truly easy for my play through!

I thought the open world concept of walking across the map was very clever accompanied by the always quirky borderlands-esk humour and story line! 

Dont play this game thinking you'll be able to hardcore blast into the main story missions and wipe out the campaign as there are level hurdles where  zones require you to be a certain level before progressing which forces your hand to dive into side quests or grinding! 

Ill be honest there were times towards the end of the game that it fell off for me and felt stale, the guns were not doing the damage i wanted them to.. the mobs were irritating to fight with resists and burrowing.. some dialog quests contained alot of standing about...  i felt alot of the quest rewards and loot were really underwhelming so upgrades were in my play through quite disappointing.

The game did pick up again eventually when i did stumble onto some good loot :) and the over all story line was quite entertaining

Love this game. Amazed it isn't better-known; is vastly underrated. Original, funny, and engaging--love the D&D setup with Tina's narrative, meta-humor, and sheer quirkiness as well as the superb voice acting by Andy Samberg, Wanda Sykes, and especially Will Arnett. It was worth the cost for that alone. Seeing a fantasy version of Borderlands has been vastly entertaining, and the game has a surprising amount of heart.

The class mixing is a great touch and adds considerable re-playability. I'm on my third playthrough (back to back to back) and the game still hasn't gotten old. 

My only real complaint is the same one I have with all Borderlands games--too much loot. So much loot. Thousands and thousands of loots. Feel like I spent half of my first playthrough organizing inventory. Barely even bother now. 

All in all, fantastic game. Get it.

It's just the borderlands 2 DLC stretched out over a whole game with Borderlands 3 gameplay. Actual reasons to look around the maps as well with the lucky dice mechanic, with rewarding secrets that give you permanent buffs for clearing out 100% of every area. For the first time in the entire series I was compelled to do side content because it scales to your level now, no more suctioning up side quests only to outlevel them all while you do them. Multiclassing lets me play as a turret character AND a companion character at once, and the spell system instead of grenades allows for much more variety. Photo mode is comprehensive and lets you turn off your player character. My 3080 and 5800x got well over 100 fps maxed out settings without volumetric fog and without AMD FSR turned on since I can't handle that amount of motion blur on everything. I'm 25 hours in and probably about to beat the game soon, not that I've been paying a high amount of attention to the story.

I'm giving it a thumbs up because it's a good (not great) addition to the Borderlands universe.

Pros

Tiny Tina is always entertaining. The Bunkers and Badasses format is fun. As with everything in the BL universe, the open world is immersive and fantastically detailed. It's just a lot of fun to walk around and look at the scenery. The game is exactly what you would expect when Tiny Tina is in charge.

Cons

The game is just too easy. The boss fights are anemic. The side quests are only there for you to look at the scenery. They don't add anything to the game. The story line is too short. Without doing any side quests, you could sleep through the game in a couple of nights. The encounters are repetitive and after awhile, downright boring.

It's probably not worth $60 US, to be honest, so you might want to wait until the price drops a little.

[h2]Better with Friends (and in cooperation IMHO)[/h2]
I have done three play throughs of the game. One by myself, one with a full party of four, and one with a single close friend.

[h3]By Myself[/h3]
It was like an excellent story game with good combat and a decent open world. I even spent the time to find all the luck dice. Loads of fun, but only once. Also the end game felt a bit shallow since there was no real reason to do it.

[h3]With a Single Good Friend[/h3]
It gave new life to the story since we could discuss it as it was happening. We had both previously played it alone and this was our second time through the game. At low levels we could get away with going to very high level areas since we could cover each others weaknesses. Since we knew how the game worked we also waited to do the side quests until after finishing the main story and hitting max lvl. This allowed us to get the side quest weapons in stronger versions. They are very comparable to most legendaries and can have entire build based around them [spoiler]rip and tear + buffmeister[/spoiler]. 

[h3]With a Full Party[/h3]
This truly felt like the chaos of my old teenage DnD sessions. One person would be trying to find collectables. Another would be organizing their inventory/shopping. Then some one else would be blowing through the map bypassing the story. I was there just enjoying the chaos of it all. 
The end game also seemed more interesting now that we can compete against each other for the best build.

[h2]End Game and Replay-ability[/h2]
I could definitely see myself coming back to this game. I recently got all the DLC and have not tried it yet. I am not sure how many full play throughs I have left in me. The end game still seems like it might have more to offer.

[h3]End Game[/h3]
I have only done the chaos chamber stuff and am at chaos rank 45. There is definitely a balance issue between weapons (Ruby/sword splosion OP). Every class has at least one viable build, but I am not sure about every combination of classes. I like the loot system in the chaos runs. It really cuts down on the grind times. My friend has an issue with the legendaries not feeling special or rare enough. I think this is fine as it allows you to try the build that you want without hours of hassle. I think that this is very fun provided that you still have quests remaining, otherwise it feels pointless.

[h3]Replay-ability[/h3]
I think that three, from the start, play throughs is a decent amount. I do not strongly feel the need to play it again in any of those fashions. The nice thing about cooperation mode is that the enemies scale to each individual. I can do another play through with someone else hosting as a lvl 6, but I join with a lvl 40 with chaos mode active and it is still a challenge. Unfortunately you do not get the quest rewards a second time. 
There is also something to be said for leveling one of each of the character. Leveling half the characters would also work due to the multiclass system. This would allow for every singe combination to be tried. I just wish the chaos ranks were account wide like the myth rank.

[h3]Wishful Thinking[/h3]
I think a new game + mode with different banter making fun of how broken the noobie is would have been fun. I would mostly want to attempt all the quests in different chaos ranks just to see how extreme the enemies get.

Never got into the borderlands games but this game blew me away. love it, 9/9

For a "Looter Shooter" the loot system in this game feels bad. I'm level 25 and all my gear is "Purple - Epic". I've been playing for 2 hours and EVERY SINGLE chest I've opened has had Trash tier guns or gear in it. When you fight your way through a Zone or find a hidden room, and open the chest, and all the guns are "Blue or Green" tier - it feels bad. But yet, you go to a Vending Machine in the city, it has 3 or 4 EPIC level guns to buy. 

This game can be fun at times, but the Loot system needs a rework BADLY.

Further, the enemies just become more Bullet Spongey as time goes on. Getting 200 "Critical Hits" on an enemy with "Fire Weakness" for example does not feel satisfying. Critical Hits should be special..

Also, you can't track more than one quest at a time. So you'll often bypass necessary objectives, enemies, or areas - just because you're tracking a different quest. But it's all in the same Zone and area.

Borderlands has fun gameplay and lots of cool guns, classes, and a neat world to inhabit. But it's really showing it's age from a Game Design perspective.

Couple that with the TRY TOO HARD writing where EVERY LINE has to try and be a joke - You've got a game with no stakes, no emotional resonance. The inventory needs work. The enemies AI needs work. The quest system needs work.

If you're a die-hard Borderlands fan- this may tickle your fancy. But for the rest of us, we deserve a bit more from the (5th?) entry in this series.

As much as I enjoyed playing Borderlands 3, as much was I bored when playing Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. It's not a bad game per se, but it just doesn't hold up to its legacy. I wanted to finish it, and I did, but it wasn't much fun most of the time.
The writing feels mostly uninspired, with the ratio of laughable jokes being far below its predecessor's, its characters(!) and its DLCs. The gameplay feels sluggish at times, although probably being built upon its predecessor's foundation. The story's highlight, from my point of view, happened quite early in the game. Its DLCs add nearly nothing to the game apart from new loot and multiple, loosely connected series of semi-horde and arena combats.

If you liked the previous shooter installments of the franchise, you might like this as well. If you really enjoyed the previous installments though, you might be disappointed.

The customization is pretty expansive which is cool, but I didn't use it too much. Id say my biggest gripes were how repetitive the dungeons felt, and how bad the loot luck is even after collecting majority of the dice. I mostly came to write this review because of how LONG the unskippable credit scene is at the end after the boss fight and cinematic show. I spent 15 minutes doing random things waiting and its still going with no end in sight. I'm not sure these credits will ever end, I may never  pick up that sweet golden loot I saw. I feel sadness.

Fantastic game. If you like D&D it's a must. Don't give up in the first 10 or so levels, it's a little slow and boring for the first few hours (dull starting areas, repetitive enemies and lame guns) but gets so much more fun later on. The guns get better as you get higher level, the areas become a lot more fun to explore and the side quests are entertaining. At least get to the "ocean" area before giving up. 

Some people will disagree with me, but I think the Borderlands series has only improved more and more over time (with the except of The Pre Sequel, which I consider to be the worst game). The gameplay has gotten more refined and polished, the graphics are fantastic, and the areas/zones are just bigger, better, more unique, and more fun to explore. The side quests in this game are the best in the series, in my opinion. The game is challenging enough without being frustrating like it could be in the first game. The dual class system is also the most fun character building system of any Borderlands games. I love being able to wear equipment (ring, necklace, chest, melee weapon, etc.), which only improves the "loot hunting" aspect. I love collecting all the customization drops, but I hate that we don't have gun skins like in Borderlands 3? Why not both? 

On to the negatives. The comedy is hit or miss, but that's how it is in every single Gearbox game, so nothing new. Claptrap is hilarious in this game, but some of the other minor characters are cheesy. Also just a general complaint about all Borderlands games that I've always hated: enemies respawn TOO fast. It should be like 30 minutes, not 5-10 as it seems in this game, which makes it annoying. The game could use some more endgame DLC, too. I don't know if they plan to release more but I hope they do. I know they said they're going to make more Wonderlands games, but I think it would be nice to make this one as big as possible first.

I enjoyed playing this game, and did so in co-op with my husband. It was fun, but disjointed, and felt "off". It was almost as though the franchise needed a filler and that is exactly what we got. Tiny Tina's voice is annoying, and even more so when you get to the over-world. it was clunky, and some of the quests didn't quite fit in. The entire weapon, and armor system is a joke. Some of the DLCs were just okay, but there was one that no matter what we did, it would get stuck in various parts, and we would have to restart it. 

I kept waiting for the real BL feel, the real quirky questions, and smart-ass one liners. It was still fun to play, but to me, there isn't real reason to try it again. The Chaos levels are boring as well. 

Bottom Line- it's fun if you love Borderlands, but please don't expect that same BL flavor.

Subpar by the numbers version of BL. Also filled with various bugs and also first game I have encountered which actually punishes players who got DLC's. 

Usually if you have DLCs, their content is not open to other players who do not own them, which is understandable. In Tiny Tina's Wonderland it's actually DLC owners who lose content like e.g. graphics of items because apparently in multiplayer you cannot show item graphics if you happen to own DLCs (game actually even mentions you that) which is a bit weird because why would the player who actually has the more content not be able to see e.g. item graphics. So after a while of playing ALL item graphics start to disappear from your menus until every item you have have its graphics missing so you cannot separate amulet from a shotgun it you do not go and see the stats which you can use to identify which type of item it is. This continues you restart the game and go back to single player. Which makes the whole loot organizing even more pain in the donkey than what it usually is. Which is bit of a bunker buster in a game build around looting stuff. Also various quest related bugs you have to restart the game to get working again.

You cannot even copy paste shift-codes within the game. If you wanted to you'd have to register to separate web page to copy paste them there IF you wanted to do in conveniently. Funny how BL2 managed to do EVEN that better over 10 years ago. It's like technology is going back in time, or 2K want's to e.g. monetize people registering to their web-page or something. Because actual sense that decision does not make nor is the code to allow it complicated because it's a input field within a application.

Game also seems to be resource hog while not giving anything particularly eye candy back in return. Got this from sale. Looking forward to finish it to get it uninstalled.

Its a Borderlands game through and through which is absolutely great. In fact, mechanically, graphically, even in terms of the gameplay loop, this game is really fun.

So what's my problem with Tiny Tina's minuscule side campaign? My problem is the price to length ratio of the game. It is stupidly short, and the end-game, while enjoyable for a bit, grows old faster than that stuff under the keys in your keyboard.

Compared to other BL games, this one is about a quarter of the length. If it ever comes to you at a reasonable price, like a really reasonable price... it might be worth it...

Tiny TInas Wonderlands developed by Gearbox is a spin off title from the Borderlands series, specifically Borderlands 2 Assault on Dragon Keep DLC. Where that DLC worked because of its brevity and setting, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands takes the great setting and improves it in multiple ways that add to the "Dnd experience" such as an overworld, and new stat/ progression paths tied to dnd like experiences. This combined with the super smooth gameplay of Borderlands 3, really makes Tiny Tina's Wonderland a compelling experience for fans of the franchise. The only issues I had was the lengthy dialog recived when picking up quests, some of these are really hit or miss for me. Other than that Tiny Tinas Wonderland was a great time and definitely worth checking out if your a fan of Borderlands 8/10

The unvariable gameplay might make 60$ being too expensive for it but one the other hand, there's no frustating part, no major mistake, no reason to not finish the game or try 2 or 3 characters.

To say this is just Borderlands with a DnD theme is incorrect. I want to start this by saying THE RUMORS ARE 100% WRONG. THIS GAME IS NOT DND WITH GUNS. This game is borderlands with a DND theme. To say this is DND with guns is like saying a nuke is basically a rocket that's fired from a bigger barrel. 

With that out of the way, this game isn't really bad. It's another run of the mill borderlands game. Nothing spectacular nor different. Nothing wrong with that, just want to make sure people understand this difference and don't buy this game thinking they're going to get a FPS version of Path of exile or Divinity. It is FAR from even being close to this. I wouldn't buy it for full price, but I won't say this game has some love in it. I like Tiny Tina and her voice acting and the jokes can be sort of clever. I found myself laughing and I've only played about 2 hours.

Valid criticism.  So many people complained about this game, and after playing for a bit I can see why.  I've been with the Borderlands franchise since jump.  Tiny Tina's DLC from Borderlands 2 was legitimately an 11 on a scale from 1 to 10.  While Wonderlands has most of the same elements, it missed the mark for me.

Firstly, The fights no longer feel organic or fluid. It has all the fantastic looting and shooting of the older Borderlands.  I think for me personally, the problem is that they incorporated too many elements from Apex, Valorant and the like into the game.  The encounters with enemies feels less open world(after main game).  Where before I could really use my environment to my advantage and take my time, it now feels like i'm being dropped into the middle of an arena and rushed. 

Next, the game is indeed too short.  Insult onto injury for the rest of the game (after completing it in one sitting ((so glad I got it on sale)) its just arena fighting, over and over and over and over and over again, ad nauseam.  Which is fine if thats your thing but its not mine.  

Lastly, I couldn't find my class.  I tried each class except Bzzerker, none of them seemed to fit my play style.  Melee seems to play heavily into the synergy of each character.  After level cap is reached you expect to feel powerful but no matter my build each class was always lacking something.  The only way to increase your effectiveness would be to fight multiple arena fights to get better loot so you can fight more arena fights... just no.

So although I would recommend this game to people who are into arena/instance/encounter based gaming I wouldn't recommend to those who like me enjoyed the actual adventure.

I should note the game is put together beautifully, voice work is excellent, along with some fantastic writing that actually had me laughing out loud.

Since the end of Battleborn, I've been growing less and less enthused about Gearbox products. I thought BL:TPS was fine(mostly cause it did a decent job of making Jack the villain he would become). But BL3, and now this...I just think Gearbox has lost the ideas it had before. TTWL is a game with a lot of memory for what made Borderlands appealing....but very little of what made it FUN. I'm not gonna touch on the DLC issues, because I'm reviewing the whole product that I got for $40. But I can cerrtainly understand the frustrations others may have had for ponying up $120 for this as a pre-order....which is why I didn't. 

TECHNICAL DIFFICULTIES
From a technical standpoint, TTWL is a decent game. There's a fair few visual splendor moments, the game runs....mostly above 60 on my machine, though there are moments where it just stops dead in its tracks and I think the game crashed for about five seconds before it picks back up. And certain locations just drag the game to sub-30 frames. I'm not running a bleeding edge machine, so I can give it some credit, but the two glitches combined, leave me wondering if there's some kind of memory sink that just isn't gonna be fixed in the game. 

ART STYLE
It's Borderlands. If you know it, you know it's the same style that is just getting up-rezzed more and more. It's not bad, but it's also not memorable. For me personally, I find the abundance of sparkles and glitter a little annoying, but I don't really slam it for that; this is supposed to be an RPG of sorts, so yeah, that should be a part of it. But the game has a tremendous amount of visual noise. It loves to throw light shows into everything, making trying to find the dark green monster against the dark green background, and next to the slightly lighter dark green monster annoying. 

SOUND
Again, it's Borderlands. While the story is okay, and Arnett, Burch and the BL voice actors do a good job of narrating it, it's still just a lot of pew-pew, boom-boom sound effects. You're not going to find the next soundscape here. 

GAMEPLAY
And we at last come to WHY I'm writing this review....the gameplay is horribly unbalanced. Maybe the game is meant to be played multiplayer. I've played BL1, 2, TPS, 3 and almost all the DLC for all three, and never have I felt so both underpowered, and beholden as a "Fatemaker" playing alone. 

I'll start with the smallest of sins: you can't really skip the narration when leveling and progressing the main story. You CAN skip the cutscenes(which ironically are better)...but after listening to the same pedantic story told again and again by floating pictures on screen so I can be allowed to see the next checkpoint or push he next button, I got bored REAL fast. Usually when one of the long ones start, I just go get myself a drink or surf online, and let the game run in the background. Dying doesn't really affect you, so you don't lose anything, and the game won't progress until you X the macguffin. But if you're making a story you can't interact with that also gets dull like a chainsaw made out of recycled paper, a skip option would be nice. From what I understand, modding the game by removing the some of the .pak files nixes the story in full. Take that as my commentary on the story's engagement: people found a way to literally tear the story out of the game, so they weren't bored to tears.

Combat is again...Borderlands. Nothing you will see here, is new or groundbreaking. If you've played anything prior to TPS...you know what you're getting. The multiclass system really isn't. You know your Moze/Axton/Roland build or your Amara/Maya/Lilith Build. And Critical Damage, of course, is still king of all builds. It's still making numbers change in different ways. 

The bosses during the story, are pushovers for the most part. Some are nice looking, others just blend into the background. But Chaos Levels basically break the game. After beating the game, you unlock Chaos Mode(Mayhem Mode or UVHM for those who are already yawning about this) You can then run a randomized set of instances, with a few bosses thrown into the mix. But here, the devs decided to swing balance well out of the player's control. SOULSBORNE games don't have the grind of some fights in Chaos Mode. A perfect example is Dry'l. In the game, your damage can outpace his shield healing fairly quickly. It makes him among the toughest fights during the story that you'll face, memorable, but not insanely difficult.....

In Chaos Mode, that changes. Dry'l's shield will INSTANTLY regenerate from nothing to almost full, every 45 seconds. So if you don't have a finely tuned lightning damage focused build that can do (infinity x million)^2 damage, you're stuck with a boss you won't ever damage after phase 1. This kind of boss fight is rife throughout Chaos Mode. Another is the Eros Wyvern, who flies around a stage, and shotgun-blasts AoE damage shots that ALSO regen their THREE health bars. If you get hit by one pellet, I'd say it gets 1/6th of a health bar back. You can't freeze them, you can't really poison them, you can't focus on them, and you have to play pillar-peekaboo to avoid the regen effect. There are fights where a main enemy is just wholly immune, or can't be reached by your build(Melee players know this one all too well), or has some insane catchup mechanic. it robs the game of any kind of challenge. To be clear, challenge is setting a clear, understandable goal before you, and providing the means and tools to achieve that goal. This isn't challenge, this is trying to ape the ways of From Software and call it original. I'm not personally a fan of Souls-like games, and when I realized that is what TTWL is ultimately, I stopped playing and started writing. 

FINAL JUDGEMENT
I think Gearbox has become another developer that's trying to ride the coattails of past greatness. So fixated on recreating the magic of BL2,  Gearbox can no longer see anything but ways to repackage that game with more modern visuals or ideas....note that I said more MODERN...not BETTER. TTWL is the game to get if your Borderlands themed bedroom still had three square feet of uncovered wall, and you just couldn't take it anymore. In the broad strokes, it's another Borderlands game....that was new and exciting a decade ago. Today, it's just a relic of big gaming.

While this is a Borderlands game, and it has the humor of one, it doesn't really play like a Borderlands to me. The crossbows (New weapon in the pistol category) have very little range, and feel bad. The characters don't feel like badasses. The level scaling feels poorly done. I don't mind mowing through waves of characters in no time. I have always been a huge fan of the Borderlands games, and have played through all of them from when the first one came out. 
I can confidently say this is my favorite Borderlands game on par with 1 (maybe better)
This game has a decently large open world, with many objectives per zone, including objectives in the 'Overworld.'
The plot of the game stays consistent and fun even through all of the side quests. I blasted through the game in the last couple weeks, and can definitely see myself going back to 100% it over time.
After you complete the campaign, there is end-game progression called 'Chaos Runs,' which get a little repetitive, but the upgraded weapons you get are increasingly fun to use.

I also am a fan of Ashly Burch, Will Arnett, and very much Andy Samberg; so hearing their voices throughout the game made it much more enjoyable and added to the humor.

I rarely write reviews for games but this one really deserves some good feedback. 

TLDR: awesome shooter in the classic looter shooter style of borderlands but with some refreshing additions along side a great cast and challenging endgame content!

It's been a wild ride playing this game, an interesting twist on the standard borderlands franchise which I've loved - the main characters being voiced by some of my favourite comedy actors (Will Arnett, Andy Samberg and Wanda Sykes) a great cast - if you love the dumb jokes all borderlands have you'll really enjoy this one - also adds some depth to Tina which hit close to home for me.

As for gameplay, it's nice to have a borderlands where you can customize your own hero even your classes too, yeh I get people aren't happy about the 3 trees but you pick your starting class then have a sub class which can make for some awesome synergies with which you can change once you finish the main story. 
For me it's great because you can really chop and change your playstyle on the fly/test out builds, really get into creating your own hero.

The spells in the game are a really nice addition aswell as the necklaces - it adds more to your builds, on normal BL you have your shields and mod but that's it, on TT it adds another layer which is more craziness. 

Each area has loot dice to find which ups your loot luck, I enjoyed finding them it really made you want to explore every nook and cranny of the maps and once you got all of them in all areas you got a beefy permanent boost to your luck.

The level cap is kind of low (40) you get to add attribute points each level up which makes it more like a classic RPG. The myth ranks at max level are nice, it still allows you to build on your character like badass rank but better imo as there's more bespoke options to really hone your builds.

The DLC I've been really enjoying, it's like 4 different multistage quests each having a main objective and an optional sub (which gives you more loot on each stage) enemies drop soul crystals which you spend to get loads of loot in the dlc hub area. 
The catch to each one is there's no save point, no checkpoints so you have to beat the whole thing to complete it - if you're playing with a buddy and they die they can't respawn until the other player has completed that stage of the mission, so if you die you're out until the next stage of the quest begins. 
You also can't leave or teleport out of a stage when you start a mission.
Each quest in the dlc after it's been beat adds another difficulty, up to difficulty 4 - I've only beaten tier 3 and it's been a real challenge.

At end game there's the chaos chamber, I've only just gotten that content unlocked and it's been really challenging so far - it even has secret bosses which honestly has kicked my ass! I breezed through the game on hard by my god the chaos levels really up the difficulty and push your builds to their limit. 
It's been awesome so far like a real new and refreshing addition to the game, curses, blessings, buffs, portals, crystals, puzzles, secret bosses, loot, EVERYTHING! 

Last point for me is the most important, you can have a mushroom boy who farts on enemies and revives you.... A. FUCKING. MUSHROOM. BOY. get this game....

8/10  - A good addition to the Borderlands games

Great improvements from the gameplay perspective, pistols, assault rifles and shotguns got a full remake and a great one, snipers are finally good in close quarters etc.

Tiny Tina is, as she always was, a great character, and it felt refreshing to see the world from her perspective.

But there are major problems with the game.

- Dialog is usually too long or drags for too much. The two other `players` you play with are really dull and uninteresting, with maybe one or two interesting lines in the while game. Player character tho has some really good comments and lines, that are MUCH better than the voices NPC-s.

- Animations are stiff, especially with the character talking or gestures, which is something that is not easily seen in a game from 2020+

- Enemies constantly run away from you, making you run to them, and they start running again if you get close. This only happens with some ranged enemies, but its REALLY dumb and annoying.

- Rocket Launchers went from being really good in B2 and B3 to being low tier trash here.

- There is no replay value. I have leveled all classes to max and did everything with them, just to figure out there is no New Game+ or beyond, just a rouge-like mode when you hit lvl 40.

Overall, get it on sale, WITHOUT any DLC-s.

[h1]Possibly the worst [i]Borderlands[/i] game to date.[/h1]

EVERY [i]Borderlands[/i] game suffers from a badly-implemented level-scaling system which makes leveling up pointless, most of your guns useless, and the gunplay so tedious that I have literally fallen asleep while playing it with my brother.

EVERY [i]Borderlands[/i] game has bad map design, poor level design, and lousy UI. However, THIS abomination somehow made the UI even WORSE and ruined one thing which I had always liked about the series, that being the character design.

[h1]No [feminine] girls allowed[/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911684581

This is just sexist. You can play as a man or you can play as an exceptionally MASCULINE woman. This is NOT "progressive"; it may be INTENDED to allow Randy Pitchford to say that he's a good boy but what it actually does is deprive EVERYONE including WOMEN of the chance to play as a cute girl. 

A LOT of women (including trans women btw) would like to be able to play as a cute girl (like Gaige or Moze from previous games) even if they don't look like that in real life in the same way that many men (including trans men) would like to be able to play as a huge hulk in a video game even if they are smaller than that when outside of the game. 

I won't complain about more options being in a game (I never had any problem with the gay romance options in [i]Mass Effect[/i] for instance nor did I complain about the trans character options in [i]Cyberpunk[/i]) but it DOES bother me when the options I like are removed, apparently because a cynical corporation under the guidance of Randy Pitchford wants head pats for being "progressive".

[h1]Map Design[/h1]

The maps seem designed to confuse and frustrate you which considering that Randy Pitchford once shared a video of a cat being hurt in order to mess with people, may be the point. Where it REALLY sucks however is when the bad map design interacts with the TERRIBLE UI. In order to move the map a relatively small distance so you can see something a short distance from you, you have to drag the mouse off the desk. 

I kept finding that my mousepad literally wasn't big enough to accommodate the dramatic, sweeping motions necessary to move the map to where I wanted it... even with mouse acceleration turned on. Perhaps it's better with a controller... or perhaps it's deliberately annoying. When you are dealing with studio led by a man a man who shares videos of animal cruelty, you never know...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0eO3UFsjv-g

[h1]Bad level-scaling[/h1]

When level-scaling is done right, for instance as implemented in ESO or SWTOR, I don't mind it. In this game however, the level-scaling makes the enemies even more bullet-sponge than usual and ensures that you rarely have a gun you like and even when you do, you have to throw it away almost as soon as you get it.

You can't upgrade the guns and they are set to whatever your level is when you get them. This means that every time you level-up, which happens a lot, your guns start to suck. At any given time, you won't actually have very many guns of the right level so despite the theoretical promise of "zillions" of procedurally-generated guns, the fact that most of them are trash means you will be stuck with a gun you don't like in this game far more often than in most other shooters.

[h1]Too much trash loot[/h1]

Your inventory in this game quickly fills up with low-quality trash that has no real function except to be sold. As a result, you spend a HUGE amount of time in this game going to or looking for shops to sell your trash as opposed to shooting or exploring. This game is TEDIOUS.

[h1]Boring combat[/h1]

The gunplay in this game is basically what you would expect from an MMORPG. Only the stats really matter because the time-to-kill is painfully low (and is made worse by the aforementioned level-scaling system.) As a result, I literally found myself falling asleep playing this game. It's BORING when you win and when you lose, it's because your guns suck... or you fell asleep.

[h1]Creepy, unsatisfying, and transgressive when not cringe and virtue-signalling[/h1]

The "writing" in this product suffers from the same problem as the [i]Velma[/i] atrocity. It's always trying to signal its conformity to certain cultural trends while at the same time constantly trying to gross you out with its attempts to be transgressive... it also never stops trying to be meta. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O7lGf_WBZJA

When you aren't helping a gay couple find true love or doing something else clearly intended to check a box, you will find yourself being an exceptionally nasty person with absolutely no choice in the matter because Randy Pitchford seems to have only two speeds which are PC virtue-signalling and "I bullied those completely innocent people until they DIED on behalf of a literal demon! Ain't I a stinker!"

Basically, this game feels like it was made by combining the gross ideas from [i]TLOU Part 2[/i] and [i]Hatred[/i] with the cringe of the [i]Saint's Row[/i] reboot. It's just gross.

If you aren't both incredibly PC and a hateful TROLL, you will HATE the writing in this game (and I am saying this as someone who loves [i]Saint's Row 3[/i].)

This actually made me sad because I really liked the story of [i]Psycho Krieg and the Fantastic Fustercluck[/i] which surprised me by actually being GOOD. Gearbox CAN do better; they just don't. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

If you want to play an extremely TEDIOUS game with a story that seems to have been written by the people responsible for [i]Velma[/i], this might be for you...

I think the best thing for this franchise is for the next game in the series to bomb so badly that they actually fix the fundamental problems with the gameplay and hire a creative director who likes what normal people like (as opposed to animal cruelty and whatever other sick garbage some people at Gearbox are apparently into.)
