As of writing this review, i have, for all intents and purposes, completely cleared the game. Every quest and side quest, every collectible, every piece of DLC. I have done so partly out of spite and partly out of a desire to make this review as thorough as possible.

[h1] Issue #1: Skill trees [/h1]

Unlike previous games in the franchise, where you choose a character with 3-4 skill trees to play around with, Wonderlands instead has you choose a Class: classes have two Action Skills to choose from and one single Skill Tree. After a certain point in the campaign, you're able to choose a secondary Class and choose from their skill tree and Action Skill. The maximum level is 40, and you have a total of 44 Skill Points to play around with.

The first major issue with this system: not enough Skill Points to experiment with builds. 44 skill points are enough to reach the final skill in a single class' Skill Tree and reach the 4th tier of skills in another (barely). Builds, as such, are basically always the same: you can't afford to experiment with different playstyles or skill choices.
Secondly: quite a few classes have zero synergy between them: often times you're forced to get skills you have no use for just so you can reach another tier. 
Worst of all, the skill trees themselves are boring and poorly designed, and there is no skill support for many playstyles. Here's an example:

The Spore Warden is the closest thing to a sniper class the game has. Its passive grants it a Mushroom Companion which deals Poison (Corrosive) damage and its skills are centered around Critical Hits. I'll discuss a few skills which I believe exemplify its poor design.
Quiver of Holding: Increases magazine size for all guns by 30% and grants them constant ammo regen (9% of the mag/second). 
Wrath of Nature: Enemies hit by Ability Damage take 30% increased damage from all sources. 
Play the Angles: Scoring a Gun Critical Hit has a 35% chance of making the bullet ricochet towards a nearby enemy, dealing Ability Damage. 

Sniper rifles as an archetype have small magazine sizes, fire slowly (barring a few exceptions) and deal a lot of damage: therefore they don't benefit from Ammo Regen and don't proc ricochets often enough to benefit from Wrath of Nature. Using a Sniper Rifle on the *only class* that has significant buffs to Critical Damage is a complete waste of time, because you're better off using something with a large magazine size and high fire rate, like an AR, pistol or SMG. 

Here's another example: the Clawbringer. It lacks damage bonuses to make it competitive with other classes, its action skills take too long to be usable, its action skill augments are worthless, some skills just do nothing (Indomitable), and what buffs it has to Companions are exclusive to its own companion and don't benefit others in any way. 

The lack of support for different playstyles is noticeable: non-elemental guns are almost universally outclassed when so many characters are based around specific damage types. The Blightcaller's entire skill tree revolves around status effects, the Clawbringer relies on fire and lightning, the Graveborn needs black magic to keep itself alive, the Brr-zerker benefits from stacking Cold damage: you're almost always better off using an element.

[h1] Issue #2: The gunplay [/h1]

Borderlands started off as an FPS, and while it's completely understandable and even commendable to have the franchise branch off in another direction, guns in Wonderlands feel like an afterthought. The addition of "proper" melee combat is certainly something. On one hand, being able to customize exactly how your character uses its melee attack is very fun and interesting, and opens up a lot of build variety (even for gun builds! you can use melee weapons as utility tools). On the other, it's another layer of grinding and even more items to dilute a boss' loot pool. 
In addition to melee weapons, Wonderlands also introduces Spells, which replace grenades. They're cooldown-based rather than ammo-based, so they feel a lot more spammable. 

Spells and melee combat are very clearly the main focus when it comes to skill tree support. As previously mentioned, the Spore Warden is the only class with significant gun buffs: though some other classes have skills that benefit gunplay (the Blightcaller's Geist in the Shell and part of the Spellshot's tree) the emphasis for almost every other character is either melee or spell combat. Even the Spellshot, whose final skill gives him a chance to instantly reset his spell cooldowns upon scoring a gun critical hit, is better off spamming Spells (usually Laserhands). 
Though playing with guns is viable (yes, even non-elemental ones), the gunplay generally feels bad: every attack (whether gun, melee, or spell) has a chance of critically hitting, so aiming for headshots isn't as rewarding because you can just spam bodyshots and be just as effective. Some enemies actively disencourage aiming for Crits: Cyclops have their critical spots disappear after taking a certain amount of damage and become Enraged, dealing increased damage and moving faster. Unlike Goliaths in BL2, where removing their helmets exposed a crit spot, Cyclopi are impossible to crit outside of random crit procs after their eye is destroyed. 

More than anything else, guns feel bad: 
[list]
[*]Crossbow-type weapons fire arcing projectiles which stick to enemies and increase the damage of subsequent shots: the arc is noticeable and annoying to aim, especially on guns with low projectile speed
[*]Shotguns firing energy blasts: no real visual or audio feedback to denote a hit outside of damage numbers: they're strong, but it *feels* like you're not hitting things
[/list]

Game is not bad but really didn't pull the weight of what I've expected from a Borderlands game. 

Base game: 

1) Solid game with different fun classes to mix and match but falls flat with story since it feels like something I've seen from a certain BL2 dlc(only one part stood out and that was with a returning side character). 

2) To get better loot you'll have to hunt down dice in different sections of the world...have fun getting poop tier weapons until you get enough dice for better drops

3) Endgame is just running chaos chambers(repetitive dungeons with modifiers and are on the same map) to upgrade your chaos level( like mayhem mode in BL3) and getting "ascended" gear. 

I would wait for a sale unless your REALLY like the DnD elements shown here(which for me it didn't click as much as other people)

DLC: 

Absolute fucking scam; do not waste your money unless you get the season pass super cheap(like I did) but even then its still not worth it. All it is a chaos chambers but with a different coat of paint and its only value is for the legendary stuff but not worth the pain and time consumption to even get them.

This is a good looter-shooter...

Now, here's my list of personal complaints:

Whenever I activate my primary skill, the in-game music and sound-effects suddenly vanish and it affects my PC's drivers. Quitting out the game // restarting Steam doesn't solve the problem, resetting my PC temporarily solves the problem. I vowed to never cast Polymorph ever again.

While using an RTX 2060, entering a random encounter causes the UI to glitch out (checkerboard patterns and artifacting on the map, subtitles, objectives, etc.) One way to solve this problem is to downgrade from Direct X 12 to 11 and disable AMD FSR 2--which is a wonderful feature to boost FPS.

The developers haven't improved the UI while navigating the inventory / skills. The way how browsing your weapons takes up a lot of visual space, but it doesn't provide enough information on what weapons are better than the other without having to open another tab. I.e. not enough space is used meaningfully, and too much space is used for clutter.
In other words, you found some good loot, and it'll take you longer than it should to equip them with confidence while your friends are running far ahead of you in-game.

However, I like this game because I get to play with friends who are enjoying the experience. And, if they're having fun, so am I!
It's not a PvP experience that's stressful and toxic towards each other. It's a PvE! Let's be silly with some good writing, humorous storytelling, and appreciative DnD themes where we can all laugh and have a good time!

That experience alone is why I recommend this game <3
I simply cannot see myself playing this game alone ^^;

It's not really that great, but not for all the reasons everyone else has listed.

I played it up until the point where you get the Brutal Narrative Dissonance achievement, which happens to also be the point where they totally ruin the immersion, hilarity, and all three characters at once, and the worst part is that it feels forced as fuck.

From the very start of the game, things feel off. You have stats that give modifiers, and backgrounds that are... Locked off if you didn't pay for a specific DLC, one of them being the most useful one that would probably give you the best time all the way through. Same for an entire class, tied to the same DLC. Oof.

From then on, the entire game just kinda... Drags on. A lot. It assumes you're going to explore everywhere and do every sidequest in order to be at the right level, but, uh... When the earliest of those side areas is the goblin mountain where things will insta-down you, it doesn't hit right. Especially not with these... Not-guns.

They basically just took actual guns, mangled them into more-fantastical "hey it's not a gun guys" versions, then gave them bad mechanics, like the smgs and shotguns firing slow projectiles instead of fast bullets, or the stuck tnts, not rockets, from Torgue weapons being op as fuck on the pistol versions. Then comes the... Basically pointless additon of spells and melee. Both... Have 0 purpose. You're going to be shooting, not casting, cause your not-guns have more dps than the entire spin-up, aim, and cast of a single spell. Melee just... No? It only felt vaguely worth using when the enemies were getting too annoying, but again, it always did less damage than the guns and was basically pointless the entire way through.

Shields are the exact same as in the other game, rings and necklaces give barely anything, and the class mods are... Worse than usual, especially if you play a certain way, then get a mod that gives you EXACTLY what you need, then you're stuck looking that way for the rest of the game because nothing else gives the same skillpoints.

The elemental system, and the enemies having innate requirements to defeat them is garbage. Skeletons, the most common enemy, basically force you to use Cryo weapons unless you want to feel like you don't have enough dps at all times. Sometimes they're shielded, though, and, that means lightning damage is required. Oh, but did I mention the Mushrooms that require you to have Corrosive? Do you see the issue there? You now NEED to have a weapon of those elements to feel like you're dealing real damage to them, meaning you're constrained to whatever terrible mangled guns you find that have those elements, and can't really shift too much from that, unless you get a Torgue weapon with basic damage and the Stuck TNT mechanic, because those will consistently give you enough DPS at all times. Oh, and, PS: Dark Damage is going to take up your last slot so that you can survive bosses or get your hp back when you need it. Sorry nothing, there go your 4 slots.

Now for what everyone else has already said that seems true:
The level cap is way too low.
The DLCs are overpriced AS HELL for what they actually give you. You can buy other, longer and better games for the price of one dlc in this one.

What everyone else seems to have wrong:
The voice acting is absolutely fine. You have two new actors, one for the two new people introduced into the game, one of which sounds like, and is, a normal human guy, the other is a rule-based robot with the voice of a black woman. They're both fine, they sound fine. The other voice-acting in the game is done by either new people, or people returing from 3, such as Lorelai coming back to voice Paladin Mike, or Cole coming back to voice the Mage in the cliffs. Otherwise, the NPCs sound like borderlands characters. Shoutout to whoever did the skeletons, though, because they actually sound like funny borderland skeletons, especially when they make borderlands-tier jokes every few seconds in battle.

Ah right, the enemies. People have said every enemy is a skeleton. They're wrong. You have skeletons, mushrooms, drakes, goblins, merfolk, pirates, cultists and crabs. They're mostly seen in certain areas by the way. It'd be more fair to say skeletons are the most common enemies, because that's actually true. The main villain IS a necromancer, after all, and the main quest does happen to also have you go through an area with pirates who were already cursed with undeath through various means. Makes sense that the antagonist would antagonize the players throughout the story, just... Maybe they overdid it a bit.

Overall, imagine Borderlands but squashed forcibly into a fantasy context with a slight paywall affecting actual gameplay. The DLC in 2 had actual guns, too, not crammed-into-context ones. (Blackpowder ones do exist, but that's literally just Jakobs as normal, and those guns actually also happen to be the weakest ones here.) If they had just done exactly that, done an extention of the DLC instead of seemingly retconning the whole thing and forcing the characters to all do something horrible at some point in the story, maybe it would have been passible. Maybe they also could have left out the magic and melee, because it does absolutely nothing ingame, too.

I didn't really know what I was getting with this game. I assumed it would basically be Borderlands 3 with random encounters and rpg humor, and it's certainly that, but the core problem is that it's just not particularly fun to play? And that comes down to the gunplay and game design. 

The guns are horrible to use, and feel extremely clunky. I suppose you could chalk that up to them trying to be 'medieval' or 'magical' but they're just not fun to use. Meanwhile, the main thing that's fun to use are the spells, which are often extremely powerful and useful, and honestly should have replaced the guns entirely. The problem of course is that because spells are so much better than the guns, there's only one real build, so there's not a ton of reason to experiment with characters. 

On top of that, every enemy has too much health; so you're dealing with damage sponge enemies with guns that aren't fun to use. Maybe I was just expecting it to be more Borderlands, but the magic just isn't really here, or whatever you want to call it.

This is such a *weird* game. And I'm not talking about the premise. Fans like me have been wanting another Bunkers & Badasses iteration since the pretty universally beloved Tiny Tina's Campaign of Carnage DLC. I don't think there's anything controversial about saying that CoC had such a fantastic story and technical execution that it could stand up to many full-on AAA releases. 

So what's so weird about this? 

Let's start with the softball stuff, performance and technical. 
I run this game on a fossil. An i7-4770K with a *modest* overclock, a GTX-1080 running slightly undervoltage to keep noise down, and 16gb of G.Skill SNiper RAM from around 2010. THis thing is a proper potato. Yet, I run it at 1440P with all settings maxed out, it holds 60FPS pretty consistently. So as a matter of optimization, it runs as well as BL3. Not unexpected.
There are some *strange* bugs though. Textures will only partially load and then hang and leave an area looking like a 1990's  2.5D shooter minus the crispiness, or they won't load at all. VO portraits won't load in. Onscreen prompts will hang on the interact button indefinitely, requiring a trip to the inventory screen to fix. Pet health bars will be stuck on KO forever regardless of pet health. Animations will play incorrectly or not at all. THe entire screen will lock for a fraction of a second and then skip another half second or so of frames upon killing a large enemy. 

All together it's annoying but not game breaking. 

Now, on a gameplay level. 

Everything seems to work as intended. I built a pretty busted clawbringer/spore warden who in general is a one-man meat grinder and the phallic mushroom and tiny dragon are, for the most part, just along for the ride until I run into a boss which requires stronger elemental damage than my barely-literate character can take a bite out of. It works well. THe level perks are all useful, though none are particularly flashy and few are super interesting. That's fine. There's a balance between effective leveling, building a playstyle through experimentation, and needing to work to get the really interesting bonuses. 
This is fine. 

What's not fine is the scaling enemies. They never really get more difficult or need more complicated strategy. THey just come at you in slightly larger numbers. THis means that there's no reason to ever do any side quest unless it specifically interests you and you want to find out what happens. 

But don't worry. That doesn't mean there's no grind. In fact, much of the game is laid out as a grind now. The game is now structures around interconnected dungeons linked with a simplified 2.5D hub world. If you're imaging a JRPG with a scaled-down overworld you walk around to go from towns to caves to castles to what-have-you, that's pretty much on point. 
The dungeons themselves are the issue. Imagine an endless chain of arena-shooter fights with very similar enemies for whom the optimal strategy is invariably "Shoot many bullets". Now imagine that the relative difficulty or intensity never changes because all enemies and encounters scale to your level. 

If you enjoy repetitive multiplayer FPS arena games, this structure is going to be very familiar and comfortable for you. 
If you're looking for a Borderlands title with wildly varied architecture, exciting setpieces, and tons of weird enemies for you to develop moving strategies to fight against on the fly, this is going to leave you a little confused, a little fatigued, and a little bored. This is *especially* true for the popup "encounter" game areas, which work exactly like a deathmatch arena. You spawn in, have a brief countdown timer, then you have to just kill until you fill up a bar. This is the same for most side dungeons too. 

So now, the writing.

Borderlands is known for being over the top, and a lot of the humor is grounded in such a way that it fits well into a a heavily stylized but ultimately serious story. Moments of levity punctuate a ridiculous, but not necessarily inherently goofy world. THe games are funny, but not because they're constantly trying to make every moment into either an absurdist take or a pop culture reference or a fart joke. It's because they know how and when to slip those into an otherwise sorta relatively dark story in a way that breaks up that darkness and rejects grimness entirely. and especially with the original CoC DLC, uses measured silliness to approach very difficult and painful subject matter without letting it become exhausting or tedious.

Wonderlands isn't a serious concept painted in over-the-top stylized shapes and colors and sprinkled with a strong but manageable helping of fart jokes. Wonderlands is an aspiring middle-school stand up comedian who forgets he was telling a joke about a complex social subject and then switches over to a fart joke halfway through a 30 second anecdote. And then keeps doing it over, and over, and over again. While standing on a pair of whoopie cushions. What little emotional buildup Wonderlands earns is immediately deflated with poorly timed body humor or some kind of pop culture reference that gets overworked to the point of tedium. Few characters stick around long enough for you to get interested in their deal. I think the longest arc anyone had were the gay pirate skeleton lovers, and that's because they were around for a whopping *two* quests. The story clearly wants to say something, wants you to feel something, but it really doesn't give you much to work with. 
The main quest line kinda loses focus after you blow up the ocean. Instead of having some kind of specific goal to accomplish in each area, the goal becomes "Get through the area" and the goal is juswt kind of a tangent that you need to go off on in order to finish passing through the area. THat can work fine as a detour to add flavor or to add depth to the world, but here it just feels like padding. THe good news is that you can skip almost anything you deem to be inconsequential because none of it matters due to the scaling enemy difficulty. If you can call that good news. 

I picked this game up because I was itching for more Borderlands and the premise held a lot of promise for me. I've played all of the Borderlands games save for the Telltale titles because I just have no interest in that type of game. I ended up a little disappointed and have been coasting by finishing the game to try to get to the expected emotional payoff at the story's end. After that I'm unlikely to pick it up again
THe bottom line is that I do not recommend this game unless you're a big fan of the structure of multiplayer online shooters, you're a Borderlands completionist, or both. At least look for a sale. THis game is not worth AAA money.

This game is pretty cool. I payed 30 dollars for this game and that's the most it should cost. The story is... fine? Jokes are shit, characters are well voice acted, general plot is maybe above average. Gameplay is pretty good, not without flaw but definitely not lacking in quality. Once you complete the main story, the game becomes a sort of roguelite, allowing you to go from randomly selected area to area, fight random enemies, and get better gear continually for quite some time. I would have liked a new game+ fairly well, but i guess this'll do. Also, all the DLC is shit, apparently.
Respec is weird. You can only respec your multiclass, skill points, and hero points. You'd better make damn certain that you like your class and background, because you can't change them. Same goes for Myth Ranks, which are like "Guardian Ranks", though I've never played BL3. In fact, I don't know much about Myth Ranks either, since my game had a game-breaking bug 48 hours in that made it so I couldn't get any xp for them. Only one other person on the internet had my problem and they didn't get a solution either. Probably because this game has an incredibly small fanbase. Oh well, that's my run over, I guess.
If the series continues, I'd really like to see some writers who could write a story that's solid as well as jokes that wouldn't make me embarrassed if someone walked in on me listening to them. And I really hope the series does continue. Borderlands is a very satisfying series to play. Consider buying it when it's on sale, shoot for $15 for a decent time.

This had a lot of mixed reviews when I bought it. I was apprehensive buying it, but I am actually really enjoying it.. Borderlands is great, and this is a fresh take on it. It's still borderlands at its heart. There are guns, spells, jumping around, and goofy dialogue, but it's still different too. Instead of just traveling places by running/driving there, you walk on a world map as a giant character piece (like literally walk, not click and go). You can run into random encounters, enter random dungeons, and pick up side quests both on the map and in those dungeons. I will admit, the encounters do quickly become repetitive (there is one where you're at this stone bridge, I've probably done that one 35 times), but the dungeons and side quests are still fresh and unique. 

The classes are fun and different from typical borderlands, but they do feel a bit lacking sometimes. I chose the poison guy (drawing blank on the name) and I was expecting more poison barrels and poison companions etc. Instead it's really just bonus damage to poison items and status effects. Once I hit level 21 I was able to choose a side-class, and I chose one that had a mushroom companion. He does help but seems really weak and useless at times. I just wish they had more of a DnD feel with companions instead of solo run-and-gun. Either way, I am enjoying it.

Inside your little "base" there are portals to do dungeons and each time you complete them you can make them more difficult. I was having a ton of fun with that. Reminded me a bit of tiers in other dungeon crawlers. They're actually incredibly challenging too. You die once and you have to restart. First difficulty is not too bad but man the bosses are INSANE on higher difficulties. 

Overall, I'd give it a solid 7.5/10. It's definitely good, it's not mindblowing, but if you like borderlands you will like this. If you like DnD styled games with goofy dialogue you may like this. If you're looking for a FPS of Divinity OS with serious dialogue and complex battle you probably will feel let down.

Since Steam doesn't have a star rating I can only give it a thumbs up, but it comes with reservations.  Wonderlands is a fun game, it has the same style of gun play and snarkiness that I loved from the other games BUT...BUT...BUT...it is a game with a lot of issues. 

First, the bugs are many and sloppy.  The co-op gameplay is hampered by all sorts of visual bugs, audio bugs, latency bugs, and downright game freezes that require you to kill the game from task manager to continue.  Honestly, for as long as this game has been out, you would think most of this would be fixed.  Of all of the Borderlands games this is by far the buggiest game.

As far as gameplay, it does have the Borderlands sense of humor, but it really is not as good and I fear that the forced wokeness has crept in and really just ruined the fun.  Many of the jokes are meh at best.  It seems a waste since Tina is one of their best characters from the franchise.

There are lots of guns, weapons and spells...which offer an interesting twist but in truth, they spells aren't all that different than the regular BL grenades which is what the spells replace.  I do like the classes and the addition of a character editor is very welcome, but they don't feel a whole lot different than what we had in BL 1, 2 & 3.

Now, after finishing the main story and all of the sidequests (I don't own any DLCs) I can say that the stories are okay, there were several instances of very funny dialogue but it is by far the weakest entry in the Borderlands franchise.  IMO the BL2 Tiny Tina DLC was better and hit much harder on all levels.

There also is the problem of this game trying to force itself into a Teen rating.  It's ultra violent but can't mention alcohol and ham fisting in "soda" and "Non-alcoholic" everywhere in the dialogue is just nuts.

My suggestion is to buy the game on sale as it really does seem like a half effort from the studio.  Skip the DLC as well since they didn't seem to put any effort into those.

Having finally come to Steam you would have expected the game to have grown a bit from it's initial release and a few more of these co-op bugs to be fixed.  Oh well.

If you enjoyed the Borderlands games, you'll probably like Wonderlands.  It's not as deep as the previous Borderlands games in some ways.  It feels more like a collection of smaller encounters in smaller levels for a large part of it.  The depth of the dual class system is awesome though.  I think Wonderlands is a fun, but different, take on the Borderlands universe allowing for some more cartoony mechanics.  I mean... it IS an RPG run by a 13 year old girl after all.  If you haven't played Borderlands games before, I'd start with Borderlands 2 and 3.  !!!NOTE!!!:  Main story in Wonderlands is awesome, but the DLC is smaller.  I wouldn't want to pay the standalone price for it.  Get the Chaotic Great Edition of Wonderlands on a sale and the DLC is well worth the small price increase from Standard Edition.

The game combines fairy tale elements with Borderlands-style technology to create an engaging experience. However, it also has several drawbacks that may detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

Pros:

+ Intriguing blend of fairy tale influences and Borderlands-style technology
+ The game becomes quite fun after the story ends and it just a gliding mode
+ The game mechanics are well crafted and offer a unique gameplay experience
+ It has a good number of missions and side quests which makes the game more enjoyable and engaging.
+ The game art and design is visually stunning and eye-catching
+ The dialogue and story-telling approach is funny and witty, adding to the overall enjoyment of the game
+ The game uses a boardgame-like structure to present the story, which adds an additional layer of interest and intrigue to the gameplay

Cons:

- User interface is difficult to navigate, with keybind overlaps making it hard to see the value of items.
- More glitches present in this game compared to Borderlands 3, such as guns that are unable to shoot bullets in co-op play
- Unskippable credit scene, although frustrating, can be understood as a necessary acknowledgement of the hard work of the developers and creators of the game, but a skip option should have been available.

If you love D&D and other tabletop RPG's like I do, Tiny Tina's will be right up your alley. It delights in poking well-meaning and hilarious fun at tabletop RPG games, tropes, and players. I've laughed my way through the game so far, and am looking forward to more chuckles as I continue to play. The gameplay is fun, the enemies are varied, and the weapons, tools, and upgrade system all make sense.

I've had so many jaw dropping moments! This game keeps me on my toes and has me dying of laughter. The spell and melee mechanics are an awesome change up to the Borderlands universe. Also, all the different movement has to be mentioned, the mushrooms that make you fly and all the slides were unexpected and just plain fun. I don't know why this game is getting so much hate. I decided to play myself before reading too many negative comments that may sway my opinion before even giving it a chance. I loved the previous games and this one is just a marvelous cherry on top. Highly recommend.

The 2 major flaws with Wonderlands is that 1. there is basically nothing to do after the main story, with the endgame feeling pointless, and 2. The DLCs all suck. 6/10 - Borderline good, borderline insufferable. Not a bad game but anything this smug needs to be a lot better.

= Intro = 

Yeah, I'm a sucker for Borderlands, even though they sometimes get right up my snout and seem to rely too much on 'if we keep talking, maybe we'll accidentally be funny' writing. But everyone loved Dragon's Keep - so what would happen if Dragon's Keep was  fleshed out into Borderlands 3.5, the Re Sequel?

= Gameplay: 8/10 =

It's Borderlands, except now guns are replaced with crossbows. And also guns. Oh and melee combat is okay. And you have spells instead of grenades.

The main campaign is Tiny Tina DMing again in an obvious Dungeons and Dragons knockoff, with two players and you. 

It's...yeah. Let's just say - this doesn't start well. It's really slow and generic until...a thing happens involving the ocean (honestly the only joke in the game that completely lands, but this one lands hard), after which it actually becomes pretty fun. 

Of course, the entire game is basically one big reference - occasionally insightful stuff about the nature of TTRPGS, DMing (which as a DM of 20+ years I definitely found myself smiling at) and it does occasionally have a few things to say about why people enjoy D&D and why it's become as popular as it has - but...ugh. Let me put it this way. 

It has a Star Wars: 'I am your father' moment. Not a joke, not playing around with it, just that reference. And that should tell you all you need to know about most of the humour. Sometimes it got a chuckle, a lot of the time I wanted to smash it over the head until it stopped talking at me.

The combat is as good as always, but it feels bit less massive and epic than BL3 did, and with the crapzillion different guns and stuff added to BL3 over the course of 4 full DLCs (1 of which being halfway good) it...does feel like you may as well just play BL3 again.

But it all works, and I did have...fun playing it. Mostly. 

= Graphics & Audio: 4/10 =

The visuals are fine, although it feels like for maybe a 20% enhancement in overall prettiness, we've taken a 500% hit to performance - not everyone has a card that can DLSS it's way to running stuff at a higher framerate, and stuff doesn't really look that much better now than it did 4 years ago - it just runs worse. 

The audio though...one of BL's strongest aspects has been it's incredible ambient soundtracks (many of which have found their way into my own D&D playlists) and TTW barely even has a soundtrack.

One thing that I have to mention though - and this sort of thing doesn't usually grate like it did here, but the game feels like it needs to inject hyper-partisan progressive politics wherever it can, and this is the sort of thing that can feel incredibly forced, smug and self satisfied. LGBT character can work, if they are treated like actual characters - Hammerlock and what's-his-face from BL3 were great. But here, it feels like every second character is trans, gay, lesbian, an objectophile (not kidding, there's like 3 of these) or what have you and it comes over...just weird and contrived. 

And yeah - as mentioned - smug. There is a smugness problem that runs through this game and it does rub me up the wrong way at times. Especially since, while it occasionally seems that the story is going in an interesting or even profound direction - it never does.

= Value: 8/10 =

Yeah...it's not a short game, but not a long one either, and it still manages to feel padded at times (and even cracks jokes about this - naturally, smugly). And the DLC is pretty crap. I got it half off and I'd say I got my money's worth, but it was a close thing. If I'd bought it for full price I'd have been annoyed.

Three things hold it back.

The aforementioned awful DLC, and the way the class system only has one tree per 'class', but you pick a second class a bit of the way in so it's running on Titan Quest logic now. Sounds okay, and there are some interesting synergies, but it also feels like substantially less effort to make.

The endgame is the third one, and while I don't hate it as much some do, it does feel a lot more constrained than previous games did.

= The Big Minus 1 =

I removed an entire point off the final score for one reason - compulsory secret hunting. There are hundreds of dice hidden around the world, which give you a *massive* boost to loot luck if you find them all. Which makes it mandatory. And you need to find every single one. 

Oh, and some of them can't even be accessed until you finish the game, so before you get to enjoy the endgame, you'll be spending 6 hours hunting through the world trying to find them. This is another example of the game's smugness - it thinks that you'll bother with this awful, awful idea and not just download someone else's savegame with all of them unlocked.

= Overall =

+ Okay plot that occasionally comes close to making me feel things.
+ One or two jokes land
+ Shooty looty action is as good as always.
+ Can be pretty
+ Voice acting can be decent

- Feels like a step back in some ways
- Mandatory secret hunting is a TERRIBLE idea. Don't do this.
- The conclusion of the story...no, no idea what this game was trying to say.
- Overpriced
- Not amazing performance
- Terrible DLC
- Overabundance of 'identity' characters with zero identity outside of 'I'm trans', 'I'm gay', 'I am attracted to objects', 'I am attracted to animals' etc.
- Fantasy/mythology parodies are so dated and common that there are probably more parody games than just plain old fantasy games now.

At the end of the day, if you're a Borderlands nut...well, you probably bought this on release. For anyone else, it's not as bad as some people are making it out, but - think the Pre-Sequel. It's basically a big DLC/overhaul sold for full AAA prices. Smugly.

Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is a simplistic shadow of the Borderlands series. Instead of opening up a brave new world of fantasy tropes to lampoon in the typical Borderlands style, Wonderlands presents itself as a completely sincere adaptation. Dual-classing is a cool addition, but the very low level cap sucks the fun out of class building. Level design is beautiful and exciting to explore but encounters are repetitive. Most egregious are the tedious arena battles, which mostly involve standing around waiting for handfuls of enemies to spawn in sad little waves.

In addition to being trite and repetitive, quest dialogue often forces the player to stand around waiting for tedious narration to finish before proceeding to the next objective. And of course the writing overall is "Young Adult" in a manner so reductive as to be insulting. There is some satisfaction to be had in exploring, looting, and shooting, but this is by far the worst in the series and a profoundly mediocre experience.

 It is soooooo boring, its not funny at all, and the story is told 98% in joke format.

They are having full multi paragraph conversations while you are fighting enemies, so if its already hard to pay attention because it is boring AF, imagine trying to pay attention while fighting, I can only assume not important if its going at the same time, the game at least is self conscious of its bad lore.

The game is full of bugs, UI is messy and confusing (good luck trying to figure out DPS or how much critical hit chance you actually have for example), elements vanish from the UI for no reason (restarting the game works sometimes), quests does not work requiring restart and many other bugs, and I got the game 6 months after the release. (1.0.6.0 or something)

The loot sucks, most of the items does not work, its not that the weapons or spells are bad, is just that they not work at all, you die trying to use them, and the other 1/3 are OP, you can blaze through the game one blue weapon in hand the whole time, don't need to worry about elemental damage or any of that on HARD difficulty (check other reviews for more details, can't use snipers or launchers).

Most bosses are weaker than elite or badass enemies, is pathetic.

And it is a shame too because the world and the graphics are gorgeous, its one of the most beautiful games of the franchise.

I recently played Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep and I have to say, I was disappointed. As a man, I expected a lot more from this game. The character Tiny Tina is a complete and total joke. She's small and weak, and her voice is just annoying. I found myself skipping over her dialogue just so I didn't have to listen to her anymore.

The gameplay itself wasn't much better. The combat was too easy and the puzzles were too simple. I'm not sure if it's because the developers were trying to cater to a female audience or what, but this game just didn't challenge me at all.

In conclusion, Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep is a waste of time. It's not worth playing if you're a real gamer looking for a good challenge. Stick with games that have strong, male protagonists and real gameplay.

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is an outrageous, fantasy-infused spinoff of the OG looter shooter and a direct follow-up to the Borderlands 2: Tiny Tina’s Assault on Dragon Keep DLC from 2013. As a game within a game, Wonderlands has you playing through a simulated tabletop roleplaying campaign called Bunkers and Badasses, a sort of alternate-reality Dungeons and Dragons that replaces generic fantasy tropes with absurdity, gratuitous violence, and tons of guns regardless of whether they’re setting-appropriate or not. But that’s the magic of this larger-than-life looter-shooter RPG, which throws caution to the wind and embraces chaos and nonsense in favor of ludicrous and memorable moments.

Tiny Tina’s Wonderlands is a fantastic fantasy take on Borderlands’ tried-and-true looter shooter formula. As spin-offs go, it sticks dangerously close to its past successes which at times felt a bit unoriginal and some of the new stuff it tries, like procedurally generated combat encounters, didn’t pan out terribly well. Luckily, the excellent writing, hilarious performances from an all-star cast, and ridiculous combat continue to shine brightly and make this tabletop-inspired explosion-fest absolutely worth your time.

Positive: Borderlands + D&D + Tiny Tina = badass game. Voice work for characters is great as well. 

Negative: Kinda one note, which is basically all Borderlands games at this point. But if you know what to expect, this is a great game to get lost in for a lighthearted shooter looter.

I really wanted to like this - while the setting & story is a nice change from typical borderlands fare, and voice acting is exceptional and full of character, the game's emphasis on 'loot' and the mountains of junk they heap at you every 5 mins breaks the immersion as I waste time & energy deciding if yet another shiny drop is worth picking up, trying out, or keeping. Exploration beyond the beaten path is rewarded with -you guessed it- even more junk loot, & the only thing less fun than trying to manage it all is saying 'fuck it' and leaving all the colorful shinies behind as I try to complete a stage with some sense of flow. Either way the fun is killed for me due to the overwhelming deluge of loot and I want my 40 dollars refunded. That's right, it's not even worth the 50% discount imo, but loot junkies might rejoice at the excess.

[h1] A Review of Tiny Tina's Wonderlands [/h1]
[u] Including my own opinion/feelings (hehe) [/u]
Okay, there's a lot to unpack here...
I'll start by saying that this review will contain minor spoilers (Nothing story-wise).
[h1]Let's start with the pros:[/h1]
1. [b][u]Class variety[/u][/b] - The class system allows you to choose a class and a sub class. Unique to this game, it adds some nice flair to the gameplay. (We don't get to see any whacky classes like Gaige Anarchy or Jacks Money is Power, which is unfortunate, but each class plays fairly differently, and getting to mix and match is kinda fun)
2. [b][u]Projectile Speed[/u][/b] - The weapons feel great to shoot, and you hardly feel the travel time. 
3. [b][u]Boss fights[/u][/b] - The bosses in this game are a mixed bag. Some of them are very good, with well telegraphed attacks, others just run at you, and some fall in between. I'd say the good bosses are arguably the best in the series. The bad bosses are just, well... Spawn a bandit, give it lots of hp, then call it a boss...

[h1]Now to the cons:[/h1]
1. [b][u]Weapon variety[/u][/b] - Weapon variety has almost never been lower in the borderlands series. 
Shotguns, Snipers, and AR's got completely gutted and are essentially no longer usable, minus a few legendary drops.
Launchers... They may as well not exist at this point, many of them have less damage than snipers, slow you down to a crawl, and just aren't worth it when they do a fraction of what an smg or pistol will do in a couple of shots. (Pistols do almost as much as snipers, just so you have context).
The weapons you used to love (Conference Call, Norfleet, The Twister, Flakker, and other weapons that have fairly unique projectiles) are almost non-existent here. Many of the legendary weapons feel fairly lack lustre.

Speaking of, with a grand total of 46 Legendary+Unique guns, 
Tiny Tina's Wonderlands somehow manages to have less than *Half* the legendary+Unique+Pearls compared to Borderlands 1. That's right, the first Borderlands game.

Now I understand that Borderlands 3 might have had quite the overflow of legendary weapons, but Tiny Tinas seems to have an underflow, with quite a few of the legendary weapons feeling very... Normal. In fact, I would argue many of them are worse than purple and blue tier weapons, thus having the same problem as Borderlands 3, but worse somehow.

2. [b][u]Enemy Spawning[/u][/b] - This could be a positive or a negative, depending on how you play the game, as well as how lucky you are. Sometimes an enemy will just magically spawn behind you (Yes, they just appear, that's how it works in this game). As such, you could be unlucky and have a bomber spawn behind you and blow up. Hence why I mentioned that snipers are almost useless in this game. 

This compounds further into (Skip this if you don't want minor spoilers to end game content)
[spoiler] Chaos Chambers, end game content that's sort of like running a raid? Enemies spawn in a small stage randomly (which means you could get a badass spawn (Or multiple... Right behind your back...)), you kill them, get some upgrades, and continue for 6-8ish stages. There are also some boss fights, where they have adds, and you can suffer from these adds, especially if you are dodging their attacks (you have to jump/duck for quite a few of of them, hindering your ability to get away from adds) [/spoiler]

3. [b][u]Enemy variety[/u][/b] - While there is a good variety, many don't feel fun to fight against. I'll go into detail about how each enemy is and how fun/unfun it is to fight against each.
[spoiler] 
Enemy archetypes include the following:
[b]Skeletons[/b] - The normal shamblers that just run at you are fine, but the mages are high priority targets that can (and will) do a large amount of damage to you. The archers predict your movement from miles away and have a spread shot, so... Well, have fun getting sniped from across the map while fighting a boss. 
[b]Pirates[/b] - Your normal bandits, nothing too bad about these, except that they dodge bullets by jumping to the side, and when you hit a weak point, they instantly stand up again sometimes, which means slow firing weapons are a no-go
[b]Mushrooms[/b] - The bombers suck to fight against, little one-shot monsters that can catch you off guard due to spawning. The mortar mushrooms are annoying since 2-3 of them can dish out a *ton* of damage. The rest are fine for the most part.
[b]Goblins[/b] - Most are fine, but the engineers can leap from a huge distance away and the leap does a ton of damage. The barrel goblins are unnecessarily tanky, and if a bomber is hiding inside the barrel that you just broke, ha ha, skill issue.
[b]Trolls[/b] - These guys are fine. Sucks when they spawn behind you, but they have clear weak points to hit. Just walking HP bars.
[b]Scyllia[/b] - Holy, the most annoying of the annoying. These things slither around at mach 10, huck spears that deal an insane amount of damage (enough to 2 shot quite often). Some carry shields, so you can't hit them with projectile weapons unless you shoot from above (good luck with that). The electric ones will cast large electric fields around where you stand, so you have to be on the move constantly, and if you are unfortunate enough to be in a cycle of 4 of them, you better hope you are fast enough to get out of that circle and kill them fast enough. (They have massive range too) Fast firing spray-and-pray weapons do best against these things.
[b]Wyverns[/b] - These guys are fine. A bit much to handle if you are unlucky and only have slow projectile weapons or low range weapons, but otherwise pretty fun to fight.
[b]Crabs[/b] - The smallest weak points known to man-kind, there are mortar crabs with the same problem as with the mortar mushrooms
 [/spoiler]

4. [b][u]Enemy weak points[/u][/b] - Don't even bother aiming for them. You can hit trolls and some goblins, but forget the rest. From dodging and tiny windows to hit the weak points, you are better off using a high fire-rate weapon to hope you get the crit from the crit chance, and not from weak points. Most bosses also suffer from this. Additionally, with the amount of sporadic movement, dodging, and questionable AI, aiming for crit points with projectile based weapons is near impossible.

5. [b][u]Story[/u][/b] - While not as insufferable as BL3 (usually), this one is not good, and the poor writing mainly falls back on the fact that it's a D&D campaign as an excuse to be bad. I understand that D&D is great with improvisation, but this takes it a few steps too far.  The main villain is aight though. 

6. [b][u]Class variety[/u][/b] - While this was a positive point, it's also a negative point. With quite a few skills being "Here, have +10% gun damage" or "Here, have a bit of move speed", etc, it means that certain classes just aren't optimal with other subclasses, resulting in what I would argue less variety than BL2. Better than BL3 though, so at least they have that, amirite?

7. [b][u]Max Level[/u][/b] - [spoiler] Max level is only level 40, with badass rank being turned into Diablo 3 Paragon (if you know what that is) [/spoiler]

[h1]Too long, didn't read? Here you go:[/h1]
[b]Shotguns/Snipers/Launchers/ARs are pretty much useless.
Bad spawning leads to tons of AoE spam that you can't dodge.
Bad weapon variety compared to previous titles.
Weak points are a thing of the past (Unless you can predict poor enemy AI causing zigzag and head wiggles) [/b]
This game feels like it could be a $25 BL3 DLC instead.

Don't buy this game yet. It has a ton of bugs and issues resulting from bad decisions, many of which can be summarized as "Gearbox is making the same mistakes they made with the previous games in the series (regarding endgame scaling) even though they've not only learned their lesson already, but also actually fixed these problems before, so clearly they know how to fix them but still chose not to".

Wait like a year for them to fix the bugs and balance issues, then get the game on sale. If they bother to fix the game's many problems, I'll see about updating my review, but right now the game feels like they're using us as beta testers.

~~~~~

Well, here's an update: they're not gonna fix the game's many problems. They did fix the awful drop rates, but they did it by adding way too many chaos trials, and there were too many already.

I will say this, though. [spoiler]Barkenstein[/spoiler], the "green" raid boss, is an amazing boss. I've told my friends that it's "to Borderlands what the Empress of Light is to Terraria", and what that means is that the boss has very fun mechanics that feel rewarding and make getting defeated by the boss feel legitimate, unlike other bosses who can feel too easy or, more likely, unfair. It's a shame such a great boss is embedded in a game that still, to this day, just feels like Gearbox aimed for making money over making a quality product. BL3 showed us what Gearbox could do after so many years of BL2 dominating (despite having its own share of many bugs and flaws), and Wonderlands feels like they intentionally threw out what they learned in favor of unhelpful aesthetics and expensive voice actors.

The whole story, including every single one of the side-quests, is incredibly fun and polished, taking you across a plethora of unique locations. The gun-play is great too and looting feels satisfying. The end-game content is however non-existent, while the DLCs are nothing more than copy-paste cash grabs from the company (with some steam achievements even locked behind these paid DLCs). [b]Would recommend the base game but do not waste your time with the accompanying DLCs.[/b]

Overall: I recommend this game for people who enjoy the looter/shooter genre.

I played this game in Epic's store for the first year and have around 300 hours logged. So yeah... I like it. 

I'm a sucker for these titles, and have loved playing them since the first Borderlands back in the late 2000's. If you enjoy the looter/shooter genre and don't mind RNG taken to the next level, you will enjoy this game. 

The story line is fun, and similar to the first Bunkers & Badasses release in Borderlands 2. Gearbox does a great job balancing the traditional table top D&D RPG with the standard BL overlay. Here are some pros and cons. 

PROs
- Gun play is tight and fast. (BL has always been a good shooter.)
- There are a million version of loot which make replaying reqarding.
- Story line is ineresting and funny with Will Arnett voicing the bad guy (and killing it). 
- Voice actors are really great and keep the story engaging.
- Maps are varied and enemies are fun.
- DLC keeps the game interesting.

CONs
- While I love Ashley Burch (Tiny Tina), her voice gets kinda grating. 
- The entire story line is a little short for a AAA game. 
- The game is kind of "One-Note", meaning it does shooting and story line well, but that's about it. 
- The potty humor gets a little much and it feels like the writers rely on it a little too much. 

TBH - If you like BL games, then this one will satisfy.

NB: I've been increasingly disappointed with Borderlands games since the first one, so if you generally enjoy them, you might have a completely different perspective.

I don't think anyone would be confused by the fact that this game isn't called "Borderlands", but just to be extra sure: yes, this is most definitely a Borderlands game. It has the same basic gameplay, the same structure, the same kind of story, the same brand of humor. The only real differences are that the player characters aren't *actual* characters anymore and are instead fully customizable, that there are no vehicles, the grenades are replaced with magic spells, and there are now different melee weapons and "armor". Otherwise it's pretty much the same game.

It doesn't even look all that different visually: despite being fantasy, it still has the same not-quite-cel-shaded appearance, you mostly pick up guns that look almost exactly the same as in other entries to the series (except some of them now have bow parts), and you fight some very familiar-looking and behaving enemies (though in the interest of fairness there are some fresh-ish additions).

Since I doubt that a lot of people would expect anything from the story of this game, I'll be brief: the story is a mess. The writers try to go for something meta with the villain, include banter between both the characters in the Borderlands setting and the in-universe Wonderlands setting, and have some fun in the process with the D&D-type setting, but stumbled on pretty much every step to the point that even stuff that you'd think would be basic is unclear. If the "Newbie", i.e., your character, is playing with two other people, where are their characters in-game? Why do they keep talking as if they have any impact on the events? And if they do, why would the villain never address them? What was the villain's plan, anyway? None of this would really be clear by the end.

One more thing that is related to writing before I move on: the jokes in this entry make my soul shrivel and die every time. They're the most shallow, often hopelessly outdated kind of referential humor, only sometimes connected with the premise of the game. It often feels like a Friedberg and Seltzer type of movie, not helped by the fact that at least one of the "jokes" in this game actually did appear in the infamous Epic Movie (2007).

In terms of gameplay, at least at the time of this review the game feels incredibly unpolished, even compared to the other games in the series. The maps can be hard to navigate (some are three-dimensional, and one has portals to complicate matters even further) and have a lot of invisible walls and odd level geometry, there are some pretty serious buggy interactions between items and skills, etc.

Perhaps the biggest issue with the gameplay, however, is the wildly inconsistent difficulty. With the exception of one particular boss, every boss fight in this game was a complete joke, some not even managing to finish their introductory monologue before getting killed. Even the final boss barely lasted two minutes. Meanwhile, battles with normal enemies can be anything from a breeze to a chore to a complete nightmare depending solely on which types of enemies you're fighting and seemingly no other reason.

Most of all, this game feels lazy. The credit sequence starts with an apology that the development was difficult due to COVID, but I don't think that can explain every problem this game ended up having and every choice that was made. About half the gameplay is done in the form of "Encounters", fights with enemies spawning out of thin air with no real explanation or reason in small combat arenas (that are repeated for each of the four main areas of the overworld map). The DLC follows the same structure, but even the main game isn't all that much better: one tiny, but illustrative example is that the levels are full of impassable black voids out of which the enemies arrive, when the previous games in the series usually at least had put enough care into this to put doors or something like that there. And this kind of laziness is felt throughout everything.

All in all, I would only recommend this if you're really, REALLY jonesing for more Borderlands, no matter the quality.

Randy has made 0 attempts to fix QoL issues from the last games, and has introduced new ones.
- Quests and story progress are blocked by lengthy NPC dialogues that have to complete before missions update or doors unlock.

- Melee attacks, a selling point of this game, have extremely heavy aim assist that can't be disabled. Will straight up hijack your cursor. Cleaving, aiming for weak spots or priority targeting is out of your hands and into Randy's.
- The writing continues to degrade.
- Game attempts to groom the player.

Meh. Definitely a weak entry in the franchise.

There's some good of course :
-The environments are really nice. They're colorful, varied, and detailed. Fantasy locations look quite good with the serie's cell-shaded style, and it's a welcome change of pace from the usual bleakness of the mainline games.
-The game lets you pick any two classes (out of 7, one of which is DLC), allowing for a bunch of combinations.
-The "fantasy" weapon variants are nice and an interesting twist on typical weapons (typical weapons are still there though, don't worry).
-Story is alright. Nothing groundbreaking, but just alright. (Although after Borderlands 3 my standards are admittedly very, very low.)
-Grenades have been replaced with cooldown based spells, which have a variety of cool effects and go a long way to sell the fantasy theme.
-The bosses are cool and more interactive than just "stand there and shoot until the health bar is empty".
-And overall the gunplay is nice and tight.

But there's a lot more bad overall :
-While you can multiclass, each class only has a single skill tree. So you'll only have two skill trees in the end, which may or may not synergize. You also can't reroll your secondary class until you finish the game, and you can never reroll your main class.

-The level cap is very low (40). You get a bit more skillpoints than that (44 total), but it's still low. You can't even get both of your capstones. And unlike the other games in the serie, no DLC increases it.

-To "compensate" the low cap, from level 40 onward you get "mythic levels" which are incredibly minor bonuses in lieu of proper skillpoints. Gain a level, get +1% reload speed! Can you FEEL the progression? It blows.

-The game is short. My playtime upon finishing is at 37 hours, and that's with a lot of idling, doing nearly every side quest, and just generally taking my sweet time.

-The humour is tired. Sure, a couple of jokes got me smiling, but when the entire game is a never ending avalanche of corny jokes, puns, and pop culture references, obviously one or two are going to land. But the vast majority did not.

-Claptrap is there. Mercifully, his appearances are brief and limited to sidequests.

-There are a few bugs. Nothing gamebreaking, but definitely some annoyances, like a pickup prompt not going away or menus not scrolling properly.

-You can now loot and equip melee weapon. Which means instead of melee scaling automatically and increasing in effectiveness with some characters' skills, now it's yet another equipment that'll become obsolete after an hour and a half. Yet another category diluting the loot pool. Yet another chance to get a legendary you don't give a damn about (because no, melee combat isn't good enough to build a character around, so it remains a gimmick).

-Most dungeons, "random encounters", and a majority of sidequests are just basic arena fights where the game plops you into a randomly selected map, throws a couple of small waves of enemies at you then calls it a day. It's a very lazy way to make content and blatant padding. It's boring (especially since the maps are somewhat big and enemies spawn sparsely and often far from you, so you regularly get gaps in the action), it's uninspired, the rewards are lousy, and you'll be sick of them by the time you've done your third one.

-There is now a luck stat, which you increase by finding random dice hidden in the maps. Fitting in theory, but in practice it means you'll mostly drop worthless trash for a good half of the game, until you've found enough dice to prop up your luck - at which point you'll start dropping thing like a normal Borderlands game. It also means you are punished if you don't take the time to explore the map and find at least a good portion of the dice in each one.

-Those arena fights I mentionned? That's THE ENTIRETY OF THE POST GAME CONTENT. Yep, instead of getting some new sidequests, raid boss, or even a harder new game+ like usual, you just get a bunch of lousy arena fights with some half-assed modifiers thrown on top. After completing a "chaos run" (that's what they call it), you get a bunch of loot, which you can then use to... do more chaos runs, I guess. Because there is NOTHING else to do.

So... yeah. "Meh" indeed. Pick the game up on a deep sale, play a bit until you've had your fill, then just move on to something better and forget about this one.

While a venture from the story of the original Borderland's Universe, this throws you into a beautiful, albeit a bit repetitive Wonderland. For both Scifi and Fantasy lovers, this is a creatively crafted and amazingly voice acted adventure into the Borderlands side-verse. 

Very refreshing is the addition of dual classing, with the ability to change that dual class once you have completed the main story. Also, replacing grenades with spells for the DnD flavor was incredibly clever on their behalf. The lack of real story content in the DLC is a tad disappointing, and the Chaos Dungeon system which is the new endgame grind system while enjoyable could use some love. Definitely Hoping for more updates on this one.

Unexpectedly fun looter-shooter. It has the traditional borderlands style graphics, looting, elemental and different rarity guns with a new twist; a DnD-style narrative where Tiny Tina is the DM and you are just a player that has set out to take on the quests in Tina's tabletop map with your friends. 

The one thing that keeps catching me off-guard though are the environmental graphics, they look reallly good for a 'borderlands' game. At times the game feels reminiscent of Skyrim in the sense that you may enter a dungeon in search of some artifact on a quest, and will be fighting skeleton warriors along the way.

With the introduction of spells slinging, this game affords you the flexibility to play it as you wish. I wasn't used to using the spells at first, so I kept forgetting about them, and the game resembled a more traditional borderlands experience with gun-based and melee weapon play, but as I began facing tougher enemies, using those spells has been instrumental to not only conserving ammo but to take on swarms

Wonderlands to Borderlands 3 feels like Pre-Sequel to Borderlands 2 - the same engine and formula, but with a bunch of new ideas and experiments in gameplay. Class combinations, the new equipment slots (melee weapon and rings), a new element (Dark Magic), spells instead of grenades, and character stats like Loot Luck or Class Power make the game fresh and fun. I hope some of the ideas we will see in Borderlands 4.

The locations, story, side quests, and loot are all gorgeous. Every part of the game is as good (if not better) as Borderlands 3. Humor and story are not for everyone, but it holds classic Borderlands style, so you either like it or not.

It has a rather lovely endgame. It's different from Borderlands, but it's a nice switch and way better than replaying the game three times to get to max level.

However, it makes more sense in Wonderlands to try more classes and play the game multiple times from level 1 compared to Borderlands instead of maxing the same character. Quests and enemies here scale to your level from the beginning, and the class system is done in a way that makes sense to play the game "horizontally" instead of vertically. Much of the content was put into variations and RPG elements, so trying many classes and their combinations will be more fun than just making a single class throughout the game.

Season Pass is often blamed for lack of content, and indeed there are no full-story DLCs like in Borderlands, but it is what it is. Could the game be expanded even more? Yes. Is it great and full of fun gameplay for 50-100+ hours as it is? Also yes.

On 50% Holiday sale, it's a must-have grab.

That is, unless you manage to find enough of the hidden dice to bring your luck up. 

Overall, really fun game to play with friends. Not worth $60, but worth $30 or less on sale.

Attacks: Loved the idea you get to pick a Class but there was not a lot, maybe 5 or 6. As for the Melee I wish there was more than just pressing a single button. Would have loved to see combos.

After playing this game for a while, I found that it got pretty boring and highly repetitive. It's basically a glorified arcady wave shooter with every level and area looking and feeling the same. It's also poorly optimized with constant frame rate drops almost every time it auto-saves, which is like every few seconds. The game also would often freeze as the frame rate dived into the 30's, possibly due to Denuvo. Vsync also does not save and has to be re-enabled every time you start the game. I also found the inventory system to be uninteresting and confusing. Ammo, loot, and weapons also fly out of enemies and chests like crazy and these items get scattered everywhere to the point that I just started ignoring them. Changing weapons didn't seem to matter anyway and there's no cool ways to really improve armor. There's also lots of gun sway with every shot that I didn't care for. Overall, I ended up not really enjoying my experience with this game so I uninstalled and moved on to other games.

This game is boring me to tears, doubly so because I loved BL2. In this game, you spend most of your time organizing piles of gear with minuscule stat buffs, fighting  the RNG that insists on giving "good" gear  which counteracts my entire build. The  game  also gives you "bonus" skin unlocks which are  level locked  to a higher level, and will not let me put them in the bank, leading to me having  4 of my 36 inventory slots permanently filled with unusable items.

The world feels absolutely  dead, compounded by the fact that even on Public nobody ever joins my session, so walking through a world populated by static "NPCs" who do  not react at all to anything (not even the perma-crouch response to gunfire from BL2/BL3) is  the norm. Even quest givers, who would comment on you not going to the objective  in every other BL game, is absent, leading to long sections of no dialog or environmental feedback at all. Items aren't destructible, nothing moves, the  world feels more like  a  backdrop than a place  the  characters can inhabit, and is a huge  leap backwards in world building and player engagement.

What makes it all the more infuriating is that it is impossible to have a  stable build in any domain at any time. Want to get a new gun, well now your spells are less effective. Want to get a buff in spell time, then take a major hit somewhere else. This wouldn't be  bad if all abilities were item-based, or if the buffs were big enough to make the debuffs palatable, but since most of the abilities are tied to specific stats, then there are massive piles of gear that look decent but will make the player a lot less capable.

The voice acting is OK, but there is  zero engagement to let us know who the new characters are, why they are stuck here beyond "ship crashed", or why I  should care about them,. Absolutely none of the  NPCs so  far have been interesting or fun, instead going for funny accents in place of writing that would give them a soul, and even Will Arnett  cannot make the villain more than a cardboard cutout with the dialog and story that he was given.

This is  such a letdown, BL1 was good,  2 was great, BLPS and TFB were good again, 3 was passable, and  now this is.... worse than even the BL3 DLC.  It's a  stain on Tiny Tina's name that so much potential for a game like  this has been flushed down the toilet of mediocrity that Gearbox seems to inhabit  these days, and as a huge fan of the series it's just terribly sad to see how far the  series has fallen in 10 years.

So comparing it to BL3, game runs a lot better, classes are more to my liking, and i quite enjoy the variety of spells replacing grenades.

Melee is a mixed bag for me because while it's great that they're now a whole new weapon type, hitting shit lacks a lot of impact.

Humor is just as fine, even with all the censorship, starts very dull, gets a lot better around the moment where Torgue shows up, it's still the same dumb shit you're used to. So unless you're a giant man-child ironically obsessed with trying to be ''mature'' you'll enjoy it just fine.

On the censorship though, and this is probably what kills the vibe the most for me, is the lack of gore... or not the lack of /gore/ itself but more about the lack of explosiveness that BL3 had, where you could make a dude explode with overkill damage, or dismember them. I feel they should've at least added it on a toggle, enemies still explode through overkill but it seems to be a lot more rare than usual, and it doesn't feel as satisfying as it is in BL3.

A slightly different Borderlands game that gives a nice breath of fresh air to the series because it's a good idea and it's well made:
[list]
    [*] The RPG setting is well done
    [*] The story has the usual Borderlands vibe with a lot of jokes and references
    [*] The fact that we are playing in a fantasy world that comes from the mind of Tiny Tina so anything could happen and we get to create our character with attributes and classes instead of having a preset one
[/list]
Also, the thing I appreciated the most is the fact that everything scales with your level, so you are free to progress however you like without the risk of being overleveled (which happens very frequently in other Borderlands games, especially if you take all the sidequests like I do).

Currently, it's the best Borderlands I've played since Borderlands 2 and I highly recommend it.

Its Borderlands except in a D&D setting. It has the best character customization of all the Borderlands games, and the combat is the best as well.  There are many interesting guns, but I ended up beating the game with a sub-machine gun I got at level 11 because it worked so well with my character's build. The story is decent, but not all of the jokes landed for me. 

The game is overpriced for what you get. If you rush, you can beat the main story in maybe only a few hours. I beat it at around 18 hour playtime around level 30 (the max is 40); that is, I beat it at the highest difficulty, completed over twenty side quests, several dungeon runs, and a few chaos chamber runs. The DLC adds optional dungeons which are too easy and not worth doing. Other end game content like the Chaos Chamber also seems pointless to me. Why grind for loot when you've beaten the game and have nothing overly difficult to fight? Now if they added difficult, mechanically complex bosses to fight maybe you could justify paying full price.

All that being said, I recommend the game IF AND ONLY IF you can get it on sale. The gameplay is good, the story is decent, but too short, and it lacks meaningful end game content.

My First Enjoyable Looter-Shooter Experience Since Borderlands 2 - Rating: 9/10
I was never a huge fan of the Borderlands series, or even the looter-shooter genre to begin with, but this game really caught my attention and I decided to try it out. Firstly, I have to say the writing in this game is hilarious. Although it has it's cringe moments (like all video games), I found myself laughing to the witty, yet dumb punch lines it provides. The voice acting really elevates the writing and helps on the delivery of most jokes. There was plenty of satire, sarcasm, and overall witty remarks which i really loved.
The game play is actually super fun. As I mentioned earlier, I never really liked looter-shooter games too much, but I found myself actively enjoying the hunt for new weapons and gear. Trying out a massive variety of weapons and spells and finding something that suits my play style was super enjoyable. The amount of variety in this game is truly amazing, not just in weapons and spells, but it also surprised me how many different enemy types there were. Blasting through hoards and waves of different enemies was my favorite part about the game.
Lastly, the artwork, graphics, and design of the game really blew me away. The game is truly beautiful. There are plenty of different areas and sections you can explore in the game and they surprised me with how great they all looked. There were lots of bright, vibrant, and colorful areas, mixed in with darker, dreary, and dungeon-like settings creating what seems like a perfect balance between light and dark. Truly a unique game and i can't recommend it enough if you're looking for something new to sink your teeth into. 9/10 overall rating and would 100% recommend to a friend.

Personally I enjoyed this way more than Borderlands 3. The world and environments are really nice to look at and explore, plus the guns.... THE GUNS!!! Been playing with the voices muted but thats been the case for me since the pre-sequel. This also seems to run way better than Borderlands 3 and looks way nicer, I've had no frame-drop or crashes. Recommended with some reservations. The good: the character creation is SUPER great and I really appreciated the inclusiveness and lack of gender-bound options. So many COOL options for classes, this is one of the few games where I spent nearly as much time agonizing over class choice as nailing the exact right slider for every single one of my cosmetic choices (mushroom bro! plague bringing! THE AGONY OF CHOICE). Loading up a co-op game was also very smooth with no problems. What little I've reached of the story and characters involved is hilarious and wonderful, and really loads up on the nostalgia for previous borderlands games. Having the different types of maps and game play is weird but cool, it breaks things up a little and makes the game unique, it's a plus for me but I can see why others might not like the overworld map when all they wanted was a shooter.

Some bad: I don't usually have problems with motion sickness during games but after playing for just a few minutes it gave me a wicked bad headache that lasted for hours. After consulting the almighty google I changed a BUNCH of different settings and to its credit, I have no discomfort now. Half of these settings I never would've been able to find on my own, however (in case you need it, the big ones for me were in accessibility and concerned turning of ALL camera motion/bobbing and then in gameplay to center the reticule. Higher field of view nice, but not as impactful). Consulting google was a constant since encountering a game-hindering/breaking bug was a very common occurrence and fully half of the initial few hours of gameplay was just making it playable. Not ideal.

In conclusion: at full price, especially for the chaotic edition, I would be pretty upset with how buggy it is. Having bought it at a significant discount, I'm feeling pretty good about things. In this context a few bugs don't bother me as much, especially knowing I've got the worst of them figured out and can more or less just sit back and enjoy Tiny Tina's particular brand of chaos and fun. YMMV.

This game is so far removed from the original borderlands games that it feels like a new game all on its own. Which is not a bad thing. In fact it does well in combining the things I loved about the borderlands games with the fanciful allure of a classic TTRPG. The best purchase I've made this year by far.

It's like my second favorite Borderlands after Borderlands 2, but it's also probably in my top ten games. It feels like a perfected, yet condensed Borderlands experience. It's the gameplay that I've always wanted from this series. I think I'm on my fifth or sixth playthrough as of writing this. Haven't played online, never played any game online in my life, but I am intrigued by it for the first time, like I could see this being my first online game. I'm committed to the Borderlands series, which makes this great for me, but I guess this would be pretty unappealing to someone who hadn't at least played Borderlands 2. That's as close as I can get to an honest criticism here. Okay well a lot of the humor is still cringe, half of everything is a reference to something else. Torgue is funnier than a thousand Star Wars lines. Tina is more likable than any amount of nerd cred that can be harvested from nostalgic movie quotes. The three new main characters, all voiced by legitimately famous, legitimately funny people are enough to keep me entertained, I don't need them to be parodies of characters from other IPs. What I'm saying is that Gearbox is at their funniest when they are telling their own jokes. I think they limit their potential for writing and worldbuilding when they fill in the blanks with referential humor. Borderlands 3 was honestly taxing with all that Reddit type humor thrown in, it made the game feel dated on release day. Borderlands has the funnest gameplay of any game I've ever played, I have no notes on the gameplay, and I'll buy the next game because the gameplay will certainly smack. The writing and worldbuilding are on par with the gameplay, they just just need to drop the reference humor and realize that they are totally capable of being funny and engaging on their own merit.
