This game isn't amazing but it is def worth a try if you like the borderlands series, especially when on sale. 

If you go in with reasonable expectations (I believe I did) then its pretty fun. 

The gameplay is actually pretty engaging, it starts off kind of slow as expected but quickly picks up. The class progression is nice and the skills seem meaningful, giving substantial bonuses (at least the classes I chose). In previous games some skills didn't feel like they did much besides have a place in the tree. I like the stat allocation system as well, I think this should be brought back in the future. 

The loot dice are a good system and overall I enjoyed the collectibles, they were placed in fun and creative ways where it felt rewarding to explore and not as if were just aimlessly running around until you spotted one. 

Something I thought was great was they didn't build the game around being replayed a few times. You finish the game at max level. It feels less tedious and not as boring when you aren't doing the same quests multiple times.

The overworld JRPG system was kind of cool, it works well for this game but I'm not sure about for future BORDERLANDS games. I did like vehicles in previous games but they were also kind of a hassle. The JRPG system made it so maps were more compact, it felt better designed and meaningful. I think borderlands wouldn't be the same without vehicles but wonderlands does a good job without them. The fast travel system was GREAT, being able to fast travel from anywhere is amazing and should be in all borderlands games to come.

I liked the chaos chamber, its a good endgame system to get good loot and expands well on the arenas you find in the overworld. I do think they should make it more roguelike-like, the replayability wasn't amazing. I hope they bring it back and improve upon it in the future.

I knew the writing was gonna be kinda bad but I was a little surprised that it was just mediocre and not BAD. The voice acting is okay, I ended up turning off dialogue and listening to music instead. There's a little too much dialogue that you have to wait for, which is kind of expected from the borderlands series at this point but I wish they added the skip dialogue by line feature from cyberpunk. The overall story was decent as well, I liked the ending but was kind of bored of it halfway through. Kind of felt like they just stitched the beginning and end together. 

I will say I bought the chaotic great edition (the one that includes the season pass) and I don't think the DLC is worth it unless you get it for the discounted price, and even then its not that great. The only thing going for it is a few new areas to explore that aren't very different from those in the base game besides aesthetic. They are more like long side quests than actual DLC. The class that you get from the DLC is fun but otherwise I'd save your money.  

TLDR: if you like borderlands and this is on sale (~30 USD or less) its def worth it

I didn't think I could love this game more than I did Borderlands 3. But I do. I love this game, the IP, the whole schtick that I'd love to come work at Gearbox to just help the team put out more great games like this -- not as a game dev but in some other tech role like helping their databases stay online. 

Anyways, come on! What's not to love: the affable "Jake Peralta" of Andy Samberg and the sultry tones of Will Arnett -- two people I think are super dope -- voicing the game under the guise of a D&D style game run by a crazy tween named Tiny Tina?! It's awesome. The maps are great. The characters are fun. I loved my setup with all the life-steal abilities and the AOE attacks -- it was such a joy. I played and beat the main campaign and now I will go back and finish all the DLCs.

Thank you Gearbox, seriously. Thank you!

Also, btw, this runs flawlessly on my Linux machine running Fedora 36 with the Nvidia Drivers and my 3060ti. Thank you to Steam and all the efforts with Proton to make that amazing.

Main campaign and side quests are not rewardable at all! We found only two legendary items for the whole entire campaign, and they were dropped by enemies. Developed by geniuses, they did not push anything worthwhile. So, we reached the end and realized that there was no frgn worthwhile! Even skull keys mostly give trash.

New classes and abilities add some  new fresh gameplay variations. Especially I liked to play as Spell Caster. However, on the 5-th chaos level I had to change it to Grave Born. Not sure about other classes but this one has most survivable abilities. I bet, other classes have balance problems too.

Side missions for blue / pink weapons is sad. We truly tried to get an achievement for all side quests but each time one of us or both just falls asleep after 30 minutes of the game. And those missions are wait for dialog, wait for NPC, wait for dialog, destroy something. You can’t skip any dialogs; you must wait. Yeah, some of them are funny, but in general I can’t remember any of them.

Why do you need levels thing in the game? All enemies auto levels to yours level or plus several levels (depends on chaos). I want to return back after final boss and beat all sheet out of annoying goblins [i](okay, it's my problem)[/i]

Badass rank is changed again, and now you must waste skills to each of four trees. But I don’t like melee weapons in the game. Why do I need to waste my points?!

The brightest moment in the game is Chaos Room. Here you can be finally rewarded by something worth or interesting. It's challenging and you can set up dungeon attempt. Without pooping dialogs to my ears; just you and clear grind gameplay. But then again, best items in vending machines costs too much at the end of the attemption. I guess, worthy only with a discount.

I have never played a game so broken it crashes so hard, my PC becomes unusable unless I restart it (and I 100%ed Cyberpunk 2077). That kept happening during a few cutscenes and I do not know why. Brought my GPU memory usage up to 18,6gb. In case someone else runs into this: I could not get past the cutscene of the final boss until i changed over to DirectX 11. That maxed out my GPU (a 3090. wtf is going on?), but at least it worked. I just switched back after the cutscene.

But that aside, the game is actually a lot of fun overall. It's got a lot of unused potential. It is overall a good game, but it could be a great game.

HOWEVER it is a game ruined by corporate greed, yet again. Just sucks to see that happen. The game feels pretty rushed in a bunch of places. But the absolute kick in the butt is a quest you get at the very beginning of the game. It introduces you to a nice mechanic that you can use to get really nice loot... only to then find out that the only way to make use of it is by buying the DLCs. "Oh, so you paid full price for this game? Well just look at what amazing stuff you are missing out on by not giving us even MORE money". They genuinely made the game less enjoyable just so you can give them more money... for a 60€ game... 

If you love the Borderlands looter-shooter gameplay and TTRPGs such as DND, you will probably like this game, even with its many of bugs. But when a company actively goes out of their way to take away the fun of a game just so they can ask for more money to get it back, I just can not give a good review.

I do hope there will be another spinoff like that that actually doesn't just have guns (melee as a better option, bows, crossbows, maybe throwing weapons and stuff like that), which isn't rushed and ISNT turned into a cash-grab. Though Borderlands doesn't seem to be on a good path, looking at the DLC of BL3 and this game.

I also feel super sorry for the devs of this game. They clearly put a lot of hard work and love into it, just for some marketing person to go "Nah let's make it worse so we can make more money off of it"

The Bad:
There's a lot that a more conservative audience would not like.
If I'm not crashing or glitching through the floor, the game is certainly a Borderlands game.
Customization is locked behind RNG drops from mobs and you can continuously pick up and find pieces you've already gotten instead of new ones.

The Alright:
The classes are a fresh take but the gameplay is similar to what you're used to. Some of the bosses had fun mechanics and gimmicks to them. Nothing new on the humor or storytelling.

This is the first time I've given a Borderlands game a poor review.  I loved the first two entries into the series.  I'd rank Borderlands 2 as one of my top 20 favorite video games ever.  I was heavily invested in the Tales from the Borderlands game.  Thought it was a great piece of storytelling that really tied into the plot of the series.  Borderlands: The Presequel was... not as good.  I didn't like the zero gravity or low gravity mechanics.  I was less interested in the backstory plot of the game.  It was the first Borderlands game I didn't finish, though I could be convinced to sit down and play through it again.  Borderlands 3 was a step in the right direction, but the planet hopping wasn't as fun as just staying on Pandora.  I didn't like where they took a few of the characters.  But I still beat it and then started a replay through it, as I did enjoy it for the most part.

And I'm a fan of tabletop RPGs.  I played DnD for close to 25 years, ever since I was 14.  This should have all the elements I like in a game.  More equipment.  More abilities.  Customization.  A fantasy theme along with the Borderlands humor.

But it lacked the plot and characters from previous Borderlands games.  It didn't feel like a part of the series, and I hadn't realized how much I needed that.  I didn't like the overmap.  I didn't like the fake fantasy world, or the weird explanation for why there was three people sitting around the table but only one "player".  I hated random encounters.  And, good lord, they really bought into the whole PC thing, with pronouns and an over-the-top dose of the gay.  They had some of this in previous games, but they double downed here.  Tells me a lot about Tina.

So finally, I got bored sliding around maps, blasting skeletons and goblins with slightly less interesting guns but slightly more interesting abilities.  Nothing in the plot made me want to keep playing.  Apparently I'm throwing in the towel for this game in less than 10 hours.  In all honesty, I could restart Borderlands 2 for the 12th time and put 50 hours into that game, but I just have no desire to continue with Tiny Tina's Wonderlands.  It feels more like a Borderlands knock-off than a Borderlands game.
Such a fun story. I am crying from laughing so hard. So much content to explore. I didn't hear good things about the DLC but it doesn't effect the main game. There is so much to explore.

The game is surprisingly good. I expected it to essentially be a big DLC for Borderlands 3...and in some ways, that's accurate. However, I think they've added more than enough to justify it existing as its own separate entity, and it feels distinct enough that I don't feel like I'm just replaying BL3. On top of that, it does a lot of things right that BL3 didn't...namely, the campaign being more enjoyable, with much better level design and side quests, and tons of optional areas. The $70 price tag might be a big steep given the amount of content, but if you can get it on sale, and if you liked the gameplay of Borderlands 3, I strongly recommend it.

For a brief overview, if you have played any of the Borderlands series you will know what to expect game play wise, and to some extent theme wise if you know Tina.

With that said, I wouldn't go much beyond that for an explanation if you have prior exposure. Beyond adding melee weapons, rings, and spell slots (grenades), everything else is consistent for better or worse. 

The theme is the major sell here, and with a brief understand of Dungeon and Dragons, it does suit it well. There are no vehicles this time around, but rather a over world to which the character moves across with the appearance of a board game. While this matches the theme, it doesn't change anything beyond aesthetic as the story progresses appropriately and with guidance.

When it comes down to much of the game, because it is D&D themed, most is just designed to match. Instead of characters, you have slight customization with a blank slate character, and classes to choose from. With that said, while the plot works around the "insert character here" theme, the engagement and characters are not as built.

Also to be noted, that classes have skill tree, and while you can "dual class" to unlock more build ideas and potentially more pets, it does feel a tad underwhelming. 

Further playing into this was items that almost felt unnecessary (rings)/melee weapons. These just played into the idea for more things to grind for, but no substance. And while this is a "fantasy" world, much of the enemies were re-skinned, and the same guns/mechanics existed. While understanding borderlands was themed around guns and the combinations therein, the new spell introduction which replaced grenades, seemed more appropriate and innovative. 

The environments had the sword and shield, bows, etc, but at most the character had a "crossbow" machine gun. The game would have benefited greater if the emphasis was greater with melee weapons, and removed guns, outside of musket esque items, and replaced them with bow variations, slingshots, etc. This is of course my opinion, but does shine on some greater things the game has.

The environments are far more diverse and engaging than in the past, and the universe and theme aloud for it. As stated before, while the universe built was great, some slight alterations that could have been designed would have greatly made the game more engaging or unique.

In simplicity, if you ever wanted to shoot guns at dragons, to then loot more guns this is your game. Outside the realm of that, I would recommend other titles in Borderlands if you haven't already played before this.

With that in mind, this is a spin off and met the expectations to that extent.

Put 10 hours into it and I can say that... I wish this was a DLC for Borderlands 2. 

On it's own, it stands fine, but I wouldn't buy it for 60+ bucks. It's Borderlands 2 with 3 and Presequel's mechanics, which I don't have a problem with. I've had a lot of fun with it, and it's likely because of the superb writing and art direction, I also appreciate the pronouns inclusion, be it limited. 

That being said, the Dragon Lord is such a good villain bc gearbox followed the Handsome Jack formula. He just never shuts up and his voice actor is hilarious and has great range (It's Bojack Horseman) so of course he feels thought out and has clear motivations, just like Handsome Jack did. The bosses have all been fun, and I mean that they are not only interesting mechanics wise, but also engaging. They all feel like they have a puzzle you have to solve while beating them to succeed, and even on normal I can say that the game is definitely challenging. 

The guns are cooler than ever and the gunplay is more engaging - I actually had to choose when I wanted to take cover or run, I built up melee not as a last resort but as the choice I wanted to use most of the time in close combat, and then the weapons, abilities, and classes compliment each other so you really feel like you're pulling off awesome DND combos on the spot. 

The characters aren't necessarily likable in this one, but they are entertaining and the themes of the main story and side quests are particularly progressive, though they do miss the mark often (Tiny Tina still talks with a little bit of blaccent, but one of the side quests told by her is all about communist revolution. IDK things like that show a disconnect between the game's goals and execution). 

Overall, no DLC, 10 hours in, I can say I'd buy this on sale for $30-$35 bucks, but not 60, and DO NOT BUY THE DLC THEY ARE AWFUL, YOU GET 6 CLASSES STARTING OFF AND THE DEVS ARENT INCREASING THE LEVEL CAPS, YOU DONT NEED THE DLC.

Seen it done before, better, ab 6 years ago, and it feels much more like an extension to Borderlands 2's Tiny Tina DLC, but it is fun, the characters grow on you, and I'm loving how these new games look and feel to play. Would've been a 6 but the accessibility options and pronouns make it a 7 for me. Only the queer folks know how rare they are even now. I feel about this how I felt about Borderlands 3, it's fun, it's new, and it's engaging, but after I'm done with it, I'm done with it. 7/10.

Edit: After 40 hours and 40+ levels, I can say that this is one of my favorite entries to the series. I thought the story would've been more meta, but it was just a feel good, simple, lighthearted adventure about the trials and tribulations of early Game Mastering, which is just up my alley. The guns and weapons keep getting cooler, and Chaos Mode makes it for me because the options to customize your RNG like a roguelike is something this series has never done before, and it works so incredibly well. The enemies get cooler in Chaos Mode, the bosses were all incredible, the characters are interesting and understandable, the set pieces and level designs were all outstanding, GIVE IT A PLAY!

Yeah the DLC shit sucks, but it is COMPLETELY optional stuff, they even gave the DLC its own area way apart from the rest of the game, to the point that it's never even mentioned, you have to find the DLC to play it (DONT).

40 hrs in, Im gonna keep playing. It's a lot more engaged than I thought. The Live Service model of all games has eaten at it a bit and saved the best until after the final boss, but hey, it's still a Borderlands title and works almost just as well.

FInal Thoughts: BL1 was Skyrim with guns, hard as nails, and couldnt keep my attention, but the characters and story kept me playing. BL2 was a thrill ride where every story mattered and where I wanted to find every secret and play every side mission, and every reward contributed to the main quest. BLtPS was a fun ride across the main games' lore, a bit unbalanced and the setting was rather dreary and it took itself a bit seriously at times, but I had fun with it. BLtPS was the first attempt at a live service model, so you can imagine how that went. TFtBL was interesting and weird, and I liked that. BL3 was some of the best gameplay the series had at the time and I continue to come back to it despite its rushed and awful story direction. 

TTWL is a culmination of all of these games and the shadows that loom over them. Gearbox's heart and soul went into this one, they listened to the fans, and it seems like the new direction this world is going is about taking the time to give the players the most options possible while exploring a well thought out story, no matter what happened in previous games - and while this game still lives in the shadow of 2 and the presequel, it stands on its own regardless and I've thoroughly enjoyed my time with it. 

At the end of the game the devs put a thank you note to the players that details how and why TTWL is the way it is and what direction they are taking moving forward, and I'd just like to thank the devs for all their continued hard work and dedication to one of my favorite series of all time, and for taking the time to make their games the best they can. 

In conclusion, the real villain is corporate greed, crunch culture, and live service models. I hope one day we see more games like Tiny Tina's Wonderlands without the terrible DLC and maybe with the Chaos Mode before the end of the game, but until then, this is the best we got.

If you like the quirky characters, humor, and shoot 'em up of Borderlands, then you'll love Tiny Tina's Wonderlands.  There are several laugh out loud moments in the game and some quests that are actually a little on the touching/thoughtful side.  You get a great mixed grab bag of Tiny Tina's humor with other great voice acting from Wanda Sykes, Andy Samberg, Will Arnett, and a host of other Borderlands characters that cross over (with a twist) into this fantasy adventure world.  I love that the game is based on Tiny TIna's DnD session in the Borderlands universe, but everything takes place in the vibrant, colorful, and fun fantasy world that Tiny Tina creates (and changes, based on her whim).

OK this will not be a scathing review but an honest one.
Positives
•	The story line is fun as hell
•	The over world stuff fits with the game
•	The weapons are actually kind of cool
•	The puzzle tasks and hunt an item thing works for me

Negatives

Was it fun?  yes, it is a typical fun borderlands game.  but the legendary drop really puts a damper on it.  Overworld is completely pointless and I wish they would have not included it.  Story was good, I am not really a fan of Tina, but the story was entertaining.  Combat encounters were also completely pointless and they should not have included them.  They could have gotten the same results in the regular levels.  Armor was also a disappointment....all you do is change the color....really lazy development.  Overall if you do buy it, make sure it is on sale for 1/2 price or less.  i would have been happier at 1/4 the msrp. The negativity surrounding the base game is unwarranted. Though I will admit, many of the jokes are niche and very slanted towards the table-top rpg theme... of the whole game... so it's warranted. And, I particularly think that is awesome. But, I've played quite a few rpg's across table-top's, on consoles and PC's. I'm biased towards the rpg jokes and theme.

But, this game is 100% not an rpg. If you know a Borderlands game, you understand the gameplay for the shiny, phat lewt-fest that it is. It's like great cheese melted over a huge awesome FPS burrito. Because even for the grindy FPS that it blatantly is, this game is phenomenally enjoyable.

And... can I just say that Wanda Sykes is the best! I have seen this lady be funny before, but hearing her running commentary through the whole game is fantastic. I makes me want to replay it just for her lines... and Tina. But, seriously... IF you are like who? Then pull up a stand up special... or her just talking sh$t. That woman is hysterical, and one of the best comedians working today.

So, get this game for the gameplay... yes. If you like FPS fun. But, really you should get it for the running commentary, situations and humor.

Only 3 months of waiting for the steam release this time. Not ideal, but it's a start! The Question must be asked; was it worth the wait, again?

[h1] The Great [/h1]

+Enemy variety. Instead of the usual reskins that you get with enemies, they have separate attack types and formations, as well as weaknesses. Multiple enemies have stacked health bars, requiring some strategy to dispatch. A zombie for example, has a fleshy shell weak to fire, but once it burns away only the brittle skeleton remains, weak to cyro. Love the new bone
health type as well, always good to have more variety.

++Loot. Luck can be increased passively by finding "Lucky Dice" throughout the world. This is a great addition that encourages exploration of the mostly open areas. Drop rates have gone back to the Borderlands 1 ways, where legendaries are still pretty rare, but you will see a couple during the journey.

+++Scaling. My want for every single Borderlands game has been achieved, enemies and missions scale with your character, meaning the challenge remains the same throughout the playthrough. Doing side quests are still required to stay up to the level requirements of new areas, though.

+Environments. All the levels across the board were enjoyed equally, all great. Only minor complaint is not enough store locations to sell off my hordes of garbage..

+Music. The entire soundtrack was a joy to listen to.

+Valentine. Loved his dialog.

+Character cosmetic customization. Tons of variety and inclusive options available.

[h1] The Good [/h1]

+-The Overworld. Has potential to become something great, but feels limited at times. I enjoy returning to earlier areas to unlock shortcuts, but it leaves me wanting more. Inclusion of actual hidden areas like Super Mario World would be a fantastic addition. The random encounters and dungeons can get repetitive with repeating maps too, though they're optional. Would like more camera adjustment as well.

+-Side quests. While some were wonderfully written and actually made me feel emotional, a lot turned into fetch quests.

+-Magic. Spells replaced grenade mods, and I do enjoy them more than grenades. That said, I felt most were inferior to any that had projectile multipliers. This may just be my build though. Speaking of...

+-Build diversity. There are quite a few options to help your character stand out. From choosing two classes, both with their own play styles, to a character stats sheet straight from D&D. Max level is 40, which means you need to choose wisely. This is all and good, but end game requires the player to choose the Spore Warden as one of their classes to survive, hurting diversity in the long run.

+-Humor. This was the funniest writing I've experienced yet, though like usual most jokes did not land for me. BHG was amazing, though.

-+Difficulty. I had the game set to "Intense", where enemies took 15% less damage unless they were attacked by the proper element, which did 25% more. Even when using the wrong element, I still melted bosses without issue. General mobbing had a nice balance though. Good to see Fire isn't objectively the best anymore.

+-Story. Borderlands 2 sets a very high bar when it comes to story, but I wouldn't completely dismiss what they tried here. The antagonist is leagues better than Borderlands 3's.

-+Similarities. A lot of people feel this is too similar to Borderlands 3 to justify the price tag. I share the same opinion as the general gameplay isn't terribly different, though I loved Borderland 3's. 40 CAD would be a better price.

+-Darkness elementals. While it's nice to have a element that heals you, least on intense, the damage loss generally isn't worth it unless you dedicate a weapon solely to getting health back.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

-Audio levels. For whatever reason, the game is abnormally quiet, even with the in game settings cranked to max. No game configuration files to adjust it further either. My work around was to blast OS volume to compensate, leading to explosive notifications..

-Bugs. Though not a broken mess, a few bugs kept reappearing during play. Dialog subtitles did not display properly, like not showing at all, disappearing too quickly, or repeating dialog from a previous cut scene. Another bug is the "interact" tip that would get stuck on your screen until you encounter another object that can be interacted with.

-Default crosshair position. Cannot understand why the crosshair is towards the bottom centre of the screen by default, it's an easy fix and I am fine with the option, but why default?

-No safe space adjustment. Ultra first world problem I know, but the ability to adjust UI elements to be closer to the centre of the screen was present in Borderlands 3.

-Performance. Specs: 5900x, 3080 Ti with 32GB Ram, all tuned for optimal performance. Borderlands 3 granted me a constant 95+ fps at 3840x1600 near max settings, where here I would run in the 70s - 80s, sometimes dropping to 50s despite no real increase in fidelity. FSR is a good addition, though I do not have much experience with upscaling technologies. In my case, FSR caused stuttering.

[h1] TLDR [/h1]

+Good changes for the franchise
+Antagonist isn't annoying
+FSR Inclusion
+Lots of build options, limited by end game though
+Magic is neat
-Performs worse than expected
-Obtuse bugs

Hopefully this turns into a full spin off series, it rivals my love for Borderlands 1. Highly recommend, on sale.

[h1] DLCS [/h1]

Tiny Tina is back... What can we expect? Nothing normal, that's for sure. Crossing the "Borderlands feeling" with the classical D&D/fantasy settings was a supercool move from the creators. I was really eager for the game, and actually I got what I wanted, although my thoughts are a bit mixed about my experiences.

First of all, we got such a detailed character creation that only a few games can be comparable. I think the main story is just a simple okay category, which is sad, because the first half of it started really well. On the other hand, the side missions were funny and creative, too bad some of them were just simple fetch quests. Probably the best thing I enjoyed was the gameplay, it was a big mess, a crazy chaotic blow-out of my mind, but in a good way. Enemies, so many effects, guns, screams, magics, and quirky humour, of course. I just went forward and played by ears many times. I can also adore the artists' works, the landscapes looked amazing and fit well into the fantasy. The music is disappointing, I can't recall any memorable tracks, but I still can hum some titles from Borderlands 2, Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep, or my personal favourite, Tales from the Borderlands.

My two big problems (and one smaller with the optimization on PC) were that the endgame builds on disgustingly massive looting, and the lack of more and braver creativity. This whole setting is screaming for more secrets, interactivities, special achievements and wild ideas. Hopefully we'll get more in the next episode... Honestly, counting everything, I can't say it's worth the full price, it's fun, but nothing extraordinary, as it should/could be.

The game isn't bad, just very mediocre. For every good thing, there's at least one bad thing. The game is not optimised at all. I could run Borderlands 3 really well at roughly 80 fps on higher end graphics but this game could barely play past 30 fps on MEDIUM. I experienced constant frame dips and was hovering mainly around 19 fps between freezing and dropping to  1 fps. I was playing with a friend who has a far better computer than mine and yet even his PC was experiencing very slide-show like gameplay.

Turns out, it doesn't support DirectX 12 very well and your performance will suffer greatly if you don't 
change it to DirectX 11. Sure, you probably won't be able to run it well anyway but at least you won't suffer constant frame dips.

Every other borderlands game (although this technically isn't a borderlands game) has done something differently than the others.

Borderlands 1 was the foundation, Borderlands 2 improved on it massively with a really well written story, Borderlands the Pre-Sequel added new types of guns, took itself into space with a story that expanded on Borderlands 2 and added oxygen related mechanics, Borderlands 3 improved the gameplay and added a lot of quality of life changes. Tiny Tina Wonderlands adds....nothing. The gameplay is ripped from Borderlands 3 (but worse). The melee weapons don't really add anything, the spells are great but a lot of them are extremely boring and basic. Some spells have you summoning a huge meteor that shatters into smaller meteors, while another spell will have you shoot one ice spike and call it a day. The quality ranges greatly.

The item balancing is......meh. I obtained a spell at the very beginning of the game that has been more powerful than anything else in my 13 hours of gameplay.

The story is entirely inconsequential in every way. There are no stakes. The villain isn't even hateable. Handsome Jack had charisma and personality but was still a huge douchebag and a major villain. Tyreen and Troy are hated by the playerbase for being annoying more than anything else, but at least they're hateable and you want to shoot them. The Dragonlord however isn't dislikeable or hateable in any way shape or form, and he isn't particularly funny or interesting. He's just there.

Overall, it's not bad. It's not great. It's just okay. I hope Borderlands 4 can salvage this series or I'm probably out.

My gaming time is few and far between so when I sit down to play a game I don't want to have to spend 30 min to an hour to get the game to run every time, especially when I only have an hour to play. The best twist on a loved game series ever. If you love D&D you'll love it, if you love Borderlands you'll love it, but most of all just like any other borderlands title you'll love it all the more if you've got friends to run the game with. If i had any sort of complaints, it would be something that I can't quite put my finger on. I feel it every time i start up the title and start playing, it's a fun title but it wears thing fairly quickly...or maybe that's just me. Something about how i feel like I'm always being hailed by a nearly insurmountable level of gunfire...
Despite any shortcomings the game is a blast, and the comedy is next level though this is possibly because of all the amazing comic talent they've managed to get into the game. Wanda Sykes, Andy Samberg, and Will Arnett to name a few. The graphics are not particularly better than Borderlands 3 but, there is a noticeable difference in the game. My favorite so far is the addition of melee weapons, which I hope make it to borderlands 4, if we get one. There are also added little bits that make the experience all the better; a custom character for one, which is always a good addition, and the way voiced characters skirt mentioning your character's name is hilarious at times. Tina's constant interferance as a makeshift Dungeon Master is amazing, and the fact that you are literally playing on a giant game board is just icing on the cake. Regardless of any kind of setbacks, the game isn't a ten but it's pretty damn close.
The D&D vibe this game got is amazing. Hopefully it will pull more people into the TTRPG genre both IRL and on pc. It is truly amazing.

I don't often leave reviews on here, mainly because I forget. However, this game really is just beyond outstanding. It's a masterpiece. From the quick-witted dialogue, to the twists and turns, Gearbox really outdid themselves this time. I've always been a huge fan of Borderlands but after three or so games of generally the same look and feel, this was a great departure from their already successful IP and I am just beyond thrilled with this one. I actually think it's by far my favorite.

One of the big selling points for me is that I get to build my own character and not play one of their pre-made characters. The amount of character customization is outstanding and I get so excited every time a new piece drops!

The story has been compelling through and through, and I'm really excited to see what will happen next!

It would be great to add it back on 4) steam achievements are not creative 5) Didnt like the long press to drop items, instant would be better

Definitely would recommend, would buy again even if full price

The best single player borderlands experience yet....but also gearbox has absolutely lost touch with what makes a borderlands game a great borderlands game. The guns never felt like an upgrade. just use the same gun for 6 or 7 levels until you find something technically stronger even if you don't enjoy using it. All the loot in the world and none of it good. Never had a weapon beyond level 5 i had any attachment too. The overworld slogs down gameplay. While the story seemed a little more a to b, it made playing alone a little more enjoyable. no memorable boss fights. no massive set pieces. i played the game once and i'm good. i enjoyed it. it was a solid one time experience. side quests seemed unimportant and skipped most of them. I never played a part of the game where i felt like "wow this would be so much better with 3 other people"

i enjoyed my time. it was a solid shut my brain off and slog through a campaign in a few nights. it is what i needed it to be. but when i finished it made me want to go speedrun borderlands 2 more than play ttw again. gearbox has really lost the pulse of it's franchise. increasing the map size and decreasing the -everything else enjoyable- has not worked. i really don't remember alot of bl3 and had similar feelings aside from a few set pieces that were best in co op. modern rpg's keep struggling to let you be over powered or under powered. i want to go to a level 5 area when im level 2 and struggle. i want to go back to that level 5 area when im a level 17. having everything leveled the same as you is not fun.stop doing this

Think of this like TPS after Borderlands 2 came out. Same engine, trying new things, named enemies don't offer much, but it gets the general vibe of what people liked about its predecessors. Some very fun mechanics are implemented (i.e. spells instead of grenades and multi-classing), however, it's the level of dedication to the main reason people play this game that is lacking. Relatable characters and an emotional attachment to them, fun times farming for weapons you can actually obtain to make a build out of, end game content to keep you coming back, and of course the OST. Nothing in this game will make you feel the way you did walking into Fyrestone (or even Sanctuary) for the first time. It is a pure entertainment in the short term and it does it well. Do all you can during the first run, mainly because you can change your secondary class later in the game, and enjoy the ride. But as a general rule, that I realized after TPS, don't ever buy the Season Pass for Borderlands games that aren't numbered. Happy shlooting! But keep your expectations reasonable.

[h3]If you don't like Borderlands 3, this game will not change your mind about Borderlands as a whole.[/h3]
If you look at this game as very expansive DLC for Borderlands 3, under the assumption you enjoy Borderlands 3, you'll likely enjoy this game — if you're not sold on the hack n' slash genre but with guns and the camera being first person instead of being isometric, stay very far away form this game.

[h3]So, what's the difference between this and Borderlands 3?[/h3]
• Melee weapons are now loot, they have weapon manufacturers and are no longer tied to specific characters.
• Grenades are replaced by spells and no longer act as a consumable but are rather recharged by a cooldown period.
• There's a lot of customization up front for your hero, voice, appearance, class etc. [u]Unparalleled to other Borderlands' games.[/u]
• Guardian Rank is replaced by Mythic Rank.
• Your character has an actual stat sheet; dexterity, strength, wisdom, all that good stuff. This is in addition to the traditional skill tree that Borderlands characters have.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2893868460
• There's an overworld map that has dungeons, random encounters that can be explored, as opposed to a HUB city. (Which is still present.)
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2893868480

And that's pretty much it. The gun manufacturers, should you have developed a favorite by now, have slightly different names from the mainline Borderlands' games. Jakobs is now Blackpowder and Dahl is now Dahlia for example. All in some vaguely humorous attempt to create a more [i]fantastic[/i] setting.

[b]If this all sounds great, read no further, enjoy the game.[/b]

The entire game is based on the [i]allegedly[/i] popular Borderlands 2 DLC “Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep”. I was never that fond of that DLC: I'm still pondering if that is due to me not liking the  Tiny Tina character, not generally enjoying [i]most[/i] fantasy settings or the fact that they tried to jam an ostensibly sci-fi theme into a fantasy setting, just for sake of it. 

[h3]But here's the thing I keep coming back to...[/h3]
These reviews are for sharing your opinion and whether or not you'd [i]recommend[/i] that someone [i]else[/i] purchase and play a specific title. And for that I would say, if you enjoy Borderlands, buy this on sale. There's really nothing worth full price here. Don't get me wrong, there are some [u]great[/u] ideas in this game that are just poorly executed. If you're on the fence, just skip it.

I do see it as a stepping stone for Borderlands 4 or whatever they call the next mainline Borderlands. More customization is always good, maybe one day they'll make a DLC package that suits everyone's desires but this one leaves a lot to be desired.

I don't usually comment too much on the games I play, but honestly I just have to on this game. I do like my borderland loot&shoot adventures, and I enjoyed BL 1-3. Never really gave much thought about the plots and such as long as there was fun gameplay to be had, but this one I really have to say makes me want to kill myself at times with how long the horribly written script has to be played out. I wouldn't mind it so much if there was a skip button for a lot of the dialogue or the "cutscenes" where you have to wait for NPCs to do whatever, but it feels like half the game is just dragging through terrible script and waiting for unskippable bad slapstick comedy sketches. 

Gameplay and graphics are completely fine, great concept for a loot&shooter game, but dragged down by the writing. Props to the voice actors though, they tried to make the best out of terrible scripts.

ARACHNOPHOBIA WARNING, as far as I can tell there is not mod available to replace the spiders with another enemy model... 
Definitely do not buy if you have a fear of spiders.

Did I really grind all the way to chaos level 100? - Yes.

This game's weakest point is that it clearly believes its writing is hilarious.

I cannot overstate how cringe the writing is. It's so bad that despite the gameplay mechanics being really really fun I would never recommend this to a friend, because I'd be worried that they think that I think the writing is funny.

I honestly don't know if I have words for just how bad it is. As an example, there is a character, who is a unicorn, who is the queen of the land you're playing in, called Princess Buttstallion. If you think that's funny, you might enjoy the story, but honestly if you think that's funny you might enjoy fingerpainting with your own feces.

The actual game is great, its an arena shooter at heart and a looter shooter beyond that. I  actually enjoy playing the game but I literally, physically cringe whenever I finish an area and a character starts talking. Every single piece of dialogue is so bad that its painful. I tried to turn dialogue volume all the way down but I'm yet to find the subtitle setting so had to turn it back on.

Imagine a game where the greatest deterrent is the fully voice acted dialogue. It blows my mind, I can't believe Will Arnett looked at this script and said "sure, that's worth my time".

On top of that its insultingly expensive. I got it on special for 50% and still wouldn't recommend it at that price. 

There are at least 10 other games that do the same thing if not better, then just as well, for a 10th of the price and with far better writing.

I'm going to continue playing this game, but never in a million years would I tell anyone that I cared about that they should buy it. They could probably have saved a million dollars dropping the writers and the voice acting and the game would have been twice as good.

Again. Just so it's clear. The writing is so bad that I constantly consider giving up on this game (past the point of refunding now) whenever a cutscene plays. 

I can't believe someone got paid to write a single line of dialogue for this.

I came into this half expecting something with a new setting and story and didn't watch any reviews or gameplay videos(my mistake) and what I got was borderlands in a fantasy setting that wasn't very inspiring. They had a good opportunity to make something and different at least on some levels but instead they just took borderlands and implemented it with some new classes in a fantasy world full of guns. it feels like it might as well just have been any other borderlands game at this point. Here are some of the sort comings I was left with.

Gameplay:
I played as a Spellshot which was suppose to be a spellcaster that uses guns, instead I throw out a few spells and then its all gun gameplay, that part can be fine but depends heavily on how good your weapons are, it can easily switch between being boring and annoying to fun to being to easy all depending on how good your weapon is at different times. and sometimes you just get trash. For the Spellshot class you get one ability and one spell, but you can instead choose to sac the ability for a 2nd spell which is overall much better. About halfway through the game you can add a second class which felt a bit strange because it seems better to finish off the skills in your own class before going into the new class. You do however gain access to 2nd classes skillls, great right? Not really because thats shared between your primary class so instead of getting additional options you end up just using the one with 2 spells from Spellshot. what a waste. All game you are using 2 spell keys and then just shooting.

Story:
Story is often very over the top and imo ruined by Tiny Tina speaking over whats happened so no chance to get engaged in it. And again its Borderlands all over right down to the bad guy "calling" you to monologue because he is basically the only bad guy in the game that has a voice. I did find some of the side missions pretty funny and engaging.

Looting:
Its a looting shooter and that part is really awful. Between the limited inventory you have to upgrade for a few extra slots, to the awful inventory UI you have to go through to discard, drop or sell, to the crazy amount of loot you have to decide if you want on the ground. It also feels like half the guns are basically just crossbows which are godawful since bolts dropoff quickly, or sawblades(even worse), so thats half the guns out. The RNG loot is awful too, the worst part was at the end of the game where the NPC all seriously tells me you need some armor befitting of your status Knight and then gives me a legendary armor for another class, its one thing what drops is random(thats awful too) but why is my quest rewards random too. 

Conclusion:
Its just another borderlands game from the borderlands factory, no soul, nothing new, just the same crap again. If you like Borderlands you will probably like this, if you come here for something else or new, find something else instead friend.

TL;DR: Get the game if you like Borderlands and when it's on discount. Post-story/endgame/DLC content is bad

If you like any of the Borderlands games, liked BL2's Tiny Tina DLC, and or a fan of DnD who wants to play a game with friends then you might like this game.

Despite its name it is very much still a Borderlands game at its core, but it has enough to differentiate itself from its predecessors; namely an overworld in lieu of vehicles, multi-classing, and spells instead of grenades. All of that plus more has me considering Wonderlands an improvement over Borderlands 3, so much so that it might be my second favourite game in the franchise, just behind Borderlands 2. Compared to 3 it has a better story (though that is a low bar and this game's story isn't amazing either, just ok) and the gameplay loop is a lot more fun, in my opinion.

The game has some glaring flaws though. Post launch content, DLC, and endgame content are abysmal, probably the worst out of every Borderlands game. There are no DLC campaigns, no second playthrough, and no level cap increase, and these missing features/content severely reduce the amount of content the game has to offer when compared to previous series entries. It has a pretty robust character creator giving you more customisation options than previous games, but it also lacks weapon skins, trinkets, and the full colour wheel that Borderlands 3 introduced to the series.

Overall this is the type of game I expect most to play through once and not touch again, which is completely fine, but if you are really into Borderlands and just want to play more of that kind of game then this can scratch that itch. Either way, definitely get it on sale as it isn't worth paying full price for. The DLCs are very lackluster so if you aren't a completionist then you can skip them completely, though the 4th DLC adds a 7th class so that's something you can consider.

Edit: Forgot to mention that the soundtrack and sound design are a significant step down from Borderlands 3.

Endgame and DLCs on the other hand are very bad and lacking content and replayability, they pretty much non-existent.
Other than the extremely repetitive and poorly balanced chaos chambers/levels and the headhunter-like very short DLCs... sorry, PLCs* that cost almost as much as the full-fledged story DLCs for BL3 there's nothing else. There is not even a TVHM, or rather TFMM (True Fate Maker Mode) aka NG+ that would allow you to replay through the story at max level.
The game becomes pretty stale very quickly due to the lack of content, especially endgame, and the poor replayability. At this point I wouldn't mind a 2nd Season Pass, but with proper story expansion DLCs like we saw for the previous BL titles which is unlikely to happen.
The game itself is not bad and I really want to love it and to be able to recommend but I really can't do it in good conscience in its current state.

I loved the original Tiny Tina DLC for Borderland 2.  I'm happy this game was made but I feel it lacks in a few areas.   I like the theme and most of the mechanics (Especially how spells and melee weapons work) However I'd be happier if Mythic Ranks helped characters pre 40 or some other persistent account thing (like the old badass rank).  Story wise I enjoyed the game but it lacks the depth of the original story had.  Lastly there seems be to be a fair number of bugs and QOL issues that none of the other Borderlands games had by this time in develpment.  Overall I do like the game but compared to the original DLC I feel this should be better.  Borderlands Fans who were not big into the original DLC or never played it may want to do some research before buying.   Fans of the original Tina DLC for BL2 or borderlands fans who like the idea of a fantasy setting are more likely to find something here but I don't think anyone is going to be blown away by this game. For reference, i have also bought this on the Epic games store and completed it (just in case my hours in game dont match with what im saying )

The story is interesting and has its moments, set as a game of their version of Dungeons and Dragons its not tied down trying to fit in with any plots from any other titles too much. 

The gameplay is fun with various classes each having their own strengths/ weakness.

Each  class gets a passive ability, for some its a companion monster to fight along side you, others its  a passive effect. 

Whats cool is that they allow you to duel class, you cant change your 1st class at all, you can only change your 2nd class after you have completed the story so choose wisely. That said its up to you if you want to min/max effectiveness or just go with whatever is cool.

The customisation options are great, you can pick from a large variety of options to create your perfect Fatemaker, you can customise things like  your own banner and statues that appear in the town as well. 

Furthermore you can get more customisation options as drops in the world so you may find a new hair style, or armour layer/colour that you enjoy after you have made the character. The new ones you collect stay unlocked so even if you choose to start a new character you will have more option later on. 

This being borderlands - esc game ( and as of this review nominated for "Better with friends" award") it would be a nice amount of fun chaos with spells and explosions all over....i assume im an anti social solo player so i can't comment too much :P

The endgame is matter of perspective and what you enjoy from the game. Be it story or challenge its time to Grind the Chaos Chambers, they offer a challenge where you can grind several levels, if you found the game to easy then these will offer the chance to buff enemies and/or Nerf you somewhat, you get more points that you can then spend on chances to get loot of a specific item. 

But personally  i found that once i reached that point i put the game down for a bit. Im mainly in it for the story, i have other games that i will put my grind hours into :) 

Came back to it new classes, new personality and its fun to sink some time into

As a side note i will only mention the DLC's briefly as they can get their own reviews. 

They are...optional....is how i would describe them, they are essentially 4 more side quests that have a vague story behind them.  They come with another class and voice option which is nice, but best to see if you can get them on a deal if possible as there isn't much meat to them. I would guess their main purpose is to add to the pool of levels and challenges for the Chaos chambers. 

Overall i would say give the game a go, if you enjoy borderlands you will enjoy this.

This is my take on Tiny Tina.  Some of my negatives you might take as positives but in the end, I wouldn't recommend it.  I played this game a bit, 57 hours, and I did not 100% it.  But I do not want to at all.  After the story the game gets very grindy in a very small game play loop.

I will try to be brief...

Pros:
- Its more borderlands
- New loot is neat and a refreshing change to the borderlands formula (Spells instead of grenades, crossbow weapons)
- The Story is cool to follow, I did really like the main villain
- I did like the over world map, for better or worse it cut out a lot of the filler in previous borderlands that made you use their terrible driving system to just plow through areas and pad game time
- I liked some of the unique areas you would travel to, they each felt unique
- Side quests were kind of amusing at times, and not all of them felt grindy

Cons:
- I am in the minority here, but it was too much Tina.  I like her as a support role, but she got obnoxious here.  Not to mention trying to fist in some emotional dialogue with Tina
- The two new support characters I found boring.  They were just commentators really.  The Robots voice was annoying to me and the other character was a text book "stupid knight"
- The actual map (M Key map) is the same terrible to use map from all the previous borderlands.  Can you make a functional map please??  You can never lock the orientation of the map (similar to previous titles) and it is VERY slow to scroll on a PC.  I have a mouse, that should make navigating this easier!  This is definitely a console port side effect
- Since the loot is RNG and you could very well roll loot that does not benefit skills of your class, 99% of your drops will be useless to you.  Since loot can roll buffs to multiple classes (since you can dual class) your chances of getting loot with buffs that you want, well, you will need to dump HUNDREDS of hours into getting that one drop.
- Speaking of loot, its not clear at all what loot you get is the best.  Its hard to see the difference between higher tier loot because it just has a glowing skull on the top and its a bit brighter of a border.  And my regular gold weapon is better than the super skull one I got.
- Your Appearance is determine by the "Armor mod" you are wearing.  Similar to a class mod.  You can change the texture and color of your gear, but it will always look the same.  I would argue there are more customization options but they are all really small.  Sure, "Red" and "Rose" colored are two options, but there is not much difference between them.
- End game is non-existent.  Through the game you dive into small dungeon instances which are basically defeat the wave of enemies three times, maybe two.  It was OK as a side thing, but that is actually end game.  When you finish the story you can just grind out waves of enemies in the same small maps for rare chances to get better loot just so you can keep playing the same exact small dungeon.
- There are four "DLC" dungeons.  But after you do each once, you really don't want to go back.  All the effort is not near worth the payout of random junk you are just going to not even pickup eventually
- The "Dual Class System" sounds good on paper, but you only get two skill tree's.  Compared to previous titles Three Skill Tree's this is a huge downgrade.  And you don't get enough points to make both viable, so you will really only focus on one tree.  The only "advantage" is you get to flip between two classes action skills.  But you wont want to, as your entire tree will only really compliment one skill.
- To me, most of the classes felt weak and under powered.  Most of them felt like they might have end game viability but that doesn't help early game.
- Classes felt VERY linear.  With only one skill tree (two when you dual class), you basically just went with a damage type (like frost) and buffed it.  Not a lot of flexibility in play style.

The cons out weight the pros.  It might be worth it on deep sale to play the story and get a bit more borderlands, but the story is much shorter than previous titles and end game will not keep you busy for long.

Game is just as fun as BL3 and personally I find the spell way better and more fun and useful than grenades. Mixing and matching different classes sound interesting, but overall it felt a little underdeveloped.
Personally I didn't really like having a costumizable character (in general not a fan of this), they usually feel really bland and forgetable, even though the voice I chose had really fun lines and really liked him, but them not having a "name and face" is not my cup of tea.
My biggest issue with this game is similar to the other BL spin off (The Pre-Sequel) that for a full priced game (even with 20% off @ 64€ for the version with season pass) the game is way too short. (about 25h for the main story with more stuff to play afterwards) In comparision I paid about 50€ or 60€ for the same version of BL3 on its Steam launch and I got about 80h for the story and way more with the DLCs and other content (currently at 166h and still can play more, if I had the time). Additionally I was missing a lot of the characters from other games.

If you are a fan of the Borderlands series, you can't go wrong with this at any price, in my opinion. However, if you are looking into getting into the series, definitely go the other entries in the series and wait for this game to get cheaper.

This is probably my favourite Borderlands series (I know, this is technically not Borderlands), even though it lacks a lot of things that makes Borderlands game a Borderlands game. There are a lot of new features; spells, melee weapons, creating your own character, etc., and I enjoy every single one of them. I feel like a lot of the new features makes the side content more worth doing, unlike in Borderlands 3, where the side content is boring and feels tedious to do. 

I don't know how's the end game content compared to the previous Borderlands series (I haven't finished Tiny Tina's Wonderlands at the time I wrote this review), but I definitely had more fun on my first playthrough in Tiny Tina's Wonderlands compared to the previous Borderlands series (so far).

My favourite things about Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is its world design, it's beautifully made, and some places reminds me a lot of Trine series, which I really love. It also seems to be well optimized on most places (except Brighthoof), and in my experience, runs a lot smoother than Borderlands 3.

A great game overall, especially for less hardcore players. If you're somebody who enjoys spending hours farming for perfect gear to finish that OP10 run, this game probably isn't for you. The main campaign is great fun though. Tons of nods to D&D, and the lucky dice system is perfect. Collectibles are usually just busy work, but the loot luck system makes these worth searching for from the start. The story is fun, and the ending is satisfying. The voice acting is great. Combat always balances well, and loot and enemy scaling seems to favor more casual players once you hit the level cap. So it's less suited to the hardcore, but great for people without 1000 hours to dump into a game.

The endgame loop isn't fantastic, mostly because the random mission generator feels like most random mission generators- a bit random. Pick an arena, pick some enemies, pick a boss, rinse and repeat. To their credit, the chaos chamber always balances well, which is tricky to do consistently. But to me the lack of story or progression makes it feel flat. Plus every map is an arena, so while they're all visual distinct, they all play exactly the same. The DLCs feel like a more polished version with some additional story to tie it all together, plus the boss progression that I haven't tried yet. They're worth grabbing on sale IMO, though I don't regret buying the whole thing at launch.

Overall, it's a great game for normal people, if not for the borderlands hardcore crowd.

Having poured in hundreds of hours into all of the borderlands games (on console and pc) I absolutely love the additions made to the game with the character customization, classes, spells, weapons, and more. It makes for some incredibly fun and refreshed game play. The story is funny and captivating with the world and graphics looking renewed and lively without requiring top of the line specs. It also gives incentive to actually explore off the main path in search of areas for loot dice and lore scrolls that are sort of like echo logs but actually interesting.  
The best part by far is the addition of spells, changeable melee weapons, and guns which are completely different from the other borderlands games. The elemental type effects that your weapons sometimes have can have amazing synergies with spells and abilities if you pair them right against your foes which allows you to shred through enemies and have a blast.
If you're a fan of borderlands I would definitely recommend you to pick this game up and play it. Even if you aren't a fan of borderlands I would still at least give it a try if you're looking for a new game to play.

This might be the worst borderlands experience ever. 

The game features an overworld-area that works as a linkage between the different playable areas. I have no fucking clue why the areas are not just linked to each other like in previous games but I guess they somehow had to find a way to remove joy from the gameplay experience.

There also is a thing called "encounters" when you travel around in the overworld. These can appear randomly or as part of a quest or as an obstacle to get somewhere. In these encounters you are just placed in a small arena like map where you have to fight off a bunch of enemies. The problem here is that there are only ever 4-5 enemies alive at the same. New enemies only spawn once you kill another enemy. You don't get too much exciting combat action out of them. Oh, and sometimes you have to do SEVEN of these boring encounters in a row. Unfortunately, it is as tedious as it sounds.

The story is horrible. To be honest, the Borderlands franchise is famous for having weak stories and humor that is written by and for 13 year olds, but this game takes that stuff to the next level.

If you ignore all the bad stuff, you might get a mediocre gameplay experience out of this. The guns have many new effects and are different to the ones from BL3, however, most of these new effects just feel terrible to play with so you'll avoid most weapon types in your playthrough anyway. An excellent spin-off to the Borderlands series. Story is genuinely much better than Borderlands 3. More of the jokes and attempts at humor hit their mark, and the references to other fantasy series and TTRPG's are hilarious. Tiny Tina is as eccentric and hilarious as usual. The handful of new characters that are introduced are far more likable than, uhh, certain new characters in BL3 were. Gunplay is still tight and responsive, the classes are varied and unique, locations are diverse and interesting, enemy type and variety is nice (and also predictably absurd.)

The inventory system has been thoroughly fantasy-fied, and is a lot better for it in my opinion. 'Wards' are the equivalent to shields in the BL games, class mods are now called 'armor', and both of these function basically the same as their BL counterparts. Grenades have been replaced by spells, which provide many different effects such as high aoe damage, crowd control, aoe buff/debuff fields, etc, and are far more useful than grenades ever were in BL games, outside of maybe the original. The primary differences in the inventory system however come from the addition of 3 new equipment slots, 1 for an amulet and 2 for rings. These act as a bit of a hybrid between class mods or armor, and the artifacts from BL3 and include many different effects, from gun/spell/skill damage, elemental damages, loot luck, boosts to certain weapon types, melee damage, and a lot more. Having more items that add random modifiers to your character really helps when it comes to min/maxing and loot grinding, which is  still the core gameplay loop in Wonderlands.

The 4 main elemental damage types from BL2/3 are still here; Incendiary, Cryo, Shock, and Poison (corrosive). The 5th elemental damage type this time around is called 'Dark Magic' which heals your character for a percentage of the damage dealt. This synergizes well with certain action skills and health stacking characters, and can be boosted a lot by class skill trees and items. In my opinion this status effect is better than both slag from BL2 and radiation from BL3 by a decently high margin, and hopefully something with a similar effect will be added to future mainline BL titles.

As far as negatives go, the story is significantly shorter than BL2/3's story, and the endgame chaos mode can get repetitive pretty quickly. This wasn't an issue for me specifically, and it likely won't be for anyone who is used to or enjoys grinding and maximizing their build potential, but for more casual players there isn't really much to tether them to the game once the story and side quests are finished (roughly 25 hours). 

The primary downside to Wonderlands however, is the absolutely awful excuses for "DLC". Each of the 3 currently released DLC's include a repeatable dungeon with 5 new areas + 1 new boss and... not much else. These new areas and bosses get added to the chaos mode pool after beating them once, which adds a bit of variety to that mode but not enough to make it worth the asking price. The 4th DLC is coming with a new class, and might be a better value than the first 3, but as of this review it is not out yet. At $10 a pop, or $30 for all 4 with the season pass, this is decided NOT worth it, and I doubt the inclusion of a new class will change that at all. Once again, this issue wasn't as big for me because I purchased the chaotic great edition for 20% off ($64) when it launched on steam, so I effectively only paid $4 more than retail for the DLC, but the season pass/DLC outside of maybe the 4th one is a HARD pass at retail price.

Overall review score: 8/10

I want to give this a fair and honest review. Would I recommend it to someone who wants a Borderlands experience? No, I wouldn't. I'd recommend this to someone who wants to run an actual Bunkers and Badasses experience without the hassle of determining who will GM and who'll pick what classes. It feels like DLC from 3, and the classes are limited to one skill tree and one playstyle. While the concept was good, the execution is what's at fault. If they made it like the older games, with one ability and three skill trees to differ playstyles and augment that ability, the game would be better. Tack the issues that the melee is finicky and the gunplay is meh at best, and the buffering that they did with "Dungeon Encounters" to help pad out the time, it really just feels half finished and haphazardly put together. I do suggest picking this up, so long as it is reasonably discounted by 50-75%, and picking it up if you have friends who would play with you.

I waited to buy this game on sale because I was so disappointing in boarderlands 3.  Granted I did enjoy 1 playthrough of BL3.  This game is definitely boarderlands, but because it is magical, you can tell imagination was less limited with this game.  

Let me start with the World.  The world and landscape is very creative and magical, which really pulls you in.  Using creative stories with a touch of a fantasy story undertones.  It really is a trip haha. Mushrooms anyone?

There are more classes and since its dnd themed, it really brings that classic mid-evil touch with a modern finish.  There is also multi classes so that really adds diversity to play styles. Spells were also added along with your action skill so it also adds an extra spectrum of damage and elemental balancing to the game. Which means, more buttons to press.

I'm not finished the game so I can't say anything about the end game, but 40 hours in and I'm impressed so far.

Considering the cringe worthy mess that was BL3's writing, Tiny Tina's Wonderlands is Tolstoy in comparison. It's a return to form in that regard, with characters that are somewhat likeable, and dialogue that's occasionally funny. 

The gameplay is par for the course for the series; it's more of the same, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. Although there's less variety in weaponry, the class system has been expanded upon, and abilities play a larger role in gameplay. Character customisation is also a welcome addition, with a modest variety of options.

My major criticism of the game is the endgame content, which is mainly just a rogue-lite mode where you clear procedurally generated encounters and replay campaign boss fights with modifiers active. I found that it got repetitive quickly, and there was little incentive to continue after a few runs. The game could use some well-crafted dungeons/raids.

Additionally. the campaign is far too easy on the highest difficulty, especially if you min-max efficiently. I would have liked it if encounters presented more of a challenge, and required me to evaluate my tactics. I rarely had to consider my elemental damage and resistances, and would have preferred if they played a bigger role.

Overall this is a solid buy for fans of looter shooters and I enjoyed my time with it.

In short: It's a game. A fun one, but not one I'm doing backflips over.

In long: Borderlands is the titular series were the phrase "looter shooter" takes you when it's used. The concept is fairly uncomplicated: You run around in first-person shooting anything that moves against you, and most enemies are pinatas of prizes waiting to be cracked open. Get better weapons/gear by cracking open said pinatas; rinse, and repeat.

If that is your ish, then Tiny Tina's will not disappoint. Even in the fantasy setting, with options for melee, magic, and companions, guns will be your primary weapon and you'll be finding yourself bouncing around arena-like areas killing baddies and sucking up their loot. Boss fights are literally just a big baddie with an even bigger health pool that you have to shoot for longer while dodging or hiding behind cover.

If you're someone with even a passing knowledge of Tabletop RPGs, TTW may also entertain you as well. It's an overall homage to the classic past time with barely a fourth wall to get between you and what's happening in the game. You play a nameless player who is stuck in a cave with Tiny Tina, a robot named Frette (played by Wanda Sykes), and some mercenary named Valentine. The how and why doesn't really matter; all that matters is you've got all the time in the world to play Bunkers & Badasses, the Borderlands equivalent to D&D. TT is a prime dungeon mistress--and all the miniatures and other stuff are hers anyway--so you dive into an adventure of her making.

Her occasional narration at key points is what keeps you grounded in the fact that you're playing a game within a game. It's key to the progression, especially since sometimes she has to change the narrative to allow you to advance--a thing DMs are all too familiar with. Overall, her voice is a welcome part of indicating progression and the start of a new round of foes.

You have classes to choose from, but I honestly haven't played with any other than the Spore Warden so far. I do think, however, with the emphasis on guns, that all classes will prettymuch end up feeling pretty samey over time. I chose Spore Warden because it felt like I was going to lean the most towards a ranger type with it, and other than some magical bow shot I get to do on occasion, I definitely do not feel like anything other then the usual shooter type from the Borderlands series.

Am I wowed by this game? Not really. To be fair, though, I enjoy story and exploration a lot more, and while the game-within-a-game is providing some chuckles, I am not as invested in the story of TTW as I was in other games. There is also a clear linearity to it. Yes, there are "open world" areas and arenas but they are limited in space and scope, and once you do find the few secrets hidden, there isn't going to be much reason to keep looking around. The game means for you to shoot your way from Point A to Point B as quickly as possible.

Overall I'd say it's a good game for mindless play. If you just want something to play with your friends, you can't go wrong here. The fights are fast-paced, the banter is amusing, and the levels are pretty quick. If your idea of RPG is something more nuanced, however, you might want to save your money.

game was for all purposes of the word, mid, a solid 5/10 I suppose

- red texts didn't feel unique. 
- nothing seemed to have any semblance of health aside from a couple sidequest bosses.
- spells are cool but so limited and just feel like an extra point for activations rather than an extra damaging part of your arsenal.
- skill trees are okay I suppose, but nothing that drastically changes your game (both positive and negative).
- Loot Luck (negative), joking aside I wish they'd done it right, having a higher world drop chance would've been great, but making all drops rely on it including dedicated just felt iffy to me, and took away from wanting to farm as opposed to just running the game as fast as possible
- chaos chambers are just every other random encounter with maybe a different modifier or objective, not fun in the slightest
- stats feel pointless outside of crit chance and crit damage, speaking of I don't like the idea of no crit spots and having it rely on a % as it let me hit something stupid like 80% crits, all the time, power boosted past the usual 2x.

as for the good of the game
- gods is it gorgeous, a lot of scenery just made me stop and stare and appreciate how much effort has gone into it over the usual strict cell shading
- most of the melee weapons have a really satisfying swing to them and the generous swing hitbox only accentuates that, it made slamming enemies with a massive axe/sword/hammer/bonkstick just hit different. 
- character customisation is top notch, allowing for a slider override to be a giant or just a lil guy was admittedly funny, but also allowed for a better character I felt suited me.
- The story is great, more focused on tinas inner mechanisms than an actual openboard story, but great nonetheless, definitely giving a great insight into a character already beloved by the community.

while I wouldn't recommend picking it up outside of a sale, or buying any of the dlc, it's defo worth at least a little bit of your time.

anyways, back to borderlands 2! c:

p.s to those who got this far, grab yourself a triple hydra feridore, you'll shred the game with no remorse c:

Don't normally do reviews but for this game I will. I absolutely love the Borderlands franchise, I've so many hours into every game spread across various consoles it's ridiculous and I must say this is my second favourite. My absolute favourite is Borderlands 1 because to me it's a classic and I wouldn't love the franchise if it wasn't for that one. For TTWL, I love the Dialogue, Soundtrack, Combat and the cool people I've met through matchmaking along the way. The classes are very fun to mix and play with, you can even do your own thing without looking up builds and have fun your own way while not falling too far behind other players using dedicated builds. Some of the guns are crazy fun, I love the Hydra and Pixie spawning weapons personally. The main story is rather short and there are not as many side quests as there have been in previous games but I feel like that is okay, sometimes too many side quests can be overwhelming to people. I recommend the game for sure but as much as I love it, I wouldn't recommend getting it at full price. I purchased the Chaotic Edition during the current 40% off for still less then the Base game itself and was very pleased with everything for the amount I spent. Thanks for reading this review, have a nice day, and if you have/get the game have fun!

Not a remarkable game in any way. Just a regular ole post BL2 Borderlands game. The random encounters do the game a disservice. It just feels derivative and inconsequential. Random encounter after random encounter for every side-quest and shrine piece gets pretty old pretty fast.

The humour is very tired. Mostly out-of-touch or forced jokes that only beget an eye roll. The overwhelming majority of the humour is just Tina's "growly" voice. Over, and over, and over. 

The gunplay sucks, just like every Borderlands game. But this game somehow feels worse since there are only two or three unique weapons in the entire game. Everything else is randomly generated. Even quest items and boss weapons.

The DLC is just so boring. Vesper is hot, but that's about the only good thing. It's a few tedious little rooms that have arbitrary wait-timers to progress. All to earn a DLC currency to roll for some gear. Nothing really fun or interesting. You have to complete each mirror 5 times to "beat" it. Really lazy way to "extend" the play time. Oh, and if you play any of the DLC, it will bug your subtitles and you'll have the last thing Vesper says on your screen until you restart the game.

The game has a lot of fun references. I guess that's about it.

The collectable hunt is really not fun, and really pointless. 

The voice acting in this game is really terrible. It's amazing how awful it is.

The "RPG" elements are simply thematic. They have no impact on gameplay. It's literally just a regular Borderlands game, but without all of the fun Borderlands stuff.

The music is uninspired. 

Earning cosmetics is a slog. They drop randomly from random enemies, and you'll almost certainly get the same one a hundred times.

If you really like Borderlands, I would recommend buying this game at like 50% off, at the minimum. Definitely skip the DLC. You're not missing anything.
