I'm still mad that this game isn't actually a looter slasher in medieval fantasy. It's really just Borderlands with a new skin slapped on.

However I quickly forgave them this wasted opportunity by the way this whole situation is framed within the game. Tiny Tina is your BnB (Bunkers and Badasses) master and she puts you into a Disney-esque fantasy world at first. However her imagination is both limited to her post-apocalyptic existence as well to being a child. It's not long before she hands out the first gun and everyone in the party goes "what...?". You know she's a child when the bartender in town tells you that they sell only soda, and the only food they ever eat is sweets.

The DnD aspect is integrated masterfully. Often you're walking around going about your business, then Tina mentions something like "sky darkens and your hear loud explosions". Those things then really happen in the game world, sometimes completely changing the map in real time.

You can customize your appearance at the start and in contrast to the previous games, you don't play a predefined character.  There are 7 classes to choose from, each of which has 2 active abilities to choose from and a bunch of passives. So far I wasn't very impressed with the skill tree. Disappointingly, you can't use a melee weapon as your main weapon (i.e. left click) - melee hits are still done by pressing V. Instead of grenades, here you equip spells that can be either projectile based, throw a meteor on someone's head, AoE damage or protection auras, and whatnot.

From what I can tell, as always this game does not really give you the option to go full melee or full spell based, you'll always have to use the shooty shooties. Yes I'm actually still salty about it. But going in with the expectation that this is a traditional Borderlands game, it's definitely among the best in the series in terms of presentation and style.

I'll keep it brief, I rarely do reviews. With so many paid shills and corporations dominating review sites like metacritic, rottentomatoes, imdb, etc, it's hard to get a gauge on quality entertainment. That said, Steam is still a pretty good proxy as to whether a game will be good or not from user reviews. In this case, Steam gets it wrong...VERY wrong.

I've played all of the Borderlands games and several mods on top. This is in my top 2 of all the Borderlands games. The combat is engaging and different (spells instead of grenades). The SETTING is a huge plus to this game as the environments are different vs the typical HUGE open spaces in the Borderlands series which are clumsily navigated with vehicles.

Overall I give this a solid 8.5/10. I played about 10 hours of endgame which indeed does devolve into a few boss runs and chaos chambers but that's generally no that different from original Borderlands.

I think this got a "mostly positive' due to a lot of the pedantic fanatics who can't objectively review a game. Definitely play this one.

Tiny Tina's Wonderland has a lot to offer and is in keeping in many ways to the Borderlands series. However the game still manages to fall short in many ways. The core game is really enjoyable and will have you engaged for many hours, the humour is on point for what you should expect from the franchise as a whole. The major pit falls with Tiny Tina's Wonderlands are the DLCs and the story as a whole. The DLCs are short, and I mean very short. They have attempted to pad the play time out with increasing difficulty options but if like me you turn to DLCs after the main gain then you will fly through these and they become annoying to have to do them each four times over. The story also seems lacking and at times like they padded it out to make the game a bit longer, very similar feeling to that of the DLCs.

However, if you take in to consideration that this game is the successor of a small DLC from an earlier game then everything begins to make much more sense, and in turn feel less disappointing. I feel that it is unfair to hold Tiny Tina's Wonderlands up against the main series games as it simply cannot compete. However, as a successor to the Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep it has done an amazing job with one exception, the price.

If you buy this game on sale, I am talking 50% or more off, then I would say it is a great game for the money. Otherwise give it a miss.

Of all the negative reviews out there. I am more towards positive of this one. Yes it does not continue the original Borderlands story nor have the original characters, besides Tina and Brick. It keeps the little haha's and funnies and quite decent gameplay along with it's own RPG-based story, which can be a hit or miss if you like that stuff. I found it nice. I grabbed the Chaotic Edition on sale and can say it's very much worth it. Nice extra content with the chaotic edition. Okay replayability, although I hear the end game chaos runs can be dog water (I've yet to see that for myself) I started off on Intense difficulty and for at few times it was difficult, the rest was a damn breeze. Really needs more challenge to make it less boring. Again with the Chaos difficulties I'm not sure how much harder it would get end game. I would say If you didn't grab Borderlands 3 but were considering this one. I recommend grab it on sale and it ought to keep you in the loop until the next Borderlands comes out!

Okay, Anyone saying this game is bad, Is smoking gas station weed. This game Embodies everything the Borderlands Franchise stands for. If you love Borderlands as a whole, This game is a must cop. Geniunely enjoying every second of this game. Deffintly better than borderlands 3 in my opinion, Better than Borderlands 2 However, nothing will top BL2, Its still the best game in the Franchise. Fuck all the bad reviews, If you enjoy Borderlands, get this game, you wont be disapointed.

PROS:
* FUN GUNS(its crazy what the game brings in terms of gun aspects, feels very balanced, even the purple loot is super viable. Different elements on guns such as; Life steal, Slow((Ice)) Explosion, Fire, Corrosive etc... 
*MAGIC!!!! (There are no gernades in this game, Instead of Gernades in the Borderlands Franchise, The gernades are swapped for Magic, WHICH IS FUCKING SICK The vast variety of the types of magic is insane, They got big ass meteors, Cyclones, Magic circles etc... Think of Skyrim spells, introduced to Borderlands. Its really fucking sick, espeecially with the different elements, types of magic, elemental stats etc... Its so vast and very fun, You will enjoy this aspect of the game a ton?
*STORY( The story is so entertaining, Will keep you laughing, The plot is so witty and Ridiculous, keeps you entertained thouroughly, This is TINAS WORLD, Where the bullshit, funny encounters, EXPLOSIONSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS and fun never ends
*SCENERY( Okay geniunely, the maps are really cool, much more diverse than any post apocalyptic borderlands scene you will get from your average borderlands game, This really spices it up!
*MOBS (This right here was what i was afraid of, as I was watching people say that the game had only 1 main mob type, everyone saying SKELETONS SKELETONS SKELETONS YOU WILL ONLY SEE THESE MOBS ON REPEAT. I wanna say fuck the youtbers saying this, thats bullshit they have shroom characters, liches, banshees, crabs etc.. lots of variety
*OVERWORLD (Really unique, to the Borderlandws Franchise, Very appealing, its basically DND but the overall feel is great to this new addition, Great side quests, Unlockables (Worth getting and grinding the Dopamine receptors that shoot through your brain when unlocking these are great)



CONS:
*THOUGHTS ABOUT ENDGAME Okay honestly I do believe the game can have a more adaptive endgame, maybe a better chaotic system, Just something to make this game more longer because i truly love this game, Maybe just more content
*MEELEE (TBH IN MY OPINION RESPECTFULLY, I dont really like meelee of any form in looters and shooters, its not terrible, but the aspect of it just really doesnt do it for me, there are certain classes that can benefit from it, But when your dealing with a hoard of enemies, the meelee swings and certain swing speeds of the meelee weapons can get you kiled very quickly. Not terrible but IMO just not a fan of it, and I find myself not using the meelee aspect of it so much.

[b]Attention: This review is based on 2 player co-op experience, not 1 player nor 4 player experience.[/b]

So, you want to read a review of Borderlands game huh? Coming right up like pizza in a restaurant you’ve eaten quite many times. This time a Borderlands entry was only three months EGS exclusive and Randy has apparently been too focused on upcoming Borderlands movie-adaptation that there wasn’t such a PR-clusterfucks like we witnessed with Borderlands 3 so great improvement on that area!
It’s hard to come up big improvements over Borderlands 3. There’s still weapons with weakest recoil ever, making gunplay feel still quite boring. Mayhem mode is gone, replaced with random generated small roguelite expeditions. I’m a fan of said sub-genre but I still preferred Mayhem mode over these expeditions. And even when writing team had more freedom with this title due to DnD-session nature, I feel I laughed more on my seven hours Borderlands 2: Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep DLC than 18 hours with this game. As for change of spaceship to overworld traveling I’m not sure. While overworld is something new to quite stagnated Borderlands-franchise at this points, there’s no more vehicles to drive with, making moving with foot only option to move in this game.
As for rest changes/ additions with sub-glasses, re-roll of gun/ equipment bonuses, hand grenades replaced with spells my opinion of those is most simply phrased “eh” with no huge benefit felt during my playthrough over previous entries.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
Tiny Tina Wonderlands is small bits of new to Borderlands-franchise, which those whom are fine with franchise’s gameplay have a good time with. As for those who wished that after Borderlands 3 Gearbox would have taken lessons back from Borderlands 2 writing/ tone will likely still feel disappointed as with third installment of main Borderlands franchise.

Wonderlands is the product of Gearbox’s polarising design decisions, combining the best strengths of the series, yet suffering from serious issues that negatively impact gameplay. And in the wake of the latest update for this game, I’m redoing this review to be more negative. 3.5/10

In its defence, Wonderlands has the most beautiful maps and open world yet, with the most extensive diversity of playstyles and character customisation in the series so far. Enemy diversity is good, and the implementation of the new game mechanics is generally positive eg; cryo on bone, melee weapons, three pseudo-reli-artefact slots, dark magic healing and timed spells replacing grenades. The clarity in combat is good, unlike its predecessor's damage numbers and combined combat effects no longer obscure targets. Arenas, overworld elements and combat encounters are good, they reflect the world well and fit the fantasy theme. Sound design, music and voiced dialogue are good, a compliment I may not have given to BL3. The narrative is superior to Borderlands 3, its side quests are cute and display its tone and characters well, as a quality RPG should. 

This does not come without its drawbacks, however.  

[b]The grinding to Chaos 100 is immense, longer than entire playthroughs of the base game[/b], is repetitive and boring, lacking the gear reward and meaningful challenge for which the series is known, and the reward is a menial meaningless bump in the game's pathetic drop rate. In addition, since higher levels of chaos do not guarantee Chaotic/Volitile/Primordial/Ascended rolls on gear, meaning that farming high-quality gear is best left to going back into Chaos Chamber for more torture. No pearls, no Chaos exclusive weapons, no raid boss. What is the point in pretending that there is an endgame when the only activity there is the exact activity the player has done over a minimum of 60 times? There’s no game anymore, no point in playing, the fun dried up long before the final boss, and Gearbox has the gall to claim that this is entertainment. 

The difficulty is a serious issue that Gearbox needs to fix with the Borderlands franchise. Just because an enemy health-gates me on every one of its attacks, it doesn’t make it a meaningful challenge to fight it, because I’ve spent the entire duration of the game fighting identical enemies with the same methods. Mayhem and UVHM from the previous games changed the way you approached enemies, as Mayhem modifiers could be rerolled to your preferred playstyle(and with new mayhem legendaries to boot), or having the endgame balanced around slag/cryo and TVHM enemy variants. But Wonderlands ONLY has enemy health and damage scaling, with no new enemies, no whacky modifiers, no unique gear, and only offers the same repetitive challenge as its previous Chaos levels did with a new fancy number taped to it. The Chaos levels experience does not offer new fun to veteran players, it’s boring to execute and identical to lower levels of play with an even slower burn on gear farming. 

The equipment slot unlocks are too late in the game to change build crafting and I should not have to complete the story to get my ring slot. Overworld challenges and collectables should not be tied to stat progression, all that incentivises me to do is open up a guide for the game, and waste hours hunting down the boring filler content. All the opening hero point allotments need to be swappable and provide an equal amount of points each. The same goes for the starting skill tree. Atop this is the bland Myth Rank system, where each level beyond 40 provides a minuscule stat increase. It just doesn’t have the same appeal as Guardian ranks in BL3, where the skills earned tangibly impacted gameplay or the earned XP giving me rewards from the Vault Cards. On a side note, enemy density in Chaos Chamber and Overworld encounters feels really low, I’d rather have a barrage of enemies that lasts a short time, than have them too spaced out and have to hunt for them. At least having variety between the two would be nice. 

Wonderlands still has game bugs, with looping subtitles, random reflection flashes, poor streaming performance and menu numbers being broken. And as a more minor gripe, I hate the elemental puddles on the floor damaging you. I can deal with enemy ones, like the “Nasty Spill” modifier in the Chaos Chamber or barrels exploding, but if cryo Buffmeister activated in ankle-high water downs me one more time, I’m going back to Deep Rock Galactic. 

The DLC for Wonderlands has also proven to be disappointing overall, merely providing Chaos Chamber rooms, 15 minutes of progress each(x4), and a depressing wheel of misfortune, spitting out crap loot for all of your trouble. I’m not denying that the gear is good, but if I paid money for this and struggle to get any of these items to drop because they share the same loot table as the world drop system, I’d wish I hadn’t bought it too. [b]Buyers beware, players can safely skip this season pass, it provides no fun to this decrepit package.[/b] All for the same price as the 4 campaign DLC of BL3, or the Handsome Collection. 

In closing, the game is mired in the same problems the series has had since 2012, flawed endgame and unrealistically rare loot drops. But the package of this game is really nice, high fantasy is really cool, and the gameplay is on-par with BL3. I want what’s best for the series, I wouldn’t 100% the other games if I didn’t, but right now, this just isn’t healthy. 
[i]”I’m just gonna take a nap - wake me up when I’m not on Pandora anymore.”[/i]

Can only Recommend the game, if you are Borderlands fan, i would give 3.5/5 rating. Unlike most i do like the lvl 40 cap, allows you to max out pretty fast. The Dual Class system is interesting, but the some classes don't synchronize well, so it does take planning. Other problem with Dual classing is loot, specially when it comes to Legendary gear. It makes farming extremely tedious. It will 80% only have 1 of your classes, and if you are playing in group 90% of time. The class gear will be for someone in your group. Now the Legendary rate has made the game better. But game is forcing social trade and interaction, that has always been part of the game. I thing its dumb, but it is something to look for socially. 

One of my main criticism of the game is the writing. I can appreciate each mission trying to be lore rich. But sometimes the NPC dialog goes on forever and take you away from the action. Having to pause and listen, to only then interact or follow a NPC really sucks when its dragged out. The jokes in this game is a joke. Maybe 1/5 jokes will stick, i know comedy is subjective. But even so, if you compare to Borderlands 2 (peak of BL comedy,) it doesn't even come close. 

Second main criticism is Connection and Group Chat. Constantly losing connection and when you try to reconnect through 
Social, it doesn't allow you to. Only fix is to restart your game by exiting to desktop. Now sound in a group, i recommend 3rd party chat, in game chat just randomly goes mute, other parts doesn't even recognize a microphone.

I would say that this game is easily the second best game in the borderlands franchise. Good visual, interesting characters, good humour, the gameplay is also solid. In average its a pretty good game, maybe short for the initial price but thats it.

Reasons you shouldn't buy this:


1) LEVEL SCALING!!!!

No, no, no, no and no.   What's the point of having levels if it all scales with you? What's the point of getting that bit more powerful if the enemies do as well? Might as well just gut the RPG levels/stats and make it a shooter because at least it would be honest then.

2) All sidequests in the overworld take place in Quake arenas with random enemies and random maps.  It makes Skyrims Radiant AI quests look beautifully handcarved.

3) Ear bleeding jumping noises, melee noises,screaming noises, sprinting noises that you can't turn off.

4) Terrible Mythic system.  Remember how in Borderlands 3 you'd hit max level and then your XP went toward skill points you get spend in whatever you wanted?  Well this game has four classes, and the stupid mythic system won't let you spend it in the class you want,  it forces you to spent a point in all 3 other classes before you can spend the point in the one you want.  Worst.Dev.Design.Ever

5) There is an enchantment reroller on your gear.  Amazing eh? No. You only get access to it once you've completed the game and there's nothing left to do.  Monty Python level of dev design.

6) Almost every NPC is gay and the game is sure to go into great detail for you about their LGBTQosadiofgaksjdgsajkdg relationships.

No one is gonna top a Cat class siren with a smg in the same way that no one can use the Unkempt Harold in quite the way that the Gunzerker can.  

These encounters made the experiences more unique and the classes feel alive and fleshed out.  I'm pretty well convinced that in both BL3 and TTW I can slap any of my gear from one character onto another and the feel would be more alike than it would be different.  I know that gearbox has actively stated its intent to make any weapon viable with any character, but it seems to me that the concept just ends up making the endgame bland.

My internet died for a minute, it came back on, and I got the achievement for completing all side quests

10/10 game
fun story or whatever, pretty shit endgame ngl
It's a quirky FPS that manages to be entertaining and fun without being overkill.
Super fun.
